status_message:
American artist John Singer Sargent was born #onthisday in 1856. He was known for his portraits, and became one of the most sought after portrait painters of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. His style echoed that of earlier artists Frans Hals and Diego Velazquez, using a looser painting technique to produce intensely personal portraits. Here are two black-and-white prints he made, along with some colourful watercolours from his travels in Europe. 
You can see more works by Sargent in the Museum's collection here: http://ow.ly/kz26307VI2n

Our curators discuss why the current #SouthAfricanArt exhibition is so special, giving you a glimpse of the history of this fascinating nation. 

You can book your tickets for the exhibition here: http://ow.ly/xHcQ307To52
link_name: Curating South Africa: the art of a nation

status_message: Come behind the scenes with #Hokusai exhibition curator Tim to get a closer look at The Great Wave and other incredible works

We're thrilled to announce a very special new exhibition exploring the work of one of Japan's greatest artists. 'Hokusai: beyond the Great Wave' opens on 25 May 2017. It will lead you on an artistic journey through the last 30 years of Hokusai's life, when he produced some of his greatest works. Our #Hokusai exhibition will be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to see sublime prints and paintings, many on loan from across the world. The exhibition is supported by Mitsubishi Corporation.  

Tickets are now on sale: http://ow.ly/lBEA307R2VH

Katsushika Hokusai (1760–1849), Shichirigahama beach, Sagami province from Thirty-six views of Mt Fuji. Colour woodblock, 1831. British Museum. On display in 'Hokusai: beyond the Great Wave' from 25 May – 2 July.
Wave goodbye to your #JanuaryBlues! Tomorrow we'll be announcing a very special exhibition…

President Richard Nixon was born #onthisday in 1913. This print portraying the President is by Andy Warhol. Nixon was running for a second term in office during 1972, and Warhol was commissioned to make an artwork on behalf of the Democrats who were running against Nixon with George McGovern. Warhol used a photo from Newsweek magazine as the basis for this print, and used the colour from First Lady Pat Nixon's outfit as the colour for Nixon's face, giving him a demonic appearance. Nixon won the election with a landslide victory, but his presidency was marred by the Watergate scandal, among other things. 

See more amazing Andy Warhol works and discover how Nixon's presidency impacted on artists' work in our #AmericanDream exhibition: http://ow.ly/ohMH307OxMH

This 2,000-year-old bronze helmet was said to be found in the gladiator barracks at Pompeii. Helmets like this would have been worn by heavily armoured fighters called 'samnites'. A medallion of Hercules features on the front – to symbolise strength and victory. http://ow.ly/QYey307c2BP
Discover how modern technology aided in the reconstruction of the Jericho Skull, on display until 19 February http://ow.ly/On75307KTKI
link_name: Face of 9,500-Year-Old Man Revealed for First Time

status_message:
In 1991 artist Esther Mahlangu was asked to decorate this BMW Art Car to mark the end of apartheid. You can see this beautiful car as part of our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/MzM8307KRCe 
Find out more about the artist and the Ndebele patterns used to paint the car in this post.
link_name: 'I have been making art all my life because it is in my heart and in my blood' – Esther Mahlangu

status_message:
The spectacular Vale of York Hoard was discovered #onthisday ten years ago! It was probably buried by a Viking leader during the unrest of the early 10th century, when the whole of England was brought under one ruler for the first time. The hoard is amazingly well preserved as a lot of the smaller items like coins and jewellery were buried within the large silver-gilt bowl. This vessel was made in France, and there are objects in the hoard from as far away as Afghanistan, which shows the extent of trade in this period. 

Read more about the hoard's history: http://ow.ly/SR96307a3eI

Today is Twelfth Night – the twelfth day after Christmas. Shakespeare's play of the same name is one of his most famous comedies and was meant to entertain people at the end of the festive season. This colourful fan shows a scene from the play with the characters Viola, Sebastian and Olivia.

In the heat and humidity of the summer of 1969, Robert Rauschenberg is busy recording the fervour and ambition of the Apollo 11 launch in Florida. The artist was invited to record the historic event by NASA, where he had access to official documents and photographs. One of the results was a towering print, over 2 metres tall, that evokes the sensory overload of the launch with technical diagrams, scenes from Cape Kennedy (now Cape Canaveral), and Florida's natural environment.

Sky Garden will be on display in our upcoming major exhibition along with other prints that reflect America through six dynamic and turbulent decades. The show charts how artists like Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and Kara Walker have responded to changing times. http://ow.ly/WcRx307Gv1Q 

Robert Rauschenberg (1925–2008), Sky Garden from Stoned Moon Series. Colour lithograph and screenprint, 1969. © Robert Rauschenberg Foundation

Jacob Grimm was born #onthisday in 1785. He's famous for his collection of fairy tales, which he compiled with his brother. Grimms' Fairy Tales, first published in 1812, includes Cinderella, Hansel and Gretel, Snow White, and the Pied Piper of Hamelin – as illustrated here by George Cruikshank. What's your favourite fairy tale?

J R R Tolkien was born #onthisday in 1892. He was Professor of Anglo-Saxon at Oxford University from 1925, and used Anglo-Saxon imagery in his books, including the Lord of the Rings trilogy. This Anglo-Saxon ring is over 1,000 years old, and although the meaning is lost, its runic inscription evokes the languages Tolkien invented http://ow.ly/1YLY307kOHS

The Jericho Skull was discovered in 1953, but modern technology has only just allowed us to properly examine this 9,500-year-old portrait. You can see it, along with the reconstruction, in our Room 3 display http://ow.ly/DmF7307gLmr
The Museum is open and ready to start 2017! There's plenty to look forward to – stay tuned throughout January for a series of exciting announcements and Facebook Live broadcasts.
Happy New Year everyone! January is named after the Roman god Janus. He had two faces so he could see the future and the past!

Fireworks have been used for celebrations around the world for centuries – here are some examples from India, Japan and the Netherlands. 

Will you be watching any fireworks tonight?

Our Tutankhamun exhibition closed #onthisday in 1972. Thousands of people flocked to see the treasures from the young pharaoh's tomb. The Queen also came to see the exhibition – here she is looking at Tutankhamun's world-famous death mask.

This striking turquoise mask is from Mexico and was made around 500 years ago. It likely depicts Xiuhtecuhtli, the Aztec god of fire. His name means 'Turquoise Lord', and this mask is made out of tiny pieces of the precious stone mounted on wood. 

Butterflies are associated with Xiuhtecuhtli, and it's been suggested that the darker pieces of turquoise on the cheeks and forehead form the shape of a butterfly. What do you think?

Read more about the object: http://ow.ly/rIhu30781D0

One of the oldest examples of jewellery, it is believed these shells formed a necklace made 75,000 years ago.

Discover the deep history of a fascinating nation in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/MkqZ307gKxh

Westminster Abbey was consecrated #onthisday in 1065. Every English (and later British) monarch since 1066 has been crowned here, and it is one of the most iconic buildings in Britain. The Abbey contains the tombs of kings and queens, as well as memorials to famous Britons including Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin.

This dazzling mermaid jewel is inlaid with 24 emeralds! Made out of gold, the pendant is also decorated with diamonds and pearls. The belly of the mermaid opens to reveal a small compartment that may have been used to store perfume. You can see this stunning piece of jewellery in the Museum's Waddesdon gallery (Room 2a). 

Read more about its history here: http://ow.ly/XX4H3075SPI

This is Albrecht Dürer's depiction of a 'fast, lively and cunning' rhino from 1515. He never actually saw the rhino, as it arrived in Portugal and Dürer lived in Germany. He produced this print from a description, and possibly a sketch, which is why the animal has scales and large armour plates. It was the first rhinoceros to be seen in Europe for over 1,000 years, and the subject of great interest – Dürer's print is one of the most famous depictions of the animal.

Read more: http://ow.ly/rLZJ30750Sa
link_name: Albrecht Dürer's woodcut of a rhinoceros

status_message: Happy Christmas! Isn't this a jolly looking snowman? He was etched by Horace Devitt Welsh in 1922.

Here's a golden nativity scene – the three wise men kneel before Christ, Mary and Joseph presenting their gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh. 

What gifts are you giving over the festive period?

French scholar Jean-François Champollion was born #onthisday in 1790. He used the Rosetta Stone as a key to decipher ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs. He identified that hieroglyphic symbols could be read either as a phonogram (which represented a particular phonetic sound), as a logogram (a symbol meaning a word or phrase), or as an ideogram (where the symbol represented an idea). It was previously thought that Egyptian hieroglyphs were purely ideographic, but Champollion used the Rosetta Stone, with its three scripts, to disprove this. 

You can see Champollion's own hieroglyphic writing here: http://ow.ly/TwT9307iifF

'Among the greatest artistic masterpieces you will ever see'

Our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition is one of The Guardian's top shows of 2016! It's on until 26 February: http://ow.ly/NzGE307mUe2

What have you enjoyed seeing this year?

This beautifully intricate pendant shows the Adoration of the Magi in stunning detail – the scene is less than 4cm across! It's decorated with rubies and peals, and the Virgin Mary holds baby Jesus below a star made from diamonds.

The figures are decorated with incredibly fine enamelwork – we can see the richly patterned material of the kings' robes. This pendant was made in Germany around 1600 and it's on display in the #Waddesdon gallery (Room 2a). Read more: http://ow.ly/PNVp3074KS9

This bear looks like it's having fun in the snow!  Japanese artist Keisai Eisen made this lovely print in around 1840.

Is there any snow near where you are?
Today is the Winter Solstice – the shortest day of the year in the northern hemisphere! Here's Stonehenge by John Constable, drawn in 1836 http://ow.ly/yHfp307kDXS
This #MysteryObject shows Christ holding a book. What do you think it was used for?

The wealthy city of Mapungubwe was a thriving place of trade over 800 years ago. It was the capital of the first kingdom in southern Africa, and developed links with China, India and Egypt. Despite its sophistication, the city flourished and declined within 100 years, leaving archaeologists a huge amount of evidence buried in the ground. These gold sculptures were found in a royal grave and depict animals of high status – an ox, a wild cat and a rhinoceros. 

You can see these precious objects, on loan from the University of Pretoria, in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/D2TU307fH1U

Reindeer pull sleds under the Northern Lights in this print from Lapland, Finland. The Northern Lights (aurora borealis) are a natural light display in the sky caused by collisions between gaseous particles, and they can appear as dramatic arcs, as seen here. The sleds and clothing are characteristic of the Sámi people who are the indigenous inhabitants of Lapland. http://ow.ly/eKoq3074Q1F 

We have paired together 2D and 3D works that showcase the best of modern design from post-war Europe in a new free display: http://ow.ly/X01V3074QmO

This swimming reindeer sculpture was made around 13,000 years ago. It's sculpted from a mammoth tusk, and was found in southwest France. The reindeer were originally thought to be two separate sculptures, and it was only discovered in the 1930s that they were meant to be joined. The presence of antlers and the shading of the female's coat suggest this could be an autumn or winter scene when the animals migrate, crossing rivers on their way. http://ow.ly/L3lL307cq4L
Here's a look at the technology that went into our touring exhibition, which has just opened at Powerhouse Museum in Sydney.
link_name: Unlocking mummies' secrets: What imaging technology tells us

status_message: Tube etiquette hasn't changed much, but not many passengers wear top hats anymore! This is Cyril Power's print of a busy London Underground District Line train from 1934. The British artist was born #onthisday in 1872.

It's 1966 and the Beatles are number one with Paperback Writer, Lyndon Johnson was asked to 'get out' of Vietnam, and a gallon of gas cost $0.32. American artist Ed Ruscha is travelling 1,400 miles on Route 66 from LA to his hometown of Oklahoma, recording the gas stations dotted along the road. Influenced by graphic design and advertising, he transformed everyday images like this into dramatic works of art.

Happy birthday to Ed, who is 79 today! You can see many of his works in our upcoming exhibition #AmericanDream http://ow.ly/68GV307cmcQ 

Edward Ruscha (b. 1937), Standard Station. Screenprint, 1966. MoMA The Museum of Modern Art, New York/Scala, Florence. © Ed Ruscha. Reproduced by permission of the artist.

'To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love' – Jane Austen, born #onthisday in 1775. Can you identify these scenes from her classic novel Pride and Prejudice? 

These illustrations were made by Helen Binyon in 1938.

A 9,500-year-old plaster-covered skull has been reconstructed to reveal the person's life, health and appearance. Found along with six other skulls in the ancient city of Jericho, then one of the largest cities in the Middle East, skulls like these were thought be used to remember the dead. Little was known about this object before it underwent a micro-CT scan at the Natural History Museum, London, allowing the skull to be studied in detail for the first time. Come face-to-face with this fascinating object in our new display: http://ow.ly/QKGe307afUE 

You can listen to our new podcast about the discovery of the skull here: https://soundcloud.com/britishmuseum/the-walls-of-jericho. We'd love to hear what you think!

This display is supported by The Asahi Shimbun.
The Eiffel Tower is an iconic Parisian landmark – this stylish view from 1928 was used as a Christmas card! Gustave Eiffel, the designer of the tower, was born #onthisday in 1832.

This is the Mold Gold Cape, named after the town in Wales where it was discovered in 1833. The cape was found around the shoulders of a skeleton in a 3,600-year-old burial mound. It's a stunning example of workmanship, and may have been worn during ceremonies by someone of religious importance.  

Find out why this fine example of prehistoric gold working is so significant in this Google Arts & Culture online exhibition.
link_name: The Mold Gold Cape - Google Exhibition

status_message:
Rock art is one of South Africa's oldest artistic traditions. It was first made by the ancestors of the San|Bushmen and Khoekhoen peoples, at least 30,000 years ago. This rock painting depicts San|Bushmen running between eland, a type of antelope that is spiritually important. We can see their delicately painted bows and arrows. 
Explore the deep history of human art and see this huge rock art panel in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/T6UI3075FCz
Can you guess what this #MysteryObject is? Hint: it's 19cm tall.

Tilt your device or use your cursor to marvel at our Enlightenment Gallery in 360°! 

The gallery opened #onthisday in 2003, restored to how it would have looked when it was built in the 1820s. One of the Museum's most popular rooms, it contains over 4,000 objects from all over the world. They demonstrate how people in Britain understood their world during the period known as the Enlightenment – an age of reason and learning that flourished across Europe and America from about 1680 to 1820.

'When you look at an object like this and think what it has endured, it is so moving.' 

Made around 1350 in the Midlands, this rare statue is one of the best surviving examples of its kind. You can see it on display in Room 40.
link_name: Once shrouded in mystery, a medieval masterpiece is back on show

status_message: This little llama is only 5cm tall. It was made by the Incas around 500 years ago in Peru. At this time the Inca empire was the largest in the world, spanning over 3,000 miles down the Andes and ruling over 12 million people. Gold was a key substance in Inca myth – it was the main attribute of the Inca sun god and was described as the 'sweat of the sun'. Small figures like this were often buried as offerings on mountain peaks. http://ow.ly/rFov306Irqs

How did a stuffed rhino called Rosie become the subject for Maggi Hambling's first portrait? Meet the artist and hear about our current exhibition of her work, open until 29 January: http://ow.ly/uQVq306TRP8

Come face-to-face with six ancient Egyptian mummies in our new touring exhibition at Powerhouse Museum, Sydney – open today! Use the latest technology to go beyond the wrappings and discover what lies beneath… http://ow.ly/r6Sg306F70d

The 9,000-year-old Coldstream Stone is an incredibly well-preserved example of early human art. Found on top of a burial of the same age in South Africa, the artist has used red and white ochre to draw three human figures. The person in the middle holds hunting equipment, and all three have blood streaming from their noses. Based on San|Bushmen tradition, they could be shamans involved in a trance or a healing dance. 
 
See objects with fascinating stories in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/urQj306YDk5

Go down the rabbit hole and explore these Alice in Wonderland etchings in this gallery from The Guardian. The Dalziel brothers illustrated the Lewis Carroll book, and their work is now being digitised in a project with the University of Sussex.
link_name: Alice in Wonderland's engravings – a forgotten story in pictures

status_message: These articulated figurines are made from iron and can be moved into different positions! They were made in the 19th century in Japan. Helmet and armour manufacturers used their skills in curving and riveting metal to produce detailed models of all kinds of creatures. The animals are stunning examples of the craftsmanship – all the scales and feathers are faithfully reproduced in iron plates.

The Korean alphabet, called Hangul, was created in 1443 to enable people to read their own language easily, with little education. 

Our curator Eleanor Soo-ah Hyun explains how the alphabet came about in this BBC World Service radio clip.
link_name: How long would it take you to learn the Korean alphabet?

status_message: The Queen opened our spectacular Great Court #onthisday in 2000. This has opened up the heart of the Museum and acts as a hub for visitors. The amazing ceiling has 3,312 panes of glass, each of which is unique! You can tour the Great Court (and the rest of the Museum) on Google Street View: http://ow.ly/jK3p306RRQt
Do you know what this #MysteryObject was once used for? Hint: it's around 44cm long.

It's #StNicholasDay – this panel from Russia shows the saint surrounded by 14 scenes from his life. He's said to have performed miracles when he was alive during the 3rd and 4th centuries including healing and saving people from drowning. http://ow.ly/dYkY306R5Tx

Set someone special on a journey through 2 million years of human history...

Give the gift of British Museum Membership this Christmas: http://ow.ly/uk1B306P06J

'The moment to bridge the chasms that divide us has come' – Nelson Mandela died #onthisday in 2013. 

See how Mandela's inspirational story helped shape the history of his nation in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: http://ow.ly/SGlO306OUcb

Cyrus the Great died #onthisday in 530 BC. His Achaemenid empire, now often known as the Persian empire, stretched from South Asia to the Balkans. This object is known as the 'Cyrus cylinder' – it details his conquest of Babylon in 539 BC. Inscribed in Babylonian cuneiform, an ancient system of writing, the cylinder has sometimes been described as the 'first charter of human rights'. In fact it reflects a long tradition in Mesopotamia where, from as early as the third millennium BC, kings began their reigns with declarations of reforms. http://ow.ly/IxBS306B7x3

Artist Mary Sibande confronts history with her art. 'A Reversed Retrogress' is on display in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition – here she discusses the issues of race, gender and identity in post-apartheid South Africa and how they influenced this dramatic work. http://ow.ly/4lyx306KvfW 

Mary Sibande (b. 1982), A Reversed Retrogress: Scene 1 (The Purple Shall Govern), 2013. © Mary Sibande. Courtesy of the artist and Gallery MOMO.

Southern Africa is one of the places where modern humans evolved, inspiring many contemporary artists. This computer-generated image was created by Karel Nel for a poster in 1985 celebrating the 60th anniversary of the discovery of the 'Taung Child'. The skull is 2.5 million years old, and is that of an early human ancestor, the Australopithecus africanus. The find provided evidence that humans evolved out of Africa, and not in Europe, as had been previously believed. 

See this work in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition http://ow.ly/ORrA306Kuvo

Karel Nel (b. 1955), Taung, Early computer-generated image, 1985. Artist's collection.  © Karel Nel.
link_name: Origins of art and artistic thought

status_message:
December takes its name from 'decem', the Latin for 10, as it was the tenth month of the Roman calendar. In the northern hemisphere it will be getting colder and darker, and there might be a chance of snow! This serene snowy scene is of Kinkakuji in Japan. http://ow.ly/ghDp306D8Pu

Kawase Hasui (1883–1957), detail of Yuki no Kinkakuji (Snow at Kinkakuji) from the series Nihon fukei senshu (Selected Views of Japan). Woodblock print, 1922.

These stunning objects are known as the Basse Yutz flagons, after the French town where they were found. Flagons were used at feasts to pour wine or beer, which on these would flow under the duck just behind the spout, making the duck look like it was swimming. The flagons date from around 450 BC and are some of the finest examples of Celtic craftsmanship. They are similar to Etruscan designs made in Italy at the same time, and are decorated with coral from the Mediterranean. http://ow.ly/Qgj1306Dmhe
What do you think this #MysteryObject is?

William Blake was born #onthisday in 1757. A poet, printmaker and painter, Blake's best-known work combines his poetry with beautiful illustrations and decoration. Although he was working at the same time as the Romantic painters and poets, his style remains unique and distinct from his contemporaries. Blake's work from the 1780s and 1790s forms an important part of the Museum's prints and drawings collection. http://ow.ly/Ltk8306A0pB

This striking mosaic was made around 500 years ago in Mexico. It's a pectoral – a type of jewellery designed to be worn on the chest. Double-headed serpents (known as maquizcoatl) were considered to be the bearers of bad omens and were associated with figures of authority who may have worn this type of jewellery as part of a ritual process. 

The object is expertly decorated with tiny pieces of turquoise that create textures and shapes on the serpent's 'skin'. The eye sockets could have been inlaid with dark gemstones giving the impression of flickering eyes. http://ow.ly/OI4D306qBzr

'Everything that I do starts with an effort in recalling who I am' – artist Kara Walker, born #onthisday in 1969. Predominantly in black and white, her work addresses race, gender, the American Civil War and slavery in the USA.
 
See prints by Kara Walker in our #AmericanDream exhibition from March 2017: http://ow.ly/1wSD306wfez

Paper currency was first used in China as early as AD 1000. It was the Chinese who first printed a value on a piece of paper and persuaded everyone that it was worth what it said it was. The whole modern banking system of paper and credit is built on this one simple act of faith. 

This banknote is from 1375, and is given the title of 'Great Ming circulating treasure note'. The Ming were the first Chinese dynasty to try to totally replace coins with paper money, however inflation quickly eroded its value. The effect of inflation was so devastating that paper money was regarded with suspicion in China for many years and it was not until the 1850s that paper money was issued again. 

Learn all about the history of money in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/A83D306nUYC

Around 3 million years ago our early ancestors collected and valued objects for their appearance. This pebble was perhaps picked up by an Australopithecus africanus because its natural shape suggests a face. Objects like this identify South Africa as one of the places where modern human behaviour began.

Discover this deep history in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition: 
http://ow.ly/qw5i306wreV
link_name: Origins of art and artistic thought

status_message: Get 10% off all products this Black Friday weekend at our online shop! From books and jewellery to sculptures and art prints, find the perfect gift. Use code BLACKFRIDAY10 on checkout http://ow.ly/S27y306wdba
Happy Thanksgiving! Today's holiday in the USA celebrates the abundance of harvest. This Botticelli drawing shows Autumn, with a cornucopia of fruit and flowers. What are you feasting on today?

Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec was born #onthisday in 1864. His artworks captured the vitality of Paris in the late 19th century. These works show some of Toulouse-Lautrec's favourite subjects: from the glamour of the theatre to the intimacy of a bathing scene. 

These are all available to buy as art prints in our online shop: http://ow.ly/qExk306u8QN

Claude Lorrain was one of the most influential artists of the Baroque period. Known for painting landscapes that were bathed in softly glowing light, his careful compositions were often imaginary scenes. Born in the Duchy of Lorraine (now part of France), he spent most of his time working in Italy and his paintings included fanciful depictions of Roman architecture. He drew all his compositions in a book called the 'Liber Veritatis' (Book of Truth) which is in the Museum's collection – the scenes here are taken from it. He died #onthisday in 1682. http://ow.ly/tavz306jhjc

'Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country' – John F Kennedy was assassinated #onthisday in 1963. JFK's time as president of the USA had a profound effect on the nation, and the world.  

Our upcoming #AmericanDream exhibition traces six decades of dynamic and turbulent US history, from the early 1960s to today. http://ow.ly/LXTY306qpEw
What do you think this #MysteryObject was used for?

'A witty saying proves nothing.' – French Enlightenment thinker Voltaire, born #onthisday in 1694.

Voltaire was a prolific writer and produced everything from plays to pamphlets. A key figure in liberal thought during the 18th century, he was imprisoned for his radical ideas. This Wedgwood figurine of him was made in 1779. French thinkers were particularly popular in England before the Revolution (1789), especially among the scientific thinkers and manufacturers of the Midlands (including Wedgwood himself). http://ow.ly/E9ZG306emx6

Hello… is it 'ancient Egypt' you're looking for? That's the most popular search on our website, and today we're launching a new search tool to help you explore! http://search.britishmuseum.org/ 

Drawing on our object database, videos, research articles, and even the online shop, this powerful tool is the first step in the redevelopment of the Museum's website in the coming months. We're at the start of this journey and would love to know what you think, so please share your experiences in our online survey and help shape our digital transformation: http://ow.ly/aVcf306n803 

Papyrus from the Book of the Dead of Ani. Egypt, 19th Dynasty, c. 1292–1187 BC.

'A fascinating odyssey through South Africa's past and present… Come, and hear the ancestors speak.'

Take a tour around our new special exhibition with The South African and discover 100,000 years of incredible history.

Find out more about the exhibition: http://ow.ly/nRq7306j7ux
link_name: Past and present collide in South African art show at British Museum

status_message: This striking gold head represents St Eustace and fragments of the saint's skull were said to be kept inside. It was made in the late 12th century and is decorated with gem stones, silver and mother-of-pearl. These types of reliquaries (containers for holy relics) are crafted from precious stones and gold as the relics contained within them were considered more valuable than any material. The plinth the head sits on shows miniature versions of the 12 apostles. http://ow.ly/7EPP306chOK

This embossed silver-gilt bowl was made in Germany in the late 16th century and is a great example of German craftsmanship from this time. The scene shows Venus and Cupid at Vulcan's forge. Vulcan is the Roman god of fire and the blacksmith who forged weapons for many of the gods. You can see it in Room 2a – the Waddesdon Bequest http://ow.ly/vNSO306cnbQ

In this double portrait Nicolas de Plattemontagne has depicted his friends in the style of Roman emperors. How would you draw your friends?
You can see this and other #FrenchPortraits in our free exhibition http://ow.ly/ppKo306cevm

Charles I was born #onthisday in 1600. This ring contains a tiny portrait of the king that's less than 1.3cm across! Commemorative jewellery was produced in great numbers after Charles' execution in 1649. Many examples like this ring have hinged lids – supporters of the Royalist cause, who wished to keep their allegiance secret, probably wore these under the rule of Oliver Cromwell http://ow.ly/xzh5306efRf

Experience our #SunkenCities exhibition in 360°! There's less than one week left to see these incredible objects for yourself and discover the history of Egypt's lost worlds. Book your tickets here: http://ow.ly/aIvI306jvKC

Rock art can be traced back around 30,000 years in southern Africa and is one of the oldest forms of artistic and cultural expression. By looking at rock art we can learn about the cultures, beliefs and activities of people who lived many thousands of years ago. With advances in technology we can see how rock art may have been altered over time.

Explore rock art from southern Africa in our free display, closing this Sunday: http://ow.ly/EIn1306dOl6

St Peter's Basilica in the Vatican was consecrated #onthisday in 1626. It replaced an earlier church on the same site. A magnificent piece of architecture executed on a grand scale, the Basilica remains one of the largest church buildings in the world. This view gives a great perspective of the colonnades stretching out around St Peter's Square from the main entrance. It is one of the holiest sites for Roman Catholics – tradition holds that St Peter's tomb is directly below the high altar. http://ow.ly/28vx306c9Yp

This amazing gold chariot model was made around 500–300 BC in Central Asia. It was found near the Oxus River, in modern Tajikistan, with over 180 other objects – the find is known as the Oxus Treasure. The tiny chariot and charioteers are finely detailed, with textured clothing, miniature emblems and harnesses on the ponies. http://ow.ly/3Jd1306bO0u

Elizabeth I ascended the throne of England #onthisday in 1558. This pendant features a cameo portrait of the queen made from onyx, in a dazzling ruby-studded mount. The cameo was made slightly before the early 17th-century mount. Jewellery containing the queen's portrait continued to be worn many years after her death. http://ow.ly/NO1O3069rgZ

How did Picasso experiment with graphic art? Join art writer Charlotte Mullins as she takes a look at a set of Picasso linocuts acquired by the British Museum in 2014, with help from the Art Fund. The two prints, 'Still Life under the Lamp' and 'Jacqueline Reading', were both made in 1962, when the artist was 80 years old.

They are counted among Picasso's most important and innovative works in linocut, a technique that he explored in the late 1950s and early 1960s. The proofs trace the step-by-step sequence by which Picasso created his linocut images, showing the development of the image into its final form. 

See 17 of these brilliant linocut prints by Picasso in our touring exhibition Lady Lever Art Gallery, until 8 January 2017 http://ow.ly/Lisy3062JgT

The Hoxne hoard was discovered #onthisday in 1992. It was found in the village of Hoxne (pronounced 'Hoxon') in Suffolk, eastern England. It is the largest hoard of late Roman silver and gold discovered in Britain. The hoard contained more than 15,000 gold and silver objects, including the largest collection of gold and silver coins of the 4th and 5th century found anywhere within the Roman Empire.

It must have been buried sometime after AD 408, as there are coins dated from this year. It also contained pieces of jewellery such as bracelets and this body-chain, and silver and gold objects like these pepper pots! The spice was extremely expensive in Roman Britain and only arrived from India in the 1st century AD – these ornaments must have come from a wealthy home http://ow.ly/PmnD3069iQN

Happy birthday to Wayne Thiebaud who was born #onthisday in 1920! Sweets, ice creams and cakes feature heavily in the American artist's sugary, colourful work – this piece is called 'Gumball Machine' and was made in 1970. His works are characterised by his focus on mass-produced objects. You can see some of his prints in our upcoming #AmericanDream exhibition – book your tickets here: http://ow.ly/lL6E306ccAo 

Wayne Thiebaud (b. 1920), Gumball Machine. Colour linocut, 1970. © Wayne Thiebaud/DACS, London/VAGA, New York 2016.
What's this #MysteryObject?

Artist Julie Manet was born #onthisday in 1878. Her family were key figures in the Impressionist movement of the late 19th century – Berthe Morisot was her mother and Édouard Manet was her uncle. As well as being an artist herself, she also modelled for her mother, her uncle and Renoir. The first painting here was done by Manet when she was a teenager, and the second was done by Morisot. They depict the same scene and are painted with the same paints – which do you prefer? http://ow.ly/ejix3069jrZ

This 19th-century #selfie by Gustave Courbet reveals a lot about the Realist artist. Famously narcissistic, his self-portrait of 1852 reflects his career at the time – confident and assured. Courbet's numerous self-portraits chart his search for his own identity, using many different ways to represent himself. What would he have made of selfies today? See more wonderful works in our free #FrenchPortraits exhibition! http://ow.ly/GWKb3068SUG

This spectacular crystal skull was originally believed to have been made by the Aztecs, but its story is complex. The first clue that revealed its true identity was found when it went for scientific analysis. Machine-made cut marks were found in the highly polished surface of the teeth. So, if it were from Mexico, it must have been made after the arrival of the Spanish in 1519. Further tests revealed the quartz was extracted in the 19th century from Brazil or Madagascar – far beyond ancient Aztec trading links. The Museum acquired the skull from New York jewellers Tiffany & Co. in 1898  http://ow.ly/JCuC305VkTe

King Edward III of England was born #onthisday in 1312. Gold coinage was introduced during his reign to facilitate international trade with countries that were already using gold coins. This coin was called a florin, and its design was influenced by French coins of the day – the king is shown seated, holding an orb and sceptre, with two heraldic English leopards beside him. http://ow.ly/BfCL305OV8d

Did you know you can explore the Museum on Google Street View? See colossal statues of ancient Egypt, admire the detail of Japanese samurai armour or come face to face with the Anglo-Saxons from wherever you are!  

Start in the Egyptian Sculpture Gallery: http://ow.ly/7DNH305VIEO   
Start in the Japanese Galleries: http://ow.ly/ulmF305VIUu 
Start in the Sutton Hoo Gallery: http://ow.ly/fAjD305VJ6c

Born #onthisday in 1840, French sculptor Auguste Rodin was known for his human figures in bronze and marble. Some of his works looked so natural that he was falsely accused of casting them from real people! Rodin visited the British Museum from the 1880s onwards and was inspired by seeing the incomplete classical Greek sculptures on display. These are some of his preliminary drawings for finished sculptures – Rodin would experiment with composition by drawing or using pen and ink, and highlighting in white. http://ow.ly/UKMk305OJqs

Discover the fascinating story of #SouthAfricanArt in our new exhibition! Contemporary works meet ancient objects in this journey through the nation's art http://ow.ly/3ILV3065yFK

These thousand-year-old clay figurines were found with hundreds of others near Schroda Farm in South Africa. Each home contained an abstract female figurine, perhaps to preserve household fertility. The animal sculptures suggest which animals were important to these people.

French painter and printmaker Édouard Vuillard was born #onthisday in 1868. His pattern-heavy interiors were inspired by the textiles his mother used in her dressmaking business. They lived together for much of Vuillard's adult life, and she features in many of his prints and paintings. These prints are typical of his colourful work at the end of the 19th century. http://ow.ly/VE9N305Od0l

For #RemembranceDay here are Mary Delany's red poppies from 1779. The Museum will observe the 2-minute silence at 11.00. 

The poppy is used as a symbol of remembrance as it grew prominently in Flanders, where many people died during the First World War.

How are contemporary works of art looked after at the Museum? See how Karel Nel's 'Potent Fields' was prepared for our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition http://ow.ly/ZKwL30639ko

The artwork is made using ochre, a natural pigment found in the earth. It is inspired by the discovery of 77,000-year-old engraved ochre in Blombos Cave on the southern coast of South Africa. The pigment alludes to the long history of art in South Africa, but also the colour division of apartheid. The work also acknowledges the potential for a colour balance in post-apartheid South Africa.

Martin Luther was born #onthisday in 1483. This double portrait portrays him as a monk and a professor. He became a priest in 1507 and then received his doctorate of theology in 1512. His radical ideas helped spark the Protestant Reformation.  http://ow.ly/cS67305MZ58

William Hogarth's 'Gin Lane' and 'Beer Street' prints helped reform alcohol laws in Britain in the middle of the 18th century. Gin had become widely available and very cheap during the early 1700s, and consumption rose to dangerous levels among the poor. In these prints, the spirit is represented as causing damage to society, and traditional lower-strength beer is shown as being a safer drink. Hogarth was born #onthisday in 1697. http://ow.ly/3tSS305MZEi

History has been made in the USA. How will America remember this day in the future? 

See artists' responses to momentous occasions in US history since the 1960s in our #AmericanDream exhibition, opening March 2017. http://ow.ly/J3Gt3060yrD 

Jasper Johns (b. 1930), Flags I. Screenprint, 1973. Collection of Johanna and Leslie Garfield. © Jasper Johns/VAGA, New York/DACS, London 2016. © Tom Powel Imaging.

Ogres, ghosts and zombies appear regularly alongside gods and humans in shadow theatre performances. Fearsome beings must be controlled within the stories to maintain spiritual harmony in the world. These three come from Bali, Java and Thailand and date from the late 1700s to the 1960s – shadow puppets and the stories associated with the performances have endured and evolved for a very long time. You can learn more about #ShadowPuppets performances in our free exhibition http://ow.ly/OxcF304h4Sh

Bram Stoker was born #onthisday in 1847. Did you know he researched his classic horror novel Dracula in the Museum? Here is his application to study in the Museum's library in 1905 after he lost his ticket – 'I have used the Rooms since 1879 or thereabouts but I have not seen my ticket for at least twenty years and cannot find it.' http://ow.ly/DqLQ305XQyi
The Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford opened to the public #onthisday in 1602. Here's a view of the library from the late 17th century http://ow.ly/5z7X305YdG9
What do you think this #MysteryObject was used for?
Have you seen #SunkenCities yet? Don't miss the exhibition before it closes on 27 November.

This imposing silver lyre was played in Mesopotamia (modern-day southern Iraq) over 4,000 years ago. Music was an important aspect of many celebratory and ritual occasions in ancient Mesopotamia. The lyre is made of lavishly decorated silver and red limestone. The frame, tuners and strings are modern reproductions made from casts of the long-decayed wooden parts. The decorated panels below the bull's head depict fallow deer and a tree on a hill, lions attacking a goat, and a lion attacking a gazelle. http://ow.ly/JPL1304fiVr

Our 'Curious Beasts' touring exhibition is open at South Australian Museum! Beautiful prints by artists including Dürer and Goya help illustrate the importance of animals in art from the 15th to 19th centuries. http://ow.ly/hTT7305R4FR

Hokusai's 'The Great Wave' was the first print in his series 'Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji'. This series of prints was made in the early 1830s and shows Mount Fuji at different times of the year and from many different locations. http://ow.ly/PvaH305QGIu

It's #BonfireNight in the UK! The night commemorates the foiling of the Gunpowder Plot in 1605. Catholic conspirators planned to kill Protestant King James I by blowing up the House of Lords on 5 November, having moved large amounts of gunpowder into the cellars of the building. Guy Fawkes was discovered guarding the barrels of gunpowder, and the night is often referred to as Guy Fawkes Night, with an effigy of him burnt on the bonfire. Nowadays the night is more associated with spectacular fireworks shows. http://ow.ly/rZT5305Rccy

Tutankhamun's tomb was discovered by Howard Carter #onthisday in 1922. It was one of the most significant ancient Egyptian archaeological discoveries of all time. The tomb was found mostly intact over 3,000 years after the young pharaoh died, and its well-preserved state revealed some incredible objects. Tutankhamun's stunning gold funerary mask is now one of the iconic images of ancient Egypt. These images are from our 1972 exhibition. http://ow.ly/ym5h305Mnyy

Don't miss your chance to see the underwater treasures of Egypt's lost worlds, discovered after 1,000 years at the bottom of the sea. Curator Aurelia Masson-Berghoff gives you a glimpse of this unmissable exhibition, on until 27 November. Book now http://ow.ly/UIUE305Qyjg
link_name: Amazing finds from Egypt's lost cities

status_message:
This is the stunning Grenville Jewel. It's a locket with a dazzling exterior set with diamonds, emeralds, opals, rubies and pearls. The intricate floral design is enamelled gold, which continues onto the rear of the locket. It opens up to reveal a miniature portrait of Sir Bevill Grenville, a Royalist general in the English Civil War. He sent this jewel to his wife, Lady Grace Grenville, between 1639 and 1643, when the political climate kept them apart. The enamelled pansies are significant as the flowers were associated with loving thoughts at the time. 

See more exquisite jewellery and other Renaissance and medieval treasures in our #Waddesdon Gallery. http://ow.ly/D6v1305OYA6
We're behind the scenes in our conservation lab with Duygu Camurcuoglu!

Every object in the British Museum is cared for by a dedicated team of conservators and scientists. They work to preserve and investigate over 8 million objects, promoting the latest scientific and curatorial research into the collection.
Join our #FacebookLive at 17.30 today as we go behind the scenes into our conservation lab. We'd love to hear from you and answer your conservation questions.

Submerged under the sea for over a thousand years, this colossal statue depicts Hapy, the Egyptian god of the Nile. It was discovered underwater in what was the thriving and cosmopolitan city of Thonis-Heracleion. It once stood in front of a temple, and would have been an impressive sight for traders and visitors arriving from the Mediterranean. Come face to face with Hapy for yourself in our #SunkenCities exhibition, closing 27 November 2016: http://ow.ly/EguL305Oeq1 

Colossal statue of Hapy. Thonis-Heracleion, Egypt, c. 380–250 BC. Maritime Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

How do we look after objects so that they can be displayed for future generations? 

Go behind the scenes to learn how this intricate Ndebele beaded blanket was repaired so it could be shown in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, which traces the story of South Africa over 100,000 years. You can buy your tickets here: http://ow.ly/JWSy305MKUS

Tune in on Thursday 3 November at 17.30 (GMT) for a special #FacebookLive in our conservation lab! We'll be looking at how and why objects in the collection are conserved.

Marie Antoinette was born #onthisday in 1755. This locket is said to contain a lock of her hair! If this blonde lock of hair is indeed that of Marie Antoinette, it must have been cut before 1791. According to the memoirs of one of her servants, Marie Antoinette's hair went white overnight while the king and queen tried to escape from Paris. Born in Austria, she was the last queen before the French Revolution and was executed in 1793. She never became popular with the French public due to her extravagant spending, and uncompromising stance towards change. http://ow.ly/Fd9E305KhSt
We're trying a new #MysteryObject this week – who do you think is in this #MysteryPortrait?

November takes its name from being the ninth month of the Roman calendar – 'novem' means nine in Latin. This Flemish print from the 1580s shows the Sagittarius zodiac symbol at the top http://ow.ly/hK1k305xVGU

Poet John Keats was born #onthisday in 1795. It's known he visited the Museum some time before 1819, which is when he wrote 'Ode on a Grecian Urn'. This Greek vase is thought to have partly inspired the poem. http://ow.ly/lGU6305CMRT

Something spooky for #Halloween! This gruesome 'mermaid' was said to have been caught in Japan during the 18th century. Curious cryptids – animals whose existence is questionable – were popular with collectors and sideshow exhibitors in Europe, where tales of exotic lands and mythical creatures roused great curiosity. This example is made from a monkey's head with a fish tail, with a wooden support in the centre. You can examine this extraordinary piece of taxidermy for yourself in the Enlightenment Gallery

'The sleep of reason produces monsters' 

For #Halloween enjoy Goya's nightmarish vision of bats and night creatures, which appear over him as he is slumped asleep at his drawing table. http://ow.ly/eTKa305AmKy

Happy #Diwali! This painting from India was made in the 1760s and shows how the festival of light was celebrated. The lanterns and fireworks represent the triumph of light over dark and the festival is one of the most important days in the Hindu calendar. http://ow.ly/5eki305khy0
Don't forget the clocks go back in the UK tonight! Monday's job for the curators: winding 49 clocks on display in our galleries http://ow.ly/KbYG305B1Uq

At around 1.2 million years old, this hand axe is one of the oldest objects in the Museum's collection, and one of the most significant. It was found in the Olduvai Gorge in northern Tanzania, and was skilfully made by ancestors we would recognise as becoming human. Made from a hard green lava called phonolite, it would have taken a long time to make, and tools like this would have been used for woodcutting or cutting meat. The symmetrical beauty of early hand axes suggests they also could have been used as some sort of symbolic communication, perhaps a status symbol or to attract a mate. http://ow.ly/sNVk305AMl8

Ancient Egyptians honoured the god Osiris, lord of the underworld, in a yearly festival. The celebrations in the ancient cities of Thonis-Heracleion and Canopus culminated in two processions on a canal, including the two-mile journey of a gilded wooden boat containing figures of Osiris. Underwater excavations have uncovered objects which provide incredible evidence of these events.

See spectacular objects from these ancient underwater cities in our #SunkenCities exhibition. Catch it before it closes on 27 November! http://ow.ly/ilCD305Dgw7

© Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

In episode 9 of our conservation series, see how new pieces are colour matched with the original Roman glass.

We'll be doing a special #FacebookLive broadcast next Thursday that will take you behind the scenes in our conservation lab.

status_message: Artist Mary Moser was born #onthisday in 1744. Moser was known for floral paintings that were alive with colour – this watercolour also showcases her effortless composition. She was one of only two female founding members of the Royal Academy of Arts when the institution was founded in 1768. http://ow.ly/gRzW305ndx6

Discover the history of South Africa through an incredible 100,000 years of art in our new exhibition, open today! 

Your journey starts with some of the earliest examples of human creativity – from rock art to perhaps the world's oldest necklace. Be amazed by 800-year-old gold treasures from the first kingdom of southern Africa, be moved by powerful anti-apartheid pieces, and be inspired by cutting-edge contemporary works.

See the history of a nation from a new perspective – book your tickets: http://ow.ly/EFU7305AvtT  

Exhibition sponsored by Betsy and Jack Ryan. Logistics partner IAG Cargo.

Tonight millions of people across the UK are watching the finale of The Great British Bake Off! Baking has been at the heart of many societies, including in the ancient Roman world.
 
In this video chef Giorgio Locatelli recreates a loaf of bread which was made in Pompeii 2,000 years ago, before the eruption of Mount Vesuvius. The number of bakeries preserved in the city shows that buying bread was just as common as it is today. Try baking this loaf for yourself with Giorgio's recipe: http://ow.ly/Bq1Q300PNXy

Float into the Museum in a bubble of 360° video. Explore a virtual vista of our forecourt and façade by tilting your device or navigating with your mouse. Once you're inside the Museum you can explore the galleries on Google Street View http://ow.ly/awxh305vVf0

★★★★★ 'This exhibition is as stirring as South Africa itself – a journey to the heart of our common humanity.' – The Guardian

Find out more and book tickets for our new special exhibition #SouthAfricanArt: http://ow.ly/74yy305yKpU
link_name: South Africa: The Art of a Nation review – from the dawn of man to the violence of apartheid

status_message:
Artist Mary Sibande has cast these figures from her own body. The one in blue represents her mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, who were all maids in white South African households. The figure in purple represents Sibande herself. It references anti-apartheid protests in which protesters were sprayed with purple dye by the police. The artist is saying goodbye to her past, and confronting South Africa's present and future. 

Watch the artist installing this incredible work in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, opening this Thursday. Find out more and book tickets: http://ow.ly/xJP2305sSGX
link_name: Mary Sibande installing her work in our South African art exhi...

status_message:
Pablo Picasso was born #onthisday in 1881. One of the most influential and prolific artists of the 20th century, he worked up until the end of his life, dying at the age of 91. He worked in many styles and genres – from his Blue and Rose Periods to Cubism, Classicism and Surrealism, and from paintings and sculpture to prints and drawings. His works remain some of the most highly valued in the world.

You can see a selection of wonderful Picasso prints on display at the Lady Lever Art Gallery in Liverpool as part of our touring exhibition http://ow.ly/rYUk305ngZy
link_name: Picasso Linocuts from the British Museum - Lady Lever Art Gallery, Liverpool museums

status_message: What is this #MysteryObject? Hint: it's around 15cm long

'I wanted to pay homage to the women in my family who were all maids. When you look at the history of South Africa, women didn't have a choice. They were discriminated against, firstly because they were women, and secondly because they were black.'

Read about artist Mary Sibande and her work 'A Reversed Retrogress', a highlight of our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, which opens this week http://ow.ly/bq4R305sQOE #BlackHistoryMonth
link_name: Mary Sibande's alter ego tells the story of post-apartheid South Africa - Apollo Magazine

status_message: This drawing by Louis Carmontelle shows a very young Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart playing the harpsichord – Mozart is so small his feet don't touch the floor! His father Leopold plays along on the violin and his sister Maria Anna (Nannerl) sings the tune. This candid view is characteristic of Carmontelle's style, allowing us an informal view into 18th-century life, while still being able to see the sumptuous clothing and interiors of the upper classes. You can see this work as part of our free #FrenchPortraits exhibition http://ow.ly/2cSM305np1I

Antinous, the Roman emperor Hadrian's lover, drowned in the Nile on this day in AD 130 while the imperial entourage was making a journey up the river. By coincidence, Egyptians were commemorating the death, by drowning in the Nile, of the god Osiris on the same day. Hadrian founded a new city, Antinoopolis, at the site of his death. Antinous was venerated as the god Osiris-Antinous. Hadrian also commissioned buildings and sculpture connected with the worship of Osiris for his villa in Tivoli, near Rome.
You can learn all about how important Osiris was to ancient Egyptians in our #SunkenCities exhibition – there's not long left to see it! http://ow.ly/hHwj305noVP
Esther Mahlangu (b. 1935), detail of BMW Art Car 12, 1991. © Esther Mahlangu. Photo © BMW Group Archives.

In this latest episode of our conservation series, discover how moulds and casts are used to reconstruct the missing pieces of a Roman glass urn. 

This urn was found in Sittingbourne in Kent, and is one of the largest Romano-British cinerary urns ever discovered. Cinerary urns like this were designed to carry ashes, especially the ashes of people who had been cremated.

Catch up on the whole series here http://ow.ly/opy8305oZKL
link_name: Conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 8

status_message:
This astonishing mechanical galleon is a marvel of craftsmanship and engineering. It is a 'nef' – an extravagant metal table ornament in the shape of a ship. 

Made by Hans Schlottheim in German, in about 1585, the central figure of the galleon is the Holy Roman Emperor, surrounded by seven noblemen. When the clockwork mechanisms were wound, the ship moved forward over the table and they bowed in front of the Emperor. Miniature figures of the trumpeters and drummers on the deck moved in time to music that was generated by an internal organ and drum. The front canon also fired, lighting a fuse which in turn fired the canons on each side of the ship. The display finished in a cloud of smoke and must have been breathtaking to a 16th-century audience.

Find out more about this incredible object in this BBC Radio 4 podcast: http://ow.ly/uY2T305patW

This richly decorated instrument, dripping with carved foliage, has an interesting story. It was originally made between 1280 and 1330 as a citole, a medieval guitar-like instrument, usually with four strings. This one is intriguing as it was converted into a violin at some point – possibly during the 16th century or later when the violin was becoming more fashionable. The coats of arms of Queen Elizabeth I and her alleged lover Robert Dudley appear on the silver plate at the headstock. http://ow.ly/K7Fn304eYdX

Robert Rauschenberg was born #onthisday in 1925. His 2-metre print 'Sky Garden' will feature in our #AmericanDream exhibition. Made in response to the 1969 Apollo 11 mission, the work captures the fervour and technological innovation of the launch. Rauschenberg was invited to NASA facilities in order to create artworks about the historic event. This composite print is a great technical achievement in itself, and was extremely complex to produce. He used official NASA photographs as well as diagrams and scenes of Florida's natural environment. 

See more incredible art from the USA in our major exhibition, opening March 2017 http://ow.ly/B2di305pmNQ 

Robert Rauschenberg (1925–2008), Sky Garden from Stoned Moon. Colour lithograph and screenprint, 1969. © Robert Rauschenberg Foundation

It's #WombatDay! Dante Gabriel Rossetti famously owned a pet wombat. He described the arrival of his new companion as 'a Joy, a Triumph, a Delight, a Madness.' Here are some of Rossetti's drawings of his marsupial friend http://ow.ly/qSA73059tz4

Post-Impressionist artist Paul Cézanne died #onthisday in 1906. This drawing is a tribute to Eugène Delacroix who had a profound influence on his work. In turn, Cézanne's style paved the way for 20th-century artistic movements such as Cubism. http://ow.ly/NI7h3056V6b

Founder of the Ming dynasty, the Hongwu emperor, was born #onthisday in 1328. He overthrew the Yuan dynasty, whose leaders had been Mongols, and reinstated Chinese styles and customs. He reigned for 30 years and ceramics developed significantly during this time. These beautiful examples showcase the complexity of designs http://ow.ly/FYmI3059e9B

Shadow puppet theatre tells many stories, including the epics that originated in ancient India – the Ramayana and the Mahabharata. The Ramayana follows the story of Prince Rama and his wife Sita, who is kidnapped by the demon-king Ravana http://ow.ly/OvjX305oPzd

These puppets of Rama and Ravana are from Malaysia and are on display in our free #ShadowPuppets exhibition http://ow.ly/OxcF304h4Sh

There's only one week before our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition opens! The team has been busy installing the huge variety of objects that will be on display in the show. You can explore 100,000 years of history in this fascinating country from Thursday 27 October. http://ow.ly/iciK305ndN0

Dutch landscape painter Aelbert Cuyp was born #onthisday in 1620. He was one of the leading landscape painters of his time, and is known for capturing the tranquillity of morning and evening light in his works. http://ow.ly/BOF23056Fvo

Architect Sir Christopher Wren was born on this day in 1632. His world-famous dome of St. Paul's Cathedral still dominates the skyline of London. The medieval cathedral burnt down during the Great Fire of London in 1666, and Wren was commissioned to design its replacement. This drawing shows the inner and outer domes of his iconic new Baroque design. The cathedral was consecrated in 1697 and, standing at 111 metres high, it remained London's tallest building until 1967. http://ow.ly/hJuk3056Ab6

'I know that long after I am gone, people will still go and see my paintings and they will remember there was an artist called Esther Mahlangu, and she came from South Africa.' – Esther Mahlangu (b. 1935) 

In 1991, to mark the end of apartheid, BMW invited Esther Mahlangu to make a work of art in their Art Car project. Her work, with its brightly coloured geometric shapes, draws on the traditional house-painting designs of Ndebele people in South Africa. #BlackHistoryMonth

See this Art Car in the Great Court of the Museum, part of our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition which opens next week http://ow.ly/1EVL305kEgA

Italian artist Umberto Boccioni was born #onthisday in 1882. Boccioni was one of the foremost members of the Futurist movement, which aimed to respond to the pace, technology and industry of the modern world. The swift, scratchy strokes of these early pre-Futurism prints convey the sense of speed that was characteristic of his works. http://ow.ly/e4FY3056tRG
Can you guess what this #MysteryObject was used for?

There are many shipwrecks discovered on the seabed in Abukir Bay in Egypt, but one in particular caught the eye of underwater archaeologist Franck Goddio as he was excavating a lost underwater city...

See more incredible discoveries found in the #SunkenCities of ancient Egypt in our unmissable exhibition: http://ow.ly/6SFh305gmBA
