status_message:
How many different animals can you spot in this incredible rock art from Zimbabwe?
Now in its fourth year, our African Rock Art project team have catalogued over 20,000 images stretching back thousands of years. You can now explore rock art from southern Africa, including images from Botswana, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.  
Follow our digital journey across Africa with the #AfricanRockArt image project.  

© TARA/David Coulson.

'Being under house arrest is a very traumatic experience. You're your own jailer. At the time, I was looking for a channel, for something to heal myself… I had an urge to become creative.' - Lionel Davis

Lionel Davis was born in 1936 in District Six, a once diverse area of Cape Town that was forcibly evacuated to make way for a 'whites only' settlement. In 1964 he was imprisoned on Robben Island for sabotage. In this work, the artist's face is partly covered by a map of District Six and one of Robben Island. The writing on his head is in an Afrikaans dialect spoken in Cape Town, and relates to black women trying to remove kinks in their hair to be less African and more European or American. #BlackHistoryMonth 

See cutting-edge contemporary works alongside some of the earliest examples of human creativity in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition. http://ow.ly/cjFU305bCWc

Oscar Wilde was born #onthisday in 1854. Playwright, poet and novelist, Wilde's decadent works placed him as a leading protagonist in late 19th-century artistic circles. His play 'The Importance of Being Earnest' and novel 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' are highlights in a career that was both dramatic and tragic. A central character to the Aestheticism movement, his flamboyant dress, avant-garde lifestyle and profound intellect garnered significant interest in a conservative Victorian society. http://ow.ly/83LR3058PWu

French artist James Tissot was born #onthisday in 1836. His works explored modern life through portraiture. Tissot was a hugely popular artist during the 1870s, when he moved from Paris to London, changing his name from Jacques to James. He recorded the fashions and the modern lifestyles of the day, and was associated with artists like Degas and Manet. Explore works by Tissot in the Museum's collection here: http://ow.ly/rCKD304UwYR

From some of the earliest examples of human creativity to cutting-edge contemporary works, discover the fascinating history of South Africa through 100,000 years of art. Our special exhibition South Africa: the art of a nation opens on 27 October - find out more http://ow.ly/TtJL305bKWx
link_name: South Africa: the art of a nation

status_message:
"On the eve of the most bitterly fought US presidential election in decades, the British Museum has unveiled a print created by Andy Warhol in 1972 … It will be a star exhibit in the museum's major spring exhibition of prints made in the US since the 1960s" – The Guardian 

Our landmark #AmericanDream exhibition traces the momentum of a superpower through six decades, from the 1960s to today. Find out more here: http://ow.ly/kmzW305bDdR
link_name: London exhibition puts US on show as postwar creative superpower

status_message: The Battle of Hastings was fought #onthisday 950 years ago. After the death of Edward the Confessor in early 1066, there was a struggle for the throne of England. William of Normandy (later 'the Conqueror') launched an invasion in late September, and fought King Harold II of England at Hastings. Famously, the Bayeux Tapestry depicts events leading up to the battle and culminates with the death of Harold on the battlefield. A plaster cast of scenes from the tapestry was made in the 19th century – you can see Harold's coronation in the centre of this section.  http://ow.ly/WNuU3054kw7

Episode 7 of our conservation series examines how missing pieces from the Roman urn are carefully reconstructed. Conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu also explains how ancient objects are protected during the reconstruction process.
link_name: Conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 7

status_message: Nero became Roman emperor #onthisday in AD 54. Roman historian Tacitus portrayed Nero as a tyrant in his 'Annals', but was writing long after the emperor's death. This statue would have originally held a spear or sceptre in its right hand and was found in Suffolk, eastern England. http://ow.ly/nQAA304SShR

Our free display #DefacingThePast opens today! See how symbols of power were subverted in ancient Rome. This basalt sculpture of Roman General Germanicus was altered by Christians in late antiquity. The cross on the forehead was carved into the statue for protection as it was believed that demons haunted such sculptures. The head of Vespasian could have been re-carved from a portrait of Nero. http://ow.ly/Rpil304XnHS 
You can examine virtual objects from this display and 3D print them for yourself! ow.ly/ukFf3058zct
Jasper Johns (b. 1930), Flags I. Screenprint, 1973. Collection of Johanna and Leslie Garfield. © Jasper Johns/VAGA, New York/DACS, London 2016. © Tom Powel Imaging.

America. Land of the free. Home of the brave... Trace the creative momentum of a superpower in our #AmericanDream exhibition – announced today! 

The past six decades have been among the most dynamic and turbulent in US history, from JFK's assassination, Apollo 11 and Vietnam to the AIDS crisis, racism and gender politics. Responding to the changing times, American artists produced prints unprecedented in their scale and ambition. 

Experience this extraordinary history in 'The American Dream: pop to the present', opening March 2017. This major new exhibition is sponsored by Morgan Stanley and supported by the Terra Foundation for American art. Book now: http://ow.ly/4fup3056aRl  

Jasper Johns (b. 1930), Flags I. Screenprint, 1973. Collection of Johanna and Leslie Garfield. © Jasper Johns/VAGA, New York/DACS, London 2016. © Tom Powel Imaging

Ooo indeed! Tomorrow we'll be announcing a very exciting new exhibition… #AmericanDream 

Image: Edward Ruscha (b. 1937), OOO. Colour lithograph, 1970. © Ed Ruscha. Reproduced by permission of the artist.
What do you think this #MysteryObject was used for?

The Mysteries of Osiris was the most important religious event of the year in ancient Egypt. It reenacted the murder and rebirth of Osiris, Egyptian god of the underworld. The festival took place between the 12th and 30th of the month of Khoiak (mid-October to mid-November). Astonishing underwater finds in the recently rediscovered #SunkenCities of Canopus and Thonis-Heracleion now allow us to see ritual equipment and offerings associated with the Mysteries http://ow.ly/AJ4x3052msm

Experience the Festival of Osiris in our free late event on Friday 28 October. Enjoy themed food and drink, workshops and performances! http://ow.ly/6gWj304V1II 

A statuette of Osiris and a model of a processional barge for this god, shown in their place of excavation at Thonis-Heracleion. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

French artist Antoine Watteau was born #onthisday in 1684. His serene, colourful compositions moved away from the exaggerated drama of Baroque artwork. These drawings were perhaps preliminary sketches for his paintings of aristocratic parties. http://ow.ly/Ed2G304SNna

You can see some of his works in our free French Portraits exhibition: http://ow.ly/8TgB3051iU6
Pre-Raphaelite artist Simeon Solomon was born #onthisday in 1840. See the medieval stylings of the movement in these prints and drawings. http://ow.ly/Dlz2304Eq3p

John Lennon was born #onthisday in 1940. As a member of the Beatles he revolutionised pop music and the group remain the best-selling band of all time. Artist Richard Hamilton designed this photo collage of the band members. It was reproduced as a poster in every copy of their eponymous 1968 album, popularly known as the 'White Album'. The Museum's version is an offset photolithograph made directly from the artist's collage. http://ow.ly/9rKq304EoSB
Sir Percival David died #onthisday in 1964. Room 95 is dedicated to his spectacular collection of Chinese ceramics. You can explore the gallery here: http://ow.ly/K3rq304XR7u
Knight at the Museum? Welcome to the armoury store, which has everything from breastplates to bayonets, helmets to halberds. Here's a quick look behind the scenes at some of the fantastic pieces.

Artist Mary Sibande has cast these figures from her own body. The one in Victorian dress, called Sophie, refers to her mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, who were maids in white South African households. The second figure, in purple, represents Sibande herself. 

The work also relates to the Purple Rain Protests of 1989, when protesters captured the police water cannon being used to spray them with purple dye and turned it on their assailants. Over the following days the slogan 'the purple shall govern' was painted on walls around Cape Town. Although a tension remains, Sibande is saying goodbye to Sophie, her past, and confronting the 'purple' present and future.

This incredible work will feature in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, opening 27 October 2016 http://ow.ly/R1Bm304ErX1 

During #BlackHistoryMonth, we're sharing the rich artistic heritage and diverse stories of black culture around the world.

Mary Sibande (b. 1982), A Reversed Retrogress: Scene 1 (The Purple Shall Govern), 2013. Courtesy of the artist and Gallery MOMO.

This statue depicts the ancient Egyptian goddess Taweret, who protected women and children. Taweret had the body of a hippopotamus, the limbs of a lion and the tail of a crocodile, making her a powerful and dangerous creature. With her fearsome appearance, she warded off evil. In this sculpture, she only bares her teeth and sticks out her tongue, but she is often shown holding a knife in each hand ready to strike down any threat. Her front paws rest above large hieroglyphic signs meaning 'protection'. 

Discover more about ancient Egyptian gods and popular belief in our #SunkenCities exhibition, closing 27 November 2016 http://ow.ly/iKs9304GcO0 

Statue of the goddess Taweret. Karnak (modern Luxor), 664–610 BC. Egyptian Museum, Cairo. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Guru Gobind Singh, the 10th Sikh Guru died #onthisday in 1708. In this print from the late 19th century, the Guru is seen creating the Khalsa (the collective body of initiated Sikhs). http://ow.ly/rvQn304EgJD

In episode 6 of our conservation series, the Roman glass urn is carefully pieced back together for its trip around the world. Conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu explains how this ancient jigsaw puzzle was completed
link_name: Conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 6

status_message:
We've had a very exciting delivery! Watch how we managed to get this amazing BMW Art Car into the Museum. The vividly decorated car was painted in 1991 by South African artist Esther Mahlangu. The geometric patterns that cover the vehicle are inspired by traditional house-painting designs of the Ndebele people. These designs can be seen as an expression of cultural identity despite marginalisation, and the car was decorated to mark the end of apartheid in South Africa. 

See this incredible Art Car as part of our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, which opens on 27 October. You can book your tickets here: http://ow.ly/20ZF304VcUN  

Esther Mahlangu (b. 1935), detail of BMW Art Car 12, 1991. © Esther Mahlangu. Photo © BMW Group Archives.

Music: "Nonstop" Kevin MacLeod (incompetech.com)
Licensed under Creative Commons: By Attribution 3.0 License

'What sort of man is this holding a staff
Gently walking and considering a poem as he goes?'

At 3.5m high, this painting by Japanese artist Suzuki Shōnen (1848–1918) is a towering composition, yet the brushwork remains refined. Its subject is the contented solitude of the ageing artist himself as he wanders among the idealised mountains of his imagination. The poem at the top reinforces this feeling.

Who's your favourite poet? What do you think makes a great poem? #NationalPoetryDay http://ow.ly/Aq3R304H2T8

Rembrandt died #onthisday in 1669. One of the most influential artists of all time, Rembrandt is known for his sensitive and reflective portraits, as well as his landscapes and carefully composed religious paintings. The Dutch artist's style evolved throughout his career – these drawings and etchings convey his artistic range. http://ow.ly/cbak304E84V

Giovanni Battista Piranesi was born #onthisday in 1720. The Italian artist is known for his scenes of Rome, and romantic depictions of ancient Roman architecture from the city. His work was appreciated by wealthy Europeans visiting Italy on a 'Grand Tour' to take in the sights and styles of ancient civilisations. http://ow.ly/tu5l304E77Y

It's #WorldAnimalDay! These adorable Japanese netsuke, each no larger than 5cm, show a range of animals. Netsuke are intricately carved toggles that were worn on a kimono by Japanese men during the Edo period (1615–1868) http://ow.ly/JBni304Ikdp

Made of cut up decommissioned weapons, 'Tree of Life' is a war memorial that celebrates the courage of the people of Mozambique. Millions of guns entered the country during the civil war (1977–1992). When the war ended, Mozambicans were encouraged to hand over weapons in exchange for ploughs, bicycles and sewing machines. They were then turned into striking sculptures by artists working in Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. 

Throughout #BlackHistoryMonth, we'll be sharing the rich artistic heritage and diverse stories of black culture around the world. http://ow.ly/5DfE304E6mo 

Made by Christavao Canhavato (Kester), Hilario Nhatugueja, Fiel dos Santos and Adelino Serafim Mathe in 2004 as a commission for the British Museum's Sainsbury African Galleries (Room 25).

This medal commemorates German reunification, which happened #onthisday in 1990. The inscription translates as 'unity and justice and freedom'. 

You can learn much more about German history – including the reunification – in this 2014 BBC radio series presented by former Director Neil MacGregor. http://ow.ly/w0hU304NDE9 

More about this medal: http://ow.ly/qZO2304ExTN

Famous for his fabulously floral designs, Arts & Crafts pioneer William Morris died #onthisday in 1896. A prolific artist and designer, he established his own company making furnishings, wallpaper and tiles, among other things. Influenced by medieval textiles and the colourful, historical work of Pre-Raphaelite artists, his designs were often layered and very intricate. Here are some of the tiles his company produced in the late 19th century. http://ow.ly/9Ht5304E5V9

Gandhi was born #onthisday in 1869. A pioneer of non-violent protest against British rule in India, he campaigned for peace and religious freedom in his home country. He was given the title Mahatma, which means 'high-souled' in Sanskrit. His birthday is a national holiday in India, and recognised as an international day of non-violence.

Circular printed badge. Made in India 2002 http://ow.ly/qF8I304Jno3
The month October takes its name from being the 8th month of the Roman calendar – octō means 8 in Latin. We love this October scene by Constable showing Folkestone in 1833 http://ow.ly/NJvC304JG2P

Sir Robert Smirke, the architect who designed the core of the British Museum building from 1823 onwards, was born #onthisday in 1780. Smirke was one of the leading neoclassical architects of the early 19th century, a style that evoked the scale and presence of ancient Greek and Roman buildings. Although his designs were inspired by ancient structures, he advocated technological progress in building and he eagerly adopted the use of cast iron and concrete.

Read more about the Museum's history: http://ow.ly/Wv7R304JmBU 

Photograph by Roger Fenton, 1857.

Collector and antiquarian Charles Townley was born #onthisday in 1737. Many objects in the Museum's collection were once owned by Townley, and one of the best known is the Townley Discobolus. The statue is a Roman marble copy of a Greek bronze original, and is famed for having a head that does not belong to the original body. The head is very close in age and style, and uses marble that is exceptionally well matched to the torso, but it has been attached at the wrong angle! Complete statues from the time reveal the head to be turned to look towards the discus, rather than the floor.

This colossal human-headed winged bull is a lamassu, an Assyrian protective deity. It once guarded the entrance to the Assyrian capital city of Dur-Sharrukin ('the fortress of Sargon'), known today as Khorsabad. The citadel, now in northern Iraq, was built by king Sargon II between 710 and 705 BC. A pair of these 16 tonne, 4.5m tall gypsum statues stood at the entrance to the city, warding away evil and keeping the inhabitants safe http://ow.ly/N8UD304sx2Y
In episode 5 of our conservation series, the Roman glass urn goes under the microscope and its secrets are revealed!
link_name: The conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 5

status_message: It's #InternationalCoffeeDay! How do you take your coffee? These coffee pots from around the world show how global coffee has become http://ow.ly/x2ii304GMx9

Caravaggio was born #onthisday in 1571. The Italian painter is best known for his dramatic and shadowy 'chiaroscuro' paintings that went on to heavily influence Baroque art. This was long believed to be the only Caravaggio etching. http://ow.ly/Hjnw304lKJR
Admiral Horatio Nelson was born #onthisday in 1758. Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square commemorates his life and naval victories. http://ow.ly/dWs0304G267

Enjoy a look at the Georgian pomp of the Enlightenment Gallery. This was originally known as the King's Library as it housed over 60,000 books collected by King George III (r. 1760–1820) – these have since been moved to The British Library. Built between 1823 and 1827, the Enlightenment Gallery was the first part of the 'new' Museum building to be completed. Between 2000 and 2003 the room was restored to its 1820s glory, and this is what you can see today. The books on display now are from the House of Commons Library. You can browse the gallery wherever you are using Street View: http://ow.ly/ZHbh304BsUw

In this royal portrait discovered in one of Egypt's #SunkenCities, a Ptolemaic king is depicted as a pharaoh. The Ptolemies were originally a Greco-Macedonian dynasty, descended from one of Alexander the Great's generals. This skilfully executed head shows a Ptolemaic king depicted in accordance with ancient Egyptian traditions. His head is adorned by the rearing cobra protruding from the traditional headcloth of Egyptian pharaohs. The portrait perfectly illustrates how Ptolemaic kings wanted to present themselves to their Egyptian subjects as the legitimate successors to the native pharaohs.

Find out more about the deep connections between the ancient civilisations of Greece and Egypt in our unmissable exhibition http://ow.ly/qxGF304DKB2

Ptolemaic king. Canopus, 300–200 BC. Bibliotheca Alexandrina Antiquities Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Eminent caricaturist and cartoonist George Cruikshank was born #onthisday in 1792. He satirised fashions and culture through his cartoons, making social and political commentary humorous, often attacking royalty or politicians. These prints show his take on the dandy fashions of 200 years ago, and the hysteria surrounding the Battle of Waterloo. http://ow.ly/adnj304lePP
What do you think today's #MysteryObject was used for?

French artist Edgar Degas died #onthisday in 1917. Known for his pastel shades and hazy depictions of Parisian ballet, Degas' composition also marked him out from his contemporaries. These voyeuristically cropped sketches and prints showcase his unique method of framing his subjects. http://ow.ly/YpTY304l2u1
'Postcards have been very little studied as historical sources, yet they are an insight into how countries choose to project themselves'.
link_name: Postcards on the edge: curator's homage to a dying tradition

status_message: Sir Francis Drake finished his circumnavigation of the globe #onthisday in 1580. This medal made in 1589 depicts the route he travelled, including the deviation he took due to a storm in the Pacific Ocean. The medal was designed by Flemish geographer and cartographer Michael Mercator, whose projection of the globe is still used today, over 400 years later.  http://ow.ly/a1Cw304lqdJ

Explore the movement and mythology of shadow puppet performance in Southeast Asia in our new free exhibition. The colourful and often intricately detailed puppets are used to tell a wide range of stories, with up to 60 being used per performance! http://ow.ly/b4Af304o5Jk
South Africa is celebrating #HeritageDay! Learn more about the history of this fascinating nation in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition http://ow.ly/4aPM304d72q

Did you know that the Museum used to have its own Tube station? It closed #onthisday in 1933 after Holborn station opened nearby. It was part of what is now the Central line, and served visitors for over 30 years. These brilliant photos are from London Transport Museum

Journey through 3,000 years of ancient Egyptian sculpture, including the Rosetta Stone and colossal statues of pharaohs. You can tour the gallery at your leisure on Google Street View: http://ow.ly/ebrT304v6Lo

Augustus, the first Roman emperor, was born #onthisday in 63 BC. Born Octavian, he was adopted by Julius Caesar and by 31 BC had established himself as the dominant force in Roman politics. He changed his name to Augustus in 27 BC. This bronze head is known as the Meroë Head as it was found in the ancient Kushite capital of Meroë, now in northern Sudan. http://ow.ly/1h3S304qnna
How to take apart a Roman glass urn (and why you might need to!) Watch episode 4 of our video series with conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu.
link_name: The conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 4

status_message: Wagner's opera Das Rheingold premiered #onthisday in 1869 in Munich. It is the prelude to a four-part cycle of music dramas composed by Wagner called 'Der Ring des Nibelungen', or 'The Ring of the Nibelung', loosely based on old Norse sagas. These prints by French artist Henri Fantin-Latour show scenes from the story http://ow.ly/XbfO304pX7r

Does this drawing count as a portrait? Pierre Dumonstier thought that portraying Artemisia Gentileschi like this would capture her essence. As a leading painter of the early 17th century, her hand was the source of her artistic brilliance. You can see other intriguing drawings in our #FrenchPortraits exhibition: http://ow.ly/c4qD304d7Kg

Feeling autumnal yet? It's the autumn equinox in the northern hemisphere today – this means there are equal lengths of light and darkness, and traditionally marks the start of the season. http://ow.ly/1lma304q6QD

German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer died #onthisday in 1860. One of the most influential thinkers of the early 19th century, he is most famous for his 1818 work 'The World as Will and Representation'. Schopenhauer's ideas started to gain traction after his death and he subsequently influenced a wide range of later philosophical and scientific thinkers. http://ow.ly/bSf6304cSUe

Holy Roman Emperor Charles V died #onthisday in 1558. As well as being emperor, he also had many other titles, including King of Spain (as Carlos I of Castile and León, and of Aragon and Sicily), Archduke of Austria and Duke of Burgundy. Weary of the pressures of ruling such a vast collection of territories, he had abdicated in 1556 and moved to a monastery. This print from 1534 follows his family tree all the way back to King Pharamundo, a legendary early king of the Franks who supposedly lived in the 4th–5th centuries AD. To capture Charles's lineage fully, the family tree is 20 pages! http://ow.ly/3dAz304coEP

This 2,000-year-old bust depicts Neilos, the Nile river god. Neilos appealed to Egyptians and Greeks alike – he was the Greek version of Hapy, the Egyptian personification of the annual Nile flood that brought prosperity and fertility to the country. Neilos played a significant role in one of the most popular festivals in Egypt, when the beginning of the annual flood marked the Egyptian New Year.

This bust was once mounted into a large decorative shield and adorned a temple in the ancient Egyptian city of Canopus. It was discovered by underwater archaeologists at the base of the wall on which it once hung.

See more incredible objects that have been preserved and buried under the sea for over a thousand years in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/GLrp304lecq 

Bust of Neilos. Canopus, AD 100–200. Maritime Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.
Can you guess what this #MysteryObject was used for?

Maggi Hambling is known for her powerful and arresting portraits, and you can see many of them in our new free exhibition. Here she portrays John Berger, an art critic and writer. Hambling visited Berger at his home in the French Alps to paint this portrait in 2000 – his searing gaze suggests his formidable intellect. As the artist has said of her sitter: 'Life force pours out of him'.  http://ow.ly/zlyk304cSAC

This 800-year-old gold rhino was found at Mapungubwe, the capital of the first kingdom in southern Africa. It was discovered alongside other gold objects, which were found in three royal graves. They are some of the most significant sculptures in Africa today, and depict animals of high status (a rhinoceros, cow, and a leopard) and objects associated with power (a sceptre and a bowl or crown). 

See these incredible sculptures in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, opening 27 October 2016 http://ow.ly/1Bdc304lb2h 

Mapungubwe gold rhinoceros, made about 1220–1290. On loan from University of Pretoria.

These illustrations for Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream were drawn by British illustrator Arthur Rackham in 1908. He was born #onthisday in 1867. You can see all his works in the Museum's collection here: http://ow.ly/LsX6304l0Nz
Get a bird's-eye view of the Museum in this 3D model on Sketchfab. You can also 3D print the model so you can have a mini British Museum of your very own! http://ow.ly/MGUl303Z4p0

Revolutionary rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix died #onthisday in 1970. This print by David Oxtoby captures the electricity of his music in a striking psychedelic portrait. Hendrix's (often literally) incendiary performances stunned audiences in the late 1960s. http://ow.ly/nFKh303YQXK

'What I find truly remarkable is Arsinoe's attitude… she exudes confidence'. 

Read more about this incredible statue of the Ptolemaic queen Arsinoe II and find out why she is curator Aurelia Masson's favourite object in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/COWh304hl7U
Our touring exhibition 'Writing for eternity' opens in Abergavenny Museum today, and explores 4,000 years of writing in ancient Egypt. http://ow.ly/hVJs303Wa5d

Philip IV of Spain died #onthisday in 1665. Well known as a patron of the arts, and a great admirer of Spanish painter Diego Velázquez, the king comissioned many portraits of himself. This print by Édouard Manet is based on a work by Velázquez, and shows Philip with his famous flamboyant moustache. http://ow.ly/LzjV3047YBT

This evening we're celebrating #Chuseok with food, drink, dance and music! Find out more about the Korean Harvest Moon Festival through films, workshops and storytelling.

Plus, tomorrow we've got a fantastic family feast with activities right throughout the day, including traditional music, K-pop, workshops, storytelling and a special photo booth.
link_name: Celebrating Chuseok: the Korean Harvest Moon Festival

status_message: Sir Anthony Panizzi, Principal Librarian of the British Museum between 1856 and 1866, was born #onthisday in 1797. This was when the national library was also part of the Museum, and Panizzi has been referred to as 'the greatest library administrator ever known' for his role in transforming the collection. He also had the idea of building the Reading Room in the central courtyard. This marble bust dates from 1856. http://ow.ly/P3DJ303WGkY
In the latest video in our conservation series, conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu starts the dismantling process on this glass urn from Roman Britain.

status_message:
Our new #AfricanRockArt display opens today! Rock art was a means of expression in southern Africa for thousands of years. This free display focuses on one central example of rock art and its importance to San|Bushmen http://ow.ly/3bxz303WwMn

Supported by The Asahi Shimbun.

status_message: We're celebrating the Korean Harvest Moon Festival #Chuseok! Join Curator Eleanor Hyun for a private tour in our Korea Gallery

Celebrate #Chuseok with us live on Facebook tomorrow! Marking the start of autumn, Chuseok is the Korean Harvest Moon Festival, held on the 15th day of the 8th month of the lunar calendar. Join us at 09.15 BST with Curator Eleanor Hyun #추석

When war broke out in 1939 many of the Museum's most important objects had already been evacuated to safe locations across the UK. Meanwhile, back in London, the Museum was still open and put on the 'Suicide Exhibition'. Find out more in our new podcast http://ow.ly/hZJg304crL7

Artist Anselm Feuerbach was born #onthisday in 1829. The leading classicist painter of the German 19th-century school, he evoked the dignity and composition of ancient Greek art with his carefully crafted works. These drawings show some of the mythological subjects he painted. http://ow.ly/pPTi303Z8Sl

The Battle of Marathon was fought #onthisday in 490 BC. The ancient battle is famous for the story of the original 'marathon runner'. According to Herodotus, when the Athenians learned that the Persians had landed at Marathon on the way to attack Athens in 490 BC, a messenger named Pheidippides ran to Sparta with a request for help. The athlete covered 260 kilometres of rugged terrain in less than two days! http://ow.ly/Y9OA3041nW1

This Japanese samurai armour may look intimidating, but during the peaceful Edo period (1600–1868) armour like this was generally only used ceremonially. This example is made up of pieces constructed for different suits. It features a bulletproof breastplate and lacquered iron platelets held together with silk. http://ow.ly/OZKL303YmyY

The #TourOfBritain cycling race arrives in London today. Bikes have come a long way in 200 years – the ones in these prints don't even have pedals! In 1819 two wheels became a particularly fashionable form of transport, and the machines were variously called 'velocipedes' or 'dandy horses' after the dashingly dressed young men who rode about on them. Capable of around ten miles per hour, the dandies were often portrayed darting around London – here a rider has made it 21 miles from the city. Today the Tour of Britain riders will be travelling 62 miles at nearly 30mph. http://ow.ly/PY2H303KEcR
Baroque composer Henry Purcell was born #onthisday in 1659. He fused elements from Italian and French styles and developed his own brand of English Baroque. http://ow.ly/Opsg3043wT4

This week we're celebrating #Chuseok, the Korean harvest moon festival that marks the start of autumn. Enjoy three days of events – live music and talks on Thursday, a Friday late event with K-pop and Korean food and drink, and a family day on Saturday #추석
link_name: Celebrating Chuseok: the Korean Harvest Moon Festival

status_message: Architect Sir John Soane was born #onthisday in 1753. One of the most celebrated neoclassical architects of the early 19th century, Soane's work is characterised by the grand ambition of his designs. He embarked on a tour of Europe in 1778, and many of the details and styles he encountered on this trip influenced his later work. His home and collection of antiquities can still be seen at Sir John Soane's Museum http://ow.ly/4ivf303IVRn

This counterfeit banknote was made in Gothenburg, Sweden, in the 1860s. Unlike official printed currency of the same time, it was painstakingly drawn by hand! It must have taken a long time to produce. Would you be convinced by this fake? You can examine the note for yourself in our #MoneyMatters exhibition. http://ow.ly/gnoY303VUbe

Hajj, the Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca, starts today. The word #Hajj means 'to intend a journey', and the pilgrimage is as much about an inward journey as it is about the act of travelling to the city of Mecca. These postcards were acquired by former British Museum curator Qaisra Khan when she completed her pilgrimage to the holy city in 2010.  http://ow.ly/C1XE30432Rd

French artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec died #onthisday in 1901. His works capture the dynamism and provocation of late 19th-century Paris. 

Some of his pieces can be seen in our new French portrait drawings display: http://ow.ly/ENdk303Ll5b

You can also browse his works in the Museum's collection: http://ow.ly/qfEC303LoWg

Here's the second video in our new series highlighting the conservation of a glass urn from Roman Britain. The urn is being prepared for a round-the-world trip. In this episode, conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu looks at the previous restoration techniques that were used to glue the glass fragments together.
link_name: The conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 2

status_message: Discover never-before-seen works and spontaneous sketches in our new exhibition of French portrait drawings, opening today. These works span centuries of art, from the Renaissance to the 19th century. They reveal a more intimate side of artists such as Watteau, Ingres, Fantin-Latour, Toulouse-Lautrec and Courbet, showcasing their experimentation with ideas around what a portrait can be. http://ow.ly/ENdk303Ll5b

Casting light on the traditional entertainment of Southeast Asia, our new shadow puppets exhibition is now open! Travel through time and discover the mythology, theatre and religion encapsulated in shadow puppet performances. http://ow.ly/Ub6e303Llbk

Could this be the ancient Egyptian equivalent of The Great British Bake Off tent? This 4,000-year-old model of a granary shows the bread-making process in the ancient world. Egyptian bread was often gritty because it contained impurities like sand, so these bakers probably never produced anything to rival the showstoppers of Bake Off contestants!  http://ow.ly/7CU3303KJ4d

This Art Car by South African artist Esther Mahlangu is inspired by traditional house-painting designs of the Ndebele people. The vividly coloured geometric patterns covered the houses of the Ndebele people, who were forced to live in ethnically defined rural reserves during apartheid. These designs can be seen as an expression of cultural identity despite marginalisation. This BMW was decorated in 1991 to mark the end of apartheid.

See this incredible Art Car as part of our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition, which opens on 27 October. You can book your tickets here: http://ow.ly/tOEI303YZDD

Esther Mahlangu (b. 1935), detail of BMW Art Car 12, 1991. © Esther Mahlangu. Photo © BMW Group Archives.

The last Tudor monarch, Elizabeth I, was born #onthisday in 1533. England under her rule is often seen now as a golden age where drama, poetry and literature flourished. This gold pendant is decorated with white, red and white-and-red roses. The white-and-red flowers were adopted as a symbol of the Tudor dynasty by Elizabeth's grandfather, Henry VII, to signify unity after the infighting of the Wars of the Roses. http://ow.ly/ZpQq303YeqC

'Drawing is the beginning of everything for me. It is the most immediate, most intimate thing an artist does, like handwriting.'

Read an interview with artist Maggi Hambling ahead of her new exhibition opening this week at the Museum. It will present an important survey of works on paper, tracing her engagement with drawing throughout her career http://ow.ly/dk7s303VMgo

This stela helped archaeologists solve a 2,000-year-old mystery, revealing that the cities of Thonis (in Egyptian) and Heracleion (in Greek) were in fact the same place! The tablet details the taxation on imports and exports going through the city http://ow.ly/bfDB303Wwdr 

Explore more incredible objects discovered in ancient Egypt's #SunkenCities in our unmissable exhibition http://ow.ly/N6iv303WwYm

The Mayflower set sail from Plymouth to the New World #onthisday in 1620. A landmark in the history of North America, the ship carried 102 passengers across the Atlantic Ocean in around two months. After a harsh journey, the Pilgrims established settlements along the east coast of Massachusetts, forming the 'Plymouth Colony'. This medal, struck in 1970, commemorates the 350th anniversary of the voyage. http://ow.ly/F800303KI8C

Today Hindus celebrate the #GaneshChaturthi festival – honouring the elephant-headed god Ganesha. During the festival thousands of small clay statues of the god are worshipped and eventually submerged in lakes, rivers or the sea. Ganesha is an especially important deity as he is the god of new beginnings and the remover of obstacles.

Explore the imagery and symbolism associated with Ganesha in this online exhibition on Google Arts & Culture ow.ly/xMA1303UxEc

Are you #BacktoSchool today? Hopefully this year you'll have no last-minute rushed homework. This Mesopotamian student handed theirs in over 3,300 years ago – a fine example to follow! http://ow.ly/gdlS303TOIb

The incredible Lewis Chessmen are part of a hoard found in a sand dune at Uig Bay on the Isle of Lewis in Scotland. It's thought that they might have belonged to a trader who was travelling from Norway to Ireland to sell them, sometime between AD 1150–1200. Around this time, chess was a very popular game among the aristocracy in Europe. 

You can see the Chessmen at the British Museum, the National Museum of Scotland, and six of the objects are on long-term loan at the newly built Museum & Tasglann nan Eilean in Scotland. http://ow.ly/COTU303t2e5

Romulus Augustulus, the last ancient Roman emperor, was deposed #onthisday in AD 476. This date has been used to mark the beginning of the Middle Ages in Europe, and the fall of the Western Roman empire. Not much is known about his life, but the 'Augustulus' part of his name means 'little Augustus' – he was around 16 years old when he was emperor. http://ow.ly/bHQT303thAt

Bauhaus artist Oskar Schlemmer was born #onthisday in 1888. He was 'Master of Form' at the Bauhaus theatre workshop and his obsession with the human figure can be seen in these two prints from 1921. Schlemmer's ideas for constructing the human form were intended to rescue figure drawing from, as he put it, "the odium of academicism". http://ow.ly/vHVD303tdTA

From Michelangelo to Mondrian, Rembrandt to Rachel Whiteread, Piranesi to Picasso, artists have used drawing as a means of both recording and provoking thought, giving us insight into the minds of some of the world's greatest artists at work. See 70 exquisite drawings from the 15th century to today in our new touring exhibition at Poole Museum Service! http://ow.ly/RYda303t9jG

Crowned king of England #onthisday in 1189, Richard the Lionheart spent most of his reign abroad. These floor tiles show him in armour on horseback, and originate from Chertsey Abbey in Surrey. He is shown opposite his adversary Saladin, the sultan who opposed him in the Crusades in the 12th century. http://ow.ly/4fTD303tb7U

British artist Joseph Wright of Derby was born #onthisday in 1734. Known for his powerful use of light and shadow ('chiaroscuro'), Wright's works are dynamic and engaging. Famous for his portrayal of contemporary scenes of science and industry during the industrial revolution, Wright applied the techniques he learned from the old masters' paintings he saw when he travelled to Italy in 1774. You can browse his sketchbook of drawings from this trip here: http://ow.ly/1Mkb303t6Hf

The Great Fire of London started #onthisday 350 years ago. Beginning in a small bakery in Pudding Lane, just north of London Bridge, the fire soon engulfed the surrounding area due to the high-density wooden housing that dominated London's streets. Fire fighting was rudimentary, and the Lord Mayor was slow in giving definitive orders to deal with the blaze. The medieval St Paul's Cathedral was the most notable building to be destroyed – it had been one of the largest and tallest churches in the world. http://ow.ly/Kkxg303t2l5

Britain adopted the Gregorian calendar #onthisday in 1752 meaning 11 days were 'lost'! The correction of the calendar meant that the next day was 14 September (rather than 3 Sep). The Gregorian calendar was introduced by the Pope (Gregory XIII, after who it is named) in order to keep the vernal equinox at a similar time of year to Easter, and was therefore associated with Roman Catholicism. Many Catholic European countries had adopted the calendar in 1582 – Protestant countries like Britain had previously objected to using it. ow.ly/1DK8303Pman

'The Sun King' – Louis XIV of France – died #onthisday in 1715. He reigned for 72 years, during a period when the country was the dominant power in Europe. He moved the monarchy's residence to Versailles and set about building the extravagant palace at immense cost. http://ow.ly/byzZ303sMM8

Go behind the scenes and follow the story of a Romano-British glass urn as Conservator Duygu Camurcuoglu prepares it for travelling around the world. 

This is the first in a new video series that tracks the process of this in-depth conservation work, from investigation through to reconstruction.
link_name: The conservation of a Romano-British urn | Episode 1: Introduc...

status_message: September is named after the Latin for 7 as it was the seventh month in the Roman calendar. This engraving shows the vegetable harvest of 1638 in Germany. http://ow.ly/Z06H303zL5j
'It changes you forever…' Find out what it's like to film underwater excavations and be part of the team who discovered the #SunkenCities of ancient Egypt http://ow.ly/8O55303L9DT

The Roman emperor Caligula was born #onthisday in AD 12. As a young boy he earned the name Caligula ('little soldier's boot') while accompanying his father on military campaigns. The name derives from 'caligae', the Roman army's hob-nailed boot. This gold coin from his reign was found in southern India – Rome was known to have traded this far east for items like silk and spices. http://ow.ly/ufVO303szrW

Happy birthday to sculptor Antony Gormley, probably best known for his statue the 'Angel of the North', in northern England. At 20 metres tall with a 50 metre wingspan, and perched on top of a hill, the statue was a significant engineering challenge. Here a preliminary drawing by Gormley shows the extent of the underground reinforcements that support the massive structure. http://ow.ly/WPlb303sxJt

French artist Jacques-Louis David was born #onthisday in 1748. Synonymous with neoclassicism, his works evoked the grandeur and power of ancient Rome and Greece in a time of great change in France. This drawing was made during a trip to Rome, and shows the intensity of the bust of Brutus from the Capitol in Rome. http://ow.ly/Yry6303vf4C
Can you guess what this #MysteryObject is? Reply with your answers!

Mughal emperor Jahangir (whose name means 'conqueror of the world')  was born #onthisday in 1569. This first image shows a twice-yearly event that proved the emperor's family were worth their weight in gold. Jahangir is seen here weighing his son, Prince Khurram, against gold, silver, silk and grain. The treasure would then be distributed among the poor http://ow.ly/XWaY303srek

Rock art is one of South Africa's oldest artistic traditions. It was first made by the ancestors of San|Bushmen and Khoekhoen, South Africa's first peoples, at least 30,000 years ago. This rock painting depicts San|Bushmen running between eland, a type of antelope that is spiritually important. Hunter-gatherer rock paintings such as this are understood to relate to a ritual practice named 'the great healing' or 'trance dance', which continues today in the Kalahari outside of South Africa. 

See this amazing piece in our special exhibition on #SouthAfricanArt, which tells a story stretching back 100,000 years http://ow.ly/JI7V303Bzlc 

The Zaamenkomst Panel. Detail of rock art depicting San|Bushmen running between eland. Made before 1900. On loan from Iziko Museums of South Africa, Social History Collections and SARADA. Photo: Neil Rusch.

French Neoclassical artist Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres was born #onthisday in 1780. Consciously conservative in his style, Ingres was inspired by painters from the past – chiefly Raphael and Poussin. Best known for his intimate portraits and classical scenes, the Museum's collection includes some of his sensitive drawings. http://ow.ly/ZPGR303splq

Listen to this brand new podcast to discover the story of how the British Museum evacuated 100 tonnes of objects in just 8 days ahead of the Second World War. They were relocated to stately homes, abandoned tube stations and purpose-built, climate-controlled bunkers.

German literary giant Johann Wolfgang von Goethe was born #onthisday in 1749. He turned his hand to poems, novels, dramas, memoirs and scientific texts. Goethe was one of the leading thinkers of the late 18th and early 19th centuries, and composers including Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert (among many others) set his poems to music. http://ow.ly/mwWI303fHvs 

Find out more about Goethe's importance to Germany in former Director Neil MacGregor's BBC podcast http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04k6rcd

Pre-Raphaelite artist Edward Burne-Jones was born #onthisday in 1833. A leader in art and design in the late 19th century, he produced paintings and drawings alongside stained glass, textiles and metalwork. His delicate dream-like compositions are shown in these works. http://ow.ly/57Lz303fCvE

These shell beads were made about 75,000 years ago and are among the world's earliest examples of jewellery. They are from Blombos Cave, South Africa, and are coloured with red ochre. Each one has a hole, and this, along with other evidence, suggests they were strung together and worn as a necklace. Ochre is earth or rock that has a high concentration of iron, and has been used for tens of thousands of years as an ingredient for paint. Other objects from Blombos Cave included engraved ochre, bone points, and paint-making kits. Together these objects represent some of the earliest artistic traditions in the world.

Discover this nation's fascinating history in our special exhibition on #SouthAfricanArt, opening 27 October http://ow.ly/toza303Bzge

Blombos Cave shell beads, on loan from Iziko Museums of South Africa, Social History Collections

Italian artist Titian died #onthisday in 1576. Leader of the 16th-century Venetian School, his long career spanned everything from prints to portraits. These elegant prints and drawings show his versatility in handling landscapes and people.  http://ow.ly/oy3x303faNT
Francisco de Zurbarán died #onthisday in 1664. The Spanish artist is best known for his religious subjects and his deft handling of light and shadow. http://ow.ly/qJ4S303fChW
It's #NationalDogDay! Here are some of the cute canines in the Museum http://ow.ly/Eu9V303BCtV

This penny of the Anglo-Saxon king Alfred the Great includes a monogram of London. Alfred the Great (r. AD 871–899) was king of Wessex, an Anglo-Saxon kingdom in the south of England. Although London was not part of this region, one of his coin types has a monogram of the name LVNDONIA. There are no definitive records of when Alfred took complete control of London. One theory suggests that he gained the city as part of a treaty following his victory in battle over the Vikings in 878. 

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! Explore the history of money in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/NV4s303uUNW

Frans Hals died #onthisday in 1666. The Dutch portrait painter is famed for his loose, flowing style that emphasised the movement and liveliness of the people he painted. This drawing shows his swift and purposeful lines, and subtle handling of tone. http://ow.ly/9u8C303f91W

Great Britain's first Prime Minister, Robert Walpole, was born #onthisday in 1676. Occupying the role for 20 years, he remains the longest-serving Prime Minister in British history. Known for his stabilising effect on politics, Walpole cemented the Whig hold on power in the early 18th century. He also accepted 10 Downing Street as the official home of the Prime Minister in 1732.

Equestrian painter George Stubbs was born #onthisday in 1724. His striking paintings drew heavily from his experience as an illustrator for anatomical textbooks – he is known for the accuracy of his works. http://ow.ly/clNH303A7Dj

Engineer James Watt died #onthisday in 1819. A prolific inventor, he is credited with developing the steam engine, which was widely used in the Industrial Revolution in Britain. He continued to refine his designs and partnered with manufacturer Matthew Boulton to become a driving force of industrialisation. The SI unit of power – the Watt – is named after him. http://ow.ly/XMjF303mzc8
Henri Fantin-Latour died #onthisday in 1904. The French artist was a prolific printmaker as well as a painter, and these are some of his sensitive, atmospheric prints http://ow.ly/Tavb303fLUw

Ready, steady, bake! With the new series of The Great British Bake Off starting tonight, take some inspiration from the ancient Egyptians! This model depicting the stages of bread-making is over 4,000 years old. The first stage was to grind the grain (barley or emmer) between a grinding stone and a saddle quern. The flour was then sieved to remove the larger impurities, and then made into dough before being shaped into loaves which were baked in circular ovens. 

Bread was the staple food of ancient Egypt. It was so important in everyday life that several hieroglyphic signs are of different types of loaf, and the symbol for 'offering' is a loaf of bread on a mat. This model was placed in the tomb of King Nebhepetre Mentuhotep II (r. 2055–2004 BC) to ensure that he would be provided with bread for eternity http://ow.ly/ThUv303x40N

The Museum began to evacuate objects #onthisday in 1939, due to the imminent threat posed by the Second World War. The order to remove the objects came a day before, and staff rushed to prepare items for transfer to safer places. Objects were stored in Aldwych Tube station – carefully lowered down the stairs as seen in this photo. Some of the collection also travelled to Aberystwyth quarry in Wales. Read more about the Museum during the Blitz. http://ow.ly/nG1t303hHA3

Plus, listen to a brand new podcast that tells the story of how the Museum pulled off 'the biggest, mass evacuation of objects in any museum's history' http://ow.ly/rynV303xTyB

The Ptolemies – the ancient Greeks who ruled Egypt for over 300 years – introduced Greek versions of Egyptian gods to encourage cultural integration and to be recognised as legitimate pharaohs. Greeks and Egyptians lived and worshipped side by side, acknowledging similarities and differences in their practices. After 30 BC, aspects of this Greco-Egyptian religion also spread across the Roman Empire.

Discover more about the deep connections between the ancient civilisations of Egypt and Greece in our #SunkenCities exhibition: http://ow.ly/1ZoL303vpZF
Can you guess what today's #MysteryObject was used for?

'Draw Antonio, draw Antonio, draw and don't waste time' – Michelangelo's comment on one of his student's drawings has survived nearly 500 years. Our curators believe the lesson is as relevant today and are encouraging art students to study and draw from works in the Museum's collection.

status_message: Richard III of England died #onthisday in 1485. The last ruler of the Plantagenet dynasty, he was killed at the Battle of Bosworth Field, the final battle of the War of the Roses. Richard's rise and fall was told by Shakespeare across his plays Henry VI Parts 2 & 3, and the eponymous Richard III. Richard's accession to the throne and the mysterious disappearance of the Princes in the Tower made him a divisive figure, and Shakespeare's version of events has sometimes been dismissed as Tudor propaganda. Richard reigned for only two years – he was defeated by the future Henry VII, first king of the Tudor dynasty. His resting place remained a mystery until 2012 when his remains were found underneath a car park in Leicester. http://ow.ly/a9WS303mypK

Boxing is an ancient sport, known to have been depicted before 1300 BC. The god Apollo is said to have won the first ever boxing match, beating Ares, the god of war, at Olympia. Here we can see one of the athletes has a bad nosebleed, but is carrying on regardless – ancient Greek boxers are often depicted with broken noses, showing the severity of their bouts. This pottery also shows their 'himantes', the wraps of leather around their hands. Unlike modern padded boxing gloves, these were solely used to protect the knuckles rather than to avoid cuts to an opponent. http://ow.ly/W6TV302SIAX

British illustrator Aubrey Beardsley was born #onthisday in 1872. His evocative style combined elements from Japanese prints and the decadence of Aestheticism. Beardsley's works focused on the grotesque, the glamorous and the erotic. He was close friends with Oscar Wilde and drew illustrations for Wilde's plays – notably 'Salome' which can be seen here. http://ow.ly/4Cah3033Osn

Leonidas of Rhodes was the most decorated ancient Olympian, and competed at four successive games. With 12 wins to his name, from the sprint to a race wearing armour (called the hoplitodromia), his record has only just been beaten, 2,000 years later
link_name: Who, What, Why: Who was Leonidas of Rhodes? - BBC News

This head from a colossal 4-metre-tall statue depicts the Greco-Egyptian god Serapis. The statue is thought to be from the Temple of Serapis, a huge sanctuary which once stood in the ancient Egyptian city of Canopus. People came from afar to sleep within the temple complex to be healed by miraculous cures that were delivered in a dream. The impressive remains of this sanctuary were recently discovered by underwater archaeologists. 

See this alongside other impressive new discoveries in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/4j9B303nVOC

Marble head of Serapis. Canopus, c. 200 BC. On loan from Maritime Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.
It's #WorldPhotoDay! The Museum has been photographed for well over a century. Share your snaps of the Museum with us!

Time is money! This Equitable Labour Exchange note is worth one hour of work. It was issued in the 1830s by social reformer Robert Owen, and meant that the value of goods was tied to how long an item took to produce. Workers could sell their products in exchange for these notes which would then be accepted as a form of currency. The system aimed to reward workers fairly for their work, instead of just profiting from their labour. The experiment ended in 1834 after disputes over the value of products and the time taken to make them. 

Our free #MoneyMatters display explores how currency affects our daily lives http://ow.ly/RtgG3038RVe

link_name: Celebrating Chuseok: the Korean Harvest Moon Festival

status_message:
In the ancient Olympic Games, the long jump was very different to today. Athletes at Olympia are often represented using jumping weights called 'halteres' to propel themselves forwards. Some historians, however, think that the weights were used to make the event even harder. These ones weigh over 1kg each!

It is thought that the long jump had a much-reduced run-up compared to the modern event, and may have been made up of multiple leaps more like the triple jump we know today. Some distances have survived which might support this point – in around 480 BC the noted athlete Phaullos from Croton jumped 16.3m! An incredible feat considering the triple jump record is now 18.29m. http://ow.ly/XHES302QkHC

T E Lawrence, popularly known as Lawrence of Arabia, was born #onthisday in 1888. Prominent during the First World War and the years after, he was an author, archaeologist, military officer and diplomat. Lawrence's works include 'Seven Pillars of Wisdom', an account of his time working during the Arab Revolt, and 'The Mint', the story of his time in the RAF after he retracted from public life in 1922 and assumed a different name.
What do you think today's #MysteryObject was used for? Let us know your guesses!

'The King', Elvis Presley, died #onthisday in 1977. A pop culture icon for over 20 years, Elvis is loved across the world, and is still the top-selling solo artist of all time. The Museum has several prints by David Oxtoby showing him at different points in his career. http://ow.ly/5RzB303aKWg

Wrestling was an extremely popular event at the ancient Greek Games. Like today, there were two types – upright wrestling and ground wrestling. Upright wrestling was far more structured and formal, with three falls being necessary to win – a fall was given when an opponent's back, shoulders or hip touched the ground. Ground wrestling was brutal, with virtually no rules apart from 'no gouging or biting' – a win was only given when an opponent acknowledged defeat by raising his index finger, as seen here. Ground wrestling became part of the 'pankration' ('all of might') – a competition so violent an athlete called Sarapion of Alexandria ran away the day before he was due to compete for fear of his opponents. http://ow.ly/6uyX30320Oc

Emperor of the French Napoleon Bonaparte was born #onthisday in 1769. One of the most important figures in the 19th century, Napoleon rose to prominence during the French Revolution and became emperor in 1804. His time of eminence in Europe came to an end in 1815 when he was exiled by the British to the island of St Helena in the Atlantic Ocean.

'He stood for centuries at the very edge of ancient Egypt, gazing down imperiously upon the trading ships as they blew in from the Mediterranean. His name was Hapy: god of fertility, lord of the river, life-giving steward of its floods… And now, more than a millennium after it was first submerged, Hapy's city is returning to the surface once again.'

Discover how the lost city of Thonis-Heracleion was found after a thousand years underwater in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/1hO6303eUOV
link_name: Lost cities #6: how Thonis-Heracleion resurfaced after 1,000 years under water

status_message: Pioneer of Pointillism Paul Signac died #onthisday in 1935. The French artist is known for developing the spotted style that came out of the Neo-Impressionist movement. Famous primarily for his landscapes, the Museum also has one of his still-life drawings, as seen here. His hazy, luminous, works experimented with colour and the application of paint onto the canvas or page.   http://ow.ly/D0hm303aGxr

The sprint was a favourite event in the ancient Games, featuring heavily in Greek art and decorated pottery. One of these amphoras (storage vessels) shows a sprinter in full flight, dashing towards the finish line. While the running style has remained the same over the centuries, the starting position would have been very different for ancient Greek runners. The second amphora depicts the start of a race. The man stands with his arms extended forwards, and his toes gripped in the grooves that provided traction http://ow.ly/XPDX303aOq8

This imposing seated marble dog is probably a guard dog, with powerful jaws and a muscular body. It is a Roman marble copy of an ancient Greek bronze statue, and was made around the 2nd century AD.

Explore highlight objects like this from all angles and print them in 3D on Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/britishmuseum

status_message: Although women were not allowed to compete in the ancient Greek Olympics, they did compete at Olympia in the Heraean Games. This competition was named after Hera, the goddess for women, and the only event was a 160-metre running race. Spartan women were particularly strong competitors, and this 2,500-year-old bronze statue is a rare depiction of a Spartan girl running http://ow.ly/oF1M302NJNy

African rock art paintings, which can be tens of thousands of years old, are very susceptible to fading. Curator Elizabeth Galvin and her team are currently working with digital photographs and photo-manipulation software to help uncover the past.

Learn more about our #AfricanRockArt project as they catalogue 25,000 images from across Africa britishmuseum.org/africanrockart

status_message: The Yongle emperor died #onthisday in 1424. His name means 'perpetual happiness'. He was the third emperor of the Ming dynasty of China, reigning from 1402 until his death. The incredible Porcelain Tower was built during his reign between 1412 and 1419, and was one of the tallest buildings in China at the time. It formed part of a temple that was built as a memorial to the emperor's dead parents. The tower was so magnificent it was described as one of the seven wonders of the medieval world, and was covered in striking white, green, yellow and brown porcelain tiles. The Museum has prints of what the tower looked like before it was destroyed in around 1854, and some of the huge glazed porcelain tiles that once lined the structure.

The discus is famed for being an ancient Olympic throwing discipline. The event features heavily on pottery commemorating the Games, and statues were also made depicting the throw. The discobolus statue is perhaps the most well-known discus thrower of ancient times – the Museum's discobolus statue, formerly known as the Townley discobolus, is actually a Roman copy of a now-lost bronze Greek original. The statue highlights the ancient technique of a three-quarter turn rather than the full rotations we see today. Greek discuses were on average slightly heavier (+0.5kg) than the modern 2kg discs, which together with the shorter turn, could account for the record being significantly shorter than today. The talented athlete Phaullos of Croton threw a record 30 metres, while the world record now stands at well over 70 metres!
http://ow.ly/vOOA302NPU3
The discobolus poster from our 1984 exhibition about the ancient Olympics is available to buy here: http://ow.ly/fCNc302SlcE

Brilliant British poet, painter and printmaker William Blake died #onthisday in 1827. Known for his sensitive and expressive artworks and poems, Blake's unconventional views made him an intriguing figure. His uniquely decorated poems from the 1780s and 90s form an important part of the Museum's prints and drawings collection. These used a new technique called 'illuminated printing' or 'relief etching' that allowed for image and text to appear together, much like 'illuminated' gilded manuscripts produced by monasteries in the Middle Ages. http://ow.ly/QpsH302SOde

It's your last chance to see our #SicilyExhibition, which closes this weekend! Tickets are now available for Saturday evening: http://ow.ly/GLUx3038I8B

You can also explore some of the incredible objects and themes of the exhibition on Google Art Project http://ow.ly/edGJ302SrbJ
