status_message:
The ancient Egyptians believed that the gods travelled through the night sky by boat. This chest ornament, or pectoral, discovered in the grave of a pharaoh shows a barque (a type of ancient Egyptian boat) carrying the sun god, Amun-Ra, sailing under a star-filled sky. This divine journey was evoked during festivals by the procession of boats carrying statues. A ritual boat and models of sacred barques are among the most important finds discovered in the lost city of Thonis-Heracleion. 

Discover more stories of ancient Egyptian myth and belief in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/YotR303754x

Gold pectoral. Tanis, Egypt, 943–922 BC. Egyptian Museum, Cairo. Photo: Christoph Gerigk © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

The Musée du Louvre opened #onthisday in 1793! The Parisian museum features in many prints and drawings, with the galleries attracting lots of painters and sketchers over the years. In these four images we can see the galleries looking very different.
For #WorldLionDay, we've assembled a pride of magnificent lions from the Museum's collection! http://ow.ly/5yT8302J0fC

One of the hardest events at the ancient Olympic Games must have been the 'hoplitodromia'. In this race competitors wore military armour that weighed over 22kg! The name comes from 'hoplite' – a heavily armed foot-soldier. The runners had to wear a helmet and greaves (lower leg armour), and carry a large round shield, as shown on this pottery. This was likely a funny race to watch – collisions and mishaps would have happened frequently. On the pottery you can see athletes stopping to pick up their shields, or people falling over having tripped up over their armour. However, the race also had a serious side. It was the last event at the Games, and this type of athletic training would have had a real-world benefit for soldiers in battle. The Greeks believed the more difficult the task, the greater the glory, so this event was highly prized.

Read more about the ancient Olympic Games in our great range of books: http://ow.ly/85C8302SjNh
Do you know what this #MysteryObject is? Reply with your guesses! (Hint: it's 28cm long)

The Roman emperor Trajan died #onthisday AD 117. He ruled Rome between AD 98 and 117 and was the first emperor born in Spain. He oversaw the empire when it was at its largest. Trajan's positive reputation has endured to this day, and he is regarded as a wise and fair emperor who enjoyed success both militarily and domestically – the second of the 'five good emperors'. This marble bust depicts him in a Greek style, with his head turned and the top of his chest visible. It was made to commemorate his tenth year as Roman leader. http://ow.ly/JnzS302JpDF

The Museum's first official photographer, Roger Fenton, died #onthisday in 1869. A pioneer of early photography, Fenton was also Britain's first war photographer, famed for his images of the Crimean War (1853–1856). He took a series of photos of the Museum in 1857 shown here – which of these objects and galleries do you recognise?

'One of Africa's greatest treasures' will be coming to the Museum this autumn to feature in our #SouthAfricanArt exhibition. The 800-year-old rhino is one of a number of iconic gold objects found in royal graves at the site of Mapungubwe, capital of the first southern African kingdom. Many of these significant loans are coming to the UK for the first time and will be transported by our exhibition logistics partner IAG Cargo.

South Africa: the art of a nation opens on 27 October – book now! http://ow.ly/d3rY3031L7l
link_name: South Africa's golden rhino to star in British Museum exhibition

status_message: Did you know that the British Museum used to have cats? One particularly special one was called Mike, and he lived at the Museum from 1909 to 1929, helping to guard the front gate. Mike became a bit of a celebrity and when he died his obituary appeared in the London Evening Standard and TIME Magazine! #InternationalCatDay

It's #InternationalCatDay so we've found some feline friends from around the Museum http://ow.ly/qz4f302Jkmd 

Know someone who worships cats like an ancient Egyptian? Find them something special in our online shop http://ow.ly/sPfK302Sknc

'Entrancing... the romance of Rome in ruin' ★★★★★ The Guardian http://ow.ly/XlWIF

It's your last chance to see our free exhibition of Francis Towne's atmospheric watercolours of Rome from 1780–1781. These works depict major Roman landmarks such as the Colosseum and the Forum, and it is the first time they have been displayed together since 1805. Catch it before it closes on 14 August http://ow.ly/fMV6302J5e6

Constantius II was born #onthisday in AD 317. He was Roman emperor from AD 337 to 361 and was the son of Constantine the Great. Here are two coins from his reign that depict him. One was official Roman currency, and the other an Aksumite forgery that was found in what is now modern-day Ethiopia. Can you identify the fake? Let us know your answers!

Discover the impressive 9-metre-long textile Vrindavani Vastra (cloth of Vrindavan) in our free exhibition 'Krishna in the garden of Assam', closing 15 August. Learn more about this intriguing period of Indian history: http://ow.ly/JzHS302GM5i

#onthisday in 1660, Spanish painter Diego Velázquez died. The Museum's collection contains some of the very few drawings attributed to Velázquez. It is believed that he worked little from preliminary drawings, and instead altered his compositions on canvas, distancing himself from the methods of older generations. This fluidity in working is reflected in his very individual painting style – his work served as an inspiration for realist and impressionist painters over 200 years later. These drawings show that Velázquez was obviously a talented and sensitive draughtsman, and the later print (by Francesco Cecchini) shows a representation of Velázquez himself. Read more about his drawings here: http://ow.ly/SHdJ302EFTE
With the opening of #Rio2016, the first Olympic Games in South America, explore the diverse regions and history of Brazil: http://ow.ly/Hapz302XsjH

Watch how a fragile 12th-century textile that belonged to a Sicilian king was carefully conserved for our #SicilyExhibition. 

Learn more about the history of this remarkable island in our special exhibition, closing Sunday 14 August http://ow.ly/OffP302XpDl

King Henry I of England was crowned #onthisday in 1100. He was known as 'Beauclerc' which translates as 'fine scholar', as he was an effective ruler and administrator. During his reign he revised Anglo-Saxon systems of law and justice, as well as tax and revenue. These coins are a silver penny showing Henry's likeness, and a rare halfpenny from the middle of Henry's reign. Halfpennies were rare during this time as previously people would simply cut pennies up into pieces for use as smaller denominations. http://ow.ly/a8ns302ECbC

Enjoy the flavours of Greece and Egypt with a #SunkenCities set menu in our Great Court Restaurant. From lamb kofta to aubergine moussaka, dukkah spiced lemon sole and the Museum's own take on Umm Ali, enhance your exhibition experience with delicious dishes inspired by the fusion of Mediterranean cultures. Find out more: http://ow.ly/xXBl302V21x

British Museum Curator Jago Cooper explores the extraordinary culture of the American Northwest in a new BBC Four documentary. 1,400 miles of rugged, windswept and rocky coastline in what is now the Alaskan panhandle, British Columbia and Washington state have been home to hundreds of distinct communities for over 10,000 years. Theirs is the longest continuing culture to be found anywhere in the Americas. They mastered a tough environment to create unique and complex communities that have redefined how human societies develop. 

Catch up on the #AmericanNWCoast programme on iPlayer and tune into the second episode tonight at 21.00: http://ow.ly/QYZP302sH83
link_name: Masters of the Pacific Coast: The Tribes of the American Northwest - BBC Four

status_message:
Animal worship was a key part of ancient Egyptian religion, and was most popular between around 700 BC and AD 400. Some animals were worshipped as living creatures embodying specific gods, while others were buried with their owners and some were dedicated as offerings at shrines. More than 30 animal cemeteries have so far been found in Egypt, some containing millions of animal mummies, from cats and ibises to baboons and crocodiles. Many animal mummies were buried in religious complexes, including those recently discovered underwater at the ancient Egyptian city of Thonis-Heracleion. 

Explore these amazing discoveries in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/M5lv302SXsJ

Joseph Paxton was born #onthisday in 1803. Best known for designing the magnificent Crystal Palace, built for the Great Exhibition of 1851, he was also a landscape gardener and an MP. While he was head gardener at Chatsworth House, Paxton helped develop the Cavendish banana, the most widely consumed banana in the world! The scale of the Crystal Palace can be appreciated in this watercolour – it was a marvel of modern engineering at the time and must have been breathtaking. The palace was later moved from Hyde Park to Sydenham Hill in South London. It was destroyed by fire in 1936 but the area retains the name of Crystal Palace. http://ow.ly/JMB7302EcIn
Can you guess what today's #MysteryObject would have been used for?

French sculptor Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi was born #onthisday in 1834. Best known for designing the iconic Statue of Liberty in New York, Bartholdi wanted his work to best express the American spirit of freedom. The statue was to represent a link between France and the USA, and the fraternal feeling between the two republics. It was built by famous French engineer, Gustave Eiffel. http://ow.ly/mdNl302GTYM

The Roman emperor Claudius was born #onthisday in 10 BC. An interesting leader, he was the first emperor to be born outside of Italy, and during his reign the empire grew significantly. His reign has been of interest for generations and has been the subject of many books and films due to contentions around his personality and his family ties. This cameo (an oval profile portrait) was made between AD 41 and 49, and shows Claudius in military dress. It is made from sardonyx, a highly prized stone. http://ow.ly/rfX3302GUhm

The 'new' London Bridge was officially opened by King William IV and Queen Adelaide #onthisday in 1831. This new bridge was made of granite from Haytor in Devon, southwest England, and replaced the medieval bridge that was built over 600 years previously. This print by H Matthews shows the opening ceremony, complete with the Grand Pavilion where the royal family celebrated the occasion. 136 years later the bridge was sold to an American businessman and rebuilt in Arizona! It was replaced by the modern London Bridge in 1973.   http://ow.ly/uVpZ302Nj2u

The 2,000-year-old body of 'Lindow Man' was found preserved in a bog in the northwest of England #onthisday in 1984. The conditions in the bog were perfect for preserving his body – cold, acidic and lacking in oxygen. Radiocarbon dating revealed that Lindow Man died between 2 BC and AD 119, and was about 25 years old. He is so well preserved that we can tell he had filed fingernails and a trimmed beard, and ate unleavened bread before he died. http://ow.ly/YDd5302Cxt6

#August is named after the Roman emperor Augustus. Before 8 BC the Romans called it Sextilis – the sixth month. This bronze head of Augustus was originally part of an over lifesize statue erected in AD 27 in southern Egypt, then part of the Roman empire. In near-perfect condition, the head was buried as a trophy in front of a small temple at the Kushite capital at Meroe, Sudan. http://ow.ly/V6gR302EMdM

Two lost cities of ancient Egypt lay submerged under the sea for over a thousand years. They were recently rediscovered by underwater archaeologists. This summer, dive in to our #SunkenCities exhibition – under 16s go free to the exhibition and families can uncover the stories behind these incredible objects with storytelling and a special trail! http://ow.ly/L51A302IVo1

Giorgio Vasari was born #onthisday in 1511. Of major importance to the Italian Renaissance, his work spanned art, architecture, and writing. Vasari worked on the painted dome in Florence Cathedral, and began the design for the Uffizi Gallery buildings. Here are some of his elegant drawings from the collection. http://ow.ly/AvRh302svLa

Henry Moore was born #onthisday in 1898. While he is mostly associated with his large abstract sculptures, the Museum's collection holds interesting examples from his wartime sketchbooks. These drawings document Londoners during the Blitz. He used pencil, ink, watercolour and wax crayon to portray the scenes of destruction and the huddled masses sheltering underground. http://ow.ly/MALo302svJP

The first coins in China do not resemble our modern idea of coins at all. Instead they take the form of everyday objects which have been cast in bronze. Created in the late 7th century BC, these coins are in the shape of common, agricultural implements bearing inscriptions that refer to a geographical area, group or weight. The earliest spade money was issued by the royal house of Zhou, known as 'The Middle Kingdom'. Within 300 years, most of the neighbouring states were also issuing spade money.

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! Discover more about the history of money in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/g1fP301tlHV

From ancient Egypt and Aztec masks to digital music and coding, kids can bring the world's history and cultures to life in our #SamsungCentre with free digital workshops every weekend this summer! http://ow.ly/tsRN302szbq
It's #InternationalTigerDay! We found these big cats prowling through the collection http://ow.ly/4jrW302svDa

Vincent van Gogh died #onthisday in 1890. This 1883 print is made from one of his early drawings. Van Gogh was sketching in the grounds of a home for the elderly and used the residents as models, trying to depict their character and the outdoor work they carried out. http://ow.ly/oKeg302svBB

Beatrix Potter was born #onthisday 150 years ago. Her short stories and illustrations continue to prove as popular as ever thanks to the enduring charm of Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny. Initially written and illustrated in 1900, 'The Tale of Peter Rabbit' was created for children of her friends, and drew on her childhood holidays to the Lake District. It was then published nationally and was an instant hit, selling over 50,000 copies in the first year.
The full set of original 1909 watercolours for 'The Tale of the Flopsy Bunnies' is in the Museum's collection, and we've picked out some of our favourites here.

Do you have a favourite Beatrix Potter tale?

Browse our #BeatrixPotter shop range, including 'The Tale of Peter Rabbit' in hieroglyphs! http://ow.ly/5hej302Gu94

Don't miss a new BBC Four programme tonight with British Museum Curator Jago Cooper. Jago explores the extraordinary and resilient culture of the American Northwest, revealing one the most inspiring stories in human history http://ow.ly/QYZP302sH83

Our #AfricanRockArt project is now in its fourth year, and the team has so far uploaded more than 19,000 digital photographs of rock art to the Museum's online collection database! 

You can now explore new images from Malawi, Angola and Tanzania: http://britishmuseum.org/africanrockart

Are you playing #PokemonGO? Come and discover the PokéStops in the Museum – all trainers welcome! From colossal statues of Egyptian pharaohs to an Aztec mask and contemporary African art, find out more about the objects you'll encounter at each of the PokéStop locations in the Museum: http://ow.ly/MLQX302Ey7m

Remember to be alert and watch out for people and objects near you. Stay safe and catch 'em all! Share your #PokemonGO catches with us on Twitter https://twitter.com/britishmuseum

Irish playwright George Bernard Shaw was born #onthisday in 1856. He wrote over 60 plays and is regarded as one of the most important playwrights in the English language. Here are some portraits and caricatures of him http://ow.ly/25mG302uQ7T

Join our live tour of the Sutton Hoo gallery! We have the Museum to ourselves as Curator Sue Brunning explores the incredible Anglo-Saxon treasures that were discovered at Sutton Hoo, in the east of England, in 1939.

Join our Facebook Live broadcast at 18.00 (BST) to explore the amazing Sutton Hoo gallery after hours! Curator Sue Brunning will answer your questions and share some of the treasures from the famous Anglo-Saxon ship burial
What do you think this #MysteryObject is? Reply with your guesses!

The stunning Sutton Hoo ship burial was unearthed #onthisday in 1939, one of the most significant archaeological discoveries ever made in the UK. Discovered in the east of England, the site was probably the burial of an Anglo-Saxon king and contained fantastically crafted metalwork and jewellery. 

The iconic helmet is particularly intriguing. Aside from being elaborately decorated, there are hidden motifs that might not be obvious at first. A bird or dragon is created, flying upwards, by the central gilding. The moustache forms the tail, the nose becomes the body and the eyebrows the wings, with a head just above. http://ow.ly/U2iI302sRGz

Join us LIVE on Facebook today from 18.00 (BST) to explore the Sutton Hoo gallery after-hours!

Join Curator Jago Cooper as he explores cave art recently discovered in the Caribbean. This research project has revealed remarkable evidence of encounters between the first generations of Europeans to arrive in the Americas and indigenous peoples.
link_name: New discoveries by El Corazon del Caribe Research Project

status_message: Constantine the Great was proclaimed Roman emperor #onthisday in AD 306. This elaborate coin pendant from AD 321 would have formed part of a necklace, together with other pendants. In the centre is a double solidus (a double-sided gold coin) of Constantine, surrounded by a highly decorated sheet of gold and characterful busts. http://ow.ly/85xq302sv8K

What is #AfricanRockArt? Find out from Elizabeth Galvin, Curator of the African rock art image project at the British Museum. Elizabeth and her team are currently cataloguing and uploading 25,000 digital images of rock art from across Africa. This collection represents some of the first purely digital objects to be registered in the Museum's collection http://africanrockart.britishmuseum.org/

Czech artist Alphonse Mucha was born #onthisday in 1860. He is best known for his Art Nouveau designs, producing many paintings, illustrations, advertisements and postcards. These two prints are from a group of 100 plates published in a series called 'L'Estampe moderne'. Many accomplished European Art Nouveau artists contributed works to this publication, which was published in 24 monthly parts over two years.

A chance discovery by metal detectorists in Ipplepen, Devon in 2010 has led to the redrawing of the Roman empire boundary in south-west Britain. Since 2010, the University of Exeter, the The Portable Antiquities Scheme and Devon County Council have embarked upon a programme of survey and excavation to explore this significant site further.
link_name: Discovery of Roman coins in Devon redraws map of empire

status_message: Don't miss our free #SicilyExhibition late event tonight with wine tasting, mosaic workshops and more!

Discover the story of the ancient Egyptian city of Naukratis in our new #SunkenCities spotlight tour at Nottingham Lakeside Arts http://ow.ly/o6L2302cpvO 

In the 7th century BC, Egypt founded a Mediterranean port at Naukratis, welcoming the peoples of the Mediterranean to trade. The Greeks were allowed to build sanctuaries there in which to worship their gods, while large Egyptian temples were also constructed nearby. This spotlight tour explores the fascinating story of these early encounters.

Realist artist Edward Hopper was born #onthisday in 1882. Hopper first learnt the technique of etching in 1915 while working as a freelance commercial artist. He produced nearly 70 etchings over the next eight years, before focusing on painting.

In this etching titled 'Night on the El Train', Hopper depicts a couple on a train late at night and places us across the aisle as an observer. The movement of the train is indicated by the billowing blinds and swaying straps http://ow.ly/1bb6302co6D

Each year we welcome nearly 7 million visitors from around the world through these doors! #LondonIsOpen 

The Museum has been free to enter for 'studious and curious persons' since 1759 and we remain open to all.

'Archaeologists exploring a remote Caribbean island near Puerto Rico have returned with photos capturing never-before-seen cave drawings ― ones said to reveal a previously untold relationship between the indigenous people and European explorers.'

A project led by archaeologists from the British Museum and the University of Leicester has discovered remarkable evidence of encounters between the first generations of Europeans to arrive in the Americas and indigenous peoples.
link_name: Cave Drawings Suggest Early Harmonious Contact Between Islanders And Europeans: Archaeologists

status_message: Artist Emil Orlik was born #onthisday in 1870 in Prague, which was at this time part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. In order to study the techniques of woodblock printmaking, Orlik embarked on a two-month sea voyage, arriving in Japan in April 1900. He spent around 10 months in Japan, where he visited ukiyo-e block carvers and printers and executed a large numbers of prints in a Japanese style.

For #InternationalChessDay, here are some of the Lewis Chessmen! These figures are part of a hoard found in a sand dune at Uig Bay on the Isle of Lewis in Scotland. It's thought that they might have belonged to a trader who was travelling from Norway to Ireland to sell them, sometime between AD 1150 and 1200. Around this time, chess was a very popular game among the aristocracy in Europe. 

The chessmen are strongly influenced by Norse culture. This is most evident in the figures of the warders or rooks which take the form of 'berserkers', fierce mythical warriors. Which is your favourite? http://ow.ly/wV393029U3M

Explore the lovely Lewis Chessmen range in our online shop! http://ow.ly/ETii302qbZ0

Alexander the Great was born #onthisday in 356 BC. By the time of his death at the age of 32, he ruled an empire from Greece to Afghanistan. 

In this portrait Alexander is depicted as youthful and god-like: he has long hair and an upward gaze, resembling his description in literary sources. He was always shown clean-shaven, which was an innovation – all previous portraits of Greek statesmen or rulers had beards. This royal fashion lasted for almost 500 years, until the reign of the Roman emperor Hadrian.

This portrait is from Alexandria, the city founded by Alexander in 331 BC. Find out more about Alexander's lasting impact in Egypt in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/BjJU302qa6T

In ancient Egypt, the New Year festival started on 19 July and lasted 14 days. This popular event was celebrated across all Egypt to welcome the arrival of the Nile flood and the fertility it brought. Gifts were offered during this festival, such as elegant vases known as New Year's flasks. These festivities were part of ancient Egypt's Inundation season (called Akhet in the ancient Egyptian language), which took place over a four-month period from mid-July to mid-November. 

Learn more about ancient Egyptian festivals in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/QdpM302oQSP

This mezzotint by artist John Martin, born #onthisday in 1789, depicts the fall of Babylon – a historical event recorded in the Bible. In 539 BC, Cyrus the Great invaded Babylonia, defeating the Neo-Babylonian king Nabonidus. Babylonia became a colony of Achaemenid Persia. 

Martin first interpreted the biblical scene of the destruction of Babylon in a huge painting exhibited in 1819. He was keen to make prints after his paintings, as a 'means which would enable the public to see my productions, and give me a chance of being remunerated for my labours'. http://ow.ly/WtrA3027xy0
What do you think this #MysteryObject was used for?

Edgar Degas was born #onthisday in 1834. Throughout his career Degas depicted many scenes from the ballet. He began studying dancers in the 1870s and, along with female nudes, these become a principal motif in his work. Degas frequently visited the backstage areas of the Opéra building in Paris where the ballet was performed. 

However, he rarely made his studies there, preferring instead to draw in his studio from posed models or memory. Through his studies, pastels, paintings and sculptures, he created a detailed picture of both the glamour of the performance and the reality of the dancers' backstage life.

The serpent played an important role in religion of the Mexica – the people often referred to as Aztecs. Many superb stone sculptures have survived, the majority of them representing rattlesnakes carved with striking realism and great skill. This magnificent sculpture has a blend of both realistic and mythical creatures. It exhibits all the elements characteristic of Xiuhcoatl, the Fire Serpent, with the head of a serpent, short legs finishing in claws and a curved snout. The end of the figure's tail is formed by the conventional Mexican year symbol (xihuitl): a triangle, like the solar ray sign, and two entwined trapezes. This piece was probably used to decorate a building.

Explore highlight objects like this figure of a fire serpent from all angles and print them in 3D on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/RuiL302mgsg
Join us this Friday for a night of Sicilian splendour, inspired by our #SicilyExhibition. Enjoy Sicilian food and drink, wine tasting, flower mosaic workshops and much more!
It's #WorldEmojiDay! If you could create an emoji of a Museum object, what would it be? 🏛 🌊 🗿

Artist and first President of Royal Academy of Arts Sir Joshua Reynolds was born #onthisday in 1723. Reynolds was the leading English portraitist of the 18th century. Celebrated for capturing important figures of his day, he also helped establish a distinctive British school of painting http://ow.ly/PEnV3

For over a thousand years two cities of ancient Egypt lay lost under the sea. They were recently rediscovered by underwater archaeologists. This summer, dive in to reveal the stories behind the objects found below the waves!

Plus, enjoy storytelling for families on dates throughout July and August. Find out more http://ow.ly/lyga302i1hy

Stela commissioned by Nectanebo I (r. 380–362 BC), Thonis-Heracleion, Egypt, 380 BC. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Rembrandt was born #onthisday in 1606. Here's a 17th-century selfie from the Old Master!

In this self-portrait, Rembrandt depicts himself fictionally, in the nostalgic clothing of his Renaissance heroes – Raphael and Titian as well as northern European artists such as Albrecht Dürer and Lucas van Leyden http://ow.ly/oaT43021qyW

The Rosetta Stone was discovered #onthisday in 1799 – key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs!

The same inscription is written in three different scripts: Greek, hieroglyphs and demotic Egyptian. 1,400 years after hieroglyphs had gone out of use, scholars were able to use the Greek inscription on this stone as the key to decipher them. The inscription is a decree that affirms the royal cult of the 13-year-old Ptolemy V on the first anniversary of his coronation in 196 BC.

Learn more about this object and the decipherment of hieroglyphs: http://ow.ly/Dbxs3021DmD

This badge depicting Thomas Becket was one of the many different badges sold to pilgrims at Canterbury Cathedral. Of all the known pilgrimage sites, the badges sold at Canterbury display a wide variety of imagery, corresponding to the various holy places that pilgrims could visit within the cathedral complex. St Thomas Becket's skull was kept in a lavishly decorated reliquary and was a highlight for pilgrims to see. 

Pilgrims' badges were a symbol of the relationship between the saint and the pilgrim who had undertaken the journey to the relic and were conventionally worn on the individual's hat or bag. 

Explore a range of incredible medieval pilgrim badges in 3D on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/cQtK3022T6f
Joyeux #quatorzejuillet to all in France! This 1790 etching by Charles Thévenin depicts the storming of the Bastille http://ow.ly/z7hNX #BastilleDay

Curator Richard Blurton reveals the stories woven into this rare 9-metre textile. Known as the Vrindavani Vastra, it is richly woven with images and texts telling stories of the Hindu god Krishna http://ow.ly/P4WY3023gcv
link_name: Krishna in the garden of Assam: the cultural context of an Ind...

status_message: Artist Wenceslaus Hollar was born #onthisday in 1607. His works are a rich source of information about the 17th century. This is his 'Long View of London', an etching made in 1647 http://ow.ly/ULgK3021nWz

Elizabethan mathematician, astrologer and magician Dr Dee was born #onthisday in 1527. These are some of the magical objects he collected and used http://ow.ly/8siS3021po1

This mirror, made of highly polished obsidian (volcanic glass), was used by Dee as a tool for his occult research. The two smaller wax discs supported the legs of Dee's 'table of practice', and the gold disc is engraved with the Vision of Four Castles, experienced during one of Dee's 'experiments' at Krakow in 1584.

Roman general and statesman Julius Caesar is thought to have been born #onthisday in 100 BC. Caesar became embroiled in the civil strife that accompanied the disintegration of the Roman Republic. In 48 BC he crossed the River Rubicon, took Rome and effectively became the first citizen. His presumed desire to abandon the Republic as a form of government and return to monarchy led to his assassination. Caesar was assassinated in the Roman Senate on the Ides of March (15 March) 44 BC by a group of conspirators http://ow.ly/5kc63021dRc
Can you guess what today's #MysteryObject was used for?

Potter Josiah Wedgwood was born #onthisday in 1730. This beautiful vase, known as the Pegasus Vase, is one of his masterpieces. 

The vase and the relief decoration, handles and Pegasus are made of jasper, a type of unglazed stoneware that can be stained with colour before firing. The decoration of the vase was modelled for Wedgwood by the artist John Flaxman junior. Flaxman adapted a variety of classical sources; the figures in the main scene are based on an engraving of a Greek vase of the 4th century BC, while the Medusa heads at the base of the handles are taken from an engraving of an antique sandal. http://ow.ly/kNA83021dpw

This magical stela is a favourite object of #SunkenCities Curator Daniela Rosenow. Made over 2,000 years ago, this stela inscribed with magical spells was thought to have healing properties and was used to protect people from dangerous animals. Water was poured over the stela to charge it with magic and then collected in the basin to be drunk. Learn more about this fascinating object: http://ow.ly/xYGa3028bT4

Magical stela of Horus. Tell el-Qalah, Egypt, 30th Dynasty, 380–342 BC. Egyptian Museum, Cairo. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Italian artist Giuseppe Arcimboldo died #onthisday in 1593. He served as court painter for the Habsburg rulers in Vienna and Prague for 25 years, creating portraits of the imperial family. However, Arcimboldo is best known today for the highly original portraits he created made entirely of objects such as plants, animals, books, fish and flowers.

This etching takes inspiration from one of Arcimboldo's works and depicts two heads facing each other made from flowers and fruit, representing the seasons spring and summer http://ow.ly/PqlQk

American artist James McNeill Whistler was born #onthisday in 1834. Based primarily in the UK, Whistler was known for his works of London at night, for his striking full-length portraits, and for his etchings and lithographs. These etchings all come from his Thames series, depicting different areas along the river http://ow.ly/yZeOm

The Roman emperor Hadrian died #onthisday in AD 138. Hadrian was a champion of Egyptian and Greek culture and visited Egypt in AD 130. During this visit, his Greek lover Antinous drowned in the Nile. Hadrian later founded a new city, Antinoopolis, at the site of his death. Antinous was venerated as the god Osiris-Antinous and this new saviour god became popular across the empire http://ow.ly/2dhA3023RbO

Learn more about the deep connections between the great ancient civilisations of Egypt and Greece in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/bbtv3023SvL

'It is only by drawing often, drawing everything, drawing incessantly, that one fine day you discover to your surprise that you have rendered something in its true character.'

French Impressionist artist Camille Pissarro was born #onthisday in 1830. He was the only artist to show his work at all eight Impressionist exhibitions in Paris. While the Impressionists are known for their depictions of city streets and country leisure, Pissarro covered his canvases with images of the day-to-day life of French peasants. Here are some of his beautiful works:

This carillon clock made in 1589 was never intended to simply tell the time. It was a performance piece, a 'Rolls-Royce level of clocks'. Made in Strasbourg, it is designed to imitate the great clock in Strasbourg Cathedral and is one of the most important surviving examples of Renaissance clockwork. Hear from Curator Oliver Cooke and former Curator David Thompson as they explain the mechanics behind this incredible object.

Take a look at some of the not-so-famous people who've been unfairly consigned to the dustbin of history in one of our #BMComedy nights. Comedians and Museum curators highlight their unsung historical heroes on 18, 21 & 28 July http://ow.ly/4AC33023vZF

Under the Norman kings of Sicily, the island became an influential Mediterranean superpower. The coexistence of western, Islamic and Byzantine cultures on Sicily created a multilingual state. Discover the story of a tombstone written in four languages in this video.

Learn more about this cultural centre of the ancient and medieval world in our #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/MBQo30231Yj

A tombstone in four languages. Sicily, AD 1149. Soprintendenza Beni Culturali e Ambientali di Palermo. © Regione Siciliana.

'The symphony must be like the world. It must embrace everything.'

Austrian composer and conductor Gustav Mahler was born #onthisday in 1860. He served as director of the Vienna Court Opera from 1897 to 1907 and later led the New York Metropolitan Opera and Philharmonic Orchestra. Having been banned under the Nazis (as his family was Jewish), Mahler's music was rediscovered after 1945 and is now enormously popular. This portrait of Mahler from 1902 is by artist Emil Orlik http://ow.ly/jVfx301TFV2

Watch the incredible discovery of this colossal statue, submerged under the sea for thousands of years.

Many of the greatest stories and legends from Homer's Odyssey were based around Sicily. From the mythical sea monsters of Scylla and Charybdis to the cyclops Polyphemus, discover how Sicily's fertile landscape and wild coastline inspired many of these stories.

Learn more about the ancient Greeks who settled on this remarkable island in our #SicilyExhibition, until 14 August http://ow.ly/BJGs301YkTU
Eid Mubarak! Today marks the end of the month of #Ramadan and Eid al-Fitr, a religious holiday celebrated by Muslims worldwide. This card depicts two girls celebrating Eid http://ow.ly/zG56g

The largest hoard of Anglo-Saxon gold ever found, the Staffordshire Hoard, was discovered #onthisday in 2009 in a field near the village of Hammerwich. It consists of more than 3,500 items, including 5kg of gold, 1.4 kg of silver and 3,500 cloisonné garnets.

The hoard is almost exclusively war-gear, including an extraordinary quantity of weapon hilt fittings and decorative items from the handles of swords and knives. Many feature beautiful garnet inlays or animals in elaborate filigree. The artefacts have tentatively been dated to the 7th or 8th centuries, placing the origin of the items in the time of the Kingdom of Mercia. Find out more about the ongoing conservation and research: http://ow.ly/vZ4I301Nl2A

Read about the fascinating history of this remarkable hoard in this book http://ow.ly/W2hC301WEJH
Do you know what this object was used for? Reply with your #MysteryObject guesses!

Sir Isaac Newton's revolutionary work Principia was published #onthisday in 1687. This groundbreaking work summarised Newton's principles of universal gravitation and his famous laws of motion. This portrait of Newton from 1726 is the title page from the 3rd edition of this work http://ow.ly/yMMhN
Happy #FourthofJuly to our friends in the US! This print of the Declaration of Independence was made in 1856 http://ow.ly/L9ur301Ni4F

The worship of the sacred bull Apis was the most important animal cult in ancient Egypt. Priests carefully selected a bull which was seen as a representative of the creator god Ptah on earth. The Apis bull was treated like a pharaoh, crowned in Memphis and given his own harem of cows! When he died, his body was mummified. This magnificent bull is over two metres long. It was dedicated by the Roman emperor Hadrian (r. AD 117–138) for the Temple of Serapis in Alexandria http://ow.ly/C5NE301TUQM

Learn more about animal cults in ancient Egypt in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/lkvU301TTcW 

Apis bull, AD 117–138. Alexandria. Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

For centuries nobody suspected that the #SunkenCities of Thonis-Heracleion and Canopus lay beneath the sea. Recorded in ancient writings and Greek mythology, the ancient Egyptian cities were believed to be lost. 

In this article, underwater archaeologist Franck Goddio describes the painstaking processes that led to magical moments of discovery, and the innovative techniques his team used to rediscover these lost cities: http://ow.ly/Kzwc300X6m5

© Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Fancy a holiday to sunny Sicily? To celebrate our #SicilyExhibition we are offering a lucky winner a spectacular holiday for two to Sicily, courtesy of adventure travel experts Exodus Travels. This 9-day adventure will include many of Sicily's historical highlights including baroque churches, archaeological sites and the landscapes of Europe's highest active volcano – Mount Etna. 
Enter now: http://ow.ly/TP12301KtPL

This 17th-century porcelain figurine from Japan shows a boy sitting on a Go board (a popular board game). This style of Japanese porcelain called 'Classic Kakiemon' was very fashionable in Europe at this time. It is characterised by bright enamel colours applied on top of a clear glaze to show off the creamy white body. 

Explore this beautiful piece of #Kakiemon porcelain from all angles and print it in 3D on Sketchfab! http://ow.ly/YYlV301KwDb

#July is named after Julius Caesar! Up until 44 BC the Romans called it Quintilis (fifth month). In the ancient Roman calendar, Quintilis was the month following Junius (June) and preceding Sextilis (August). The year began at this time with Martius (March) and only had 10 months. In this engraving from 1698, Julius Caesar is depicted on a cloud, with Jupiter and an eagle in the background http://ow.ly/OL9l2

Meet our new Director, Dr Hartwig Fischer, as he reflects on his first months at the Museum and introduces some of his personal highlights. From piecing together fragments of an ancient tablet to the wonder of walking into the Great Court, follow Hartwig's journey and find out how he sees the role of the British Museum in the world today.
link_name: Meet the new Director of the British Museum

We are delighted to announce our special autumn exhibition on #SouthAfricanArt, exploring a 3 million-year history through archaeological, historic and contemporary artworks.

In this exhibition a diverse range of art from across the ages tells a story that stretches back to the Early Stone Age. From rock art made by the country's earliest peoples to works by South African artists at the forefront of contemporary art, the exhibition features beautiful and important works, which illustrate South Africa's rich history.

Tickets are on sale for 'South Africa: 3 million years of art' – book now! http://ow.ly/wNmA301O3xr

This inlaid ceiling panel is from the Norman Palace in Palermo, Sicily. It depicts animals associated with the royal court, where they were kept as curiosities, pets or for hunting. Some were also used as dynastic symbols, like the eagle and falcon. The complex geometrical design also creates an Islamic, eight-pointed star motif, and the whole panel reflects the mix of cultural influences in Norman Sicily.

Discover the cosmopolitan history of this remarkable island in our #SicilyExhibition, until 14 August http://ow.ly/RHwv301LhjL 

Ceiling panel from the Norman Palace in Palermo, Sicily, c. 1130–1200. Galleria Interdisciplinare Regionale della Sicilia di Palazzo Abatellis, Palermo. © Regione Siciliana.

Porcelain making in Japan began 400 years ago. It is said to have started in 1616 in Arita, a town on the southern island of Kyushu near Nagasaki. One of the most famous of Japanese porcelain styles is Kakiemon. 

Learn more about #Kakiemon porcelain in our free display, supported by The Asahi Shimbun http://ow.ly/8Djp301KrUH
link_name: Kakiemon: a history of making Japanese porcelain

status_message: Charles V was elected Holy Roman Emperor #onthisday in 1519. This woodcut depicts the Charles in the same year, aged 19. This coloured woodcut by Hans Weiditz is printed on vellum (calf skin), presumably as a deluxe coloured edition for wealthy clients. The lengthy inscription below describes the extent of his office and his territories. Printed portraiture such as this developed only in the first decades of the 16th century, at a time when the ruling classes became increasingly aware of the value of producing and distributing images of themselves http://ow.ly/zQ4a301F84W
It's time for this week's #MysteryObject! Any ideas what these objects were used for?

Peter Paul Rubens, one of the most famous and successful European artists of the 17th century, was born #onthisday in 1577. Rubens was a key figure of the Baroque style which emphasised colour, movement and sensuality. Born in Germany, Rubens moved to Antwerp in around 1588. During his career, Rubens travelled to Italy and Spain, and was influenced by the great works of Titian, Tintoretto, Leonardo da Vinci, Raphael and Michelangelo. In 1609 he was appointed court painter to the Archduke Albert and his wife the Infanta Isabella, the Spanish governors of the Netherlands. The demand for Rubens' work was extraordinary, and he was able to meet it only because he ran an extremely efficient studio. Here are some of his exquisite works

The discovery of this stela, which once stood at the entrance of the main entry port into ancient Egypt, was an extraordinary moment. Its inscription detailing taxes helped solve a 2,000-year-old mystery! Find out more http://ow.ly/XZuf301F8Ea #SunkenCities

Stela commissioned by Nectanebo I (r. 380–362 BC), Thonis-Heracleion, Egypt, 380 BC. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.
#Wimbledon starts today! Who would like to see a return to this look from 1769? http://ow.ly/Kct5301BCtX

Baron Ferdinand Rothschild collected nearly 300 beautiful medieval and Renaissance objects. See them in exquisite detail and hear from experts and artists including Grayson Perry and Edmund de Waal in this video.
link_name: A mania for collecting: the Rothschilds and the Waddesdon Bequest

status_message: During the #EURO2016 football competition, we've been pairing British Museum objects on Twitter to represent the countries playing in every match. Now that the competition has reached the final 16 stage, here's a round-up of the matches so far! http://ow.ly/ARy8301Byf9

Happy #Pride2016! Discover stories of same-sex relationships and gender identity from across the world in the Museum's collection. From erotic scenes on the Roman Warren Cup to a gender-changing Mesopotamian goddess, explore the diversity of love, desire and identity through the centuries in this Museum trail http://ow.ly/OnBB2

This is Taweret, the ancient Egyptian goddess who protects children and women in labour. She has the body of a hippopotamus, the limbs of a lion and the tail of a crocodile, making her a powerful and dangerous creature. She stands on her hind legs, her forepaws rest above large hieroglyphic signs meaning 'protection'. The inscription on the back pillar is the plea of a pharaoh to Taweret to protect his daughter. This statue was discovered in Karnak (modern Luxor), believed to be the birthplace of Osiris.

See this fearsome figure in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/wyMx301x2ba 

The goddess Taweret, 664–610 BC. Egyptian Museum, Cairo.  Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

2016 marks the 400th anniversary of porcelain production in Japan. It is said to have started in 1616 in Arita, a town on the southern island of Kyushu near Nagasaki. Our new free display celebrates the art of Japanese porcelain making through 15 generations of the #Kakiemon dynasty, open today! http://ow.ly/h66L301wVNh

Under the Norman kings of Sicily, the island became a prosperous and influential Mediterranean superpower. The coexistence of western, Islamic and Byzantine cultures on Sicily created a multilingual state. In Palermo, the messages on public monuments were frequently in two or three languages. This funerary inscription was set up by Grisandus, a Christian priest, for his mother Anna in AD 1149. Her eulogy is written in Judaeo-Arabic (Arabic written in Hebrew script) on top, Latin on the left, Greek on the right, and Arabic below.

Learn more about this cultural centre of the ancient and medieval world in our #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/nJyJ301vIVp 

A tombstone in four languages. Sicily, AD 1149. Soprintendenza Beni Culturali e Ambientali di Palermo. © Regione Siciliana.
Can you guess what this week's #MysteryObject is?

It's #WorldGiraffeDay! These two remarkable #AfricanRockArt engravings depict life-size giraffes. They are thought to date from between 6,000 and 8,000 years ago – a period when environmental conditions in the Sahara were able to sustain large mammals such as giraffes. The two giraffes, thought to be one large male in front of a smaller female, were engraved on the weathered surface of a sandstone outcrop. The engravings cannot be seen from ground level and are only visible by climbing onto the boulder http://ow.ly/ZyBs301twY1

Our African Rock Art image project is cataloguing and digitally preserving 25,000 images of rock art. Find out more http://ow.ly/JCZfm

Italian artist Salvator Rosa was born #onthisday in 1615. He worked in Naples, Florence and Rome and achieved great success with his landscape paintings of wild and mountainous scenery with travellers and bandits. His one hundred or so etchings, which have always been admired for their inventive figure groupings, reflect his desire to be known as more than a landscape painter. 

In this etching based on Ovid's Metamorphoses, Rosa depicts the hero Jason pouring the magic potion given to him by Medea over the dragon guarding the Golden Fleece. Overcome with drowsiness, the creature rolls onto its side, enabling Jason to carry off both his treasure and Medea as his bride. This etching of Jason stepping over the dragon bursts with violent energy. http://ow.ly/jamn301if5Z
Today is the longest day in the northern hemisphere! This etching by Bertram Buchanan depicts the #SummerSolstice at Stonehenge http://ow.ly/ygNas

The Cyrus Cylinder is one of the most famous objects to have survived from the ancient world. It was inscribed in Babylonian cuneiform on the orders of Persian King Cyrus the Great after he captured Babylon in 539 BC. Introduced by former Director of the British Museum Neil MacGregor, discover the story of this incredible object and its enduring legacy in this video.
link_name: The Cyrus Cylinder and ancient Persia

status_message:
Born #onthisday in 1566: King James, the first Stuart king of England, who was also James VI of Scotland. This beautiful jewel is in fact an enamelled gold locket, with a portrait of James by the great miniature painter Nicholas Hilliard http://ow.ly/nZGY301hnEX 

You can see this beautiful locket on display in our #Waddesdon gallery http://ow.ly/38sI301hnGe

#onthisday in AD 827: the Arab Aghlabid dynasty of North Africa invaded Sicily, marking the start of their conquest of the island. They ruled Sicily for two centuries and their cultural influence was profound and long-lasting.

The Muslim conquerors and settlers lived mostly peacefully with their Christian and Jewish neighbours, who were free to keep their faith as long as the religious tax, the jizya, was paid. The Arabs revolutionised agriculture by introducing new irrigation techniques and crops, such as oranges, rice, sugar cane, date palms and cotton. http://ow.ly/7cIy301meOD 

Find out more about the cosmopolitan history of this remarkable island in our #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/BD77301mwHZ

The Battle of Waterloo was fought #onthisday in 1815, marking the final defeat of the French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte. Napoleon rose through the ranks of the army during the French Revolution, seized control of the government in 1799 and became emperor in 1804. Through a series of wars, he expanded his empire across western and central Europe. However, unsuccessful invasions and defeats led to his abdication and exile in 1814. He returned to France in 1815 and briefly resumed power. The Battle of Waterloo, in which Napoleon's forces were defeated by the British and Prussians, ended his reign. After Waterloo, Napoleon abdicated and later died in exile.

This print produced in 1817 depicts the harrowing scenes on the battlefield the morning after http://ow.ly/ybuu1

Dutch Artist M C Escher was born #onthisday in 1898. Escher specialised in using lithographs, woodcuts and wood-engravings and is best known for his representation of buildings or views with unusual perspectives. This printed poster is his depiction of the Tower of Babel. Escher wrote of the image: 'Some of the builders are white and others black. The work is at a standstill because they are no longer able to understand one another.' http://ow.ly/k4Wy301fHPd

Artist Edward Burne-Jones, a key figure of the Pre-Raphaelite movement, died #onthisday in 1898. These small jewel-like watercolours are from his album 'The Flower Book', containing his fantasies inspired by the names of flowers. He added to it periodically from 1882 until his death.

This stunning statue depicts the Egyptian queen Arsinoe II (c. 316–270 BC). Discovered in the lost ancient Egyptian city of Canopus, this statue is the perfect combination of Egyptian and Greek style. She is the embodiment of Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of beauty and 'fortunate sailing'. While the choice of a local dark stone and the queen's striding posture are Egyptian in style, the sensual rendering of her flesh is reminiscent of Greek masterpieces. 

Arsinoe II was the eldest daughter of Ptolemy I and married her brother Ptolemy II. This marriage was the first of a series of such unions in the Ptolemaic dynasty. It emphasises the status of the ruling couple as an earthly incarnation of the divine siblings Osiris and Isis, who form the archetype of the royal couple.

See more incredible objects preserved and buried under the sea for over a thousand years in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/wx0v301k0ot

Statue of Arsinoe. 3rd century BC, Canopus. Bibliotheca Alexandrina Antiquities Museum. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Today is #Bloomsday, a celebration of Irish writer James Joyce that takes place both in Dublin and around the world. It celebrates Thursday 16 June 1904, which is the day depicted in Joyce's novel Ulysses, in which Leopold Bloom wanders around Dublin. Artist Richard Hamilton spent 50 years visualising his love of Joyce's great modernist masterpiece. http://ow.ly/Onogk

This cross is made from the wreckage of a refugee boat that sank off the coast of the Italian island of Lampedusa. Some of the survivors were Eritrean Christians, fleeing persecution in their home country. 500 people were on board when the overcrowded boat caught fire, capsized and sank. Only 151 people survived. 

Francesco Tuccio, a carpenter on the island, made each survivor a cross to reflect their salvation. Mr Tuccio made and donated this cross to the Museum's collection as a symbol of the suffering and hope of our times. It will feature in a service at St. Paul's Cathedral on Sunday, to mark the beginning of #RefugeeWeek.

The cross will also feature in our 'Crossing borders' public forum, an event in partnership with Financial Times, on Monday 20 June. More information here: http://ow.ly/7XSp301hCV7

King John of England put his seal to #MagnaCarta #onthisday in 1215. Magna Carta, meaning 'The Great Charter', is one of the most celebrated documents in history. It was issued by King John as a practical solution to the political crisis he faced in 1215. However Magna Carta also established for the first time the principle that everybody, including the king, was subject to the law. This copy of the document was made in 1733 http://ow.ly/YM6l301eWim

Find out more about the history and legacy of Magna Carta with this introduction from The British Library http://ow.ly/GeQo301fzks

American abolitionist and author Harriet Beecher Stowe was born #onthisday in 1811. She published more than 30 books and she is best known for her novel 'Uncle Tom's Cabin', which depicted the harsh life for African-Americans under slavery. These illustrations are by British artist Louisa Corbaux.
From the earliest Greek settlers to the splendour of Norman architecture, read about our #SicilyExhibition in History Today http://ow.ly/nqJv3014KlL
link_name: Of Greek vases and Byzantine mosaics | History Today

status_message: Do you know what these beautiful objects were used for? Reply with your #MysteryObject guesses!

Writer, poet and playwright W B Yeats was born #onthisday in 1865. As a young writer, he was active in the effort for an Irish literary revival. In these early years, he focused more on dramatic works than on poetry, typically incorporating themes of Irish legend, mysticism and spiritualism. In 1923, he received the Nobel Prize in Literature. Yeats founded the Irish Theatre, to become the Abbey Theatre, and served for a period as its chief playwright. These drawings by James Torrance are illustrations to his Irish Fairy and Folk Tales http://ow.ly/OajBy

What shape was Noah's ark? How Dr Irving Finkel discovered the earliest account of the ancient Babylonian 'Story of the Flood' – closely related to the biblical account of Noah. The sixty-line passage not only provided the materials and measurements required to build the ark, it also suggested that the vessel was round.
link_name: Was the ark round? The new Babylonian text that reshaped Noah'...

status_message: How has money affected our everyday lives? Our new free display explores the world of money and financial concepts through objects drawn from different societies through history. From one of the earliest coins in the world minted in Lydia to a 2015 Brixton banknote, these objects explore the different relationships people have had with money through history http://ow.ly/r0WD300X7qP

'The landscape painter who does not make his skies a very material part of his composition neglects to avail himself of one of his greatest aids.'

Artist John Constable was born #onthisday in 1776. He devoted much of his life to painting the local landscape, with most of his works depicting the Suffolk countryside where he was born and lived. He made many open-air sketches, capturing the changing skies and effects of light. 

Constable had little success for many years and was only elected to the Royal Academy of Arts at the late age of 54 (Turner, his great rival, was elected at 26). He is now recognised as one of the most important artists of the Romantic movement, which emphasised emotion and a sense of the power of nature.

Alexander the Great died #onthisday in 323 BC – he was just 32. By this time, he ruled most of the then known world from Greece to Afghanistan. 

Alexander was always shown clean-shaven, whereas all previous portraits of Greek statesmen or rulers had beards. This royal fashion lasted for almost 500 years until the Roman emperor Hadrian (r. AD 117–138) brought beards back into vogue.

Alexander was hailed as a liberator when he conquered Egypt in 332 BC. He notably founded Alexandria in 331 BC and introduced Greek traditions such as athletic and musical contests, while also adopting the Egyptian belief in divine kingship to his own advantage. 

Learn more about Alexander's lasting impact in Egypt in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/Hk6G3015N4V

Underwater archaeologist Franck Goddio reveals his favourite underwater find from #SunkenCities out of the hundreds excavated from Abukir Bay in Egypt. It's not gold, or even a colossal statue… http://ow.ly/rYHm3015uXX

Gustave Courbet, leading French Realist artist, was born #onthisday in 1819. He made numerous self-portraits, often in fanciful guises. He considered them demonstrations of his inner life, though some of his contemporaries saw him as a notorious narcissist! 

In black chalk and charcoal, this is one of Courbet's largest self-portraits. It was made in 1852, the year following the public exhibition of his groundbreaking works, 'A Burial at Ornans' and 'The Stone Breakers'. He presents himself in a well-lit space, directly engaging the viewer, and without props or attributes, although the full beard would have made him easily recognisable http://ow.ly/feZg300XbUJ

Peter the Great of Russia was born #onthisday in 1672. In an attempt to modernise Russian society and discourage the growing of facial hair, Peter the Great introduced a beard tax. Those who wished to grow a beard were taxed and given this token as proof of payment!

Learn more about the different forms tax has taken throughout history in our new free display http://ow.ly/wgzx300QVg0

In 241 BC, Sicily became the Roman Empire's first province, when Rome defeated the Carthaginians and Greeks in the Mediterranean. To the Romans, Sicily's primary importance lay in its abundant supply of grain, which they used to feed the growing population back in the capital. Sicily was dubbed 'Rome's granary'. However, the island's language and culture remained Greek. It was over 200 years later during the emperor Augustus' reign (27 BC–AD 14) that Sicily adopted the Latin language and Roman way of life.

Learn more about Sicily's role within the Roman Empire in our #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/EWoJ300X3km

Edward the Confessor became King of England #onthisday in 1042. Son of Æthelred II 'the Unready' and Emma of Normandy, Edward was one of the last Anglo-Saxon rulers. He is also known for the construction of Westminster Abbey. Edward had no children and upon his death in 1066 the throne passed to his brother-in-law, Harold, who was quickly overthrown by William the Conqueror. This coin with Edward's portrait was minted in Chester http://ow.ly/lxiK300QK36

Pre-Raphaelite John Everett Millais was born #onthisday in 1829. Millais was a child prodigy who became, at the age of 11, the youngest ever student at the Royal Academy of Arts. In 1848, the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood was founded at Millais' house. With his friends William Holman Hunt and Dante Gabriel Rossetti, they sought a return to the intense colours, incredible detail and complex compositions of 15th-century Italian art.

'Art is the Flower. Life is the Green Leaf. Let every artist strive to make his flower a beautiful living thing, something that will convince the world that there may be, there are, things more precious more beautiful - more lasting than life itself.' – Scottish artist, designer and architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh was born #onthisday in 1868.

For over 20 years Mackintosh worked almost exclusively in Glasgow where all his best-known work was created and where much of it still remains. The Glasgow School of Art was one of the leading art academies in Europe in architecture and the decorative arts at the time and Mackintosh was at the heart of this success.
It's time for another #MysteryObject! Can you guess what this beautiful glass object was used for?

The British Museum was established by an Act of Parliament #onthisday in 1753! 

The Museum first opened to the public in 1759. It was originally housed in a 17th-century mansion on the site of today's building. Entry was free and given to 'all studious and curious Persons'.

With the exception of two World Wars, the Museum has remained open and free ever since. The number of visitors has grown from around 5,000 per year to today's nearly 7 million!

Paul Gauguin was born #onthisday in 1848. Gauguin came late to art and was first a stockbroker. He developed an amateur interest in art and his early works are influenced by Camille Pissarro. After the stock market crashed in 1882, Gauguin decided to become a full-time artist. He showed works in the later Impressionist exhibitions (1880–1886), and in 1888 he worked briefly with Vincent Van Gogh in Arles.

In 1891 he left Paris to work in Tahiti, where he produced many of his most famous works. These woodcuts are based on his time there.

Spanish artist Diego Velázquez was born #onthisday in 1599 in Seville. Velázquez moved to Madrid in 1623 and was named 'Pintor del Rey', leading artist to King Philip IV. He spent the remainder of his life in Madrid in the service of the king as both painter and royal chamberlain. His most famous work is 'Las Meninas' (Museo Nacional del Prado) but he is also known for his portraits, mythological paintings and religious works. These studies of horses in the Museum's prints and drawings collection are attributed to Velázquez.

See more extraordinary works by Velázquez in this book http://ow.ly/NOojn

Greeks settled on Sicily over 2,500 years ago, drawn to its fertility and riches. Throughout Greek Sicily, wealth was displayed through sumptuously decorated homes, gold jewellery and large silver coins. Success in battle and trade also provided Greeks with the wealth for major building projects. Some of the Greek temples on Sicily were among the largest and most impressive anywhere in the ancient world.

Learn more about the arrival of the Greeks in our #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/JHKO300PZnG

Rock gongs were used for thousands of years in several parts of Africa. We asked an archaeologist specialising in rock art and a drummer to try and discover how a rock gong might have been played. 
Although rock gongs look like plain boulders, they have a hollow, metallic sound when struck due to the composition of the rock. They may have been used as part of rituals, to signal other people, or as a form of expression.
link_name: How to play an ancient rock gong

status_message: King George III was born #onthisday in 1738. His collection of over 60,000 books was donated to the Museum in 1823. When the library was donated there was not enough space to house it in the original British Museum building. The room for the King's Library was constructed between 1823 and 1827, making it the oldest room in the Museum today http://ow.ly/NRnOQ

This 16th-century figure of a bull from India symbolises strength, virility and fertility as well as religious and moral duties. The crouching image, often housed in a small pavilion, is at the entrance of every Shiva temple. Explore this object from all angles and print your own version in 3D: http://ow.ly/P3BX300Ku6D

From Greek temples to Norman palaces, there's more to Sicily than sunshine, beaches and lemons! Our #SicilyExhibition Curators Peter and Dirk introduce the story of this remarkable island, and explain what makes its history so fascinating http://ow.ly/yq0W300R40c
link_name: Curating Sicily: from Greek temples to Norman palaces

status_message:
Today Bank of England has unveiled their first polymer (plastic) banknote, a £5 note featuring a portrait of Sir Winston Churchill. Did you know that banknotes have a history stretching back more than 1,000 years?

Paper currency was first used in China as early as AD 1000. It was the Chinese who first printed a value on a piece of paper and persuaded everyone that it was worth what it said it was. The Ming were the first Chinese dynasty to try to totally replace coins with paper money. After seizing power from the Mongol rulers of China in 1368, the rulers of the Ming dynasty tried to reinstate bronze coins. However, there was not enough metal available for this, and paper money, made of mulberry bark, was produced from 1375. 

The first banknotes in Europe were issued in Sweden by the Stockholm Banco in 1661. They were carefully printed on handmade paper and were given official authority by impressions of several seals and no less than eight handwritten signatures. The first plastic notes in Britain entered circulation in Scotland last year when Clydesdale Bank unveiled its new £5 note. The durability and increased security afforded by polymer notes have made them an attractive proposition to issuing authorities throughout the world from Australia and Nigeria to Brazil and Canada.

Discover more about the history of banknotes in the Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/iOmi300QrSR

Cleopatra VII was the legendary last pharaoh of Egypt. A descendant of the Greco-Macedonian rulers of ancient Egypt, her political alliances and reputation as an immoral seductress have become infamous. Find out more… http://ow.ly/qFIu300Ne4j 

Our #SunkenCities exhibition sheds new light on the interaction between ancient Egypt and the Greek world at a crucial period in history, from the arrival of Greeks in Egypt around 650 BC, to the end of Cleopatra's reign and beyond http://ow.ly/izsM300Lqhg

The month of #June is named after the Roman goddess Juno, protector of women and patron deity of marriage and childbirth. In this print by Dutch artist Jacobus Harrewyn she is depicted sitting on a cloud with a peacock and sceptre http://ow.ly/r9i3300E0AV

It's #MysteryObject time! Can you guess what this beautiful object is?

Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

The Houses of Parliament clock, often popularly referred to as Big Ben, first began keeping time #onthisday in 1859! In 1846 a competition was held to decide who should build this new clock, and the clockmaker Edward John Dent was appointed. The clock was installed in the Clock Tower in April 1859. At first, it wouldn't work as the cast-iron minute hands were too heavy. Once they were replaced by lighter copper hands, it successfully began keeping time. Find out more about the history of Big Ben at the website of the UK's Parliament http://ow.ly/Ev7v300E0qH 

This print from 1858 depicts the new Houses of Parliament with the clock tower still unfinished and scaffolding around the top http://ow.ly/NeRwM

From calamari and swordfish to arancini and tiramisu, complete your visit to our #SicilyExhibition with a special Sicilian menu in the Great Court Restaurant. Enjoy dishes inspired by traditional Sicilian food and the island's diverse culinary influences, from Greece to North Africa. You can also try a refreshing Sicilian cocktail! http://ow.ly/Dgzl300i6Xl

Peter Paul Rubens, one of the most sought-after painters in northern Europe, died #onthisday in 1640. Rubens was a key figure of the Baroque style which emphasised colour, movement and sensuality, and is known for his altarpieces, history paintings, large-scale decorations and landscapes.

Born in Germany, Rubens moved to Antwerp in around 1588. He spent the years 1600 to 1608 studying and working in Italy, where he was influenced by ancient and Italian Renaissance art. Returning to Antwerp, he continued to travel as both a courtier and painter and in 1609 he became court painter to Archduke Albert and the Infanta Isabella, Governors of the Netherlands for Spain. Regular trips to Madrid, Paris and London allowed him to negotiate treaties while also accepting royal commissions for art. These are some of his exceptional drawings.

Come to the Museum this #halfterm for a week of family activities exploring the wonders of #SunkenCities! Write using hieroglyphs and make your own ancient Egyptian papyrus roll to take home. Plus, help make a diorama of the ancient city of Alexandria by adding your own statue to the city landscape. Find out more http://ow.ly/qbWh300zgp8

Our new UK touring display opens today at Corinium Museum! To complement our #SunkenCities exhibition, this tour will explore the fascinating encounters between the ancient civilisations of Egypt, Greece, Cyprus, Phoenicia, Persia and Rome! 

The display focuses on this unique Cypriot sculpture of a hunter from the ancient Egyptian city of Naukratis, and is dedicated to Aphrodite. The display will also highlight the ongoing excavations at Naukratis and underwater archaeology in the region. http://ow.ly/zeU8300DTSG

Why did ancient Brits throw out their valuable possessions? This is a question that researchers across Britain and northern Europe are asking about the Bronze Age hoards that have been left in the ground across Britain. Many have lain undiscovered for 4,000 years. Our curators are interviewed in this BBC Britain article http://ow.ly/VHkn300z9UG

status_message:
Discover how this underwater treasure helped solved a 2,000-year-old mystery! 

This monument was crucial to revealing that Thonis (in Egyptian) and Heracleion (in Greek) were in fact the same ancient Egyptian city. It was issued by the pharaoh Nectanebo I, regarding the taxation of trade. The inscription tells us that this decree was housed in the city's main Egyptian temple, at the mouth of the 'Sea of the Greeks' (the Mediterranean).

Learn more about ancient Egypt and Greece in our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/9Abc300zGwf
link_name: What's in a name? An ancient mystery solved

status_message:
This is one of the earliest coins in the world! Cities and empires traded without using coins for over 2,000 years, but when ancient kingdoms like Lydia (in modern Turkey) began issuing pieces of electrum (a mixture of gold and silver) like this one around 600 BC, the idea quickly caught on and spread to city-states in the ancient Greek world.

These coins had a design on one side only – a result of the method of manufacture. The coins were hand struck. A die with a design (in this case a lion's head) for the front of the coin was placed on an anvil. A blank piece of metal was placed on top of the die, and a punch hammered onto the reverse. The device of the lion on these coins has often led to the assumption that they were issued by a royal power, the kings of Lydia, although we cannot say for certain who minted these earliest coins. http://ow.ly/RCU9300zkpq

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! Discover the history of money over 4,000 years in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/RVV8300zi0A

Bram Stoker studied at the British Museum's library while researching his novel Dracula, which was published #onthisday in 1897. 

This is his application for a ticket to use the library, which was required for all readers. In his application Stoker admits that (like many other readers) he has lost his ticket – although his has been missing for longer than most! 'I have used the Rooms since 1879 or thereabouts but I have not seen my ticket for at least twenty years and cannot find it.' The Principal Librarian of the Museum replied to Stoker's letter on 24 May 1905, telling him that a new ticket would be issued to him.

Sicily has been shaped by waves of conquest and settlement by different peoples over 4,000 years. Since the 8th century BC, Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs and Normans all settled or invaded the island, lured by its fertile lands and strategic location. Phoenicians and Greeks were two of the first peoples to develop colonies on Sicily. However, archaeologists have uncovered evidence of indigenous communities living on the island long before they arrived, and we know that there was interaction between these populations.

Discover more about Sicily's first inhabitants and early settlers on Tumblr http://ow.ly/OPVm3006T0A #SicilyExhibition

Over the last 20 years, world-renowned marine archaeologist Franck Goddio and his team have excavated spectacular underwater discoveries, including two lost cities of ancient Egypt. Our #SunkenCities exhibition showcases this ongoing research and includes objects excavated as recently as 2012 http://ow.ly/fNNR300zn24

In this video Franck talks about finding important, beautiful and fascinating objects every year.
