Queen Victoria was born #onthisday in 1819. Large numbers of these badges were sold as souvenirs of her Diamond Jubilee in 1897. They showed a portrait of Victoria when she came to the throne in 1837, aged 18, alongside an image of her in her jubilee year. 

The reverse of the Queen Victoria badge shows the name of Whitehead and Hoag. The company was based in Newark, New Jersey, USA, and had agents in London. In 1896 the company patented the modern 'button' badge, consisting of a printed paper disc covered with a thin layer of celluloid with a stick pin behind. The first such badges were given out with cigarettes and confectionery, and immediately caught the public imagination. Their potential for publicity was quickly realised, and they were used in the US presidential campaigns of 1896.

Learn more about this badge including teaching ideas and in our online resource http://ow.ly/L9Hl300i62N
To celebrate the opening of the #ChelseaFlowerShow today, here's some floral inspiration from the collection! http://ow.ly/N87JV

Our 2016 blockbuster exhibition #SunkenCities is now open! This is the Museum's first major exhibition on underwater discoveries. Over the last 20 years a team of marine archaeologists, led by Franck Goddio, has been exploring the submerged land off the Mediterranean coast. Their work has led to the rediscovery of two ancient cities and revealed a vast number of artefacts and monuments of unique importance and beauty.

Exhibition Curator Aurélia Masson-Berghoff introduces #SunkenCities and the incredible 'secrets of the sea' in this new feature http://ow.ly/zWne300tYcR

How we helped Christie's return this beautiful 17th-century bowl from a private collection to the National Museum of Afghanistan – read the full story: http://ow.ly/7YsB300tyj6

Lost during the 1990s civil war, the bowl was bought from an Afghan antique dealer in good faith by a German couple. They recently contacted Christie's for a valuation and it was identified as having come from the museum in Kabul. The bowl was presented to the Embassy of Afghanistan in London for its immediate return.

British Museum Curator St John Simpson: 'This is another important step in the rebuilding of the National Museum of Afghanistan and we are delighted to have played a small part in the return of this important object to Kabul'.

American artist Mary Cassatt was born #onthisday in 1844. In 1874 Cassatt settled in Paris, where her work was shown regularly in the Salons. Edgar Degas invited her to join the group of independent artists later known as the Impressionists. The only American officially associated with the group, Cassatt exhibited in four of their eight exhibitions in 1879, 1880, 1881 and 1886. http://ow.ly/Z1L23006mHb

Author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of Sherlock Holmes, was born #onthisday in 1859. This is his application to study at the Museum's Reading Room from 1891. All prospective users of the British Museum Library had to apply in writing, stating their reasons for study there. At the time he applied for a reader's ticket, Arthur Conan Doyle was already well known as the creator of the great detective Sherlock Holmes, but he had not yet given up his work as a doctor, and in this letter of application from 1 April 1891 he gives his occupation as 'physician'.

As well as his detective stories, Conan Doyle wrote many historical novels. When he wrote this letter he was probably carrying out research for his novel The White Company, which is set during the Thirty Years' War (1618–1648) in Europe.

Mary Anning was born #onthisday in 1799, one of the most famous fossil finders of her day. Her family had earned a living for years by gathering fossils on the shore at Lyme Regis in Dorset to sell to collectors, leading to the well-known rhyme: 'She sells sea shells by the sea shore'. Mary learned about the fossils from her parents. Despite the lack of a formal education, she became an expert on the fossils she found, and the most eminent geologists of the day often sought her advice. In the 1820s she became the first person in Britain to find complete specimens of an ichthyosaur, a plesiosaur and a pterodactyl.

The specimens that Anning collected can still be found in museums throughout Britain. This large skull is part of the skull and lower jaw of an ichthyosaur (Ichthyosaurus platyodon). The British Museum purchased this shortly after Anning discovered it. The Museum's natural history collections moved to South Kensington in the 1880s and this is now on loan from the Natural History Museum, London, on display in our Enlightenment Gallery.

Today we open a new free display celebrating love and courtship in Iran and neighbouring regions. In Persian culture, the theme of love has permeated literature, art and music for thousands of years. 

In this display, love and courtship are explored through drawings, illustrated manuscript pages and objects, depicting intimate scenes and classical accounts of celebrated romances. Illuminated Persian marriage contracts (ghabaleh), along with a Judaeo-Persian example (ketubbah) and an Old Babylonian contract carved onto a clay tablet, reflect the legal and social aspects of marriage and its roots in ancient tradition. The works are complemented by a number of richly embroidered textiles, including wedding garments and accessories. http://ow.ly/Nnxt300n3XD

Albrecht Dürer was born #onthisday in 1471 in the city of Nuremberg, one of the key artistic and commercial centres of Europe in the 15th and 16th centuries. Dürer was apprenticed with his father, a goldsmith, and with the painter Michel Wolgemut, whose workshop produced woodcut illustrations for books and publications. 

He travelled widely including visiting northern Italy, where the works of artists such as Mantegna and Giovanni Bellini had a powerful influence on him. In 1495 Dürer set up his own workshop in Nuremberg, specialising in the production of innovative, high quality prints. Dürer's revitalisation of printmaking techniques attracted the attention of many Nuremberg scholars and patrons. Although his Europe-wide fame rested on his graphic art, he also excelled at drawing and painting. Here are some of his exceptional works.

Over 3,500 years old, this ancient Egyptian statue depicts Senebtyfy-Ptahemsaf, a scribe 'who kept royal records in the king's presence'. His title 'royal seal bearer' indicates his high position at the court and we can assume that the statue was made in a royal workshop. His status probably also explains his access to quartzite, a rather rare material exclusively used for high officials and members of the royal family. 

See this object, and discover 4,000 years of writing in ancient Egypt, in our UK touring exhibition – opening tomorrow at The Salisbury Museum http://ow.ly/22GE3006rFV

Red quartzite figure of the scribe Senebtyfy, 13th Dynasty (1781–1650 BC).

'One of the most extraordinary archaeological discoveries of the century' – The Times and The Sunday Times speak to marine archaeologist Franck Goddio, who discovered the #SunkenCities of ancient Egypt http://ow.ly/UvGl300eAuC (£)

Explore incredible objects preserved and buried under the sea for over a thousand years in our blockbuster exhibition, opening tomorrow http://ow.ly/Zpm1300eD7c

Walter Gropius, architect and founder of the #Bauhaus school, was born #onthisday in 1883. The Bauhaus (meaning 'Construction House') was a progressive German design school based in Weimar 1919–1925, then in Dessau 1925–1932. It ended in Berlin, where it was closed by the Nazis in 1933. The school employed many leading European artists and architects and its purpose was to train designers to work in industry. The basic design course introduced students to different materials and from there they progressed to detailed study of individual craft disciplines in specialised workshops. 

This porcelain teapot is part of tea-set called 'Bauhaus Hommage I'. The shape was designed by Walter Gropius and Louis McMillen, an American architect. The decoration in primary colours was designed by Herbert Bayer. http://ow.ly/MWk5J

status_message:
Florentine artist Sandro Botticelli died #onthisday in 1510. This is one of his most elaborate and beautiful drawings. The female figure is believed to represent either Abundance or Autumn because of the cornucopia she carries in her right hand, from which flowers and fruit are tumbling. She is dressed in late-15th-century costume with buttoned sleeves and high waist. 

This unfinished drawing probably dates from the late 1470s or early 1480s, the period when Botticelli painted the Primavera and the Birth of Venus (both Uffizi Gallery, Florence). The drawing is densely worked with a warm background tone established by rubbing red chalk in the paper. The contours are drawn in black chalk and then pen and brown ink, while the forms are modelled by hatching and the sparing use of brown wash.
http://ow.ly/MVOK3006kkQ

'It was a city with perhaps 16,000 inhabitants, full of temples to gods…and dominated by a vast sanctuary dedicated to the Egyptian deity Amun-Ra, from which a sphinx-lined avenue led to the Canopic branch of the Nile, which long ago flowed here.'

Read a new article in The Guardian on the ancient city of Naukratis and our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/fW2t300eyhk
Joan of Arc was canonised #onthisday in 1920. This book illustration from around 1612 is by Léonard Gaultier and depicts the French heroine with a feathered hat and sword http://ow.ly/IBXt3006k0k

Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI of France were married #onthisday in 1770. They would later rule as king and queen with Louis' accession in 1774. This pair of portraits drawn in pen and ink is by Jean Joseph Bernard and was completed around 1786. The royal couple were dethroned in 1792 following the constitutional reforms of the French Revolution, and were both executed under charges of counterrevolution in 1793.

Happy birthday to American artist Jasper Johns! Johns was one of the leaders of the Pop Art movement of the late 1950s and early 1960s. Since 1960 he has also made nearly 300 lithographs, etchings and screenprints. He is best known for his images of targets, flags, maps, and other instantly recognisable subjects. These two prints are from the 1980s.

This is a sculpture of the #PacificGod A'a, an object that has been a source of fascination and inspiration to artists, poets and others across the world. Henry Moore and Pablo Picasso both had their own casts made of the figure, poet William Empson wrote a poem about A'a and the Museum, and it continues to inspire people today. 

A'a has undergone scientific tests to try and understand why and how it was made, and new discoveries are transforming our understanding of this enigmatic object. When removing tiny wood samples from the figure, curators found a small red feather caught on a splinter inside the hollow interior. The feather was examined by experts from the Natural History Museum in London, who identified it as coming from a Kuhl's lorikeet – an endangered species of bird found on Rimatara, a neighbouring island to Rurutu, where A'a was made. Red feathers were considered sacred in Polynesia, so the presence of this feather proves that whatever was stored inside A'a was of the highest cultural significance. Read more about these new discoveries: http://ow.ly/txM1300awCz

Encounter this sculpture of the god A'a in our free display in Room 3 http://ow.ly/txM1300awCz

The enormous Cuerdale Hoard of Viking silver was discovered in Lancashire #onthisday in 1840. The hoard, which is the largest Viking silver hoard known from western Europe, consists of over 8,500 silver objects, weighing some 40kg in total. Most of the pieces are coins, together with ingots (silver bars) and cut-up brooches, chains, rings and other ornaments (known as hacksilver). Most of the hoard's coins were minted in Viking-controlled England, while the hacksilver is mainly Irish or Irish-Viking in form and decoration. Other pieces originated from further afield – Scotland, the continent, Scandinavia, the Baltic Sea region and the Islamic lands of Central Asia and the Middle East. In this way, the Cuerdale Hoard reflects the Vikings' extensive international connections across much of the known world.

This enormous silver treasure was discovered by workmen repairing the bank of the River Ribble in 1840. Records from the time describe how one workman's spade hit loose coins, spilling them into his wheelbarrow. The hoard was taken to Cuerdale Hall, where it was said to cover a sitting room floor.
A hoard of this size represents extraordinary wealth – probably of many persons rather than one individual. It is likely to have been collected over time as loot, tribute and through trade. The reasons for the Cuerdale Hoard's burial are not known. It may have been hidden for safe-keeping at a time of unrest, or represents a secure method of stock-piling riches over time.
The latest coins in the hoard enable us to date its burial to between about AD 905 and 910. This, together with the Irish origin of most of the hacksilver, has fuelled speculation that the hoard belonged to Vikings who were expelled from Dublin in AD 902.

Learn more about this incredible discovery and other Viking hoards in this book http://ow.ly/2pLQ30047Dg

'Hapy seemed like an impossible find. No one had ever seen such a huge statue of an Egyptian god' – read the story of how this colossal statue was discovered underwater in a Time Out London article on our #SunkenCities exhibition http://ow.ly/ZEji3006vAI

status_message: Thomas Gainsborough was born #onthisday in 1727. Gainsborough sometimes said that while painting portraits was his profession, landscape painting was his pleasure. Throughout the 18th century, landscape painting was considered a lowly branch of art. However Gainsborough was innovative in often fusing these two genres within the same composition, and landscape provided the ideal subject for his poetic vision. The British Museum holds one of the richest collections of Gainsborough's drawings http://ow.ly/STPS3002WqV

Mary Delany was born #onthisday in 1700. She began making paper collages, or 'mosaicks' as she called them, at the age of 72. The idea came to her while staying with her companion, Margaret Bentinck, Duchess of Portland, in Buckinghamshire. She had noticed the similarity of colour between a geranium and a piece of red paper that was on her bedside table. Taking up her scissors she imitated the petals. Upon entering the room, the duchess mistook them for real: 'Her approbation was such a sanction to my undertaking... and gave me courage to go on with confidence'. Delany later wrote that her work was intended as an imitation of a 'hortus siccus' or collection of dried flowers. 

In creating a 'mosaick', she would cut minute pieces of coloured paper and stick them on a black background to represent each part of a specimen. She created nearly 1,000 collages before failing eyesight caused her to stop in 1782. They filled ten albums which came to the British Museum in 1897. Here are some of these wonderful collages http://ow.ly/qXvY3002UWf

Young Friends can experience a monumental sleepover at the Museum, spending the night in the Egyptian and Assyrian galleries! Our next sleepover for 8–15 year olds in June 2016 is themed around the #SicilyExhibition and activities will include Sicilian puppet workshops, storytelling, designing your own coin and a tarantella dance workshop!

Find out more about becoming a Young Friend http://ow.ly/yAxD3002L7c

Sicily has been shaped by waves of conquest and settlement by different peoples over 4,000 years. Since the 8th century BC, Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs and Normans all settled or invaded the island, lured by its fertile lands and strategic location.

Learn more about the history of this remarkable island in this online exhibition on Art Project, by Google. http://ow.ly/VYm33008Kve #SicilyExhibition
Happy Birthday Stevie Wonder! This 1974 portrait of the legendary musician is by British artist David Oxtoby http://ow.ly/MTPfx

Feeling unlucky this #Fridaythe13th? Well, even ancient Egyptians had good days and bad days! This papyrus from around 1225 BC is a calendar of lucky and unlucky days. The oldest surviving Egyptian calendar of lucky and unlucky days dates to the Middle Kingdom (2040–1750 BC). This calendar contains parts of the records for eight months. It is one of the most extensive and dates from the late 19th Dynasty (around 1225 BC).

The entry for each day is prefaced by three hieroglyphs that indicate 'good' or 'bad'. The 'bad' hieroglyphs are written in red. If a day is partly good and partly bad, the relevant hieroglyphs can be mixed to represent the assessment of the day. The character of a day often derives from events told in mythological history. An example of a bad day: 'Do not go out on this day. Do not turn your back to do any work at sunset. Whoever is born on this day will die through a serpent'. An example of a good day includes: 'This is the day on which the gods received their hearts. The world keeps the festival' http://ow.ly/qHX13008zbQ

#SunkenCities opens in just one week! Here's a glimpse of some of the objects being installed. From magnificent colossal statues to intricate gold jewellery, the objects in the exhibition tell stories of political power and popular belief, myth and migration, gods and kings http://ow.ly/J2WK3002PDw

Artist and poet Edward Lear was born #onthisday in 1812. Lear is best known today for his nonsense verse (and accompanying illustrations) which he produced alongside his lifelong activity as a landscape painter. He spent much of his life abroad, and stayed regularly in Corfu from 1855, using it as a base for his travels in the eastern Mediterranean. This was the beginning of a decade which produced Lear's most accomplished watercolours. Here is a selection in the collection http://ow.ly/iQeB3002OrI

Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, was born #onthisday in 1820. This portrait by Herbert Carmichael (1856–1935) is titled 'The Lady with the Lamp', the name by which she became known during the Crimean War of 1853 as she continued her work into the night, making her rounds with the aid of a lamp http://ow.ly/MwALp

Learn more about Florence Nightingale with objects from the Florence Nightingale Museum in this online teaching resource http://ow.ly/1Six3002Pc0

How to make a Celtic torc: Curator Julia Farley explains the processes behind making a torc (or big metal neck ring), and reveals some of the beautiful and surprising aspects of these Iron Age treasures... http://ow.ly/jCPv3006Yl7

status_message:
The Lacock Cup is one of the most significant pieces of secular English medieval silverware. It began life as a drinking vessel and would originally have been used at late medieval feasts, underlining the wealth, status and taste of its owner. It is made from finely hammered sheet silver, creating a shimmering reflective surface, and has been edged with gilded decoration and twisted ropework. Surviving English medieval silverware is exceptionally rare. Because of the value of the material, it was almost always melted down so the metal could be reworked.

Early in its history the Cup was given to St Cyriac's Church in Lacock, Wiltshire where it was used as a chalice for over 400 years. During the English Reformation many churches were stripped of their medieval furnishings and church plate. However the Lacock Cup's elegant simplicity, and its capacity to hold wine for the whole congregation, made it appropriate for use in post-Reformation worship. Having survived in near perfect condition, the Cup is a testament to the deep regard and care which the people of St Cyriac's invested in it.

The Lacock Cup is currently on tour around the UK, on display from today at Wiltshire Museum http://ow.ly/5fTL3002zwK

Jean-Léon Gérôme, one of the most prominent academic artists in 19th-century France, was born #onthisday in 1824. In 1856, he visited Egypt for the first time and would later travel widely in the Middle East. Reflecting European stereotypes of the Near East, his precisely detailed scenes were largely dedicated to subjects of violence and sensuality, but also included scenes of caravans, markets and prayer. 

This drawing from around 1886 is a study of a girl playing a stringed instrument. Gérôme has transcribed with care the costume and elaborate hair of the musician. The woman's eyes are hidden behind her hair, but her open mouth suggests that she is singing as she plays her instrument http://ow.ly/GXJFD

Katsushika Hokusai died #onthisday in 1849. Hokusai is one of the most famous Japanese artists, and a key figure of the ukiyo-e ('floating world') school 🌊

These prints all come from his series Fugaku sanjūrokkei ('Thirty-six Views of Mt Fuji') made around 1829–1832. The major factor in establishing landscape as a new genre of ukiyo-e print was probably the sudden availability in the later 1820s of cheap Berlin blue. This strong, brilliant pigment could be used for water and sky, and would not fade. Hokusai used this new blue pigment to revolutionary effect in this series.

The sweet smell of success? Today's #MysteryObject is an incense burner from Iran. Incense was used to sweeten the smells of houses, temples, palaces and tombs. This magnificent object is cast from copper alloy and was used as a portable incense burner. It probably dates to about the 1st–3rd centuries AD http://ow.ly/4nuzcN
Any ideas what today's #MysteryObject would have been used for?

#onthisday in 1941, the British Museum was badly damaged by fire following an air raid during the Blitz. However, the Museum had made plans for this eventuality. Towards the end of August 1939, when war seemed inevitable, the first container vans were sent to the Museum to start packing up items to protect them from damage during anticipated air raids. The Museum's collection was evacuated to locations around the country, including Aldwych Tube in London and Aberystwyth Quarry in Wales.

In total six bombs fell on the Museum during the Second World War, with the final bomb on 10 May 1941 causing serious damage and fire which destroyed some of what had remained at the Museum, including 250,000 books.

The Museum reopened some of its galleries on 24 April 1946, but it was many years before all the damage was repaired. These images from our archives show some of the damage caused by the air raids and resulting fires http://ow.ly/jN0v3004fKj

Lincoln Cathedral was consecrated #onthisday in 1092, having been commissioned by William the Conqueror. After a number of fires and earthquakes some of the cathedral had to be rebuilt, and it took on a Gothic style of architecture. When the central spire was eventually raised in 1300, it became the tallest building in the world, taking the top spot from the Great Pyramid of Giza. This lasted until 1549 when the spire collapsed. 

This beautiful watercolour by J M W Turner from 1795 shows the cathedral towers rising above the Exchequer Gate http://ow.ly/MjHob

Archaeologist Howard Carter was born #onthisday in 1874. Carter became world famous when he discovered the tomb of Tutankhamun in November 1922. Tutankhamun's is the only tomb dating from Egypt's New Kingdom (c. 1550–1069 BC) to have been found substantially intact. The contents provide an unequalled insight into royal funerary practices, art and craftsmanship of the period http://ow.ly/MwUAX

This image showing the antechamber of the tomb of Tutankhamun is part of Carter's excavation records which are kept in the The Griffith Institute - University of Oxford.
Colossal statue of a Ptolemaic king. Thonis-Heracleion, 3rd century BC. Maritime Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

This limestone head of a male statue, probably made between 475 and 450 BC, comes from the Sanctuary of Apollo (now in modern Cyprus). In 526–525 BC Cyprus was absorbed into the Persian Empire which, since the fall of Babylon in 539 BC, included Syria and Phoenicia. 

Freedom of movement within the Persian Empire intensified contact between these areas. Cypriot sculptors became more dependent on East Greek models and influenced by Phoenician taste. In this statue the short hair, secured by a laurel wreath decorated with rosettes, is East Greek, as is the smile on the lips. However, the double bank of snake curls on the forehead, and the treatment of the artificially curled beard, reflect Persian influence. 

You can explore this 2,500-year-old limestone head from all angles and print it in 3D on Sketchfab! http://ow.ly/4nrZlp
link_name: Cypriot limestone head by The British Museum - 3D model

status_message:
'For 1,000 years, Thonis-Heracleion was completely submerged. Fish made their homes among the rubble of mighty temples; hieroglyphs gathered algae. Gods and kings sat in stasis, powerless, their statues slowly withdrawing from the world, one inch of sand at a time.'

Discover how these #SunkenCities of ancient Egypt were uncovered in this CNN article about our blockbuster exhibition, opening 19 May http://ow.ly/4nunOm

Head of a Greek (Ptolemaic) ruler represented as a pharaoh, discovered in a statue dump at Canopus, 3rd century BC. Bibliotheca Alexandrina Antiquities Museum. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

David Hume, philosopher, historian and key figure of the Scottish Enlightenment, was born #onthisday in 1711. This drawing by Thomas Stothard was the design for a frame to an engraved portrait of Hume. On the frame's right side is the figure of Britannia who is dictating to the muse of History on the left. http://ow.ly/4nrT0u

Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore was born #onthisday in 1861 in Kolkata (formerly Calcutta, now in India). Tagore was a prolific writer and artist. His international fame came in 1913 when he won the Nobel Prize for Literature for Gitanjali, a collection of poetry initially brought out in Bengali in 1910 and then translated by the poet and published in English in 1912 with an introduction by W B Yeats and a cover by William Rothenstein.
 
This ink drawing by Tagore is of a stylised animal depicted in profile. It seems to have three legs, a head with one eye and a long tail with a tuft at the end, very likely his rendering of the humped bull or zebu (humped cattle) found in India http://ow.ly/wzW8Z

status_message: Artist Ernst Ludwig Kirchner was born #onthisday in 1880. Kirchner founded the German Expressionist group 'Die Brücke' in June 1905 with fellow artists Erich Heckel, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff and Fritz Bleyl. They revived older media, particularly woodcut prints http://ow.ly/4mZvdQ

On Ascension Day, here's the biblical scene depicted by Albrecht Dürer in a woodcut from 1510. The print depicts an empty tomb in the centre, surrounded by the apostles and the Virgin looking upwards with Christ's legs in the sky. This work is an impression from a series of 37 woodcuts http://ow.ly/4nrOqu

Napoleon Bonaparte died #onthisday in 1821. This cameo by Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres depicts the 'Apotheosis of Napoleon I', his promotion to divinity. 

Ingres' first portrait of Napoleon Bonaparte had been commissioned by the city of Liège in 1803. He was to paint Napoleon several more times during his career. In 1859, Napoleon III (a nephew of Bonaparte) commissioned the sculptor Adolphe David to carve a companion cameo to the largest surviving cameo from the classical world: the Grand Camée de la Chapelle Royale, now in the Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris. 

Ingres made this design for David in the shape of the Grand Camée, based on his design for a ceiling in the Hôtel de Ville, Paris. The ceiling, executed by Ingres in 1853 (but destroyed by fire in 1871), showed the same subject as this drawing. Although David worked on this commission for 13 years, no suitable stone was ever found. The final cameo showed only the central group of figures http://ow.ly/4mYXDZ

Karl Marx was born #onthisday in 1818. Shown here on a 1980s badge, Marx was a hugely influential revolutionary thinker whose writings formed the theoretical base for communism. He wrote his most important work 'Das Kapital' in the Museum's Reading Room http://ow.ly/MwvOB

Submerged for thousands of years, the lost cities of Thonis-Heracleion and Canopus lay at the mouth of the Nile. Their amazing discovery is transforming our understanding of the deep connections between the great ancient civilisations of Egypt and Greece. Alongside the colossal statues found in these cities, underwater archaeologists have also recovered many stunning examples of gold jewellery.
This group of rings, earrings and pendants reflects the cosmopolitan nature of this society, displaying a variety of artistic styles relating to the many cultures in Thonis-Heracleion. While the cobra is an Egyptian symbol, the ring engraved with a winged Nike – the personification of victory – shows Greek influence. The hoop earrings with a mythical creature are inspired by motifs commonly found in the Middle East, associated with Persian craftsmen. The majority of this jewellery was discovered in temples where they were probably deposited as offerings http://ow.ly/4n7Ep6 

Discover more incredible objects in our #SunkenCities exhibition, opening in 2 weeks! http://ow.ly/4n4QBS
May the fourth be with you! Here's a chocolate coin featuring Darth Vader for #StarWarsDay http://ow.ly/M32dL

Today's #MysteryObject is an ancient Egyptian bronze hinge, which probably comes from one of the many monumental doorways of a temple in Thebes. Although there are extensive remains of the stone parts of these structures, little remains of the door and doorway furniture and fittings, which were often taken down and reused. 

The hinge is inscribed with the names of Amenirdis I and Shepenwepet II, both of whom held the important religious office of 'God's Wife of Amun'. Amenirdis was the sister of King Piye, who was the first major ruler in Egypt of the Kushite Dynasty (referred to as the 25th Dynasty). He installed his sister in this position in order to maintain control of the southern region of Egypt, administered from Thebes. The holder of the office was celibate, and the successor was adopted by the current holder. Amenirdis adopted Piye's daughter, her own niece, Shepenwepet II. http://ow.ly/4mYU23
Can you guess what this week's #MysteryObject would have been used for? (Hint: it's 38cm long)

'Never was anything great achieved without danger' 

Italian Renaissance historian, politician and writer Machiavelli was born #onthisday in 1469, depicted here in this engraving. This quote comes from his most famous work 'The Prince' (II Principe) http://ow.ly/wpKUB

In May 1061 the Normans began their conquest of Sicily, a key moment explored in our #SicilyExhibition. The Normans were Christian descendants of the Vikings ('north men') who had settled in northern France. Around AD 1000, groups of Normans left France for southern Italy. After earlier raids on Sicily, the Norman brothers Count Robert Guiscard and Duke Roger de Hauteville began a full-scale conquest of the island in May 1061, supposedly with only 450 knights. It took them until 1072 to reach Palermo, and only took it after a long siege. Eventually, the conquest of the island would take 30 years. This was partly due to a rebellion against their rule in the south of Italy at the same time, but mostly because warfare was necessarily seasonal – ships had trouble making the crossing to the island during winter. Over time, the Normans realised that in order to found a successful new kingdom, the existing populations of the island – Muslims, Orthodox Greeks and Jews – needed to be integrated in society, not marginalised. Under Roger's son, King Roger II, this multiculturalism became much more visible in the island's art and architecture.
Discover more about this important period in the #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/4n6E7g

Leonardo da Vinci died #onthisday in 1519. One of the great creative minds of the Italian Renaissance, Leonardo was hugely influential as an artist and sculptor but also as an engineer, scientist and inventor. Though many of his works were never finished, and even fewer have survived, he influenced generations of artists.

These drawings are part of a group of six studies by Leonardo showing the Virgin and the infant Christ who holds, or plays with, a cat. The forms twist and turn within the space and in the most complete version of the composition, the moving figures form a triangle or pyramid, a geometrical composition that is typical of Leonardo's work. Although Leonardo made a number of these drawings, no painting of the Virgin and Child with Cat survives. The geometry and balance of the composition and sense of movement became characteristic of his High Renaissance style http://ow.ly/4mVIdd

Artist Mary Moser died #onthisday in 1819. She was one of two women who were founding members of the Royal Academy of Arts. Mary Moser gained her artistic reputation as a flower painter and in the 1790s was commissioned by Queen Charlotte to design a complex floral decorative scheme for Frogmore House in Windsor. This watercolour is a study of roses and marigolds http://ow.ly/DcSU1

Josiah Wedgwood founded the Wedgwood pottery company #onthisday in 1759. Wedgwood was an innovative designer, a manufacturer of high-quality pottery and a campaigner for social reform. Wedgwood was also one of the main promoters of a neo-classical style in the mid-18th century, considering the art of ancient Greece as one of the highest human achievements. From the second half of the century this thinking inspired a revival of classical forms and motifs in architecture and the decorative arts http://ow.ly/10F3xM

The Great Exhibition in London opened #onthisday in 1851. This was the grand showcase of a nation in the middle of unparalleled technological and industrial progress. These prints show its unveiling at the Crystal Palace in Hyde Park http://ow.ly/LZabA

Visitor numbers to the British Museum had been rising during the 19th century, but the Great Exhibition nearby helped draw in a record 2.5 million visitors in 1851.
#May is named after the Greek goddess Maia. She's depicted with flower garlands and wreaths in this 17th-century engraving by Dutch artist Jacobus Harrewyn http://ow.ly/10AuP1

Happy #MayDay! There have been – and still are – many rich traditions marking 1 May and representing fertility and warmer weather in the northern hemisphere. 

The Romans marked the start of May with the Floralia. They held a five-day festival to honour Flora, the Roman goddess of flowers, which was declared a holiday by Julius Caesar. People would dance, gather flowers and celebrate with public games, theatre and merrymaking to mark the arrival of longer days and the start of the farming season. 

In the UK, May Day has long been celebrated with a mix of Anglo-Saxon and Celtic traditions. The Celtic festival of Beltane takes place on 1 May. In Celtic tradition, the sun was held prisoner during winter months and was released each spring to rule the summer sky. Other UK May Day traditions include dancing round a maypole, although there is no agreement on when it began, or why! 

Discover more about how this festival has been celebrated over thousands of years on Tumblr http://ow.ly/4n7vz6

The Queen of Sheba is probably the best-known and most enigmatic figure from ancient #Yemen. 

She first appears as an unnamed monarch referred to in the Old Testament (1 Kings 10:1–13, 2 Chronicles 9:1–12) as coming to Jerusalem to visit King Solomon, to 'test him with hard riddles' and bring offerings of 'spices, a great quantity of gold, and precious stones'. Her real identity – or even whether she existed at all – is unclear, but she continued to be remembered by later cultures as a powerful, even dangerous, lady. In later writings she is given many names, including Bilqis, Makeda, Nikaulis or just Sheba. To some people she has become a powerful female role model, to others the focus of sexual fantasy http://ow.ly/4n77Vl

Bilqis, the Queen of Sheba. Painted in opaque watercolour and ink on paper. Iran, c. 1590–1600.

Tin ingots in the shape of animals like this cockerel were used as money in the Malay peninsula (now Malaysia) from the 15th century. Many of the ingots which survive are in the form of animals, especially crocodiles, elephants, tortoises, grasshoppers and cockerels. This practice survived into the 19th century in the sultanates of Perak and Selangor. The currency systems of the sultanates also used more conventional forms of money, such as gold and tin coins and imported Spanish (later Mexican) silver dollars. It has been suggested that these tin animals were originally intended as talismans, weights or even toys, but it is clear that they were also accepted as currency. http://ow.ly/10Cchg 

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! Explore the history of money in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/10Cd3O

'The chief products of Arabia are frankincense and myrrh' – Roman author Pliny the Elder

A market for perfumes and incense existed in the ancient Near East and Egypt since at least the 3rd millennium BC. In the 1st millennium BC historical sources begin to refer to an Arabian origin for many of these. According to classical writers like Pliny, the most valuable forms of incense were frankincense and myrrh. These were two of the three gifts (along with gold) offered by the Magi or 'three wise men' to the infant Jesus in the Bible. Texts from South Arabia (modern Yemen) refer to many more types of aromatics, which became essentials in the royal courts, temples, houses and tombs. Their high value, light weight and long shelf life made them ideal trade goods, and their sale was carefully regulated. 

This week we're working with UNESCO to raise awareness of Yemen's unique cultural heritage, in response to recent conflict. Incense burners have a long history in ancient Yemen – here are some fascinating examples from the collection http://ow.ly/4n78D1

The stunning Palatine Chapel in Palermo was consecrated #onthisday in 1140. It was commissioned by the Norman king Roger II, under whose reign Sicily was characterised by an unusual, but fragile, religious tolerance. Roger welcomed scholars of all races and faiths to his court and a new art and architecture emerged from the mixture of influences, centred on the king's court at the Norman palace in Palermo.

Learn about the incredible chapel in this video with #SicilyExhibition Curator Dirk Booms.

This week we're shining a spotlight on the valuable cultural heritage currently at risk of destruction in Yemen, in collaboration with UNESCO and museums across the world http://ow.ly/4mZGG4

Each of the ancient South Arabian kingdoms seems to have had its own national god. Saba, the oldest kingdom in ancient Yemen, had a god known as Almaqah – a sun god whose motifs included a bull's head. These fine representations in gold, bronze and calcite, with exaggerated folds of skin around the muzzle and eyes, are characteristic of ancient South Arabian depictions of bulls.

Writer and women's rights advocate Mary Wollstonecraft was born #onthisday in 1759. This quote comes from her most famous work 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman', written in 1792. This etching of her was made by Anna Lea Merritt and is based on an earlier portrait by John Opie http://ow.ly/LVNt8

This week we're raising awareness about Yemen's rich and distinctive cultural heritage, as part of a UNESCO campaign in response to recent conflict http://ow.ly/4mZGG4

The south-western part of the Arabian Peninsula has been a centre of culture for thousands of years and the ancient South Arabians had many gods. Though the whole pantheon of gods is not well understood, we know that several tribal groups had their own divine 'patron'. Objects like this beautiful bronze hand and temple plaque refer to two of these local deities. 

By the end of the 4th century AD, monotheism – the worship of a single god – was spreading. References in inscriptions to other gods were superseded by Rahmanan, 'Lord of Heaven and Earth'. Such ideas were influenced by Jewish and Christian communities that had established themselves in Yemen at this time. Find out more on Tumblr: http://ow.ly/4n77H4

The Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius, who appears on the coin set in this ring, was born #onthisday in AD 121. He is best known for his philosophical work, 'The Meditations'. Although he was the most powerful man in the Roman Empire, he dwelt on the emptiness of glory: 'Shall mere fame distract you? Look at the speed of total oblivion of all and the void of endless time on either side of us and the hollowness of applause... For the whole earth is but a point, and of this what a tiny corner is our dwelling-place, and how few and paltry are those who will praise you.'

In the Roman world gold coins were sometimes set within gold rings for personal adornment. The image of the emperor was believed by many to be a powerful good luck charm http://ow.ly/10AoQf

Today's #MysteryObject is a navigation chart (mattang) used in the Marshall Islands, a group of more than 1,000 islands and islets located in the western Pacific. The numerous islands are difficult to navigate, as they are so low they cannot be seen from a distance. The experienced navigators of the region made charts to record the location of the islands, together with their knowledge of the swell and wave patterns. These charts were constructed from sticks tied together. The horizontal and vertical sticks are intended as supports to the chart, while diagonal and curved ones represent wave swells. The information was memorised and the charts would not be carried on voyages. This chart is of the type known as a mattang, specifically made for the purpose of training people selected to be navigators. Such charts depict general information about swell movements around one or more small islands http://ow.ly/10ArWX
Can you guess what this week's #MysteryObject was used for?

Artist Eugène Delacroix was born #onthisday in 1798. Delacroix was at the head of the Romantic movement in France. The emotional intensity of his work, its exotic subject matter, and his pioneering use of colour all had an impact on the course of French art. He also produced a suite of animal studies, a genre that earned him great popularity.

The south-western part of the Arabian Peninsula (modern Yemen) has been a centre of culture for thousands of years, and this week we're highlighting its fragile heritage as part of a UNESCO campaign http://ow.ly/4mZGG4 

We'll be sharing objects from the collection that show the range and significance of this distinctive culture. We get a glimpse of the people of ancient Yemen in unique personal sculptures like these. Although each is recognisably from this region, the variations in detail, style of dress and facial appearance suggest that there was great effort to represent real individuals http://ow.ly/4n4oxz

We are working with UNESCO and nine other museums across the world to raise awareness of the damage to cultural heritage in Yemen during recent conflict. This week we will shine a spotlight on the current destruction and encourage people to explore and understand the region's rich legacy. In this video Curator St John Simpson explains why Yemeni culture is so important http://ow.ly/4n4htg

Good luck to everyone taking part in the #LondonMarathon today! Although never part of the ancient Olympic Games, the marathon does have ancient Greek origins. According to Herodotus, when the Athenians learned that the Persians had landed at Marathon on the way to attack Athens in 490 BC, a messenger named Pheidippides ran to Sparta with a request for help. This original 'marathon runner' covered 260km of rugged terrain in less than two days! The Persians were subsequently defeated at the Battle of Marathon. The word marathon is the Greek word for fennel, which seems to have grown in the area and gave the battlefield its name.

Find out more about the modern marathon's ancient origins on Tumblr http://ow.ly/4mYqfa

J M W Turner is thought to have been born #onthisday in 1775. Turner entered the Royal Academy Schools aged 14. He worked as a landscape watercolourist, but from the mid-1790s, he also began to paint in oils. By attempting to paint Romantic subjects of disasters in extreme weather conditions, with historical and mythological themes, his intention was to show that landscape painting could convey the emotional range of subject or history painting. 

During the 1830s, Turner's painting became increasingly bold and free. He worked in jewel-like bright colours as well as luminous pale ones, with forms dissolving in what John Constable described as 'tinted steam'. The Museum has one of the finest collections of Turner's finished watercolours – here is a selection for you to enjoy!

Happy #StGeorgesDay! This medieval pilgrim badge shows St George slaying the dragon and rescuing Lady Una. St George was probably born in the late 3rd century AD in Cappadocia, now in Turkey. He was a Christian soldier in the Roman army who refused to make a sacrifice to the Roman gods, and was executed on the orders of the Roman emperor Diocletian. He became venerated as a Christian saint and martyr and was made patron saint of England in 1222. 

Hundreds of pilgrim badges like this have been found in Britain. These personal objects vividly bring to life the faith of medieval Christians. Going on pilgrimage was an important part of Christian belief in medieval Europe and pilgrims often travelled hundreds, even thousands, of miles to visit a saint's shrine. People wore these badges attached to clothes and hats or around the neck to show where they had been on pilgrimage. This badge was probably a souvenir of a pilgrimage to Windsor. The Royal Chapel there contained relics of St George and was the centre for an important order of knights, the Order of the Garter http://ow.ly/10zvPD

William Shakespeare died #onthisday in 1616, 400 years ago. This engraved portrait by Martin Droeshout is from the Third Folio of Shakespeare's works of 1663–1664 and was originally engraved for the title page to the First Folio, published in 1623. It is therefore one of the earliest portraits of Shakespeare. 

The portrait was commissioned and approved by the compilers of the First Folio, John Hemmings and Henry Condell, both members of the King's Players, Shakespeare's acting company. The involvement of these men suggest that, despite the stiff and oddly-proportioned garments, this portrait is an authentic likeness of England's most celebrated playwright. An engraving is not worked directly from life, but from a flat model, either a painting or a drawing. Droeshout must have been given a painting or drawing of Shakespeare as a young man, from which to engrave his plate http://ow.ly/4mTBKB #Shakespeare400

Inspired by the Bard, explore our range of books, prints, jewellery and even a Shakespeare cookbook available in our online shop http://ow.ly/10zax2

At less than 1cm across, this tiny gold amulet from ancient Egypt will be the smallest object in our #SunkenCities exhibition! 

It represents the eye of Horus, known to Egyptologists as the wedjat eye. The wedjat eye is half human (the eye and brow), and half falcon (the vertical and spiral elements underneath). This is because it is closely associated with the god Horus, who could be shown as a falcon or falcon-headed man. Amulets in the shape of the eye were very popular in ancient Egypt for thousands of years, from the Old Kingdom to Roman times. http://ow.ly/4mYz50 

From intricate gold jewellery to magnificent colossal statues, discover more incredible objects in this blockbuster exhibition http://ow.ly/4mW3ha

Legend has it that #onthisday in 753 BC Romulus founded Rome. The myth is depicted on the back of this coin which shows the founding twins of Rome – Romulus and Remus – being suckled by a wolf. The design may have been inspired by a statue in Rome that we know from historical sources was set up in 296 BC, shortly before this coin was made. The Romans first started to make and use silver coins around the middle of the 3rd century BC http://ow.ly/10zlRE

These objects are ivory chess pieces from Sicily and will feature in our #SicilyExhibition opening on Thursday. Chess was invented in India, from where it spread to the Middle East. It reached Europe via the Arab conquests of Spain and Sicily, by crusaders returning from Jerusalem, and through Byzantine contacts with Scandinavia. The inclusion of chess players in court scenes on the Palatine Chapel ceiling in Palermo indicates that the game was fashionable in Norman Sicily. Its increasing popularity at English and French courts was probably due to their close contact with the Norman kings http://ow.ly/4mQXdq

The Venetian artist Canaletto died #onthisday in 1768. He came to London in 1746, seeking British patrons. Apart from a visit to Venice of a few months in 1750–1751, Canaletto remained in the country until 1755. His drawings combine elegance with everyday description, seen here in these four works from his time in London.

status_message: Sir Hans Sloane, whose encyclopaedic collection became the foundation of the Museum, was born #onthisday in 1660. Sloane's collection amounted to more than 71,000 objects by his death in 1753, including 23,000 coins and medals, 50,000 books, prints and manuscripts and a herbarium (a collection of dried plants). In his will, Sloane bequeathed the whole collection to George II for the nation in return for payment of £20,000 to his heirs. On 7 June 1753 an Act of Parliament established the British Museum with royal assent. This drawer was once part of the 'materia medica' – a sort of pharmaceutical cabinet in Sloane's collection http://ow.ly/10opHM

Leonardo da Vinci was born #onthisday in 1452. As an artist he was technically superb in every medium he used – silverpoint, pen and ink, black and particularly red chalks. Driven by his scientific curiosity, he studied the world around him in minute detail, making botanical and anatomical studies. 

This work of a bust of a warrior is drawn in silverpoint, a popular medium with early Renaissance artists. The detail is extraordinary – the armour, the curls in his hair and the splendid elaborate helmet as well as the incredible modelling of the man's face and the lion on his breastplate. Metalpoint lines cannot be easily erased and requires artists to carefully plan the design or run the risk of having to start all over again. Endless patience must have been required of the young Leonardo to produce the very fine shadows of the man's face, each a separate line http://ow.ly/10ok3O

Experience the Enlightenment Gallery after hours in this tour with Curator Janet Larkin. From dinosaur fossils to the solar system, discover how Europeans tried to classify the world in the 18th century, and find out about the Museum's founding collection http://ow.ly/10Fx2s

US president and one of the principal authors of the Declaration of Independence Thomas Jefferson was born #onthisday in 1743.

Artist Sir Thomas Lawrence was born #onthisday in 1769. Lawrence was a self-taught child prodigy: he was working as a professional portraitist by the age of 10. He became official artist to George III in 1792 on the death of Sir Joshua Reynolds and in 1820 he was made President of the Royal Academy of Arts. Portrait drawings were an extremely popular genre of art at this time and were powerful indicators of taste and status. Here are some of Lawrence's beautiful portraits drawn in pencil and chalk http://ow.ly/10obYn

Born #onthisday in 1484: architect Sangallo the Younger, who designed an early plan of St Peter's Basilica in Rome. He trained under Giuliano and Antonio Sangallo and also worked for Raphael. In 1520 he became the architect to St Peter's, but his design was later abandoned and a new design made by Michelangelo http://ow.ly/10p2J1

Today's #MysteryObject is a canopy or 'tengai', which hangs from the ceiling of Japanese Buddhist temples above the images of Buddhas and bodhisattvas. These originated in India as a sunshade used by the nobility, although they also suggest the foliage of a tree, beneath which people in authority sat to speak in public. In Japan, the tengai are usually made of painted wood on a metal frame and are often elaborately carved. This example has a lotus flower at the centre surrounded by rings of floral and scroll designs with gilt, copper and glass fittings http://ow.ly/10p4Iu
Tuesday calls for a #MysteryObject! Can you guess what this object is? (Hint: it's 60cm wide)

Artist William Kent died #onthisday in 1748. Kent travelled widely around Italy between 1709 and 1719, spending most time in Rome, Florence, Parma and Venice. In 1714, Kent encountered the decorative scheme representing Antony and Cleopatra by Ricci and Pellegrini in the Villa Giovanelli. This beautiful red chalk drawing depicts Cleopatra dropping a pearl into the wine and was based on an original painting by Carlo Maratta, now in the Palazzo Venezia, Rome http://ow.ly/10p31s

Septimius Severus was born #onthisday in AD 145, the first Roman emperor born in Africa. He was an accomplished general who, having defeated his internal enemies in a series of civil wars, went on to victories at the furthest frontiers of the Empire from Mesopotamia to Britain, where he died at York (Eboracum) in AD 211. In this marble bust he is shown with his characteristic forked beard and tight curled hair http://ow.ly/10s8Vf

Byzantine emperor Theodosius II was born #onthisday in AD 401. This gold coin from his reign was minted in Constantinople http://ow.ly/L88J9

Long before the #GrandNational, the ancient Greeks were champion chariot racers. Chariot racing was one of the most popular spectator sports in ancient Greece and the Roman Empire. Usually, teams of four (sometimes two) horses pulled a two-wheeled chariot round a course, called a hippodrome in Greek, and a circus in Latin. The races were often extremely dangerous for both charioteer and horses – crashes, injuries and deaths were common. But chariot racing wasn't just mass entertainment – it was a way that Greek city-states and their rulers could demonstrate their power and prowess.

Greek settlements in Sicily were mostly controlled by unelected aristocratic groups and rulers called tyrannoi (tyrants). Between 490 and 468 BC, Sicilian tyrants won no fewer than 17 victories in horse racing competitions, the most famous of which were at Olympia and Delphi. Monumental sculptures of chariot groups, portrait statues and trophies were produced to celebrate these victories, and placed in sanctuaries with inscriptions praising the tyrants and honouring the gods http://ow.ly/10rVcC 

Find out more about the ancient Greeks who settled on Sicily in our #SicilyExhibition, opening 21 April http://ow.ly/Z45SH
The National Gallery opened in its new building in Trafalgar Square #onthisday in 1838, having previously been in Pall Mall. Here's how it looked at that time http://ow.ly/Lodae

Poet and artist Dante Gabriel Rossetti died #onthisday in 1882. He founded the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood with William Holman Hunt and John Everett Millais in 1848. The brotherhood sought a return to the intense colours, incredible detail and complex compositions of 15th-century Italian art. From the 1860s Rossetti also became a pivotal figure in what became known as the Aesthetic movement, at the centre of which was the celebration of beauty and art for its own sake http://ow.ly/10iZXm

'A multicultural paradise' and 'a cultural and artistic powerhouse' – read new articles from The Spectator and The Times and The Sunday Times (£) on the splendour of Sicily and the incredible objects in our #SicilyExhibition, opening 21 April http://ow.ly/10rdtT http://ow.ly/10oL9k

Picasso died #onthisday in 1973, aged 91. As a painter, sculptor, etcher, designer and ceramist, Picasso has had enormous influence on 20th-century art. Suite 347, named after the number of its etchings, was created in 1968 when Picasso was almost 87. The suite was produced in an edition of 50 sets, and the Museum has one of the surviving few which remained intact. Find out how these 347 etchings have been conserved in this blog post http://ow.ly/10iBgM

The British Museum was one of the first public buildings in London to install electricity. Until the late 19th century the Museum was lit by natural daylight. Candles, oil lamps and gas lamps were not used in the galleries for fear of fire. The first home of the Museum, Montagu House, was replaced by a much larger building between 1823 and 1852, which was designed with roof lights in all the new exhibition galleries. Although a great improvement, the Museum was often forced to close early due to poor light in winter or during a London fog. 

In 1879 experimental electric lighting was provided in the Front Hall, the Round Reading Room and in the Forecourt and within 10 years an improved system had been extended to most of the public areas #ThrowbackThursday

This engraving from the Illustrated London News in 1890 shows guests at a private evening view of the Egyptian Sculpture Gallery, then recently transformed by the electric light. http://ow.ly/10onP2

This artwork explores our approach to health and prescribed drugs in Britain today. It illustrates the medical stories of one woman and one man, knitted into two lengths of fabric. Each length contains over 14,000 drugs, the estimated average prescribed to every person in Britain in their lifetime #WorldHealthDay http://ow.ly/10o9HP

Today marks the 120th anniversary of the first modern Olympic Games held in Athens in 1896. The ancient Olympic Games were held every four years from 776 BC to AD 393 at Olympia in Greece. Held to honour the god Zeus, the ancient Olympics attracted thousands of citizens from all over the Greek world. Athletes competed as individuals, but a victory would also bring great honour to their home city. Over the long history of the ancient Games, huge numbers of athletes were immortalised by statues and songs written in their honour. Victors were granted the privilege of having a statue of themselves set up at Olympia, the oldest sanctuary of Zeus, which became a sort of athletic 'hall of fame'. At the first 13 Olympics the only event was the foot race. Later, more events were added including the pentathlon, combat sports and chariot racing.

Since 1896 the modern Olympic Games have also taken place every four years, but moved to a new city each time. Many of the competitions of the modern Olympic Games are inspired by ancient games and sports. These objects tell the history of the ancient and modern Olympic Games http://ow.ly/10lMBK

Raphael died #onthisday in 1520. Born in Urbino in 1483, Raphael trained with his father and then the Umbrian artist Perugino. From around 1504 he worked in Florence where he was much influenced by Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci, learning from their depictions of the idealised human body, their understanding of anatomy and the suggestion of movement within these forms. With Leonardo and Michelangelo, Raphael is considered the third great artist of the Italian High Renaissance. His contribution to the art of drawing was a mastery of several techniques: metalpoint, chalk or pen and ink. His figures have a grace and classical beauty that was imitated by many later artists. The serene figures of his altarpieces, frescoes and cartoons are composed with balance and harmony http://ow.ly/10gbTC

This statue from Easter Island, Hoa Hakananai'a, was probably carved to commemorate important ancestors. These moai were made from around AD 1000 until the second half of the 17th century. The back of the figure is carved with designs, believed to have been added at a later date. 

Explore this incredible 4-tonne statue from all angles on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/10gtWL

status_message: Rococo artist Jean-Honoré Fragonard was born #onthisday in 1732. Here are some of his drawings from a journey in 1761 between Naples and France http://ow.ly/L1aq6

Today's #MysteryObject is a wooden cosmetic pot from ancient Egypt used for kohl, a black cosmetic for the eyes. The owner of this object, Ahmose of Peniati, served as overseer of works to many of the kings of the early 18th Dynasty, from Amenhotep I to Thutmose III. This pot for kohl is likely to have come from his tomb. 

The pot is divided into five compartments, four of which have associated texts on the outside. One says 'fine eye paint for every day', while the other three refer to the beginning and the end of each of the three main Egyptian seasons of four months each. This suggests that different forms of the cosmetic might have been used at different times of the year. Between two of the tubes is a metal loop which would have held the applicator stick http://ow.ly/10gqST

Pocahontas married John Rolfe #onthisday in 1614. In this print from 1616 she was 21 years old. Discover the stories behind some of the famous Disney Princesses on Tumblr: http://ow.ly/L78kr

'Epic blockbusters of the ancient world.' See this rare statue of a stumbling Greek warrior from Museo Archeologico Regionale Pietro Griffo in Agrigento in our #SicilyExhibition from 21 April. Read more about how these sculptures told ancient stories in The Guardian http://ow.ly/10gCww

The Roman emperor Caracalla was born #onthisday in AD 188. This large bronze coin was minted at the Greek city of Cyzicus (Belkis in modern north-western Turkey) to provide small change for the local community. In common with the rest of the eastern parts of the Roman Empire this community spoke Greek. At this point of time it had developed into a form known as koine (the 'common' language). This Greco-Roman cultural mix is reflected in this coin, which looks Roman in style and displays an image of the emperor, but has Greek text. Caracalla is vividly depicted dressed in armour and carrying a spear. 

This particular example has a Christogram (a monogram of Christ) scratched just behind the bust. This could have been added at any time during the 3rd century, until this type of coin dropped out of use in the 270s. The maker of this mark was a Christian living at a time when it was very dangerous to follow such a faith. To the pagan inhabitants of the Roman world, the image of the emperor was a sacred object, even when on a coin http://ow.ly/10fzDv

Come to the Museum for a week of family drop-in activities, inspired by the amazing shoes from the Islamic world in our free display in Room 34. Listen to stories and design, create and try on shoes! http://ow.ly/10fyQN

Famous for his fairy tales, author Hans Christian Andersen was born #onthisday in 1805. Here's an illustration of his 'Snow Queen' http://ow.ly/L10tf

Pioneering scientist and artist Maria Sibylla Merian was born #onthisday in 1647. She specialised in painting plants, animals and insects. For her period, her work is scientifically accurate and she is considered by modern scholars to be one of the founders of entomology, the study of insects. 

In 1699 she travelled with her younger daughter to Surinam, a Dutch colony in South America, where she made extensive notes and sketches, and collected dried plants and animals preserved in alcohol. She returned to Amsterdam, where in 1705 she published her work on Surinamese insects, the first scientific work produced about the colony. Merian was an unconventional figure – few women could have achieved in art and science what she did at that time http://ow.ly/10aeJT

The Admonitions Scroll is one of the most important paintings in the world. It was originally painted by Gu Kaizhi (about AD 345/406), considered to be the father of classical Chinese figure painting. The original painting is now lost, but is known through this close copy made over 200 years later. Throughout history, Chinese artists have sought to emulate Gu Kaizhi's 'gossamer brush line'. This scroll bears the red seals of Chinese emperors and private collectors who once owned the painting.

The scroll's full title, 'Admonitions of the Instructress to the Court Ladies', indicates the work's moralising tone. The scroll's protagonist is the court instructress who advises the ladies of the palace on correct behaviour. The poem was originally written around AD 290 to reprimand Empress Jia, who was accused of using her influence to manipulate the emperor and murder rivals, during an unstable time in Chinese history known as the Period of Disunion. 

Discover this beautiful Chinese scroll in incredible detail on Art Project, by Google. http://ow.ly/10blev

#April derives its name from the Latin word aperire, meaning to open (i.e. spring). Here are some lovely spring flowers to celebrate the new month!

During the First World War, many of the Museum's large sculptures were too heavy to move, so sandbags were used to protect them against German air raids. The most important objects which could be moved (including Greek vases and bronzes, the major Assyrian reliefs, the Rosetta Stone, and nearly the whole collection of coins and medals) were transferred to a station on the newly completed Postal Tube Railway, 50 feet below the surface of Holborn. Printed books, manuscripts and prints and drawings went in 15 vanloads to the National Library of Wales in their new buildings at Aberystwyth. 

This drawing from Imperial War Museum London and photograph from our archives both capture this moment during the First World War when the Egyptian Sculpture Gallery was eerily quiet, with the sculptures hidden away behind walls of sandbags.

Today we're sharing stories of the Museum's history and collection for #MuseumWeek.

The foundation of the British Museum's collection came from the physician, naturalist and collector Sir Hans Sloane. Over his lifetime, Sloane collected more than 71,000 objects which he bequeathed to George II for the nation in return for a payment of £20,000 to his heirs. The gift was accepted and on 7 June 1753, an Act of Parliament established the British Museum, the first national public museum in the world. 

Chiefly natural history specimens, Sloane's collection also included 23,000 coins and medals, 50,000 books, prints and manuscripts, a herbarium (a collection of dried plants) and 1,125 'things relating to the customs of ancient times'. 

The natural history collections were moved to a new building in South Kensington in the 1880s, which then became the Natural History Museum, London. The collection of books grew to become The British Library, which moved to St Pancras in 1997 http://ow.ly/107ssL

We're sharing stories about the Museum's history and collection for #MuseumWeek.

Spanish artist Francisco de Goya was born #onthisday in 1746. In 1799 Goya produced a series of 80 etchings known as Los Caprichos. These 'fantasies' satirise the vices and follies of Spanish society at the time – greedy monks, quack doctors and foolish aristocrats are all held up for ridicule http://ow.ly/102Tp2

Vincent van Gogh was born #onthisday in 1853. In February 1888 he moved to Arles in the South of France. When he had to economise on paint for several weeks he made numerous pen and ink drawings around the hill of Montmajour. Van Gogh described this drawing at length to his friend and fellow artist Émile Bernard:

'an enormous stretch of flat country, a bird's eye view of it seen from the top of a hill – vineyards and fields of newly reaped wheat. All this multiplied in endless repetition, stretching away towards the horizon like the surface of a sea, bordered by the little hills of the Crau. It does not have a Japanese look, and yet it is the most Japanese thing I have done: a microscopic figure of a labourer, a little train running across the wheat field is all the animation there is in it'.

In another letter to his brother Theo he stated that 'the two views of the Crau... are the best things I have done in pen and ink'. The other view he mentions is in the Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam.

The Great Court opened in 2000, a two-acre space enclosed by a spectacular glass roof and the largest covered square in Europe. The roof has 3,312 glass panels and each one is unique as the space is asymmetrical. It takes 2 weeks to clean the whole of it! #MuseumWeek http://ow.ly/105gGD
These photographs by Frederick York from our archives capture how the Main Entrance Hall, libraries and galleries looked in 1875 #MuseumWeek

Today's #MuseumWeek theme is 'architecture' and we're sharing stories of our building's history. The British Museum opened to the public on 15 January 1759, the first national public museum in the world. It was originally housed in a 17th-century mansion, Montagu House, on the site of today's building. Entry was free and given to 'all studious and curious Persons'. With the exception of the two World Wars, the Museum has remained open and free to visit ever since http://ow.ly/104MAS

Artist Georges Seurat died #onthisday in 1891. These drawings are studies for his most famous painting 'La Grande Jatte', which depicts Parisians at leisure on an island in the Seine http://ow.ly/KOblm
From experts on cuneiform to Korean moon jars, meet some of our curators in our video series #MuseumWeek http://ow.ly/1028OO

Today for #MuseumWeek we're highlighting some of the unusual and surprising roles in the Museum. Wendy Adamson is Collections Manager: Care and Access, based in the Museum's Department of the Middle East. Here she tells us the most rewarding thing about her job http://ow.ly/102zZk  

'I'm responsible for all aspects of caring for and safeguarding the department's wide-ranging collections. From storage to display, a quick trip to photography or a long trip to the other side of the world, it's my job to make sure every object stays safe! There are many aspects I love about my job (including jetting round the world) but the most rewarding thing for me is knowing that the work I do will ensure that the objects you enjoy today will also be enjoyed by your great-grandchildren.'

Image: the Cyrus Cylinder on an international tour in 2013, visiting 5 venues in the USA and Mumbai.

It's #MuseumWeek and today's theme is 'people', so we're introducing you to Museum staff who have some unusual roles! Michael Neilson has been the Museum's replication specialist for 20 years, and works in the Department of Conservation and Scientific Research, creating reproductions of objects in the collection. 

'My work crosses every department, era and culture. Projects can vary from replicating a Palaeolithic carved bone to making an intricate piece of modern jewellery. Although I usually make a 'one-off' copy of an original for a specific purpose, when a mould is made, it is always retained for future use. I've even used the moulds made by my predecessors several decades earlier! For example, in 2003 I used an old mould taken directly from the front surface of the Rosetta Stone to complete a model for visitors to touch in the Enlightenment Gallery (Room 1). Since then, I've made a further 25 copies of it which are dispersed across the globe.' 

Find out more about some of the interesting moments in Michael's unique job on Tumblr http://ow.ly/101WhC

Take a closer look, many objects like this incredible tabernacle have secrets within... 

Carved in boxwood in the Netherlands around 1500–1530, this object was designed as a portable object of private devotion. It is an outstanding example of the minutely detailed, small-scale works of art that were owned by nobles or wealthy merchants in northern Europe during this period http://ow.ly/ZOnnI

Today we're sharing some of our secrets. Did you know the Museum has over 120 mummies? The Museum hasn't unwrapped a mummy in over 200 years, but we're able to discover some of their secrets through CT scanning technology and digital visualisations. As well as human remains, there are over 300 animal mummies in the Museum – including mummified cats, dogs and even a 4-metre crocodile! #MuseumWeek
It's #MuseumWeek this week! Today's theme is 'secrets' and we're going behind the scenes. There's more to the Museum below the galleries…

Charles I became King of England, Scotland and Ireland #onthisday in 1625. This is an example of the cheapest sort of print available in 18th-century England. It was cut in a wooden block, printed in London, and coloured using a stencil. Such prints sold for about one penny each and were displayed in country inns and cottages. They were rarely framed and although many were printed very few have survived. As was often the case with such cheap prints, the design was copied from a more expensive engraving: in this case a print by Joseph Sympson in 1731 after Anthony van Dyck's portrait of Charles I on horseback, now in the Royal Collection Trust http://ow.ly/ZExqR

On Good Friday, this engraving by Rembrandt shows 'The Three Crosses'. He has illustrated the moment of Christ's death, when 'there was darkness over the whole land' (Mark 15:33). A flood of supernatural light illuminates the ground immediately around the cross. Dark shadows fill the four corners, and the two figures hurrying away in the foreground are silhouetted against the brightness. On Christ's right, the centurion kneels, his arms expressing the words 'Truly, this man was the Son of God!' This is one of Rembrandt's most formidable masterpieces as a printmaker. The extraordinary painterly effects must have astonished his contemporaries, and have rarely been rivalled since http://ow.ly/ZEzls
Planning an #Easter visit? We're open 10.00–17.30 today, and as usual Saturday, Sunday and Monday http://ow.ly/ZEwFp

Submerged under the sea for over a thousand years, two lost cities of ancient Egypt were recently rediscovered. Over the last 20 years, world-renowned archaeologist Franck Goddio and his team have excavated spectacular underwater discoveries using the latest technologies. Discover their incredible story in this blockbuster exhibition #SunkenCities ow.ly/ZCw4d
