status_message:
Japanese artist Koya Abe created a series of digital prints as a poignant response to the earthquake and tsunami that struck north-east Japan in March 2011, in which thousands lost their lives. Abe has taken images of famous Edo-period landscape and figure prints by artists such as Hokusai, Hiroshige and Kuniyoshi and radically altered them to remove almost all evidence of human culture from view. Even Mount Fuji, which dominates the landscape in several of the original prints, has been eradicated in Abe's works, emblematic of the toll that the earthquake took physically and nationally on the Japanese psyche. 

The Museum has acquired this landmark series of 26 prints, titled 'Animism'. One of the prints is on display in Room 94 until 10 April http://ow.ly/ZTfjO
Happy #Holi! These paintings depict celebrations of the colourful Hindu festival, which marks the arrival of spring and the triumph of good over evil

James VI of Scotland also became James I of England #onthisday in 1603, following the death of Elizabeth I. His portrait is featured in this enamelled gold locket known as the 'Lyte Jewel'. 

The openwork cover, set with diamonds, bears the royal monogram 'IR' (Latin, Iacobus Rex) for King James, the first Stuart king of England. Inside the locket is James' portrait by the great miniature painter Nicholas Hilliard. The 'jewel' was presented by James to Thomas Lyte in thanks for Lyte's royal genealogy tracing James' descent, through Banquo (whose murder is a key element in Shakespeare's Macbeth), from Brutus, the mythical Trojan founder of Britain. This was a political message which James wished to promote at court in establishing his rule as king of Great Britain, and the genealogy was displayed in Whitehall Palace for all to see http://ow.ly/ZEv6X

You can see this beautiful locket on display as part of the #Waddesdon Bequest in Room 2a http://ow.ly/ZEwws

'Have nothing in your house that you do not know to be useful, or believe to be beautiful.'

Celebrated British designer, writer and craftsman William Morris was born #onthisday in 1834. Morris produced a broad range of decorative arts from furniture and stained glass to wallpaper. His textile and wallpaper patterns are still in commercial production today. Morris set up the Kelmscott Press in 1891 with the aim of producing beautiful books. He commissioned designs from many artists, including friends Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti http://ow.ly/ZEusT

This is one of the most iconic (and largest!) objects in the Museum – a 7.25 tonne fragment of a statue of Ramesses II who ruled Egypt for 67 years. It was cut from a single block of two-coloured granite. Ramesses is shown wearing the nemes headdress surmounted by a cobra diadem. The sculptor has used a slight variation of normal conventions to relate his work to the viewer, angling the eyes down slightly, so that the statue relates more to those looking at it. 

You can now explore this object from all angles, and find many more British Museum objects available to download and print in 3D, on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/ZK2zG
link_name: Statue of Ramesses II, the 'Younger Memnon' by The British Museum - download 3D model

status_message: Ruff day? Don't worry, it's #NationalPuppyDay! Here are some of our favourite puppies from the collection.
Go behind the scenes with BBC Radio 4 as they follow the installation of our #SunkenCities exhibition, including this 5.4-metre statue of the ancient Egyptian god Hapy http://bbc.in/1WG3Xps

Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I was born #onthisday in 1459. He commissioned this 'Triumphal Arch', one of the largest prints ever produced. The work was devised by the court historian and mathematician Johann Stabius, who explains underneath that it was constructed after the model of 'the ancient triumphal arches of the Roman emperors'. Above the central arch, entitled 'Honour and Might', is a genealogy of Maximilian in the form of a family tree. Events from his life are represented above the left arch, 'Praise', and the right arch, 'Nobility'. These are flanked by busts of emperors and kings on the left, and a column of Maximilian's ancestors on the right. The outermost towers on either side show scenes from the private life of Maximilian.

The architect and painter Jörg Kölderer designed the overall appearance of the structure, and Albrecht Dürer designed the individual scenes and architectural elements. The date 1515, which appears on the Arch, refers to the completion of the designs. The blocks were cut by Hieronymus Andreae of Nuremberg between 1515 and 1517. This impression belongs to the first edition of 1517–1518 when about 700 sets were printed, but they are today very rare http://ow.ly/Zxyup

Read about the ongoing conservation of this enormous 3-metre-tall print on our blog http://ow.ly/ZG5zU

These unusual objects dating from around 950–750 BC are known as 'crotals' – globular or pear-shaped bells or rattles, which probably hung on a wagon. The sound they produced while in motion would have drawn attention to and enhanced the procession of the wagon. During this period wheeled vehicles were accessorised with a number of ornamental bronze objects, of which crotals were just one type. These three crotals were part of a large find of bronze metalwork found in Dowris bog, Ireland, in the mid-19th century, which included weapons, tools and elaborate metal vessels http://ow.ly/Zy46F #MysteryObject
It's #MysteryObject time! Any idea what these objects might have decorated?

This captivating self-portrait is by artist Anthony van Dyck, born #onthisday in 1599. It captures the immediacy of an autograph drawing and the backward glance suggests spontaneous movement. The unfinished state may mean that van Dyck distributed the print in this form among friends and patrons.

On his return to Flanders from Italy in 1628, van Dyck planned an ambitious project to publish portrait prints of distinguished contemporaries, which became known as his Iconographia. Initially he etched the heads, but he soon left all the printmaking to specialist engravers, supplying them with oil sketches and drawings from which to work. 52 of the 80 portraits published in the 1630s represent artists or art connoisseurs. They are shown elegantly dressed and at their ease, in a clear attempt to enhance the social status of the profession http://ow.ly/Zxxqw

This weekend, kids discovered the scientific techniques that have uncovered new information about some of the Museum's most famous objects. Today is #WorldPoetryDay! The scene on this terracotta altar comes from Homer's Odyssey – an epic poem written down around 700 BC. It recounts the mythical travels of the Greek prince Odysseus as he tries to return home after the Trojan War. During their travels Odysseus and his men land on an island, thought by the ancient Greeks to be Sicily. They find a cave filled with food, which they feast on. However, at dusk the cave's monstrous owner, a one-eyed giant shepherd – the Cyclops Polyphemus – returns. The Cyclops eats several of the men but Odysseus, known for his intellect, makes a plan and plies the Cyclops with wine and blinds him. This altar shows how Odysseus and his men cunningly escape from the cave, by hiding underneath Polyphemus' sheep when he lets them out to graze. Two rams amble by with men clinging to their bellies. The man on the right looks back at his unfortunate companion, whose face is pressed against the sheep's bottom.

Ancient Greeks explained the unknown through myths and legends, collected and told by poets. Sicily's fertile landscape and wild coastline inspired many of these stories. Find out more about the ancient Greeks who settled on Sicily in our #SicilyExhibition, opening 21 April http://ow.ly/ZK6Qu

Terracotta. Sicily, about 550 BC. Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi di Siracusa.

It's #WorldPoetryDay! This papyrus features a copy of an ancient poem. It is said to have been spoken by the Egyptian king Amenemhat (r. 1991–1962 BC) appearing in a dream of his son, Senwosret I. In the first part of the poem, the king warns his son not to trust anyone, and he describes how he was killed by his own bodyguard. He moves from the dangers that face kingship to describe his own achievements and ends by acclaiming the accession of his son Senwosret. 

The poem became a classic and many copies survive from the New Kingdom (1550–1070 BC). Copies that survive from the 4th century BC indicate that the text was still being read hundreds of years later. The interest that the text held for the original ancient Egyptian audience probably had much to do with the central nature of kingship and the dramatic nature of the poetry. This particular copy has an additional importance – it was first studied by Jean-François Champollion, the man who deciphered hieroglyphic script using the Rosetta Stone http://ow.ly/ZuKdY
The Roman poet Ovid was born #onthisday in 43 BC. These works depict scenes from his poem Metamorphoses, which tells love stories about the classical gods http://ow.ly/ZCumJ

For #InternationalDayOfHappiness, meet Hapy – the Egyptian god of the Nile! This colossal 5.4-metre statue of Hapy was discovered underwater in what was the thriving and cosmopolitan seaport of Thonis-Heracleion. It once stood in front of the temple of Amun-Gereb, where pharaohs received the power and right to rule over Egypt. The statue must have been an impressive sight for traders and visitors arriving from the Mediterranean – a promise of the wealth and fertility of Egypt. As the personification of the Nile's annual flood, Hapy was believed to bring prosperity and fertility to the country. He brought offerings to the gods of the temple and in return they ensured the wellbeing of Egypt.

See this incredible statue in our #SunkenCities exhibition, opening 19 May http://ow.ly/ZCw4d

Bauhaus artist Josef Albers was born #onthisday in 1888. Albers enrolled at the Bauhaus in 1920 and 3 years later was appointed by its founder Walter Gropius to teach the compulsory foundation course. During his 13 years at the Bauhaus, Albers experimented and taught in a variety of media and techniques, including graphic design and typography, but produced no prints. It was only after the Nazis closed down the Bauhaus in 1933 that he took up printmaking in the USA. These prints developed the abstract geometrical motifs he had explored at the Bauhaus http://ow.ly/Kf8CA

These exquisitely crafted indoor wooden clogs (qabqab) from Aleppo in Syria are covered in purple silk velvet, and decorated with embossed metal plaques and bells. They belonged to an Armenian woman whose family migrated to Syria in the early 20th century, and had been part of her grandmother's wedding dowry. 

Before the exhibition the clogs were examined to check their condition – the metal was tarnished and the textile dirty and peeling off in places. As such, they were treated by two conservators, one specialising in the treatment of metals, the other organic materials. Interestingly this work is often a combination of art, culture and science – the conservators and curator have to decide what to do, but also what to leave. The idea with these clogs was to clean, but not overclean, and stick down the lifting velvet in the right position as shown by the folds and wear in the textile. The marks where the clogs have been worn tell their own stories... 

This week we're sharing behind-the-scenes stories from our conservators and scientists for British Science Week.

You can see these beautiful clogs in our current free display in Room 34 http://ow.ly/ZgA8I

When the British government failed to supply sufficient small change between 1649 and 1672, it prompted thousands of shopkeepers and innkeepers to issue private tokens to fill the gaps. These tokens give a fascinating insight into the workings of trade and business during this time, but also city life in general. Spreading only as far as the knowledge of the shop or business extended, they contain information which is very local in nature – the name of the issuer, the business they were involved in, their address and the token's value. The sheer size of London, as compared to other urban centres, meant that there were more tokens issued in Drury Lane than in the whole of the city of Gloucester.

This copper coffee house token was issued by Timothy Child at some point between 1649 and 1672 and was to be used as tender in 'YE COFFE HOUSE IN RUSSELL STREET' – very near to where the British Museum is today! Coffee shops sprang up throughout London following the arrival of the first in St Michael's Alley, Cornhill in 1652 and became popular venues for people to discuss the news of the day http://ow.ly/Yrhzs

This statue depicting a warrior was made in the 5th century BC, and was found at the site of the ancient Greek colony of Akragas (Agrigento) on Sicily's southern coast. It would have originally been part of a larger group of figures, whether high on a temple or at eye level. Combat figures reminded the Greeks of their legendary past and of the ever-present threat of war. There are no natural reserves of marble on Sicily, so the marble used in this statue would have been imported from another part of the Mediterranean.

The statue has recently undergone conservation work at the Museo Archeologico Regionale Pietro Griffo in Agrigento, in preparation for our #SicilyExhibition. Conservators examined the overall structure of the sculpture and its marble surface, and the process led to some exciting new discoveries. They cleaned the surface of the sculpture with a laser and applied pads made of rice paper to treat areas of discolouration caused by iron oxidation. This helped to balance the different tones of the three marble fragments that make up the sculpture. Through the cleaning process they discovered that the warrior's helmet featured remnants of a painted palmette (fan-shaped) design. Ancient Greek sculptures such as this would have originally been painted, often in vibrant colours, but the paint rarely survives. #BSW16

See this statue of a warrior in 'Sicily: culture and conquest' from  21 April http://ow.ly/ZD78t 

This work was completed at the Museo Regionale Archeologico Pietro Griffo in Agrigento by technicians of the Centro del Restauro of the Assessorato dei Beni culturali e dell'Identita' siciliana.

This Renaissance turquoise goblet – currently on display in Room 2a as part of the Waddesdon Bequest – was recently examined and analysed by our team of scientists and conservators. When the goblet was assessed, the conservator found that the adhesive used to previously repair the object had weakened. This meant that the whole vessel needed to be dismantled and reconstructed. Museum scientists chemically analysed the glass of the goblet to highlight its ingredients, using the technique of scanning electron microscopy. This research confirmed that the goblet's production was consistent with methods used in Venice in the late 15th century. 

Learn more about this exciting research and other objects in the Waddesdon Bequest in a free talk by Scientist Andrew Meek on Friday http://ow.ly/YY6lm

Thousands of years before the striking of the first coins there were comprehensive systems of financial exchange in place. 

These ingots and metal rings date from the 14th century BC and were found at el-Amarna in Egypt. They give us rare archaeological evidence for Egypt's earliest money system. Before coins started to circulate in ancient Egypt around 500 BC, there was a system of values based on weights of gold, silver and copper. Metal measured in units of weight known as deben (around 90g) could be used to settle bills and to trade. Egypt had no easily accessible source of silver, but the Egyptian word for silver, hedj, came to mean something close to 'money'. The complete ingots from el-Amarna weigh around 3 deben (265–286g) and the rings seem to be fractions of the deben http://ow.ly/Yrguu #MoneyFact

Many Museum objects are treasures, but did you know that 'Treasure' has a very specific definition in England and Wales? You can find out what that is at finds.org.uk/treasure

The British Museum is responsible for administering the Treasure Act 1996. As part of this process, every Wednesday morning, the Museum's metals conservators work on newly found Treasure objects. Conservators examine each find, investigating its context as well as carrying out chemical and physical treatments to reveal enough detail for identification. Where coins are found it is necessary to determine, as far as possible, the legend stamped on each side so that experts are able to identify each one. This conservation treatment means that it's possible to identify many coins and gain valuable insights into the objects that would otherwise be lost. 

This week we're sharing a behind-the-scenes glimpse into the work of our scientists and conservators for #BritishScienceWeek!

This week, to celebrate Global Money Week, we're sharing interesting stories about money from around the world! 

Throughout history currency has taken many different forms. The worth of a material can be based on a number of factors, including its availability, versatility or simply its aesthetic qualities.

This feather money is used as a form of currency in the Melanesian island group of Santa Cruz (south-east of the Solomon Islands and north of Vanuatu). This currency, known as 'tevau', is formed as coils resembling long belts. It is used to make payments to a bride's family, for purchasing pigs and large canoes. The supply is limited by the availability of these feathers and the man-hours involved in its manufacture. The production of the feather coils is limited to just a few hereditary specialists, working on one island, who are thought to receive their skills from spirits. The value of a coil is dependent on its condition – newly made, vividly coloured examples are most valuable http://ow.ly/Yroyd 

From the earliest evidence, to the latest developments in digital technology, explore the amazing history of money in our Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/YqouT

The nine turquoise mosaics in the British Museum's Mexico Gallery (Room 27) are famous for their high quality and amazing craftsmanship. Extensive studies undertaken by the Museum's scientists have now revealed striking new insights about how they were made and from which raw materials. The research shows that skilled woodworkers, lapidaries and mosaic-setters drew on a great array of materials gathered through the far-reaching trading and tribute networks of the Aztec empire, which at its height encompassed much of Central America. The combination of colours, materials and iconography in the mosaics was intrinsic to their high status and the purposes for which they were made – they were probably worn or used by priests and rulers for religious rituals and ceremonies.

Discover more about the scientific analysis of these extraordinary mosaics in a free talk this Friday by Scientist Caroline Cartwright http://ow.ly/YY53U

The history of money can be traced back 4,000 years! We're highlighting amazing stories about money each day this week for Global Money Week.

In the late 4th century AD, Roman taxes were only payable in gold. It was by far the most valuable material available and was the most stable in value of all monetary materials. To ensure the continued purity of the gold coinage, in about AD 367 the emperors ordered that all gold coins paid in tax were to be melted down into bars before being turned back into coin. There were many forgeries and it was easier for the government to test a smaller number of large bars than millions of individual coins. Roman gold coins contained about 98% pure gold. These gold bars represent the intermediate form which the gold took after melting and before it was turned back into coins. http://ow.ly/Yrm5r

Explore the history of money from prehistory to today in our Citi Money Gallery #GMW2016 http://ow.ly/YqouT

Beware the Ides of March! Julius Caesar was assassinated #onthisday in 44 BC. According to the ancient historian Plutarch, a seer had warned that harm would come to Caesar no later than the Ides of March. This was later famously dramatised in William Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, when a soothsayer warns Caesar to 'beware the Ides of March.'

This coin was struck in honour of Marcus Junius Brutus, one of the assassins of Julius Caesar. The back of the coin shows the cap of liberty given to freed slaves flanked by two daggers. This indicates Brutus' intention of freeing Rome from Caesar's imperial ambitions and the murder weapons employed to do so. Below the cap is the day of the deed – EID.MAR, the Ides of March.

Few coins capture a moment in history with such stark and brutal imagery. Brutus had carried out the attack with some fellow Roman Senators in 44 BC when Caesar had come unarmed to address the Senate on 15 March. This day was known to the Romans as the ides, or the middle day of the month and was recognised on a new calendar system that Caesar himself had established just two years before.

The assassins, or 'freedom party' as they regarded themselves, fled Rome to Macedonia to raise an army. However, they were defeated by Caesar's allies led by Mark Antony and Octavian at the Battle of Philippi (42 BC). Brutus subsequently committed suicide http://ow.ly/ZiIT0

For #BritishScienceWeek, we're sharing insights into the work of our conservators and scientists.

Egyptian blue is a pigment that was used in ancient Egypt for thousands of years, often associated with depictions of divinity. It has many interesting scientific properties, one of which is that it exhibits visible-induced infrared luminescence (VIL) – this means it emits infrared light when illuminated with visible light. Because of this, we can detect whether the pigment is present using a camera sensitive to infrared. British Museum scientists have used this method to reveal hidden secrets in wall painting fragments from the tomb of Nebamun, dating from 1350 BC.

You can find out more about Egyptian blue and its scientific properties in a free talk this Wednesday by British Museum Scientist Joanne Dyer http://ow.ly/YY50O

We're celebrating Global Money Week with fascinating stories each day about money from throughout history.

During the English Civil War besieged towns were sometimes required to issue 'money of necessity'. This may have been to reassure mercenaries, or also simply to allow for everyday transactions. In 1645–1646, three royalist fortresses under siege produced coinage. When Carlisle was surrounded by a Scottish army, an order was published to every citizen to bring in their silverware. Overall, 1,162 ounces of silver was gathered on that occasion. During the year-long siege of Scarborough Castle, the commander, Sir Hugh Chomley, handed out the siege money himself to encourage the morale of those who were repairing the walls. The Newark coinage produced during its third siege is of a very good quality and includes weights of the correct official standards. Here are examples of money produced during these three sieges http://ow.ly/YqRaa

The Roman emperor Elagabalus was assassinated #onthisday in AD 222. This bronze coin of the eastern city of Tarsus comes from the period of his reign. As with many coins of this region and period it carries on the front a portrait of the reigning emperor, and on the back a scene with local significance. The reverse of this coin bears a depiction of the elaborate crown of the high-priest of the imperial cult in the city. The city had been granted the title of neokoros ('temple-warden'). The crown worn by the high-priest of the imperial cult was probably made of gold, and was also remarkable for its decoration: representations of the heads of the reigning emperor, his family and predecessors. Eleven such heads are visible on this crown http://ow.ly/YnStb

This lion (one of a pair) acted as a guardian figure for a temple built by Amenhotep III (r. 1390–1352 BC). Originally inscribed by Amenhotep III, they were renewed by Tutankhamun (r. 1336–1327 BC), along with an indication that they were moved by his successor Ay. In the 3rd century BC the Meroitic ruler Amanislo moved the lions south to his city of Gebel Barkal (modern Sudan) and engraved his names on them. Unlike the traditional pose of the lion or sphinx, which lies straight with its paws out in front of its body, these lions are depicted naturalistically, lying on their sides with forepaws crossed. These lions also showcase the skill with which Egyptian artists could represent animals, even on a monumental scale http://ow.ly/ZcSYE

Over 3,000 years old, this incredible lion is now available in 3D on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/ZcSVT

Today's #MysteryObject is a Viking brooch which was usually worn in a pair by women to secure an overdress. Viking oval brooches have been found in areas settled by the Vikings right across northern Europe, from Ireland and Iceland to the Volga in Russia. Sienese artist Baldassare Peruzzi was born #onthisday in 1481. This intriguing pen and ink drawing shows a fashionably dressed young woman flanked by two young men. Over the figures are drawn a circle and pentagon, inscribed by Peruzzi with measurements, perhaps related to some architectural project. The informal, intimate nature of Peruzzi's portrayal of three figures is not typical of his work. Peruzzi was born in Siena but worked in Rome as a painter and architect and it is possible that this work dates from the period when he was working alongside the Venetian painter Sebastiano del Piombo in around 1511. According to Giorgio Vasari, Peruzzi was somewhat timid and felt uncomfortable around his noble patrons. At his death, however, Peruzzi was eternally honoured by being buried next to Raphael in the Pantheon in Rome http://ow.ly/Ynnf2

The Roman emperor Antoninus Pius died #onthisday in AD 161. This bronze coin, called an 'as', shows his portrait on one side and the figure of Britannia on the other. Britannia, the personification of Britain, first appeared on coins of the emperor Hadrian (r. AD 117–138), the builder of the great wall across Britain. However, Antoninus Pius (r. AD 138–161) also built a wall, across lowland Scotland between the rivers Forth and Clyde, known as the Antonine Wall. 

This coin, dated to AD 155, was common in Britain but rare in other parts of the Roman Empire. It may well have formed part of a special shipment of coin to the island. The image on this coin has long fascinated scholars. Some argue that the figure of Britannia is in mourning because she holds her hand to her forehead. The traditional explanation of this is that a British revolt had recently been put down by the Roman army. It could also be argued that the coin shows Britannia in a state of relaxed peace, perhaps in the act of drawing up the hood of her cloak. There is a shield at her side and a Roman army flag nearby in order to remind the local people of the protection given by the Roman army on the northern frontier http://ow.ly/YnnK7

'The true work of art is but a shadow of the divine perfection' – Italian Renaissance artist Michelangelo was born #onthisday in 1475. Underlying all of his achievements in the fields of sculpture, painting and architecture was a dedication to drawing. His drawings offer a unique insight into how he worked and thought, bringing us closer to him as an artist and a man. Michelangelo's mastery of the human anatomy was based on intense study, both of flayed corpses and of life models, which gave him a profound knowledge of the structure and articulation of the human body. Here's a selection of his impressive drawings.

'How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
I love thee to the depth and breadth and height
My soul can reach, when feeling out of sight
For the ends of Being and ideal Grace.'

This funerary mask was made by the Quimbaya civilisation in South America around 1,500 years ago. The Quimbaya culture developed in the central valley of the Cauca River, in what is now south-western Colombia. This mask is cast in the classic form of the Quimbaya style, representing a person with filed teeth and a nose ornament. The eyes on this mask appear closed, which is common with many Quimbaya figures in gold. This may be used as a visual device to give the idea that the gaze is not directed outward to the visible world, but rather focused on the spirit realm and the sources of natural inspiration. The ancient cultures of Colombia used a variety of metalworking techniques, such as hammering, casting and gilding http://ow.ly/YZ1MS 

You can now explore this beautiful mask in 3D on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/Z4C4n

status_message: Happy #StPiransDay! To celebrate, here are some spectacular views of Cornwall by a range of artists

Naukratis was the first Greek settlement in Egypt, a bustling centre of cross-cultural contact. It was located 77km south of the harbour city of Thonis-Heracleion, up the Canopic branch of the Nile. Naukratis was both a royal Egyptian port and a Greek port of trade. The site was discovered in 1884 by Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie, a pioneer of Egyptian archaeology. Since 2012 the British Museum has conducted new fieldwork at this important site. This has revealed the whole extent of the city – at least 600,000m2 in size with over 16,000 inhabitants. New excavation at the Hellenion, the largest Greek sanctuary in Egypt, has uncovered new evidence for religious practices, as well as material culture suggesting a high degree of cultural mixing between Greeks and Egyptians – but also Cypriots and Phoenicians.

Find out more about the rediscovery of lost cities of ancient Egypt in our exhibition #SunkenCities, opening 19 May http://ow.ly/YYrPF

Northern Naukratis in 2015 overlooking the excavations within the Hellenion and Dioskouroi sanctuaries.

English landscape artist Alfred William Rich was born #onthisday in 1856. Rich was known for his watercolours and his style was influenced by earlier English painters Peter De Wint, Thomas Girtin and John Sell Cotman. He held his first solo exhibition in his Croydon studio in 1896, as well as a major one-man show at the Egyptian Hall in Piccadilly in 1902, and was also included in the 1914 Venice Biennale. Here are some of his beautiful works.  
http://ow.ly/JUWsy

Vanished beneath the waters of the Mediterranean, the lost cities of Thonis-Heracleion and Canopus lay at the mouth of the Nile. Now mostly under the waters in Abukir Bay, the sunken city of Canopus used to be a major religious centre in ancient Egypt. It was particularly famous in antiquity for its temple of Serapis, where the priests practised healing by incubation (sleeping in a sanctuary to obtain divinely inspired dreams). Underwater archaeologist Franck Goddio and his team discovered the temple's impressive remains, as well as the head of its cult statue – which was originally more than 4 metres high. The head was found in a statue dump along with other stunning pieces of Greco-Egyptian art such as the elegant statue of queen Arsinoe II. 

Underwater exploration has also shown that Canopus was connected by a 3.5km long canal to Thonis-Heracleion. This sacred waterway was used during the Mysteries of Osiris, the most important annual festival celebrated in ancient Egypt.

The story of these lost ancient Egyptian cities is told for the first time in our blockbuster exhibition #SunkenCities, opening 19 May http://ow.ly/YYrPF

'The British Museum is undergoing a historic once-in-a-lifetime transformation, from being a physical place to a digitally connected place.' Chris Michaels, Head of Digital, British Museum

This week we're highlighting the Museum's varied partnerships, including a new collaboration with Google. You can now virtually walk through the Museum – the largest space ever to be captured on indoor Street View, putting the world collection at your fingertips. Plus, explore over 4,500 British Museum objects in the Google Cultural Institute http://ow.ly/YNkm0 

Learn more about digital projects created through partnerships at http://ow.ly/YNqnJ #MuseumOfTheCitizen
Today we're sharing extraordinary books from around the world and throughout history for #WorldBookDay!

This week we're highlighting our work with partners across the UK. More than one million objects, from hoards of Viking silver to Jacobean tableware, have been recorded through the British Museum's Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS). 

The millionth object recently recorded by PAS was a Roman coin in a hoard of 22,000 others dating to around AD 341. The copper-alloy coin, called a nummus, was struck in AD 332 at the mint of Lugdunum in Gaul (modern Lyon in France) and found in Seaton, Devon, near the previously excavated site of a Roman villa. The coin shows the personification of Constantinopolis on the obverse and a Victory on prow on the reverse. This very common type was struck by Constantine the Great across the Roman Empire to celebrate the inauguration of the new city of Constantinople, which was to become the capital of the Eastern Empire. The hoard is the largest of its kind found in Britain. 

Discover more about recent finds and our partnerships with organisations across the UK http://ow.ly/YNhNf #MuseumOfTheCitizen

Submerged under the sea for over a thousand years, two lost cities of ancient Egypt were recently rediscovered. The ancient Egyptian city of Thonis-Heracleion was named after the Greek hero Herakles. It was one of Egypt's most important harbour towns between about 600 and 100 BC. Located on the Mediterranean coast at the mouth of the Canopic branch of the Nile, the city guarded the western entrance to Egypt and controlled its maritime trade. The whole site consists of several islands, with a network of channels and port basins connecting the inland areas with the Mediterranean Sea and the Nile. Thonis-Heracleion was also a major religious centre – the two most important temples discovered so far are dedicated to Amun, king of the Egyptian gods, and his son Khonsu-the-Child (who was identified with the Greek Herakles).

Vanished beneath the waters of the Mediterranean, Thonis-Heracleion was only recently rediscovered by Franck Goddio and his team at the European Institute for Underwater Archaeology. 

Find out more about Thonis-Heracleion and its amazing rediscovery in our blockbuster exhibition #SunkenCities, opening 19 May http://ow.ly/YYrPF

These works are by French Impressionist artist Berthe Morisot, who died #onthisday in 1895. Morisot received significant recognition in her lifetime, exhibiting in official Salons, and alongside her peers Renoir, Manet, Monet, Degas and Pisarro in seven of the eight Impressionist group exhibitions. http://ow.ly/YYiCo #WomensHistoryMonth #5womenartists

Did you guess today's #MysteryObject? It's a cradle with a wooden board, foot rest and hoop from North America. The cradle could easily be carried on an adult's back, with the child tied to the board, and a deer skin placed over the top. Toys and amulets were usually attached to the hoop, including feathers, animal teeth, navel bags and dream catchers to trap bad dreams. This cradle features bells and porcupine spines. http://ow.ly/YKDNb

Rossini is shown here with rolled sheets of music bursting from his pockets while supporting three singers as characters from his operas: Manuel del Populo Garcia (as Othello in 'Othello'), Madam Mainville-Fodor (as Rosina in 'The Barber of Seville') and Pellegrini (as Figaro in 'The Barber of Seville'). http://ow.ly/YRXD1

This colossal 1,400-year-old statue of the Amitābha Buddha stands in the Museum's North stairs. Standing 5.78 metres tall on a lotus base, it's difficult to do conservation work on it, but in the past few months a team of conservators used scaffolding to examine its surface condition and carefully clean it. This also allowed an inscription on the Buddha's plinth to be fully read for the first time. The script names the Buddha's original location in Chongguang Temple in what was then Hancui Village, Hebei Province, northern China. Additionally it names 80 members of the Yi-yi, a Buddhist society which was very popular during the northern dynasties (AD 439–589), who originally patronised the building of this Buddha. The Department of Conservation also used scanning electron microscopy to identify the wood in the left arm of the Buddha as Ziziphus jujuba (jujube tree), widely cultivated in China for over 4,000 years http://ow.ly/YMLXC

The conservation of the Amitābha Buddha was made possible by funding from the Bank of America Merrill Lynch Art Conservation Project.
With only one week until #MothersDay in the UK, explore our range of unique gifts in our online shop! http://ow.ly/YHsYn

Sir John Tenniel, who illustrated the first edition of Alice in Wonderland, was born #onthisday in 1820. 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' began as an impromptu story told by Charles Dodgson (who used the pen name Lewis Carrol), a mathematics lecturer at Oxford University, to the daughters of a colleague (Alice, Lorina and Edith Liddell) while on a boating trip. Dodgson expanded his story into book form, published in 1865. Tenniel was chosen to illustrate this first edition. His illustrations were engraved on wood by the Dalziel Brothers, who ran the most important wood-engraving workshop of the time http://ow.ly/Ywaqn

The Roman emperor Constantine the Great was born #onthisday in AD 272 (or it may have been 273 as records differ!). Constantine had a huge influence on the development of Europe in the Middle Ages. Under his rule, Christianity was no longer persecuted, and his reforms led to it becoming the official religion of the Roman Empire (in AD 380). He also re-founded the city of Constantinople (named after himself) and made it the Empire's new capital. Constantinople (also known as Byzantium, modern Istanbul) survived as the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire until 1453, almost a thousand years after the fall of Rome in 476.
 
Another important legacy of Constantine's authority is his coinage. This silver argenteus comes from the very beginning of Constantine's reign, when he was still Caesar (junior emperor). The design on the other side of the coin shows the gate of a Roman military camp. This design was copied on coins of the Anglo-Saxon king Edward the Elder (r. AD 899–924), where it may have symbolised the establishment of fortified towns in the war against the Vikings http://ow.ly/YlPIv

Roger II, the first Norman King of Sicily, died #onthisday in 1154. Sicily's wealth made the island a prized possession and Roger fought off invaders from Rome, the Byzantine Empire and Islamic North Africa throughout his reign (1130–1154). Roger's dream was of an enlightened kingdom to rival these empires and he took elements of their iconography to position himself as their equal. 

Roger – shown on the left in this metal plaque – presents himself in the same pose and clothes as the Byzantine Emperor. He is being crowned by St Nicholas and holds Byzantine regalia. However, Roger has made the image his own. The names of Roger and St Nicholas are written in Latin, not Greek, and Roger's Norman roots are demonstrated by his long hair and the fleur-de-lis on his clothes.

Discover more about Roger II and the extraordinary period of enlightenment under Norman rule in our #SicilyExhibition, opening 21 April http://ow.ly/YlOCH

Plaque depicting St Nicholas crowning Roger II. Bari, Italy c.1140. © Museo Nicolaiano di Bari.

It's #PayDay, so time for a #MoneyFact! One of the most common designs on 1st-century Indian coins was an elephant accompanied by a triangle-headed standard. The design originated in the late Mauryan period (3rd century BC) and was used on the earliest bronze cast coinage of northern India. From there it spread southwards, ultimately as far as Sri Lanka.

The elephant on this bronze coin is contained by a square moat containing a row of fish. The inscription, in the Brahmi script, is incomplete but can be restored from legends on more legible coins as 'Rano Shri Satakanisa'. This inscription identifies the issuer of the coin as Satakarni, one of the earliest rulers of the powerful Satavahana kingdom based in the Deccan region of India. On the reverse is the ancient Indian symbol of a sacred tree enclosed by a railing. Beside it is a cross with four circles – the emblem of Ujjain, the Satavahana capital http://ow.ly/YGFlL

Explore over 4,000 years of history in the Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/Ndaru

French Romantic writer Victor Hugo, best known for his historical novels 'The Hunchback of Notre-Dame' (1831) and 'Les Misérables' (1862), was born #onthisday in 1802. As well as being one of the most prolific writers of the 19th century, he was also an artist, producing around 3,000 drawings. Working mostly in a monochrome manner in ink wash, Hugo created dramatic and moody works, drawing on the same Romantic sensibility that fuelled his writing http://ow.ly/Jn4vC
Legendary opera singer Enrico Caruso was born #onthisday in 1873. Here's a caricature self-portrait from 1906 drawn in pen and ink http://ow.ly/JASmf

This statue is of Idrimi, who was King of Alalakh in the 15th century BC. Alalakh was an ancient city-state (now in modern Turkey), and was part of the territory of Aleppo (now in modern Syria). The front of this statue is inscribed with a vivid account of Idrimi's life and achievements, including the political misfortunes that caused him to flee Aleppo, and the circumstances that led to his spectacular return. The inscription is one of the most important cuneiform texts ever found.

Three lines are etched on the edge of the right cheek and run down the side of the beard, out of line with the rest of the inscription. They appear to issue from Idrimi's own mouth. They imply that all those who read the text will learn from Idrimi's achievements, paying homage to his memory forever:
'For 30 years, I have been ruling. Having written my accomplishments upon my statue, let him (who cares to) inspect them thoroughly, and (thus) let (all of them) constantly bless me.' http://ow.ly/YlTCC 

You can also see this 3,500-year-old statue in incredible detail and from all angles on Sketchfab http://ow.ly/YFpCV
link_name: Statue of Idrimi, king of Alalakh by The British Museum - download 3D model

Pierre-Auguste Renoir was born #onthisday in 1841. He began his career as a painter of porcelain in Limoges before studying with Sisley and Monet at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. He was, with Monet, at the forefront of the movement that became known as Impressionism. The two artists painted side by side on occasion, most famously for their paintings of the popular bathing-spot La Grenouillere on the banks of the Seine. 

Renoir's paintings were always light-hearted, with soft-feathered brushstrokes capturing fleeting movement and mottled light. His later works concentrate on the female nude and he tended to emphasise simple forms and solidity, as well as relishing pink and orange flesh, as this study illustrates. Despite suffering from rheumatism in his last years, Renoir continued to work, saying: 'If painting were not a pleasure to me I should certainly not do it.' http://ow.ly/YJz9R

Eleanor Soo-ah Hyun curates the British Museum's Korean collections – something she never dreamt of growing up in New York City!

In this new video Eleanor talks about the need for the displays in the Museum's Korean gallery to change regularly – to show new objects and make sure others can be conserved. Sometimes it's like being on a scavenger hunt to find contemporary pieces that speak to the ancient objects… http://ow.ly/YHY0m

status_message: Charles Le Brun, who painted many of the ceilings at Château de Versailles, was born #onthisday in 1619. Here's a study for a section of ceiling in the Galerie des Glaces, which was also used as inspiration in Windsor Castle! http://ow.ly/YdxUY

Holy Roman Emperor Charles V was born #onthisday in 1500. He is featured on this incredible Renaissance woodcut commemorating the genealogy of the House of Habsburg. This family tree comprises 20 sheets that were meant to be joined together and hung from a height, or rolled up and spread on a flat surface. 

The tree itself begins at the bottom with King Pharamundo and ends with the Emperor Charles V, who was the Holy Roman Emperor at the time this was produced in 1540. He is shown seated about to be crowned and above him are four virtues: Justice, Prudence, Fortitude and Temperance. Little is known about the printmaker except that he worked in Antwerp http://ow.ly/YGQB6

Wilhelm Karl Grimm of the Brothers Grimm was born #onthisday in 1786. These four illustrations are proofs from the first English edition of their 'Children's and Household Tales' (Kinder- und Hausmärchen), illustrated by George Cruikshank http://ow.ly/YdS2b

'Strange to see how a good dinner and feasting reconciles everybody' – Samuel Pepys, famous diarist who witnesses the plague and Great Fire of London, MP and President of The Royal Society, was born #onthisday in 1633 http://ow.ly/YdpxQ

Recently discovered in Oxfordshire, part of this rare Viking hoard will be on temporary display in the Citi Money Gallery. Buried in the 870s in Watlington, Oxfordshire, this hoard includes 186 rare coins of King Alfred of Wessex and King Ceolwulf II of Mercia as well as Viking jewellery. The hoard comes from a key moment in English history and has the potential to provide important new information http://ow.ly/YEZs0

See these beautiful porcelain figures by sculptor Etienne Maurice Falconet on loan at Liebieghaus Skulpturensammlung, Frankfurt, in their current exhibition on the French Rococo http://ow.ly/YkUeY

These figures are ranked among Falconet's best known porcelain works. Falconet was also artistic director of the Sèvres royal porcelain factory. Under Falconet, Sèvres produced ambitious, sophisticated porcelain figures. Rather than serving as table decorations as in the past, these miniature statues were intended to decorate drawing rooms and other reception rooms. These works depict a scene inspired by an opéra comique, based on a story by the writer Jean de La Fontaine. In the story, the lord of the manor insists on his right to kiss the young wife of one of his tenant farmers after the wedding. Soon afterwards, the nobleman marries as well – and the tenant farmer insists on the same right, and kisses his lord and master's young wife!

Did our #MysteryObject get you in a tangle? This case holds a Viking comb found in York, the former Viking capital then called Jorvik. Both comb and case are made of several pieces of antler fitted together with iron rivets. The simple decoration on this comb set implies that it probably belonged to someone of middle rank. Both men and women wore their hair long in the Viking period and combs probably acted as implements for removing lice as much as for making the hair look beautiful. Like many smaller combs, this comb and case have holes in them for hanging from a belt or brooch. Comb cases were made to protect the delicate teeth from being accidentally broken, and this comb is remarkably well preserved http://ow.ly/YdtVd
For this week's #MysteryObject, can you guess what this case holds? (Hint: the case is 10cm long)

Baroque composer George Frederick Handel was born #onthisday in 1685 – Hallelujah! Although born in Halle in Germany, he moved to England and wrote many successful operas and oratorios (often based on Biblical episodes such as Solomon and Messiah, or ancient history such as Giulio Cesare and Serse). He also wrote music for royalty, including Zadok the Priest for the Coronation of George II (played at every subsequent coronation), the Music for the Royal Fireworks and his Water Music. This portrait from 1749 was made by John Faber the Younger. Handel died in 1759, the year the British Museum first opened its doors, and he's now buried in Westminster Abbey http://ow.ly/YdmUC

This hoard of Roman coins was found by a young boy digging in his back garden one evening in Muswell Hill, London in 1928. He had reached a depth of about 4 feet before he struck what was thought to be two pottery bowls embedded in the clay. The 654 silver coins (41 of which are now in the Museum) suggest that the hoard was buried in or shortly after AD 209.

The broken fragments of pottery were at first thought to be two bowls. When they were later reconstructed they turned out to be a purpose-built money box, with a slit for coins. It is a unique vessel, perhaps made by the owner of the hoard. We will never know why the hoard was never recovered but the money box is instantly recognisable to modern savers.

Find out more about #hoards and the intriguing stories behind buried treasure from prehistoric and Roman Britain in our free display http://ow.ly/YmarW
'Change alone is eternal, perpetual, immortal' – German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer was born #onthisday in 1788. This portrait was made by Spanish artist Rogelio Egusquiza http://ow.ly/IWQ6i

Our #SicilyExhibition opens in 2 months! Discover an island with a cosmopolitan history and identity – a place where the unique mix of peoples gave rise to an extraordinary cultural flowering. Happy 144th birthday The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, which opened #onthisday in 1872! This 1989 print by artist Robert Kipniss shows a view of the Museum from Central Park http://ow.ly/JnRne

Edward VI of England was crowned at Westminster Abbey #onthisday in 1547. This spectacular gold medal was the first coronation medal produced in England. 

The Latin inscription around the king's image translates as 'Edward VI by the Grace of God King of England, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith and the Supreme Head on Earth of the Church of England and Ireland, crowned 20 February 1546 at the age of ten years'. (The date says 1546 as until 1752 in England and Wales the new year began in March.) The same inscription appears in Greek and Hebrew on the back, the other two languages of the Bible, to affirm his legitimacy http://ow.ly/Yt5pt

This is the largest surviving example of an Assamese devotional textile, the 'Vrindavani Vastra'. This 9-metre textile was produced in Assam in north-eastern India in the late 17th century. It is made of woven silk and figured with scenes from the life of the Hindu god Krishna during the time he lived in the forest of Vrindavan. 

See this incredible textile and discover a little-known chapter of Indian history in our free exhibition in Room 91 http://ow.ly/Yag7J

Renaissance astronomer and mathematician Nicolaus Copernicus was born #onthisday in 1473, most famous for his model of the solar system which placed the Sun rather than the Earth at its centre http://ow.ly/Y9G1d

Designer and decorator Louis Comfort Tiffany was born #onthisday in 1848. He was the son of Charles Lewis Tiffany, who ran the prestigious Tiffany & Co. department store in New York. Trained as a painter, Louis Tiffany embarked on a career as an interior decorator in 1879. An initial interest in stained glass led to the founding of his own glassworks at Corona on Long Island in 1893, renamed Tiffany Furnaces in 1902. These are some of his famous designs http://ow.ly/Y7fFB

Mary Tudor, Queen of England and daughter of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon, was born #onthisday in 1516. During her reign Mary restored Roman Catholicism after the short-lived Protestant reign of her half-brother Edward VI (son of Henry and Jane Seymour). Her re-establishment of Catholicism was reversed after her death in 1558 by her successor and younger half-sister Elizabeth I, the daughter of Henry and Anne Boleyn http://ow.ly/IVRMk

Michelangelo died #onthisday in 1564. His artistic achievements set him in a class apart from his contemporaries. After the death of his main rival Raphael in 1520, he was to dominate the Roman art world for more than four decades. His primary focus as an artist was the male body, and his drawings chart his relentless search to find poses that would most eloquently express the emotional and spiritual state of his subjects. Here are two striking studies in red chalk made for the Sistine Chapel ceiling http://ow.ly/Y5nN6

'Entrancing... the romance of Rome in ruin' ★★★★★ The Guardian http://ow.ly/XlWIF 

Step back in time to the 18th century through an astonishing series of watercolours by British artist Francis Towne in our free exhibition. Towne made this remarkable group of watercolours during a visit to Rome in 1780–1781, drawing famous monuments such as the Colosseum, the Palatine Hill, ancient baths and temples, and the Forum. Together these 52 views of Rome are among the great creative landmarks in the use of watercolour within British art http://ow.ly/Yatfq

Renowned Japanese artist Kanō Eitoku was born #onthisday in 1543. These beautiful paintings are attributed to his workshop http://ow.ly/Y5lE7

OK, time to stop horsing around! Today's #MysteryObject is a horse's bit, the metal mouthpiece attached to a horse's reins. This example from Japan is nearly 2,000 years old! The Japanese are believed to have used horses in battle from the beginning of the Kofun period (late 4th century). This example was found in a tomb at Rokuya in Tamba Province. It shows advanced skill in the forging of iron and working of decorative metals: the end pieces have gilt copper overlay and the rivet heads are dressed with sheet-silver http://ow.ly/Y5gZL
It's time for this week's #MysteryObject! Tell us what you think this is…

Tutankhamun's burial chamber was unsealed #onthisday in 1923. The discovery was an incredibly important archaeological event. Tutankhamun's is the only tomb dating from Egypt's New Kingdom (c. 1550–1069 BC) to have been found substantially intact. The contents provide an unequalled insight into royal funerary practices, art and craftsmanship of the period.

In 1972 the Museum hosted an exhibition called 'Treasures of Tutankhamun', the most popular exhibition in the Museum's history http://ow.ly/Y5k4h

Charles Tiffany, famous jeweller, silversmith and founder of Tiffany & Co., was born #onthisday in 1812. These pieces were made around 1880 http://ow.ly/YluNN

The ancient Egyptians believed this mummy was incarnation of the crocodile god Sobek. Nearly 4 metres long, it is coated with resin and has over 25 mummified crocodile hatchlings attached to its back. Charles Darwin was born #onthisday in 1809, best known for the evolutionary theories published in his groundbreaking 'On The Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection' in 1859, which were to have a profound influence on future scientific theory. This medal was made by the French artist Alphonse Legros. Inspired by what he regarded as Darwin's 'powerful and noble head', Legros sketched his portrait on an envelope during a meeting of the Royal Society. The finished medal was enthusiastically received, the Magazine of Art noting that 'There never was such a head for a medal as Darwin's, and the artist has made the most of it.' http://ow.ly/XG1Ut

University College London was founded #onthisday in 1826. This etching shows a view of the building, then called the University of London, from around 1827 http://ow.ly/IzDOK

Oscar Wilde's notorious play Salome premiered #onthisday in 1896 in Paris. This is a design for an illustration by Aubrey Beardsley for the English edition of Wilde's play. Beardsley's style is epitomised in the sparse but elegant line, and the delicacy of detail. The lazy fall of Salome's cape and the disturbing perspective together create a sensuous atmosphere http://ow.ly/XE55q

Curator of the Citi Money Gallery Ben Alsop found a love note inscribed on the back of a coin in the British Museum. The inscription was simple: 'From Fred to Nellie, France 1916'. This is the tale of how Ben tracked down Fred and Nellie, and uncovered a 100-year-old love story http://ow.ly/YaDgY

The incredible Frome hoard is a highlight of our free #hoards display. Discovered in 2010, this hoard of 52,503 coins is the largest from Roman Britain found in a single container. This hoard is also significant as aspects of its burial suggest that it might not have been intended to be recovered. This challenges the conventional view that hoards were buried in emergency situations in the unstable 3rd century AD. It was found on high ground, near a spring, in a place that was used again for the burial of another hoard of coins around a century later, clearly a place with some longer term importance. The total hoard, weighing 160kg, was so heavy it could not have been lifted out of the ground without breaking the fragile pot. These factors together suggest that the hoard was a ritual offering made by the community.

Discover more about hoards and the reasons why they were buried in our free display in Room 69a http://ow.ly/XWDKH
Today #Carnival is celebrated in many parts of the world! This poster celebrates the 1896 festival at the Théatre de l'Opéra in Paris http://ow.ly/Y4RFS #MardiGras

Today's #MysteryObject is a group of three strigils or cleaning blades from around AD 100. Together with an aryballos (oil-flask) and a sponge, they probably formed a portable set for the athlete to take to sport sessions. Before exercising or competing, athletes applied oil to their bodies to keep the dirt out of the pores of the skin and perhaps also to avoid sunburn. Afterwards a strigil was used to scrape off the accumulated oil, dirt, and sand from the sports ground. Strigils are often of different sizes and shapes to suit different parts of the body. This set of strigils is decorated with scenes from the Roman circus, where chariot races took place that attracted huge crowds. This prestigious set must have belonged to a successful or at least a wealthy sportsman, with a keen interest in chariot racing or perhaps himself a winning charioteer http://ow.ly/XDuXO
Get your hooks into this week's #MysteryObject! Any ideas what these objects were used for?

Today is #PancakeDay! Traditionally known as Shrove Tuesday, it celebrates the last day before the Christian fasting season of Lent. These illustrations are depictions of traditional Dutch pancake women http://ow.ly/XWxTa

The Russian Tsar Peter the Great died #onthisday in 1725. He was fascinated by western European science and culture, and travelled widely in the pursuit of knowledge. He became involved in the minting of Russia's new coins. In the 17th century, Russian coinage was based on the kopek. At the turn of the new century, Peter decimalised the Russian currency, fixing the ruble at 100 kopeks. The royal House of Romanov, with the Tsar at its head, continued to issue these coins, with heraldic emblems, monograms and portraits, until the Russian Revolution of 1917 http://ow.ly/XAMFp
Dutch artist Jan van Huysum, who drew these beautiful flowers, died #onthisday in 1749 http://ow.ly/Y4JXs

To celebrate #LunarNewYear, explore a range of new objects on display in our Korea Gallery (Room 67) taking inspiration from the iconic moon jar. In post-war South Korea, artists became enamoured with round white porcelain jars made in the 17th and 18th centuries, giving them the name 'moon jars' for their colour and shape. Moon jars then went on to become a modern icon, representing the aesthetic characteristics of porcelain made in Korea's Joseon dynasty (1392–1910). In the gallery, you can see the work of several contemporary artists and discover how they have been inspired by moon jars.

In Chinese culture, each year is named after one of twelve animals of the traditional zodiac. Legend has it that 12 animals came to visit the Buddha when he asked for visitors. As a reward, the Buddha named the years after each animal as they came before him. It is believed that people take on the special qualities of the animal of their birth year.

Today marks the start of the Year of the Monkey. They are known to be entertaining, mischievous and love anything creative! Discover what your Chinese zodiac animal says about you! http://ow.ly/XRn1t

Happy #ChineseNewYear! These are called xiao hongbao, literally translated as 'little red envelopes'. Red is the colour associated with celebration in China. In the 1990s, a new style of money envelope appeared. Although it still had a red back, the front was printed in many colours and overstamped in gold. On this envelope there are lush peony flowers in full bloom. They are symbolic of spring, as well as feminine beauty, love and affection. In Chinese, the peony is known as mudanhua or fuguihua. The characters fu ('wealth') and gui ('honour') appear frequently in good luck wishes, and pictures of peony flowers add strength to the wish. The inscription on this envelope reads 'May wealth and honour blossom, in abundance year after year'. The arrangement of the peonies and the inscription is reminiscent of traditional Chinese flower painting http://ow.ly/XAPVr
Colossal statue of a Ptolemaic king. Thonis-Heracleion, 3rd century BC. Maritime Museum, Alexandria. Photo: Christoph Gerigk. © Franck Goddio/Hilti Foundation.

Artist Henry Fuseli was born #onthisday in 1741. Born as Johann Heinrich Füssli in Zurich, Fuseli altered his name to be more pronounceable in Italy and England where he spent most of his life. He spent eight years in Rome drawing from the classical antiquities and from Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel. In 1799 he was made Professor of Painting at the Royal Academy of Arts, where he taught both John Constable and Benjamin Robert Haydon. He was a friend of William Blake whom he confessed to find 'damned good to steal from'. Blake returned the compliment, describing Fuseli as, 'the only man that e'er I knew/ Who did not make me almost spew'. This drawing is one of many by Fuseli inspired by Shakespeare. It shows Brutus running onto the sword held by Strato (Julius Caesar, Act V Scene 5). http://ow.ly/XYWLm

Septimius Severus, the first Roman emperor born in Africa, died #onthisday in AD 211. He was an accomplished general who, having defeated his internal enemies in a series of civil wars, went on to victories at the furthest frontiers of the Empire, from Mesopotamia to Britain, where he died, at York (Eboracum) in AD 211. In this marble statue he is shown with his characteristic forked beard and tight curled hair, and is wearing military dress. Severus' two sons Caracalla and Geta were instructed by their father on his deathbed to 'pay the troops, get on with each other and ignore everyone else'. Within a year, however, Caracalla had murdered his brother and reigned alone, with all vestiges of Geta's image and name removed from buildings, official inscriptions and dedications http://ow.ly/XAmpq

Go behind the scenes and meet curators Peter Higgs and Dirk Booms as they reveal some of the fascinating stories behind the Greek and Norman objects in our forthcoming #SicilyExhibition http://ow.ly/XTmQX

status_message: Johannes Gutenberg, pioneer of the printing press, died #onthisday in 1468. Born in Mainz, Germany, Gutenburg invented the European technology of printing with movable type around 1447. This technical revolution was one of the most important developments of the modern era, spreading information and ideas far beyond what was possible with the previous methods of woodblock printing and handwritten manuscripts http://ow.ly/I20ZD

Today's #MysteryObject is a gold buckle, which would have been worn at the waist of a woman's silk coat or long waistcoat. It is part of a collection of 44 items made by a Kazakh mining engineer between 1904 and 1910. The Kazakh metalsmith's craft flourished in the 19th and early 20th centuries, when their work was actively traded in Russia. The most complete set of jewellery was bought or commissioned when a girl was to be married. 

Although the jewellery types which make up this set were similar across Central Asia, women's buckles were a particular feature of those from the Kazakh region. The two buckle plates are set with rhinestones and turquoise, with further turquoise in the hanging pendants, and in the five larger plates which are also set with agates http://ow.ly/XA7rn
It's #MysteryObject time! Any ideas what this object is?

Irish novelist and poet James Joyce was born #onthisday in 1882, best known for his great modernist masterpiece Ulysses, which recounts Leopold Bloom wandering around Dublin on 16 June 1904. Artist Richard Hamilton spent 50 years visualising Joyce's Ulysses, which was first published in Paris in 1922, the year of Hamilton's birth. This collection of works is in many ways the odyssey of Hamilton's own artistic career and reflects his lifelong interest in Irish culture and politics and his unique artistic experimentation. Its stylistic variety provides visual reflects Joyce's own linguistic inventiveness and demonstrates Hamilton's skills as a draughtsman and printmaker. Discover his works http://ow.ly/Xyr8p

Edward III was crowned #onthisday in 1327, aged 15. He was King of England for 50 years and his reign saw the beginning of the Hundred Years' War (1339–1453). This engraving from 1677 depicts the great seals of Edward III http://ow.ly/XyjJK

February is named after the ancient Roman festival of purification called Februa. This print from 1807 depicts a personification of Februa pouring water surrounded by two fish representing Pisces http://ow.ly/tj5Ei

The Xuande Emperor of China's Ming dynasty died #onthisday in 1435. Cloisonné enamel decoration dates back to the Xuande period, by which time imperial pieces were being produced, such as this large jar. The decoration is very similar to that on blue-and-white porcelain of the same period, however cloisonné consists of coloured glass paste applied to metal vessels. Various metallic oxides were mixed with the glass paste in order to colour it. http://ow.ly/XGCja
Guy Fawkes was executed #onthisday in 1606. This print depicts his arrest for the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 ow.ly/XGEBq

Born #onthisday 58 BC: the Roman empress Livia Julia Augusta, wife of Augustus and mother of Tiberius. This head from an oversized marble statue depicts her as Ceres, the goddess of cereals. The cult of Livia as Ceres, a mother whose fertility benefited the whole empire, became widespread, indicating the vital role that grain played in control of the empire. It was particularly embraced on Sicily, where Ceres' Greek equivalent, Demeter, had been worshipped for centuries. Sicily – dubbed 'Rome's granary' – was important as it provided an abundant supply of grain, which was used to feed the ever-growing populace back in Rome. http://ow.ly/XFKjK

This representation of Livia will feature in our #SicilyExhibition from April. Find out more: http://www.britishmuseum.org/sicily

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! Before the introduction of silver coinage, Romans used cast ingots ('heavy bronze') as a form of money – this example weighs 1.746kg! 

They seem to have been used as a means of making official payments, such as taxes or judicial fines. Their value was used as a unit to assess a citizen's wealth. The ingots were no longer made after the mid-3rd century BC, when the Romans moved over entirely to silver coins, but bronze remained important within the Roman monetary system. 

The elephant design on this example was probably inspired by the war elephants in the army of the Greek king Pyrrhus who invaded Italy and attacked the Romans in 280 BC. The pig on the other side may refer to a bizarre occasion when, in one of the battles, Pyrrhus' elephants were frightened away by the grunting of pigs kept by the Roman army! http://ow.ly/XGxcI

Discover the history of money in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/Ndaru

Artist and poet Edward Lear died #onthisday in 1888. Lear is best known today for his nonsense verse (and accompanying illustrations) which he produced alongside his lifelong activity as a landscape painter. He spent much of his life abroad, and stayed regularly in Corfu from 1855, using it as a base for his travels in the eastern Mediterranean. This was the beginning of a decade which produced Lear's most accomplished watercolours. Here is a selection from the Museum's collection http://ow.ly/XFxpm

Today we are delighted to announce our next special exhibition, which will explore the story of a remarkable island. Sicily has been shaped by waves of conquest and settlement. Since the 7th century BC, Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs and Normans all settled or invaded the island, lured by its fertile lands and strategic location.

Our #SicilyExhibition will be the first in the UK to explore over 4,000 years of Sicily's cosmopolitan history. Over 200 objects will reveal the island's rich architectural and artistic legacy, focusing on two extraordinary eras in the island's history: Greek settlement and Norman rule.

Book now for #SicilyExhibition, opening 21 April 2016 http://ow.ly/XD2Mq

Sponsored by Julius Baer
In collaboration with Regione Siciliana

The Roman emperor Hadrian was born #onthisday in AD 76. During his reign (AD 117–138), he famously built the wall across Britain, from the Solway Firth to the River Tyne at Wallsend, to protect the Empire from northern tribes. There are many known marble statues of him, but this head is from an example made in bronze, and is a rare survival. It was found in the River Thames in the 19th century and might have been made to commemorate his visit to Britannia in AD 122. http://ow.ly/XpPvh

Queen Victoria died #onthisday in 1901, at the age of 81. After 63 years on the throne, she was at that time the longest-reigning British monarch – a record surpassed by Queen Elizabeth II in 2015. Prince Albert gave Victoria this Celtic-style brooch for Christmas in 1849, and their royal patronage popularised the fashion for Celtic jewellery. The gesture was also political, a way for the royal family to show support for the Irish jewellery trade at a time when all Ireland was part of the United Kingdom.

See this beautiful brooch and other art from the Celtic Revival in our #Celts exhibition – until 31 January http://ow.ly/XgN8L

One of the Founding Fathers of the United States, Franklin was the only person to have signed all four documents which helped create the United States of America: the Declaration of Independence (1776), the Treaty of Alliance, Amity and Commerce (1778), the Treaty of Peace (1782), and the Constitution (1787). #onthisday in 27 BC: Octavian is granted the title Augustus and becomes the first Roman emperor – a title he held until his death in AD 14. His reign as the first leader of the Roman Empire was characterised by a period of relative stability after years of infighting. He was careful to present himself as leader of the Senate rather than as a king to avoid the same fate as his great-uncle and adopted father Julius Caesar, who was assassinated by rebellious senators that opposed him. http://ow.ly/X6Qko

'It is a fine seasoning for joy to think of those we love'
French playwright and actor Molière was born #onthisday in 1622. 

Born as Jean Baptiste Pouquelin to a bourgeois family, he took up the stage name Molière after he gave up his intended career in the courts for life in theatre. He spent years trouping across France, at first unsuccessfully but later renowned for his comedies, so much so that he received regular patronage from Louis XIV. He is now regarded as one of the greatest masters of comedy in western literature. ow.ly/X7efg

Queen Elizabeth I was crowned at Westminster Abbey #onthisday in 1559. This bronze medal features a bust of Elizabeth, wearing a crown, ruff and a rich dress. The reverse has a phoenix amid flames. The phoenix was adopted by Elizabeth as her device – it was the symbol of celibacy, but also of something that was incomparable http://ow.ly/X6F8h

Elizabeth was the daughter of Henry VIII and Ann Boleyn, and came to the throne at the age of 25 on the death of her half-sister, Mary I. Her 45-year reign was a time of relative stability and great prosperity, during which the Church of England was established, trade and exploration intensified, and the literature and arts scene flourished with the works of famous playwrights Shakespeare and Marlowe. Elizabeth never married despite having many suitors, and died without an heir at Richmond Palace on 24 March 1603. She was the last Tudor monarch and was succeeded by James I, who was already James VI of Scotland.

We opened to the public 257 years ago today, and now we welcome nearly 7 million visitors a year. Our aim is to reach many more people digitally in order to truly become a museum of the world, for the world – so we're delighted to now have over a million Facebook followers! 

Thank you all for your interest and support. We'd love to hear what you think of our Facebook posts, and what you would like to see more of on our page.

The British Museum opened its doors #onthisday in 1759, the first national public museum in the world. Entry was free and given to 'all studious and curious persons', and the Museum initially received around 5,000 visitors per year. 

Discover more of our history here: ow.ly/X5Ugo

French artist Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres died #onthisday in 1867. Ingres won the Prix de Rome, a prestigious travel bursary, in 1801. On arrival in Rome, he devoted himself to history paintings and prepared for a triumphant return to Paris. As a result of Napoleon's defeat in 1815, Ingres was cut off from potential patrons, and he turned again to portraiture to support himself. 

Although he disliked the drudgery of such commissioned work, Ingres drew many beautiful and intimate pencil portraits of his friends, and this style of portrait became popular with paying customers. In 1816, Ingres was commissioned by George Forbes, a Scottish tourist, to draw him with his fiancé Mary Hay. Ingres developed a composition appropriate to a betrothal, but Forbes was called away from Rome before the drawing could be completed. Mary's brother, Sir John Hay, stood in for Forbes, but Ingres refused to alter the composition.
http://ow.ly/W1Rbr
Artist Henri Fantin-Latour was born #onthisday in 1836. This lithograph from 1898 depicts a scene from Wagner's opera Lohengrin http://ow.ly/HaGPz
