status_message:
Roman general Mark Antony was born #onthisday in 83 BC. As Julius Caesar's right-hand man in 44 BC when Caesar was murdered, Mark Antony had the chance to succeed to his position as effective monarch of the Roman world. Foiled in this by Caesar's adopted son, Octavian, he became embroiled in an alliance, as much romantic as military, with Cleopatra VII, queen of Egypt. They were eventually defeated by Octavian at the naval Battle of Actium in 31 BC. In August 30 BC, they committed suicide in Alexandria, the capital of Egypt.

The couple are depicted on either side of this coin: http://ow.ly/X2Exn
Flemish artist Jan Breughel the Elder died #onthisday in 1625. Here are some of his beautiful drawings
Happy 90th birthday to Paddington Bear creator, Michael Bond! Here's Paddington on a Selfridges Christmas badge from 1983

Artist and scientist Maria Sibylla Merian died #onthisday in 1717. She specialised in painting plants, animals and insects. For her period, her work is scientifically accurate and she is considered by modern scholars to be one of the founders of entomology, the study of insects. 

In 1699 she travelled with her younger daughter to Surinam, a Dutch colony in South America, where she made extensive notes and sketches, and collected dried plants and animals preserved in alcohol. She returned to Amsterdam, where in 1705 she published her work on Surinamese insects, the first scientific work produced about the colony. Merian was an unconventional figure – few women could have achieved in art and science what she did at that time. 

This drawing shows a caiman crocodile wrestling with a red and black snake, and is now believed to be the work of her daughter Dorothea http://ow.ly/WZuh7

Artist John Singer Sargent was born #onthisday in 1856. Born in Florence of American parents, Sargent studied in Paris until 1884. He had great success as a portraitist, both in the United States, and in Britain, where he came to live after Paris. He was a friend of Monet, whom he painted around 1885. 

In 1907 he gave up his successful portrait practice and, apart from a few distinguished exceptions, he devoted himself to landscapes, murals and watercolours from his travels. He was also an official War Artist in the First World War. This fresh, bright but uncharacteristically personal watercolour shows the view from Sargent's hotel, with the artist's sketchbook and paintbox propped open by the window http://ow.ly/W1J3x

Some terrific guesses for today's #MysteryObject! It is a decorated funerary diadem, found on the skull of a skeleton in a tomb. It was made in Late Bronze Age Cyprus (1400–1200 BC), by stamping sheet gold with specially prepared punches. If you look closely, depicted on the diadem are two rows of figure-of-eight shields and bulls' heads, each decorated with a lotus flower. Together with the diadem, funerary mouthpieces were also found placed over the mouth http://ow.ly/WWIUE
It's #MysteryObject time! Can you guess what this object is?

Charles Perrault, writer of folk tales like Cinderella, was born #onthisday in 1628. Cinderella was first published in French as 'Cendrillon' in Perrault's 1697 book 'Histoires ou contes du temps passé' and then published in German as 'Aschenputtel' in the 1812 edition of Kinder- und Hausmärchen by the Brothers Grimm. There were many variations in the story – the Grimms' version had help from a magic wishing tree, not a fairy godmother! Here are some works from the collection depicting the story of Cinderella.

This cross is made from the wreckage of a boat that sank off the coast of the Italian island of Lampedusa, carrying refugees from Eritrea and Somalia. Some of the survivors were Eritrean Christians, fleeing persecution in their home country. 500 people were on board when the overcrowded boat caught fire, capsized and sank. Only 151 people survived. 

Francesco Tuccio, a carpenter who lives and works on the island, met some of the survivors in his church. He collected some of the timber from the wreckage to make each survivor a cross, to reflect their salvation and as a symbol of hope for the future. Mr Tuccio also made a cross which was carried by Pope Francis at the memorial service. The British Museum heard about the crosses and contacted Mr Tuccio to see if one could be acquired. Mr Tuccio made and donated this cross to the collection as a symbol of the suffering and hope of our times. It is now on display in Room 2.

'A powerful, humble symbol' – Curator Jill Cook explains why the cross is so moving in this BBC radio programme: http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03dy67s …

Sir Hans Sloane died #onthisday in 1753. He was a physician whose collection became the foundation of the British Museum, The British Library and the Natural History Museum, London. 

Sloane died at the age of 93 and was buried at Chelsea Old Church. At his death, his collection amounted to more than 71,000 objects. In his will, Sloane bequeathed the whole collection to George II for the nation in return for payment of £20,000 to his heirs. Parliament accepted the gift and on 7 June 1753 an Act of Parliament establishing the British Museum received the royal assent, and Sloane's collection became the foundation of the British Museum. The British Library and Natural History Museum collections were both originally part of the British Museum.

Italian artist Parmigianino was born #onthisday in 1503. Parmigianino's real name was Francesco Mazzola, but was known as the 'little Parmesan' as he came from the north Italian city of Parma. Before moving to Rome in 1524, the young Parmigianino had received important public commissions in his native Parma. Once in Rome he collaborated with specialists such as Ugo da Carpi to produce engravings and woodcuts that captured the movement and drama of his figure drawings. 

After moving to Bologna in 1527, he experimented with the new technique of etching to find a style that reproduced the personal refinement of his drawings. This etching, titled 'The Entombment', represents his greatest success. The graceful movements of the women turning towards or away from the light, and the virtuoso draughtsmanship of the artist, give the work a self-conscious style, which was much admired in the Italian courts http://ow.ly/W1DP3

#onthisday in 49 BC: Julius Caesar and his army crossed the Rubicon into Italy on their way to Rome. This was considered an act of insurrection and treason, as the Rubicon River marked the division between the Roman province of Cisalpine Gaul and Italy proper (controlled directly by Rome). The historian Suetonius reported that Caesar uttered the famous phrase 'alea iacta est' meaning 'the die is cast' – the idiom 'crossing the Rubicon' now means to pass a point of no return. Caesar was to be victorious in the civil war that followed. Here's a later imagining of this historic moment – an 1806 print based on a work by Henry Fuseli http://ow.ly/GQeaG
Sculptor Barbara Hepworth was born #onthisday in 1903. Here are some of her beautiful figure drawings http://ow.ly/H2CEC

The London Underground opened #onthisday in 1863! Here's the Museum's own tube stop in 1898, 1903 and 1921 in photographs from London Transport Museum. The British Museum station was closed in September 1933 when the new Holborn Underground station opened.

Undoubtedly helped by the dry climate of Egypt, papyrus has proved to be a very durable writing material with remarkable powers of preservation. In this new blog post, find out how five rare papyri were conserved for display in our #EgyptExhibition http://ow.ly/WO7H2
Happy birthday to Jimmy Page from Led Zeppelin! Here's a badge with the band's symbols http://ow.ly/H4sM7
Elvis Presley was born #onthisday in 1935. This print by David Oxtoby is titled 'Boss Man' http://ow.ly/GZ442

Take an in-depth look at the conservation processes involved in getting a crocodile mummy ready for display for the first time in 75 years! You can see this enormous mummy in a free display in Room 3 until 21 February ow.ly/VYFjO

David Bowie was born #onthisday in 1947. He features on this UK local banknote in the Museum's collection. Bank of England notes tend to be conservative in appearance, whereas local currencies have no such restrictions. This freedom means that while historical figures are depicted, it also allows for a fantastic array of contemporary designs. This Brixton £10 note with David Bowie was designed by Charlie Waterhouse and Clive Russell. Find out more about local currencies in this blog post http://ow.ly/GQarm

Discover the 4,000-year history of money from around the world in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/Ndaru

The magnificent Gundestrup cauldron is one of the most important and intriguing finds from ancient Europe and features in our current #Celts exhibition. See it before it closes on 31 January 2016!

Panel from the Gundestrup cauldron. Iron Age, c. 100 BC–AD 1. Found in Gundestrup, northern Jutland, Denmark. © The National Museum of Denmark.

While many Christians celebrate the birth of Jesus on 25 December, for the Copts and the Coptic Church of Egypt this takes place on 7 January, as they use the Julian calendar. Today is Christmas Day and a public holiday in Egypt. It is a time for feasting and enjoying the company of friends and family. Celebrations include a visit to church to attend the liturgy, pray and reflect on inner thoughts, followed by a festive meal. Christmas food includes fruits, honey, vegetables, fish and bread.

This wooden panel depicts the Nativity, and comes from a door of the Church of the Virgin in Old Cairo http://ow.ly/WL2B5

See it in our #EgyptExhibition, until 7 February http://ow.ly/VYLMC

A #ThrowbackThursday from our archives! As early as the 1820s the Museum saw the need to inform its visitors and to use the collection as an aid to teaching. Objects were displayed and labelled in order to help visitors learn about other cultures. The British Museum's first lecture theatre was opened in the Assyrian Basement in the early 1890s. 

In this engraving from 1881 we see a visiting lecturer talking to adults and children about the Greek and Roman sculpture collections. Behind her, artists sketch at their easels and beyond visitors enjoy the Assyrian and Egyptian collections. http://ow.ly/WKqEj

Portraitist Nicholas Hilliard died #onthisday in 1619. Hilliard specialised in painting miniatures (known as limning) of members of the Tudor and early Stuart courts. He had a large workshop which designed jewellery, woodcuts, portraits, decorative paintings and miniatures. 

This is a detailed design for the principal side of the Great Seal of Ireland. To either side of Queen Elizabeth are two shields. On the left is the design of an Irish harp adopted by Henry VIII as the official arms of Ireland. On the right are three crowns which represent England, France and Ireland. Around the circumference are the faint Latin words: ELISABET D[EO] G[RATIAS] ANGLIE FRA[NCIAE] ET HIBERNIE REGINA ('Elizabeth, by the Grace of God, Queen of England, France and Ireland'). 

The Queen herself appears young, as, indeed she did in nearly all painted images of her right up to her death. Crowned, she holds the orb and sceptre and Tudor roses, symbols of her family, appear to her right and left and at the foot of her throne. This design, however, was not used. http://ow.ly/W1glt

Richard II of England was born #onthisday in 1367. This astronomical quadrant was made for him, identified by the roundel on the front which depicts a stag with a crown around its neck and a chain around its body. The quadrant enables the user to tell the time from the height of the sun. The table on the back of this instrument, shown here, would have helped to calculate the date of Easter http://ow.ly/VYIQm

Today is the Christian feast of Epiphany. This pen and brown ink drawing by Rembrandt depicts a Dutch custom in celebration of the Epiphany, the commemoration of the visit of the Three Kings to the newborn Christ. Children went from door to door carrying a lantern shaped like a star (the 'Star of the Kings'). They asked for money from the occupants of the houses. Rembrandt may have drawn this scene from life http://ow.ly/VYHVu

The Vale of York Hoard was discovered #onthisday in 2007, containing spectacular Viking objects. The hoard shows the diversity of cultural contacts in the medieval world at the time, with objects coming from as far apart as Afghanistan in the east and Ireland in the west, as well as Russia, Scandinavia and continental Europe. It contains coins relating to Islam and to the pre-Christian religion of the Vikings, as well as to Christianity. 

The hoard was probably buried for safety by a wealthy Viking leader during the conquest of the Viking kingdom of Northumbria in AD 927 by the Anglo-Saxon king Athelstan. This was a key moment in English history, with the whole of England brought under one king for the first time http://ow.ly/VYG2l 

Discover more about the hidden history of hoarding in our new free display in Room 69a http://ow.ly/VYG8t

Did you guess today's #MysteryObject? It's a wrist clasp used to secure the cuffs of long-sleeved garments worn by women. They functioned rather like modern hook and eye fasteners. This is the hook plate of what would originally have been two sections of a clasp. Wrist clasps derive from Scandinavia (the closest parallels are in Norway) and were not introduced into England until the last quarter of the fifth century AD. This example is one of a number of similar clasps found in East Anglia, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire. The elaborate decoration, settings for inlays and the fact that it is made from silver suggests that this clasp was made for a woman of high status http://ow.ly/W1K7C
It's #MysteryObject time! Can you guess what this object is?
'Journeys end in lovers meeting'. Celebrate #TwelfthNight with this hand-coloured fan inspired by Shakespeare's play http://ow.ly/GNncz

Edward the Confessor died #onthisday in 1066. This is a cut farthing issued during his reign. The only coin that was circulated widely in early medieval England was the silver penny, and in the later Anglo-Saxon period this was probably equivalent to £20 to £25 in modern terms. Although the economy was less heavily based on cash payments than today, there was a clear need in the 11th and 12th centuries for smaller coins. Rather than issue smaller coins, it was thought simpler to cut pennies into halves and quarters. The majority of coin designs throughout the period had a cross on the reverse and, by lining a chisel up along the limbs of the cross, it was possible to make a neat division. The term 'farthing' literally means 'a fourth part' or 'quarter' in Old English http://ow.ly/VIHHp

This rare early Hebrew Bible is one of the earliest surviving examples of Jewish manuscript illumination from the Middle East. The Hebrew Bible or Tanakh consists of three parts, the Torah (the Law), containing the Five Books of Moses, the Nevi'im (the Prophets) and the Ketuvim (the Writings). 

Discover more about this incredible object on loan from The British Library for our #EgyptExhibition in this new blog post: ow.ly/WBs2P

Discover the hidden secrets of a four-metre mummified crocodile in our free Room 3 display! The ancient Egyptians believed this mummy was incarnation of the crocodile god Sobek. It is coated with resin and has over 25 mummified crocodile hatchlings attached to its back. Uncover this creature's hidden secrets with state-of-the-art CT scans http://ow.ly/VYFjO

'To many, perhaps to most people… 'Celtic' of any sort is… a magic bag into which anything may be put, and out of which almost anything may come… 
Anything is possible in the fabulous Celtic twilight.'
J R R Tolkien, 1963

Be inspired like J R R Tolkien and discover amazing objects of Celtic art and identity in our major exhibition, until 31 Jan 2016 http://ow.ly/VYCN3

The magnificent Gundestrup cauldron is one of the most important and intriguing finds from ancient Europe and features in our current #Celts exhibition. On loan from Nationalmuseet, the cauldron reveals connections between communities thousands of miles apart. Although it depicts objects used in central and western Europe, it was found in a bog near Gundestrup in Denmark, beyond the northern edge of the Celtic regions. The style of the designs suggests that it was made further east, in Bulgaria or Romania. The strange animals and cross-legged pose of the antlered figure hint at even wider influences, from as far afield as Asia. The scenes on the panels give a glimpse into a world of ancient myths, and the stories of gods and heroes whose names are now lost http://ow.ly/VR5t8
Here's a first glimpse of our 2016 blockbuster exhibition #SunkenCities… http://ow.ly/WbuZS
Happy New Year to our (nearly 1 million!) followers  http://ow.ly/G6xy2 #NewYear2016
January is named after the Roman god Janus. He had two faces to see the future and the past! This engraving of Janus by Dutch artist Jacobus Harrewyn was made in 1698 http://ow.ly/VIGKt
How are you celebrating New Year's Eve in your part of the world? #NYE2016 http://ow.ly/GbFXh
The Museum is closed on 1 January, but will be open 10.00 to 17.30 on Saturday 2 January http://ow.ly/GspWF
Henri Matisse was born #onthisday in 1869. This coin from the collection features a painting from his Blue Nudes series http://ow.ly/GbGBw

From the early 19th century until 1870, the Chinese gambling houses in the Thai capital, Bangkok, produced ceramic tokens for use as counters. During the same period there was a shortage of silver metal for coins, and cowrie shells (a traditional form of money) were losing their value as currency. As a result the ceramic gambling tokens began to be used as everyday small change within the city. The onus of redeeming the tokens rested with gambling houses, who tried to pre-empt forgeries by frequently changing the design of the tokens. In cobalt blue underglaze on the back is the character qian (coin), which indicates the token is worth one Thai salung coin (equal to one quarter baht) http://ow.ly/VIEEX

Discover more about the history of money in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/Ndaru
Novelist, poet and writer Rudyard Kipling was born #onthisday in 1865. Here's an illustration to an edition of his 'Jungle Book' by artist David Gentleman http://ow.ly/GbI0F

The Roman emperor Titus was born #onthisday in AD 39. The Colosseum was completed under his reign, shown here on this coin from AD 80. The Colosseum is a marvel of ancient engineering. With an estimated capacity of 50,000, seats were arranged in three tiers corresponding to the bottom three of the four storeys visible on the coin. Underneath the wooden floor of the area were cages for beasts, and drains. These were to service the events that took place in the amphitheatre, including gladiatorial combat and wild beast fights. The word 'arena' comes from the Latin for sand, which covered the floor to soak up the large quantities of blood spilt http://ow.ly/VIxIP

These 19th-century wooden bath clogs (nalın or qabqab) from Turkey are inlaid with pewter and mother-of-pearl. The leather straps are covered in gold-embroidered velvet. At 26cm high they lifted the wearer above the wet and dirty floor, but a personal attendant was needed for support. Their Arabic name, qabqab, derives from the clacking noise they made on the marble floors.

Learn more about footwear from the Islamic world in our free display in Room 34 http://ow.ly/VTESd

Today's #MysteryObject is a wooden breast ornament (rei miro) from Easter Island, which would have been worn with a cord around the neck. Such pendants were worn by men as emblems of high rank. The ariki mau, or paramount chief, wore a distinctive costume which consisted of a barkcloth cloak stained yellow with turmeric, a feather headdress, and wooden ornaments including rei miro. Smaller examples were worn by women http://ow.ly/VIvNG
It's time for another #MysteryObject! Any ideas what this is?

If you look closely at the intricate gold-embroidered paisley patterns on these loafers you can see tiny stitches in green, pink, purple and blue silk threads. The leather insoles are also decorated with delicate floral motifs, which would have been admired when the shoes were removed indoors. Made in the former North West Frontier Province, these loafers are a fusion of eastern aesthetics with western shoe design.

Explore around 25 pairs of shoes, slippers, sandals, clogs and boots from the Islamic world in our new free display http://ow.ly/VTESd

Westminster Abbey, consecrated #onthisday in 1065, is where all English and then British monarchs have been crowned since 1066. This hand-coloured aquatint and etching is a book illustration by John Bluck made in 1811 http://ow.ly/FMmdO

These boots from Kazakhstan in the early 1900s feature in our free display of footwear from North Africa, Turkey, the Middle East, Iran, Central Asia and South Asia. Made for men and women these soft, light, indoor boots (ichigi or masi) have thin, flat soles. They are decorated with brightly coloured leather appliqué patterns that evoke the natural world such as beetles, rams' horns and cat faces. Leather overshoes are worn over these boots to protect them from the dirt and moisture outside http://ow.ly/VTESd

Charles Darwin embarked on his journey on the HMS Beagle #onthisday in 1831. The observations Darwin made on this momentous voyage would lead to his theory of evolution. This is the ship's chronometer, made by Thomas Earnshaw, originally an extraordinarily skilled watchmaker. This chronometer is a precise timekeeper and also contains a temperature compensation balance. This balance was designed to keep the timekeeper running at a constant rate in the varying ambient temperatures encountered at sea. While the mechanisms within chronometers were simple, they were made to very exacting standards and the escapement makers, finishers and adjusters were among the highest skilled in the clock-making world. The dial indicates hours, minutes and seconds. The whole machine is housed in a simple wooden box with mounts to keep it level irrespective of the motion of the ship http://ow.ly/Vs5IQ
The Museum is open this week! It's a great chance to see our special exhibitions – #Celts and #EgyptExhibition http://ow.ly/VRE7P

From Boston Celtics to Asterix, the name #Celts is now proudly embraced to demonstrate Celtic identity in communities around the world. Find out more about the Celtic diaspora on Tumblr http://ow.ly/WaXAx

King Stephen of England was crowned #onthisday in 1135. When Henry I of England died in 1135, he left no surviving legitimate sons; he wished his daughter Matilda to succeed him on the throne. While Henry was still alive, most of the nobles promised to accept Matilda as queen, but after his death his nephew Stephen seized the throne. Matilda raised an army, and a civil war between Stephen and Matilda followed. This was only finally resolved in 1153, when it was agreed that Stephen would be king until he died, but would be succeeded by Matilda's son Henry, who became Henry II. Stephen and Matilda both issued coins in their own names http://ow.ly/Vs5vo
Charlemagne was crowned Holy Roman Emperor #onthisday in AD 800. Discover more about his legacy in this blog post http://ow.ly/Vs4XJ
Happy Christmas to all! For our final #Christmas post, it's all smiles on this giant snowman. This sweet black and white etching from 1922 is by Horace Devitt Welsh http://ow.ly/VTBjv

Did you know the Museum used to have a Zoological Gallery? This 1841 engraving from our archives depicts a gallery of stuffed birds and minerals before they were moved to the newly built Natural History Museum, London in the 1880s. Find out more on Tumblr http://ow.ly/WaV7v
For Christmas Eve's #advent, a nativity scene carved in mother of pearl, set in a silver and gold frame http://ow.ly/VTwCX

The Museum will be closed on 24, 25 and 26 Dec (and 1 Jan 2016). After today, we're next open at 10.00 on Sun 27 Dec. More visiting information can be found here: http://ow.ly/Vs4EG

Happy holidays!

The French scholar Jean-François Champollion was born #onthisday in 1790. He used the Rosetta Stone to fully decipher Egyptian hieroglyphs for the first time. Find out more about this incredible discovery: http://ow.ly/W4eBT 

YouTuber Tom Scott looks at how the Rosetta Stone unlocked hieroglyphs in this video, shot behind-the-scenes at the Museum http://ow.ly/Vs3CY
A lovely collage of mistletoe by Mary Delaney for today's #advent http://ow.ly/W5gLx

'Beautifully captures how religion shaped the region'
Great new review of #EgyptExhibition in The Art Newspaper  http://ow.ly/We9SV  Have you seen it yet?

For #advent today, this elaborately carved 16th-century boxwood tabernacle – a portable object of private devotion – reveals the Virgin and Child. It consists of several sections which come apart. Find out more on Tumblr: http://ow.ly/VRNRX

Today's #MysteryObject is a 4,500-year-old gold strainer for beer or wine. It comes from the 'Queen's Grave' in the Royal Cemetery at Ur, which contained the body of a woman and two serving ladies surrounded by extraordinary rich material. There are no gold deposits in Mesopotamia, and the metal would probably have been imported from Iran or Anatolia (modern Turkey). Beer and wine were drunk in Mesopotamia from at least the 4th millennium BC and it is possible that the strainer was used to remove any debris when serving http://ow.ly/Vs2Zp
It's time for this week's #MysteryObject! Any ideas what this object was used for?

Today is the #WinterSolstice in the northern hemisphere! This 1836 watercolour of Stonehenge is by John Constable. After visiting Stonehenge in 1820, Constable made a sketch that was eventually worked up into a large watercolour for his last exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts. This watercolour represents a middle stage in the process – it is squared for transfer to a larger sheet. 

The finished work (now at the Victoria and Albert Museum) was captioned: 'The mysterious monument... standing remote on a bare and boundless heath, as much unconnected with the events of the past as it is with the uses of the present, carries you back beyond all historical records into the obscurity of a totally unknown period'
Enjoy playing in the snow? Here's a bear on a snow-covered pine tree in this Japanese woodblock print from 1840 #advent http://ow.ly/VtdYn
Snow White premiered #onthisday in 1937, the first full-length animated movie! This Timex watch dates from between 1947 and 1953 and features Snow White on the face http://ow.ly/Gb3Gq
The Nativity is depicted in this graphite drawing, with grey wash and gold detail. Three wise men kneel before Christ, the Virgin and Joseph #advent http://ow.ly/W5dZF
Born #onthisday in 1797: architect Sydney Smirke. He designed the Museum's Reading Room and built the Entrance Hall and Grand Staircase, both shown here in these images from our archives.

Read about the development of Christianity in Egypt from its beginnings to the state religion of the Roman Empire http://ow.ly/W5t7C
 
Discover Egypt's incredible journey over 12 centuries in our #EgyptExhibition http://ow.ly/W5uNX
For today's #advent highlight from the collection, a Christmas angel ornament from Hungary made of rush stems stitched together http://ow.ly/VQtZD
Henry II was crowned King of England at Westminster Abbey #onthisday in 1154. This image of him on horseback was made around 1660 http://ow.ly/FLXd7

To celebrate our #Celts exhibition with National Museums Scotland, enter this exclusive competition to win a luxury weekend in Edinburgh followed by a wild Scottish adventure with Aurora Expeditions! http://ow.ly/W40G9

Swiss artist Paul Klee was born #onthisday in 1879. In 1921, he was hired as a faculty member of the Bauhaus school of art and design, where he taught the introductory course in basic design principles. This work titled 'Die heilige vom inneren licht' (The saint of the inner light) was made for publication in the first of the Bauhaus portfolios, devoted to the work of the masters teaching there http://ow.ly/VnZyD
Reindeer pulling a sledge under the northern lights for today's #advent. This 1825 illustration is from 'A Winter in Lapland and Sweden' by Arthur de Capell Brooke http://ow.ly/VRidO

We now say goodbye to our Director, Neil MacGregor, who is off to pastures new in Germany. In honour of the great man we wanted to share some never-before-seen footage of Neil in the 2014 exhibition 'Germany: memories of a nation'. Auf Wiedersehen Neil – all of us at the Museum will miss you! http://ow.ly/W43YU

Today we also reveal the official portrait of outgoing Director Neil MacGregor, by German artist Wolfgang Tillmans RA. Commissioned by the Trustees of the Museum, this is the first photographic portrait of a British Museum Director. There is a tradition stretching back 250 years of a portrait being produced of each Director of the Museum.

To mark Neil MacGregor's last day as Director of the Museum, we can now reveal the final acquisition made under his directorship: the Lampedusa Cross. It is made from the wreckage of a boat carrying refugees from Eritrea and Somalia that sank off the coast of the Italian island Lampedusa in 2013. 500 people were on board when the overcrowded boat caught fire, capsized and sank. Only 151 people survived. The cross was made by Mr Francesco Tuccio, a carpenter who lives and works on the island. Mr Tuccio met some of the survivors in his church of San Gerlando and, frustrated by his inability to make any difference to their plight, he went and collected some of the timber from the wreckage and made each of them a cross to reflect their salvation and as a symbol of hope for the future http://ow.ly/W45RB

'In my time at the Museum we have acquired many wonderful objects, from the grand to the humble, but all have sought to shine a light on the needs and hopes that all human beings share. All have enabled the Museum to fulfil the purpose for which it was set up: to be a museum of the world and for the world, now and well into the future.' – Neil MacGregor.

This manuscript, known as the Codex Sinaiticus, is the world's oldest surviving Bible and a highlight of our current #EgyptExhibition. Discover more about this incredible 4th-century AD text on loan from The British Library in this new blog post http://ow.ly/W2wjo

Every object in the British Museum, including everything you see on display, is cared for by a dedicated team of conservators and scientists. They work alongside curators and other staff to preserve and investigate over 8 million objects, promoting the latest scientific and curatorial research into the collection. Find out more about the work of conservators and scientists in this behind-the-scenes film http://ow.ly/W2y8Y

This is one of four pilot episodes we've made for a potential new video series. Vote for your favourite! http://ow.ly/V1cCa

status_message: This carved ivory polyptych from late medieval France shows the Virgin and Child in the centre. On the left is the Annunciation by the Angel Gabriel to Mary and the Adoration of the Magi. On the right is the Nativity and Presentation in the Temple to Simeon. #advent http://ow.ly/VQxxf

This week we're highlighting the #AfricanRockArt project as they catalogue and digitally preserve 25,000 images of rock art http://ow.ly/Jzl3g

A remarkable feature of North African rock art is the existence of numerous engraved or painted inscriptions which can be found throughout the Sahara Desert. These inscriptions, generically named Libyco-Berber, are found from the west of Egypt to the Canary Islands and from the Mediterranean Sea to the Sahel countries to the south. Together with Egyptian hieroglyphs, they show us one of the earliest written languages in Africa. Find out more http://ow.ly/W1jBd

Henri IV of France married Marie de Medici #onthisday in 1600, both shown on this bronze medallion. The period preceding the coronation of Henri IV was one of great turbulence, with the wars of religion dividing French Catholics and Protestants, leading to infamous events of violence. Henri's accession as king was not unifying – he was a Protestant, on the side of the Huguenots. Crowned King of Navarre in 1572, he married Margaret of Valois in an attempt at unity but he became a prisoner at court. After the assassination of Henri III in 1589, he became King of France. Opposition from the nobility forced Henri to convert to Catholicism in 1593. 

Henri's second marriage to Marie de Medici in 1600 and the birth of an heir (later Louis XIII) in 1601 helped to quell uncertainty. Henri commissioned versions of this medal in silver and gold in 1602–1603 to celebrate the birth of the Dauphin Louis. Henri appointed the artist Guillaume Dupré as chief modeller of portraits on coinage in 1604 and gave him a workshop in the Louvre http://ow.ly/VnH4H

'I loved this exhibition... It's Game of Thrones without the slaughter, The Hobbit without the overlong film version. If you leave untouched by mystic fire, you have no imagination.' http://ow.ly/VZ4B4

Our #Celts exhibition is The Guardian's number 1 art show of 2015! See it before it closes on 31 January 2016 http://ow.ly/VZ6JF

In the late 19th century, artists and designers working in the 'Celtic nations' – Scotland, Ireland, Wales, Brittany, the Isle of Man, Cornwall – drew on their local heritage, incorporating ancient motifs and stories into their art. This Celtic Revival was part of the wider Arts and Crafts movement. Both aimed to promote the preservation of traditional crafts in response to the increasing standardisation and industrialisation of Victorian Britain. 

In 1890s Scotland, Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Herbert McNair, and Margaret and Frances Macdonald became prominent figures in an art movement called the Glasgow School. Their sources of inspiration included early medieval manuscripts and metalwork. This celebrated poster shows their characteristic elongated figures and stylised flowers. The Trustees of the British Museum first met #onthisday in 1753. The British Museum Act of 1753 set up a Board of Trustees to govern the Museum and to be responsible to Parliament for its collections, buildings and staff. There were three Principal Trustees – the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Lord Chancellor and the Speaker of the House of Commons. There were also several Official Trustees, including the various Secretaries of State, and Trustees representing the Sloane, Harley and Cotton families, whose gifts had helped to establish the Museum.

At the time of their first meeting the British Museum did not yet have a building of its own, so the Principal and Official Trustees met in Whitehall. On that day they elected fifteen other Trustees, listed here in the minutes of the meeting, and agreed to meet again in six days' time. A Board of Trustees still governs the British Museum, although nowadays there are no 'Principal' or 'Official' Trustees. The Museum's Archives contain a complete series of minutes of its Trustees' meetings from this first in 1753 to the present day.

Today we revealed some of the amazing archaeological finds made by the public in England and Wales, including this recent major discovery of a Viking hoard! Buried in the 870s in Watlington, Oxfordshire, this hoard includes 186 rare coins of King Alfred of Wessex and King Ceolwulf II of Mercia as well as Viking jewellery. The hoard comes from a key moment in English history and has the potential to provide important new information.

Finds like this are recorded in a vast online database: the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS). In 2014 over 113,000 archaeological finds have been recorded by the PAS, making significant historical contributions. Find out more about the scheme here: https://finds.org.uk/

In the late 19th century Celtic Revival artists began using archaeological discoveries to inform their imagined visions of the Celtic past. The themes of Celtic Revival paintings also sometimes came from ancient sources. These included early medieval myths, such as Irish tales of the Sidhe, a fairy people.
 
In this painting, a group of druids, an ancient priesthood, emerge from a grove of oaks where they have been ceremonially gathering mistletoe. This romantic Victorian reimagining of a scene described by Roman author Pliny the Elder was intended to evoke an authentic Scottish past. The image incorporates elements that the artists thought of as Celtic: spiral motifs, the brilliant colours of illuminated manuscripts and a snake design inspired by Pictish stones #advent http://ow.ly/VEMZu

Today's #MysteryObject is a monumental Etruscan gold earring, made around 400 BC. The goldsmiths of Etruria became very accomplished from the 7th century BC, producing rich objects in striking forms that were technically very difficult to make. This truly monumental gold earring is a typically Etruscan piece of jewellery. How would it have been worn? Certain terracotta heads show that they acted almost as ear covers, nestling behind the curls of the wearer and tucked into the side of the neck. This ear decoration is shaped from thin sheet gold, with attached rosettes, clusters of gold globules and further decoration http://ow.ly/VkZm0
It's time for this week's #MysteryObject! Any ideas what this object is? (Hint: it's 14cm and weighs 500g!)

Mary, Queen of Scots was born #onthisday in 1542. Only a few specimens of this coin of Mary Stuart are known. It comes from the time of her personal rule in Scotland, and after her marriage to Henry, Lord Darnley in 1565. By this time large silver coins had been introduced into most European coinages, and the coinage ordered by the Privy Council in 1565 was to include such a piece, worth 30 shillings Scots. This design has the portraits of Mary and her husband facing each other. The back shows the Scottish shield with thistle heads on either side, surmounted by a crown. The reverse legend reads (in Latin) 'Those whom God has joined together, let no man put asunder', suggesting that the issue may have been created to celebrate and commemorate the wedding http://ow.ly/VmYP9

The Roman emperor Diocletian died #onthisday in AD 311, depicted here on a large medallion. Pierre-Auguste Renoir died #onthisday in 1919. He began his career as a painter of porcelain in Limoges before studying with Sisley and Monet at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. He was, with Monet, at the forefront of the movement that became known as Impressionism. The two artists painted side by side on occasion, most famously for their paintings of the popular bathing-spot La Grenouillere on the banks of the Seine. Renoir's paintings were always light-hearted, with soft-feathered brushstrokes capturing fleeting movement and mottled light. His later works concentrate on the female nude and he tended to emphasise simple forms and solidity, as well as relishing pink and orange flesh, as this study illustrates. Despite suffering from rheumatism in his last years, Renoir continued to work, saying: 'If painting were not a pleasure to me I should certainly not do it.' http://ow.ly/V4VVM

Metalpoint is a famously challenging graphic technique, as the lines cannot be easily erased and the artist needs to carefully plan the design or run the risk of having to start all over again! 

Discover this fascinating process and see masterpieces of #metalpoint from artists including Leonardo da Vinci, Raphael, Albrecht Dürer, Rembrandt, Edward Burne-Jones, Otto Dix and Jasper Johns in our exhibition, closing this Sunday (6 December) http://ow.ly/Vobgq

Artist Otto Dix was born #onthisday in 1891. Dix had been strongly affected by his experience as a soldier in the German army in the First World War and his work would be haunted by the brutality that he witnessed. He was also particularly interested in the metalpoint technique, executing more than 200 silverpoint drawings between 1931 and 1944. The medium was a perfect match for his desire to see things frankly and honestly and to achieve the detail and precise form he observed in the art of the Old Masters. In this portrait titled Old Woman, he tenderly portrays the ageing character of his model. Each line is crisp and distinct as he closely studied her wrinkled, furrowed, and sagging skin, and the sheen and texture of her hair.

See works by Otto Dix alongside masterpieces by some of the greatest artists across six centuries in our #metalpoint exhibition, closing this Sunday (6 December) http://ow.ly/V6KB8

Napoleon Bonaparte became Emperor of the French #onthisday in 1804. In the wake of the French Revolution (1789–1792), a Republican government became the ruling authority in France, but it remained weak and was eventually undermined by a coup d'état in 1799. Napoleon Bonaparte led French campaigns in Italy and Egypt in 1796–1799 and, as an ambitious general serving the revolutionary regime, won a series of important victories. Napoleon became First Consul of the French Senate in 1799 and was pronounced Emperor in 1804. This 2 franc piece shows the portrait of the new Emperor. The coin's neo-classical design, based on ancient coins of the Roman emperor Augustus, was intended to emphasise Napoleon's power http://ow.ly/V6OiU

This Etruscan banqueter with stylish #Movember moustache is shown here reclining on a couch. The Etruscans lived in what is now Italy before the rise of the Romans, flourishing between the 8th and 1st centuries BC. Feasts, with music and entertainment, were important in Etruscan life, and scenes of banqueting are common. This bronze figurine may have been placed as a dedication in a shrine or sanctuary. Feasts depicted on the walls of tombs may represent funerary feasts or feasting in the afterlife, though other representations seem to be everyday social occasions. The bronze banqueter reclines on a couch, in a way that was typical in the Classical world. He has an impressive and carefully delineated beard and moustache, and is dressed in a decorated chiton or tunic. The bowl that he holds is of the type used both at banquets and for libations – the offering of small quantities of liquids, such as wine, to the gods http://ow.ly/UQvd0

Today's #Movember moustache features on this mummy case, part of a group of mummies (most likely part of a family group) discovered at a tomb at Akhmim, near Sohag in Egypt in 1896. The body of this case is decorated with scenes of Egyptian gods against a gold background, together with a scene of the mummification of the deceased. It is rather unusual for a (non-divine) beard to be shown on the face of such a coffin. While this may be more a stylised representation of the beards which were soon to form part of mummy portraits, it does also look back to burials of the First Intermediate Period (about 2160–2040 BC) in this part of Egypt, when these were common http://ow.ly/UQlXZ

Every #PayDay we share a #MoneyFact! These tiny bronze dolphins were used as money in Greek cities around the Black Sea, which began to be established as colonies from the 8th century BC onwards. There was also a strong native non-Greek population in the area, which flourished alongside the colonists. This mixture of cultures resulted in a curious variety of monetary forms. Around the city of Olbia on the north coast of the Black Sea large numbers of tiny, cast bronze dolphins have been discovered. They are sometimes found in groups, and in several instances have been discovered in tombs in the hands or mouths of the dead. These facts, together with the appearance of the dolphin on later coins of the city, make it clear that the bronze dolphins had a monetary use. In general they are approximately 35mm in length, and weigh between 1 and 3g, although larger examples are known http://ow.ly/UQR4p 

Discover the 4,000-year history of money from around the world in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/Ndaru

Some divine #Movember inspiration! This Roman statue of Dionysos is heavily draped, and his hair is bound with an ivy wreath. His beard is long, recalling archaic and early classical images of the god. Dionysos was often represented in this way in Roman times (he was associated with the Roman god Bacchus), and many versions of the figure exist. The god was particularly popular because of his association with wine and good living. His entourage of satyrs and maenads provided inspiration for artists, and their often wild antics made superb subjects for decorative reliefs, wall paintings, vessels and sculpture. The statue is carved out of one large block of Pentelic marble, except for the missing right arm, which was made separately and attached http://ow.ly/UQqxs
Leonardo da Vinci (1452–1519), Bust of a warrior. Silverpoint, on prepared paper, c. 1475–1480.

Fragments from the past can transform our reading of history. Christians adopted the Greek translation of Jewish scriptures (Septuagint) as their Old Testament, and in time, their compilation of gospels, letters and other works formed the New Testament. Early Christians debated which texts should and should not be included in the New Testament. The Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, giving an account of the life and sayings of Jesus, were accepted. Others such as the so-called Gospel of Mary were not. In this video, Roberta Mazza, University of Manchester, explains the survival of such texts only in Egypt and the role of Mary, probably Mary Magdalene, in this 'lost gospel' in which a woman is shown in a role of spiritual leadership http://ow.ly/V0Uvs

Today's #MysteryObject is an ivory salt cellar made in Nigeria between 1525 and 1600. It shows Europeans with long hair, beards and hooked noses. Objects of this type were perhaps the first known examples of 'tourist art' from Africa – luxury items made as souvenirs for foreigners. Africans along the continent's west coast first encountered Portuguese traders in the mid-15th century. Although ivory carvings were traditionally produced only for the royal court in the city of Benin, the ruling Oba (king) allowed decorated salt cellars, horns, spoons and forks to be made for Europeans http://ow.ly/UQnr2

Charles Darwin published his groundbreaking evolutionary theories in 'On the Origin of Species' #onthisday in 1859, which were to have a profound influence on future scientific theory. This medal of Darwin was made by the French artist Alphonse Legros, who in 1881 had started a medallic portrait series of the great men of his day: Alfred Tennyson, Thomas Carlyle, John Stuart Mill and Charles Darwin. Inspired by what he regarded as Darwin's 'powerful and noble head', Legros sketched his portrait on an envelope during a meeting of the Royal Society. The finished medal was enthusiastically received. http://ow.ly/UQJQF

This Japanese netsuke depicts the Chinese god-general Kanyū, featuring an impressive beard and #Movember moustache! Chinese legend provided endless material for Japanese artists and craftsmen. Kanyū was a Chinese general whose exploits are described in the classic 'Tale of Three Kingdoms'. He came to be regarded as the god of war. Even this small figure conveys the power of the god-general with his fierce expression, impressive beard and ornate Chinese-style robes http://ow.ly/UQgOC

#DoctorWho first aired #onthisday in 1963! This prop banknote was created for use in the 2006 Christmas episode 'The Runaway Bride'. A large number of banknotes were required for the scene in question so for practical and legal reasons the Doctor Who art department opted to design and make notes of their own. Strict Bank of England guidelines limit the production of fake banknotes for TV and film, so BBC Cymru had to create notes that looked authentic on screen but were obviously not genuine currency on closer inspection. The note itself is in the style of a British ten pound note. It features the head of David Tennant as the Tenth Doctor instead of the Queen, as well as quotations from the series, a TARDIS hologram and other Doctor Who references (the mention of satsumas on the note, for example, harks back to Tennant's debut episode). 

You can see this Doctor Who prop banknote on display in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/ExRbg
Holy Roman Emperor Otto I was born #onthisday in 912. This coin was minted in Cologne http://ow.ly/EAxEN

From the AD 400s, the Celtic-speaking peoples of Ireland and Scotland converted to Christianity. The early medieval monasteries of Britain and Ireland were flourishing centres of faith, art and learning. Although they shared beliefs with a wider Christian Europe, they developed local forms of worship and art. This cross may have been paraded by churchmen during ceremonies. The decoration on objects like this was an important way for them to communicate Christian teachings, as few people in early medieval Ireland could read or write. Some of the tinned and gilded panels illustrate biblical stories, such as Daniel in the lions' den.

See this beautiful cross in our #Celts exhibition, until 31 January 2016. 

Processional cross. Bronze, tin, gold, amber, oak (now reconstructed around a modern core). Tully Lough, Co. Roscommon, Ireland, AD 700–900. On loan from the National Museum of Ireland.

This luxuriant #Movember moustache and beard entwined with ivy leaves is an ancient Greek ivory inset from a couch-end ornament, made between 200 and 100 BC. Couches made of wood and bronze were often decorated with a pair of satyr's heads in bone or ivory inlaid into the ornamented sides of the fulcra (head rests). The elongated shape of the head and beard fitted the characteristically curving space perfectly, and the association of satyrs with pleasures of the flesh made them an appropriate choice. This head has the snub nose, heavy-lidded eyes and pointed ears that is typical of the satyr, with the mouth slightly open to reveal the teeth http://ow.ly/UQfQM
John F Kennedy was assassinated #onthisday in 1963. This badge from the collection was produced for Kennedy's 1960 presidential campaign http://ow.ly/ExKgD
Today is St Cecilia's Day. This Netherlandish engraving with hand-colouring depicts the patron saint of music holding a book and organ http://ow.ly/EAAA9

'What do we live for, if it is not to make life less difficult for each other?' – Novelist George Eliot was born #onthisday in 1819. Here's a portrait of her by artist Frederick William Burton http://ow.ly/Egj0z

Some #Movember inspiration: this figure of a bodhisattva was made in Pakistan over 1,800 years ago! Bodhisattva are Buddhas-to-be, the name meaning 'one whose essence or being is knowledge' (bodhi). According to Buddhist beliefs, they are individuals who stand on the brink of Buddha-hood but defer final Enlightenment so as to dedicate their lives to the welfare of all beings. As Buddhas-to-be are usually born into princely families and apply the heroic virtues of warriors and rulers to the spiritual quest, they are often shown in royal attire, with elaborate jewellery and crowns. His thickly pleated and heavy garments show strong Greek and Roman influences. However, his posture, shape of face, mouth and, most importantly, the underlying Buddhist philosophy have their origin in India http://ow.ly/UQaWh

Celebrated playwright and philosopher François-Marie Arouet, known as Voltaire, was born #onthisday in 1694. Voltaire became closely identified with the principles of the French Revolution. His body had been refused burial in Paris because of his attacks on conventional religion, but was finally re-interred to public acclaim in the Pantheon in 1791. This unusual caneware figure of Voltaire, with crisp modelling and realistic detail, was made by Josiah Wedgwood and Thomas Bentley and is based on a small marble dated 1773 by Jean-Claude Rosset http://ow.ly/UQac1

Charles I (r. 1625–1649) was born #onthisday in 1600. When he inherited the throne he determined to have a series of medals made that commemorated the events in his life and which reinforced the concept of the monarch's divine right to rule. The success of his ambitious plans was largely due to the French engraver Nicolas Briot (c. 1579–1646). This medal made by Briot was a formal assertion of English power at sea that had been made at regular intervals in the past. The Latin legend boldly asserts 'Nor is that a limit to me, which is a boundary to the world' http://ow.ly/UPRSH

Take part in our #HugeHistoryLesson competition! We are challenging students to explore history through objects. The winning class will get the chance to tell the world about their object and receive an exclusive behind-the-scenes experience at the British Museum http://ow.ly/UNVfj

In Victorian England many people were fascinated by their past, and the ancient tribal leader Caratacus (also spelt Caractacus) was adopted as a symbol of national pride and independence. Like Boudica, Caratacus resisted the Roman invasion of Britain. Although he was eventually defeated, he earned a reputation as a noble and worthy foe. The Victorian sculptor J H Foley portrays him here standing triumphant, the embodiment of courageous English spirit. 

See this magnificent #Movember moustache in our #Celts exhibition, until 31 January 2016 http://ow.ly/UvrA3

J H Foley (1818–1874), Caractacus. Marble, 1856–1859. On loan from Guildhall Art Gallery and London's Roman Amphitheatre, City of London.

Born #onthisday in 1785: Scottish artist David Wilkie. Wilkie began his artistic training in 1799 at the Trustees Academy in Edinburgh under the instruction of the history painter John Graham (1754–1817). While continuing his studies at the Royal Academy in London he began to exhibit. Influenced by Dutch 17th-century genre painting, Wilkie developed a talent for depicting scenes from everyday life. This is one of the very few nude studies he made.

Legend has it that William Tell shot an apple off his son's head #onthisday in 1307. This woodcut from around 1500 depicts the moment when the Swiss folk hero takes aim with his crossbow http://ow.ly/Ef2kY

Italian artist Agnolo Bronzino was born #onthisday in 1503. Bronzino was court painter to Duke Cosimo I, ruler of Florence. He painted many of Florence's nobility with an emphasis on their rich costumes and icy, aristocratic poise. Although Bronzino specialised as a portrait painter, very few of his portrait drawings survive. This fine study is executed in black chalk with touches of red chalk. The drawing is typically Florentine, with clear outlines and precise shading.

Today's #Movember moustache is from our #EgyptExhibition: a mummy portrait of an Egyptian priest of Serapis. The Roman practice of commemorating the dead with naturalistic portraits combined with the Egyptian practice of mummification. Sometimes shrouds depicting the dead covered the mummy, or wooden painted panels like this one were inserted over the face. This man wears a diadem with a seven-pointed star, worn by priests of the god Serapis – a fusion of Egyptian and Greek gods http://ow.ly/Uvo8H

Today's #MysteryObject is feather money used as a form of currency in the Melanesian island group of Santa Cruz (south-east of the Solomon Islands and north of Vanuatu). This currency, known as tevau, is formed as coils resembling long belts. It is used to make payments to a bride's family, for purchasing pigs and large canoes. The supply is limited by the availability of the feathers used and the man-hours involved in its manufacture. The manufacture of the feather coils is limited to just a few hereditary specialists, working on one island, who are thought to receive their skills from spirits. The value of a coil is dependent on its condition – newly made, vivid coloured examples are most valuable.
It's #MysteryObject time! Any ideas what objects like this are used for?

#onthisday in AD 9: the Roman emperor Vespasian was born in the Roman town of Reate (Rieti), about 65km north-west of Rome. Vespasian distinguished himself in military campaigns in Britain and later became a trusted aide of the emperor Nero. This naturalistic portrait of Vespasian clearly shows the lined complexion of this battle-hardened emperor, and also the curious 'strained expression' which the Roman writer Suetonius said he had at all times!

Elizabeth I ascended the throne #onthisday in 1558. Elizabeth understood that she needed to avoid the excesses of the reign of father, Henry VIII (r. 1509–1547) and that of her sister, Mary I (r. 1553–1558). She pursued a careful propaganda campaign, with particular emphasis on the legitimacy and stability of her monarchy. Attributes of majesty, authority and virginity were frequently represented in court balls, theatre productions, portraits, coinage, and jewels. Elizabeth is generally portrayed in an idealised manner: her portraits in the later years of her long reign show no sign of ageing. This magnificent jewel is a unique survival – no matching example is known. The phoenix rising from the flames is a well-known symbol of renewal, while the entwined red and white roses symbolise the consolidation of England under Tudor rule.

Today's #Movember object is a pottery jug with painted moustache. It comes from the Coptic town of Wadi Sarga in Egypt. Like most of the pottery of the Coptic period (around the 3rd–7th centuries AD), it was wheel-made, with the decoration applied after the basic form was achieved. Although fairly coarse, this vessel would have been a suitable, if quirky, item for household use http://ow.ly/UyuTy

The Hoxne Hoard was found #onthisday in 1992 in Suffolk. The hoard consists of over 15,000 gold and silver coins, gold jewellery and numerous small items of silver tableware, including pepper pots, ladles and spoons. Also found were the remains of a large wooden chest and smaller caskets with tiny silver padlocks, into which the treasure had been carefully secreted. Find out more about this significant find http://ow.ly/UyuET

Born #onthisday in 42 BC: the Roman emperor Tiberius, who succeeded his stepfather Augustus. This bust was commissioned in AD 4 to mark his adoption as the successor of the emperor Augustus. At the time Tiberius would have been 46 years old, but he is shown as much younger http://ow.ly/UyuLj

In parts of medieval Britain and Ireland large, intricately carved stone crosses acted as beacons of belief in the landscape, marking processional routes and places where communities could gather to hear Christian preaching. 

These fascinating crosses are featured in our #Celts exhibition – find out more http://ow.ly/UyKd6

Some Japanese #Movember inspiration! This mask with a bristling moustache and beard was used for a Japanese courtly ritual dance which has survived in Japan since the Heian period (AD 794–1185). This is the mask for Ryō-ō, the Dragon King, a character who appears in a Chinese story from the Northern Qi dynasty (550–577). He was so handsome that he had to wear a fearful mask into battle so that his enemies would be terrified and his allies would not be distracted.
Justin II became emperor of the Byzantine Empire #onthisday in 565 http://ow.ly/DWEW0
Born #onthisday in 1738: astronomer William Herschel, who discovered the planet Uranus http://ow.ly/EhPMH

This #Movember moustache features on one of the finest survivals of early Celtic art. Made for serving wine, these flagons were found in northern France, which in 400 BC was home to communities of farmer-warriors. The coral for the inlays would originally have been a vivid red. It must have been brought from the Mediterranean and the metalworker who made the flagons drew on an impressive range of influences. The forms were inspired by Etruscan flagons from northern Italy, while the stylised dogs on the handles resemble central Asian art. Dogs hunting a duck may represent a scene from a local myth. 

See these beautiful flagons in our #Celts exhibition, until 31 January 2016 http://ow.ly/UtCOi

After a lapse of over 100 years, the #metalpoint technique regained popularity from the 1820s as part of a renewed interest in the purity and directness of Renaissance art. Learn more on Tumblr about the artists in Britain who shaped this revival http://ow.ly/UyBA5

Explore 25 pairs of shoes from the Islamic world in a new free display, opening today! These shoes, sandals, clogs and boots from North Africa to South Asia are being shown together for the first time. Dating from 1800 onwards, they reveal some of the past and present beliefs, customs, pastimes and traditions from across the Islamic world http://ow.ly/UzJ0x

By the time the Romans arrived in Egypt, Judaism was well established and they allowed Jews to continue their religious practices. However, the Roman authorities viewed the new religion of Christianity with suspicion – to them it was a difficult, occasionally criminal sect. Despite this unpromising beginning, Christianity later became the privileged religion of the imperial household and wealthy and influential people throughout the empire adopted it. 

Discover more about the development of monotheism in Roman Egypt in this new #EgyptExhibition post on @Tumblr http://ow.ly/UC4kQ
Born #onthisday in 354: St Augustine of Hippo. This engraving with hand colouring from around 1460 depicts the saint with St John's eagle http://ow.ly/E9tkm
This Anglo-Saxon coin features some impressively long #Movember moustaches! http://ow.ly/UbjUM

Edward III of England was born #onthisday in 1312. Gold coinage was revived during his reign to help with international trade. This new coin consisted of a florin, or double leopard, of fine gold, exactly double the size of the Florentine florin, to be worth six shillings. Although the new coinage's standards were based on the florin, its designs followed French influence. The king is shown seated, holding orb and sceptre, with two heraldic English leopards beside him, and a Gothic canopy overhead, with a background of fleurs-de-lis. These, and the title 'king of France' included in the inscription, reflect Edward's claims to the French throne which underpinned the beginnings of the Hundred Years War (1339–1453).

The new coinage was not a success: its face value was higher than the value of the gold. Also, a coin worth six shillings did not fit well into the English monetary system, with 20 shillings in the pound, or 13s 4d in the mark. It was soon replaced by the noble, a coin worth 6s 8d which, being worth a third of a pound, and half a mark, was much more useful.

Today's #Movember moustache is a lovely detail on the magnificent St Cuileáin's bell shrine. The iron hand bell inside was first used to call members of a monastic community to prayer. It comes from the ancient monastery of Glankeen, Ireland, founded by St Cuileáin in the 7th century. St Cuileáin was a powerful figure, and the bell was venerated and later enshrined as a relic associated with him. The elaborate outer brass case was added in the 12th century.

See this beautiful bell-shrine in our #Celts exhibition http://ow.ly/UzVzG

Cnut (Canute) the Great died #onthisday in 1035. Having conquered England with an army of Vikings, he shortly afterwards became king of Denmark as well and in 1030 he became king of Norway. 

The Anglo-Saxons did not have realistic portraits on their coins in the way that we are used to today. However, Cnut became the first king of England to introduce a more contemporary style of bust. This coin shows him wearing a helmet typical of the type worn by Anglo-Saxons, Normans and Vikings in the 11th century. Contrary to the popular myth about Viking helmets, they had no horns! http://ow.ly/Uytpm

We mark #ArmisticeDay at the Museum's War Memorial every 11 November. Also pictured here is a ticket to the unveiling of the memorial in 1921, along with the original design for the wreath. You can also read the original minutes of the British Museum War Memorial Committee.

The British Museum is also connected with the First World War through Laurence Binyon, Keeper of Oriental Prints and Drawings. Binyon wrote the Ode of Remembrance, taken from his poem For The Fallen, from which we recite the famous words:

They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old: 
Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. 
At the going down of the sun and in the morning, 
We will remember them.

William Hogarth was born #onthisday in 1697. This etching was designed as a subscription ticket – a receipt presented to all those who had placed an advance order for one of his series called Marriage à la mode. Hogarth's subscription ticket announces that he is a comic artist, not a caricaturist. At the base of his design Hogarth contrasts 'characters' taken from Raphael's cartoons with caricatures by Leonardo, Carracci, and the fashionable contemporary Italian artist Pier Leone Ghezzi. For today's #Movember post, we're sharing this lovely Scottish comb, which features in our #Celts exhibition. Hair combs first appeared in Britain shortly before the Roman invasion of AD 43, at around the same time as tweezers, nail cleaners and cosmetic pigment grinders. People were becoming more concerned with their appearance, and perhaps used combs like this to groom beards and moustaches as well as hair.

Comb made of bone. Found in Langbank, Renfrewshire, Scotland, AD 1–200. On loan from National Museums Scotland.

Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent was born #onthisday in 1494. He ruled the Ottoman Empire from 1520 to 1566. This is his tughra – an intricate decorative device that served as the imperial monogram of the Ottoman sultans and was the ultimate symbol of their power. First adopted on documents – the earliest examples are from the 14th century – its use extended to coins, seals and other inscriptions.

Each sultan generally chose the precise form of his tughra on the day of his accession from specimens prepared for him in advance. This one bears the name Suleiman Shah, and that of his father, Selim, and the phrase 'the one who is always victorious' (common to all tughras). Find out more http://ow.ly/DOHwV
Photo by Benedict Johnson
A #Movember fact: Peter the Great of Russia introduced a beard tax in 1698 and this token was given as proof of payment!

Tutankhamun's tomb was discovered by archaeologist Howard Carter #onthisday in 1922. It is the only tomb dating from Egypt's New Kingdom (c. 1550–1069 BC) to have been found substantially intact. The contents provide an unequalled insight into royal funerary practices, art and craftsmanship of the period.

In 1967, Egypt's President Nasser consented to a loan of objects from Tutankhamun's tomb to the British Museum. The exhibition date was set for 1972, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the discovery of the tomb. Originally scheduled to run for six months, the exhibition was extended until 30 December 1972 because of its popularity. A total of 1,694,117 visitors saw the objects, over 7,000 per day. It still remains the most popular exhibition in the Museum's history http://ow.ly/TXMov

This horned helmet was cast into the River Thames over 2,000 years ago, and was discovered at Waterloo Bridge in the early 1860s. Greek sources tell us that Celts wore horned helmets into battle, but this is the only Iron Age helmet with horns ever to have been found in Europe. Ancient Greek warriors wore less elaborate headgear like the helmet on the right. Greek writing can still be understood, unlike the enigmatic Celtic designs on the horned helmet. Discover more about these intriguing objects in our #Celts exhibition http://ow.ly/UcdvT
This well-groomed #Movember moustache features in our #Celts exhibition. Originally part of the decoration on a wooden bucket, this face is over 2,000 years old! http://ow.ly/TXLDU

Benvenuto Cellini was born #onthisday in 1500. This pen and brown ink drawing was a study for the seal of the Accademia del Disegno, the Florentine Academy, founded by Duke Cosimo de' Medici in 1562 http://ow.ly/DJvBY

Today's #MysteryObject is a Japanese sword travelling case made of lacquered wood from the late 16th or early 17th century. Daimyō (provincial governors) and other high-ranking samurai carried mounted swords. However, they were not able to wear these long swords when travelling in a palanquin (covered litter), and their swords accompanied them in cases carried by attendants. This sword case is made of lacquered wood with gold makie and shell inlay with an all-over design of a grapevine. The outer leather case has the family crest of the owner in gold leaf http://ow.ly/TZ6hU

Today we are celebrating #DaysOfTheDead! In Mexico, this is an annual tradition where families gather to remember the dead. Its origins can be traced back at least 3,000 years among Mexico's pre-Hispanic indigenous cultures. Contemporary festivals reflect a blend of native traditions and Roman Catholic beliefs. These include building private altars, honouring the dead using sugar skulls, marigolds and the favourite foods and beverages of the deceased, and visiting graves with these as gifts. Discover more about the rich cultural significance of this Mexican festival in this new blog post http://ow.ly/U3gdp

Today Samhain is celebrated, a traditional festival that predates Halloween marking the end of the 'light' half of the year and the beginning of the 'dark' one, as the nights draw in towards winter. It has a long history of being celebrated in Scotland, Ireland and other Celtic nations. Scottish artist John Duncan (1866–1945) drew inspiration from ancient objects and stories to create this painting, titled 'Riders of the Sidhe'. The Sidhe (pronounced 'shee') are a fairy people in old Irish myths and this painting shows them riding out on a hunt at either Samhain (autumn) or Beltane (spring). See this wonderful work in our #Celts exhibition http://ow.ly/TWlsx

#onthisday in 1517: Martin Luther nailed his 95 Theses to a church door, traditionally thought of as sparking the beginning of the Reformation. This broadsheet – published in 1617, on the centenary of the Reformation – depicts the early Reformation of the Christian Church as a prophetic dream of Friedrich III, a political protector of Martin Luther.

Luther is shown writing on a church door with an enormously long pen, referencing the moment he publicly posted his 95 Theses in the town of Wittenberg. The pen stretches across half of the picture to emphasise the importance of the written word to Protestants, as opposed to images which were popular in the Catholicism of the time. The end of the pen passes through the ears of a lion and knocks off the tiara, or crown, of the pope of the time, Leo X, hence the lion. This is a clear reference to Luther's criticism of the authority of the Pope as head of the Catholic Church in Rome http://ow.ly/DBJC0

Cowrie shells have been used as money in many parts of the world, including China, Africa and Arabia. In China, inscriptions which talk of 'gifts of cowries', 'cowries in the treasury', 'seizure of cowries', 'use of cowries' and 'rewards of cowries' are found on bones and on bronze vessels of the Shang (16th–11th centuries BC) and Zhou (11th century–221 BC) dynasties.
Archaeologists have found that the distribution of cowrie finds coincides with the gradual acquisition of territories by the Zhou dynasty and noble lords. The natural supply of cowrie shells from the coastal regions could not meet the growing demand inland. People began to make imitation cowries out of bone, horn, shell, stone, clay, lead, bronze, gold and silver http://ow.ly/THb6q

King of Persia Cyrus the Great entered Babylon #onthisday in 539 BC. This clay cylinder is inscribed in Babylonian cuneiform with an account by Cyrus of his conquest and capture of Nabonidus, the last Babylonian king. Cyrus claims to have achieved this with the aid of Marduk, the god of Babylon. He then describes measures of relief he brought to the inhabitants of the city, and tells how he returned a number of images of gods, which Nabonidus had collected in Babylon, to their proper temples throughout Mesopotamia and western Iran. At the same time he arranged for the restoration of these temples, and organised the return to their homelands of a number of people who had been held in Babylonia by the Babylonian kings.

This cylinder has sometimes been described as the 'first charter of human rights', but it in fact reflects a long tradition in Mesopotamia where, from as early as the third millennium BC, kings began their reigns with declarations of reforms http://ow.ly/DcZ6m

Our #EgyptExhibition is now open! The exhibition charts the change from a world of many gods to the worship of one God. The remarkable objects in the exhibition have been uniquely preserved in Egypt's arid climate, and many have never been on display before. Their survival provides unparalleled access to the lives of individuals and communities, revealing how the shift to monotheism – the belief in one God – affected every part of life. Egypt's experience reflects the wider move from the ancient to medieval world, a transition that has shaped the world today. Find out more and book tickets http://ow.ly/THZEO

Beijing was designated the principal capital of the Ming empire #onthisday in 1420. At the beginning of the Ming dynasty the imperial court was located in Nanjing, but between 1403 and 1445 it was gradually moved to Beijing. The Yongle emperor commissioned the building of a new palace in 1417, modelling it on the Nanjing palace. It was built on the site of the abandoned Mongol Yuan dynasty palace. Beijing was established as the capital with the palace – now known as the Forbidden City – at its heart, and through a network of regional courts, the Ming emperors controlled a country the size of Europe. 

This hanging scroll shows the Forbidden City swathed in clouds, giving a sense of the vast size of the palace complex which covered over 720,000 square metres. The perspective allows us to see right up to the emperor's private quarters at the back. Built by forced labourers, the Forbidden City was then the world's largest walled complex http://ow.ly/DsAjx

This grant will help us deliver specialised training to establish a dedicated corps of Iraqi heritage professionals, fully skilled to deal with the aftermath of the destruction of key archaeological sites such as Nineveh, Nimrud and Hatra. Athelstan, Alfred the Great's grandson and widely regarded as the first King of England, died #onthisday in 939. On his father's death he was accepted as king first of Mercia, then of Wessex. Between the two kingdoms, he was effectively ruler of the whole of England south of the River Humber. 

In 927 he drove the Viking king Guthfrith out of York and seized the kingdom of Northumbria, thus bringing the whole of England under his control. Various rulers of neighbouring kingdoms in Wales and Scotland are said to have submitted to his authority, and it was probably around this time that Athelstan began to use the title Rex Totius Britanniae ('King of All Britain'). This appears on this coin in the form REX TO BRIT http://ow.ly/DcSOV

Artist William Hogarth died #onthisday in 1764. He asserted that these prints 'Beer Street' and 'Gin Lane' were 'calculated to reform some reigning Vices peculiar to the lower Class of People'. Beer Street celebrates the virtues of the mildly intoxicating traditional national drink: beer inspire artists and refreshes tradesmen and labourers, it can be drunk safely on rooftops! However 'Gin Lane' portrays the newfangled foreign spirit gin, inspiring violence and careless inebriation http://ow.ly/DcGIc

Pablo Picasso was born #onthisday in 1881. This study, probably executed in the winter of 1906-1907, was one of many leading up to his famous painting, Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (MoMA The Museum of Modern Art, New York).  The composition as a whole was conceived as a brothel scene with the more explicit title of Le Bordel d'Avignon provided by the artist himself, referring to a street in Barcelona. Les Demoiselles d'Avignon was the most difficult and revolutionary work of Picasso's career, and it profoundly disconcerted even his supporters when it was first exhibited in 1916 http://ow.ly/DbSab

status_message: Marcus Junius Brutus, assassin of Julius Caesar, took his own life #onthisday in 42 BC. This coin was struck in his honour. One side shows his portrait and the other the cap of liberty given to freed slaves, flanked by two daggers. This indicates Brutus' intention of freeing Rome from Caesar's imperial ambitions and the murder weapons employed to do so. Below is the day of the deed – EID.MAR, the Ides of March. The assassins, or 'freedom party' as they regarded themselves, fled Rome to Macedonia to raise an army. However, they were defeated by Caesar's allies led by Mark Antony and Octavian at the Battle of Philippi (42 BC). Brutus subsequently took his own life http://ow.ly/CTZXx

Today is #WombatDay! Wombats had a special place in Dante Gabriel Rossetti's heart and here in this pen drawing he laments the death of his wombat. Rossetti loved exotic animals and in a letter to his brother he described the arrival of his first pet wombat as 'a Joy, a Triumph, a Delight, a Madness'. This drawing commemorates the short-lived second wombat. It is inscribed with a verse:
'I never reared a young wombat
To glad me with his pin-hole eye,
But when he was most sweet and fat
And tail-less he was sure to die'

The Battle of Trafalgar, fought #onthisday in 1805, was probably the single most decisive naval engagement of the Napoleonic Wars. A fleet of 33 ships (18 French and 15 Spanish), under Admiral Pierre de Villeneuve, sailed into the Mediterranean to assist the French campaign in southern Italy. West of Cape Trafalgar, Spain, they met a British fleet of 27 ships under Admiral Horatio Nelson.

At 11.50am Nelson signalled the message 'England expects that every man will do his duty', a sentiment which has been reproduced in the legends of this and many other medals struck to celebrate the victory and commemorate the victor, who was killed by a sniper during the battle. This medal was struck at the expense of the manufacturer and engineer Matthew Boulton (1728–1809), and was intended for presentation to the men who fought under Nelson at Trafalgar http://ow.ly/TzqLw

Today's #MysteryObject is a Chinese belt hook, which is over 2,000 years old! The long robe known as a shenyi, which became popular during the Eastern Zhou period (770–221 BC), was secured by a belt which also required a hook. Belt hooks quickly became items for elaborate ornamentation. Personal decoration became very important as a marker of status and wealth. This example is made of bronze, inlaid with silver in geometric designs http://ow.ly/TzjPy

Sir Christopher Wren, one of England's most distinguished architects, was born #onthisday in 1632. He famously designed the new St. Paul's Cathedral, after the old Gothic structure burnt down in the Great Fire of London in 1666. From the beginning he planned a dome over his new building, making it England's only cathedral built in the classical architectural tradition. He altered the shape and profile of the dome several times but it was not until around 1697 that the exact design for the dome was agreed and it was finally completed in 1710. This freehand drawing by Wren was made to show the relation of the inner and outer domes. 

The cathedral also marks the site of Wren's tomb. The Latin inscription on his tomb beneath the dome, reads: 'Si monumentum requiris, circumspice' ('If you are seeking his monument, look around you') http://ow.ly/CUdhG
