The Roman poet Virgil was born #onthisday in 70 BC. His Aeneid reached every part of the empire, as shown by this writing tablet from Roman Britain! 

In the commanding officer's residence at Vindolanda Roman fort (modern Chesterholm), probably during the occupation by Cerialis and his family, someone took a wooden writing-tablet on which a private letter had been begun, but not finished. On the back of it they wrote a complete line from the second half of Virgil's Aeneid (9.473). It was certainly not a readily memorable line, which makes us wonder: Were the texts of Virgil available at Vindolanda? Were they used for writing practice as is commonly found on papyri? And by whom? http://ow.ly/CJO21

Here's a #MoneyFact for #EducationDay! The phrase 'piggy bank' originated from the use of 'pygg' clay (a type of orange clay) in the Middle Ages to make wide-necked storage jars, which were sometimes used to store money. The name stuck and people even began to make money-boxes in the shape of pigs! http://ow.ly/TqtN0

We're celebrating #EducationDay today! These cuneiform tablets are examples of homework from up to 3,500 years ago. Schooling in Mesopotamia began at an early age in the 'tablet-house'. The first thing a boy (and very rarely a girl) had to learn was how to make a tablet and handle the stylus which made the impressions in the clay. After learning the basic cuneiform signs the pupil went on to learn the thousands of different Sumerian words. The teacher would write out some lines on one side of a tablet. The schoolboy studied these, turned over the tablet and tried to reproduce what the teacher had written. Find out more http://ow.ly/Tqxzp

The Roman general Germanicus died #onthisday in AD 19. This statue of Germanicus, great-nephew of the emperor Augustus, was probably carved around the time of his death, shortly after a visit to Egypt. Years later, after the establishment of Christianity, someone inscribed a cross on his forehead. We can only speculate as to why the cross was added – did it neutralise spirits thought to dwell in images, or was it added to 'Christianise' a popular member of the imperial family? Or perhaps, following the ancient tradition of marking slaves with tattoos, was it to mark Germanicus as a 'slave of God,' just as we are told some Christians marked themselves?

You can see this magnificent bust in our forthcoming #EgyptExhibition http://ow.ly/STy1q

A #ThrowbackThursday from our #archives: an admission ticket to the Museum from 1790! http://ow.ly/S3emY 

The British Museum opened its doors to visitors for the first time on 15 January 1759. The Trustees decided that the Museum should be freely open to the general public as well as to academic visitors. However, they were afraid that the collections would be damaged if large crowds of people were allowed into the building. They therefore ordered that visitors should not be admitted unless they held tickets, and that only a small number of tickets should be issued for each day.

Like this ticket, issued for 1 p.m., all tickets were issued for a particular time. Visitors were taken around the Museum in groups of five, each group guided by one of the Under-Librarians. They were taken up the Great Staircase, through the upper rooms and down again to the ground floor. During their tour they were shown the collections of manuscripts, medals, antiquities and natural history.

Born #onthisday in AD 214: Roman emperor Aurelian, known as the restorer of the Roman Empire. For a brief five-year period, Aurelian returned stability and unity to the Roman empire. He brought both western and eastern provinces back into the fold, built powerful walls around the city of Rome which still stand to this day, and re-established the reputation of the Roman coinage.

This beautiful gold piece is a perfect symbol of Aurelian's rejuvenated empire - made of pure gold and of full weight. It is unlike the debased and light gold coins made by his predecessor Gallienus (AD 253-68) http://ow.ly/AXuOh

This portrait medal was commissioned by Goethe's son, and copies were given away to guests at Goethe's 80th birthday celebrations in 1829. Today for #MuseumInstaSwap we are exploring the incredible photo archives at Imperial War Museum, and discovering the surprising role that the British Museum played during the First World War. 

The Museum was used as part of the 'Prisoners of War Information Bureau'. The property of prisoners of war was stored at the Museum, where they were catalogued and, in the event of the POW's death, returned to their friends and relatives. These photos give a sense of the scale of this operation and show both the human cost of the conflict and the administrative machinery of the war effort.

This handkerchief commemorates the Peterloo Massacre, which occurred #onthisday in 1819 http://ow.ly/Qz2dk
 
More than 60,000 people from Manchester and the surrounding area had gathered at St Peter's Field in the city to demand the right to vote. Local magistrates ordered the arrest of the main speakers and the dispersal of the crowd. 18 people were killed and several hundred were injured. In the months that followed, prints, poems and a range of everyday objects such as plaques, jugs, bowls and handkerchiefs were produced in memory of the massacre. The Peterloo Handkerchief is a powerful reminder of this event and, more generally, of people's long struggle for universal suffrage in Britain.

A real mystery for #MysteryObject today! Can you help us to decipher the inscription on this sword? Find out more on Tumblr http://ow.ly/QKGBG

This double-edged sword was found in the River Witham near Lincoln. It is an extremely well preserved example of the type of sword which was common from about 1300. The blade is made of steel, which combines a sharply honed edge with the flexibility not to shatter in use, and is inlaid with gold wire to form an inscription which is yet to be deciphered. This sword is on loan to The British Library until 1 September as part of their #MagnaCarta exhibition.

Today's #MysteryObject is an Inca wooden drinking vessel from Peru known as a paccha. 

This drinking vessel is cleverly designed to circulate life-giving liquid. The bowl at one end on the puma's back is used to hold fermented maize beer (chicha). When tilted upward, the beer passes through a hidden, interior opening into the seated man, whose head is held by the puma's jaws. It then runs down the zigzag channels on the handle http://ow.ly/PSiCE

The spectacular Sutton Hoo treasure was discovered #onthisday in 1939! http://ow.ly/Q5x6j

The ship buried at Sutton Hoo is the largest Anglo-Saxon ship yet unearthed. It was 27 metres long, dug deep into the yellow sand in a tight-fitting trench. Learn more about this incredible archaeological discovery in this online exhibition http://ow.ly/Q1WBz

The spectacular Sutton Hoo treasure was discovered #onthisday in 1939! http://ow.ly/Q5x6j

Mrs Edith Pretty, a landowner at Sutton Hoo, Suffolk, asked archaeologist Basil Brown to investigate the largest of many Anglo-Saxon burial mounds on her property. Inside, he made one of the most spectacular archaeological discoveries of all time. Beneath the mound was the imprint of a 27-metre-long ship. At its centre was a ruined burial chamber packed with treasures: Byzantine silverware, sumptuous gold jewellery, a lavish feasting set, and most famously, an ornate iron helmet. 

You can see the treasure from Sutton Hoo on display in Room 41 http://ow.ly/Q5xME

Pearl shell is found along the north-west Australian coast but was also traded thousands of miles inland. Pearl shell was prized for its iridescent qualities – its capacity to shine – which spoke to Indigenous aesthetic sensibilities. It was incorporated into decorative forms for personal adornment or ritual http://ow.ly/PqB27

It's #NAIDOC week! We're celebrating the remarkable art and traditions of #IndigenousAustralia http://ow.ly/P5PQX

To celebrate #NAIDOC week, we're sharing some of the amazing objects from #IndigenousAustralia http://ow.ly/P5PQX

Spearthrowers like these are the Swiss army knife of the desert. Created and used exclusively by men, the broad body of these spearthrowers hints at its other functions. Its firm edges were used for digging in the desert sand and scraping the ground in preparing a place to sleep. Those same hardwood edges were sawed furiously against softer wood, to create the smouldering embers by which desert people made fire. In some parts of Australia stone knives were hafted to its end with natural resins, allowing the spearthrower to also be used for butchering animals and as a chisel for engraving other objects http://ow.ly/PgNg3

It's #NAIDOC2015 – a week celebrating the history and culture of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. We'll be sharing objects each day this week from our #IndigenousAustralia exhibition http://ow.ly/P5PQX

This masterpiece of Indigenous art is called 'Yumari' and is on loan from The National Museum of Australia. It was created by the artist Uta Uta Tjangala in 1981 and is a highlight of the exhibition. Tjangala was one of the artists who initiated the translation of sand sculptures and body painting onto canvas at Papunya in 1971, making him a pioneer of contemporary Australian art. This iconic work now features on the Australian passport.

Today Torres Strait Islanders celebrate the #ComingoftheLight, marking the day the London Missionary Society first arrived in the Torres Strait at the island of Erub on 1 July 1871. Since this date, customary beliefs have coexisted with Christianity. Today, Torres Strait Islanders celebrate this significant day with religious and cultural ceremonies across the Torres Strait and on mainland Australia.

This Torres Strait drum known as a warup is decorated with human figures and animals, including a dog, crocodile, turtle, fish and cassowary. The red cross on the skin is a sign of Christianity http://ow.ly/OM8nl
July is named after Julius Caesar. Fun fact: up until 44 BC the Romans called it Quintilis (fifth month) http://ow.ly/OL9l2

We're delighted to announce our first exhibition of the autumn 'Drawing in silver and gold: Leonardo to Jasper Johns', which opens 10 September http://ow.ly/P1NNn

This exhibition will feature around 100 of the best examples of #metalpoint spanning six centuries. Metalpoint is a challenging drawing technique where a metal stylus is used on a roughened preparation, ensuring that a trace of the metal is left on the surface. When mastered it can produce drawings of crystalline clarity and refinement. 

This exhibition was organised by the National Gallery of Art, Washington in association with the British Museum.

Book your tickets now to see these spectacular works http://ow.ly/P1NNn

The mummy case of this temple doorkeeper called Padiamenet is covered with hieroglyphic inscriptions and religious images. The inscriptions on this brilliantly painted cartonnage tell us that he was the Chief Doorkeeper of the Domain of Ra, the Chief Attendant of Ra, and also Chief Barber of the Domain of Ra and of the temple of Amun. This largest scene shows Padiamenet, dressed in a long fringed robe, adoring the god Osiris, who is grasping the royal crook and flail. Behind him stands his sister, the goddess Isis #MummyMonday http://ow.ly/OFll4

In ancient Greece, the household comprised an extended family of three generations, slaves and animals. The wife was at the centre of this network of familial relations and her authority extended across all aspects of domestic management. Men, by contrast, spent most of their lives outdoors, either securing the raw materials essential for the family's survival – grain for bread and fleeces for wives to process into textiles – or away on military and civic duties.

Discover ancient Greek depictions of male and female roles in the household #FridayFigure #DefiningBeauty http://ow.ly/OPs1R

This etching illustrating Ovid's Metamorphoses is by artist Salvator Rosa, born #onthisday in 1615 http://ow.ly/ObyGx

Rosa worked in Naples, Florence and Rome. He achieved great success with his landscape paintings of wild and mountainous scenery populated with travellers and bandits. His one hundred or so etchings, which have always been admired for their inventive figure groupings, reflect his desire to be known as more than a landscape painter.

Sickness and injury were features of everyday life for ancient Egyptians. The treatments of these ailments were a mixture of practical remedies, and magical rituals and incantations. This section of papyrus from c. 1300 BC describes treatments for four types of ailment: skin complaints, eye problems, haemorrhages and burns.

Come face to face with the Museum's amazing collection in unique object-based learning experiences. Our workshops, self-led tools and classroom resources inspire learning across the curriculum and are designed to meet the varied needs of students.

George III, born #onthisday in 1738, collected the King's Library, donated to the nation in 1823. 

When the library was donated there was not enough space to house it in the original British Museum building. This led to the construction of the quadrangle building at the centre of today's Museum, designed by the architect Sir Robert Smirke. The room for the King's Library was the first wing of the new building to be constructed, between 1823 and 1827, making it the oldest room in the Museum today http://ow.ly/NRnOQ

Today Minister Ed Vaizey launched the Treasure Annual Report, highlighting the latest finds from around the nation http://ow.ly/INvrj

One of the most amazing finds is the Lenborough Hoard, found in Buckinghamshire in December 2014. With over 5,000 Anglo-Saxon coins, this hoard is one of the largest of its kind ever found in Britain.

Through The Portable Antiquities Scheme we work with museums nationwide, enabling them to acquire key finds for local display. For now, coins from the Lenborough Hoard will be on display in the Citi Money Gallery (Room 68) http://ow.ly/IBFW4
Five artists from the Middle East and North Africa explore ideas of exile in a free display in Room 34 http://ow.ly/Iytsi

We're delighted to announce our next major exhibition 'Defining beauty: the body in ancient Greek art', which opens 26 March. 

The exhibition will feature over 150 works including iconic white marble statues, alongside terracottas, vases and beautiful bronzes. It will also include some of the most beautiful surviving Greek sculpture, including six Parthenon sculptures. 

Tickets are now on sale! Find out more and book now: http://ow.ly/GYVeA #DefiningBeauty

The art of restoration: new blog post on conserving a #Ming50Years painted scroll http://ow.ly/FwyUi

In this important collaborative project, Mrs Jin Xian Qiu, the Museum's Senior Conservator of Chinese paintings, and Chu Hao, a Shanghai Museum colleague, worked together to conserve this impressive painting on silk. Precious silk from the Ming era itself was used to painstakingly repair the areas of missing silk in the scroll, and it was hung up to dry post-conservation on board for three and a half months from March to July 2014.

Today we are helping the State Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg celebrate its 250th anniversary. Our Trustees are delighted to lend the marble Parthenon sculpture of the river god Ilissos to the State Hermitage Museum, in recognition of the shared Enlightenment principles and parallel histories uniting our museums. 

Read British Museum Director Neil MacGregor's blog post here: 
http://blog.britishmuseum.org/2014/12/05/loan-of-a-parthenon-sculpture-to-the-hermitage-a-marble-ambassador-of-a-european-ideal/

Edward III of England was born #onthisday in 1312. Gold coinage was revived during his reign. 

By the 1340s England was in a position to join other western European lands in successfully adding a gold coinage to its money. The new coins consisted of a florin, or double leopard, of fine gold, exactly double the size of the Florentine florin, to be worth six shillings, along with its half and quarter. Find out more http://ow.ly/DXtHi

Cnut the Great died #onthisday in 1035. He conquered England with an army of Vikings. He was also the first king of England to introduce a more contemporary style of bust on his coins http://ow.ly/DWxEF

King of Persia Cyrus the Great entered Babylon #onthisday in 539 BC. This iconic clay cylinder, known as the Cyrus Cylinder, is inscribed in Babylonian cuneiform with an account by Cyrus of his conquest of Babylon in 539 BC and the capture of Nabonidus, the last Babylonian king. 

The cylinder has sometimes been described as the 'first charter of human rights', as it describes measures of relief Cyrus brought to the inhabitants of the city after its capture. However it in fact reflects a long tradition in Mesopotamia where, from as early as the third millennium BC, kings began their reigns with declarations of reforms. http://ow.ly/DcZ6m

The Sydney Opera House opened #onthisday in 1973.

Designed by the Danish architect Jørn Utzon, the Sydney Opera House provoked fierce public controversy in the 1960s as much over the escalating cost of its construction as the innovative brilliance of its domed sail-like halls. Now recognised the world over as a magnificent architectural icon jutting into Sydney Harbour, the Sydney Opera House finally opened in 1973. 

In this Christmas card for 1972 Eric Thake (1904–1982) cheekily anticipates the long awaited opening with his domestic version of the grand architectural statement. Crockery stacked in a drying rack forms the shape of the Sydney Opera House, with water from the kitchen sink adjacent. The small housefly resting on one of the stacked plates adds an unmistakably Australian touch. http://ow.ly/D1sbs 

Text from Stephen Coppel's 'Out of Australia: Prints and Drawings from Sidney Nolan to Rover Thomas' http://ow.ly/D1s63

Today we announced that the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS)  online database has recorded over one million archaeological finds made by the public!

The #PASmillionth object is a copper alloy coin, part of a hoard of 22,000 Roman coins found in Seaton, Devon. This discovery is one of the largest Roman coin hoards ever found and the combined weight is 68kg! http://finds.org.uk/

Born #onthisday in 1890: author Agatha Christie. The British Museum held an exhibition in 2001–2002 called 'Agatha Christie and Archaeology: Mystery in Mesopotamia'. It presented a fascinating look at the secret life of one of the world's most popular writers. Christie originally became interested in archaeology on a visit to the site of Ur (in modern Iraq) in 1928. It was there where she met her future husband, the archaeologist Max Mallowan, and became involved in excavation of the sites in Iraq and Syria that were to make his name.
Find out more about her love for archaeology in this online tour http://ow.ly/Bukch

Be part of the #MuseumOfTheFuture conversation at our first debate on 11 September. 

The first debate will be introduced by Director Neil MacGregor and chaired by British Museum Trustee Dame Liz Forgan. 

Contributors will include James Cuno, President and CEO of The Getty Museum, Los Angeles, Sir Nicholas Kenyon, Managing Director of the Barbican Centre, Wim Pijbes, General Director of the Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam, author and playwright Bonnie Greer, and sculptor and British Museum Trustee Antony Gormley ow.ly/Au9H4

status_message: What do contemporary Islamic scholars/historians say about the Vikings? Curator Gareth Williams explains they thought the Vikings were 'the filthiest of God's creatures'

On this day 1,000 years ago the survivors of the Battle of Clontarf were burying their dead, some Irish, some Viking. Warriors were buried with possessions and weapons, ready to wake every morning and fight again in Valhalla. #VikingsLive is coming to a close with a torch-lit boat burial re-enactment.
Bettany Hughes is talking to runes expert Martin Findell. The Hunterston Brooch is Celtic, with a Gaelic name in Viking runes – an example of Britain's mixed heritage! #VikingsLive

Vikings founded kingdoms in Ireland, Northumbria and Normandy.
The Normans were originally Vikings and came to rule England as a whole after 1066. Here's Cnut, King of England 1016–1035, shown as a Christian warrior king in the Liber Vitae. Cnut controlled a great North Sea empire but the famous story of him and the sea probably isn't true! #VikingsLive
We're now moving on to talk about women in the Viking world. Bettany Hughes talks with Judith Jesch, author of Viking Poetry of Love and War http://ow.ly/w7Nh9 #VikingsLive

Curator Gareth Williams is now dressed as a 'fairly high status Viking'. Viking shields were made of wood, with a leather coating to help bind the planks, and a metal boss in their centre. Normally this metal boss is all that survives, but there is one example of an entirely intact shield in the #VikingExhibition. Viking armour was very hot and very heavy #VikingsLive

The Vale of York Hoard is a fascinating example of Viking emergency banking. The 700 individual items in the hoard were crammed into a liturgical cup and wrapped in lead before burial. 
Curator Gareth Williams helped unpack the cup – a Carolingian religious vessel. The hoard includes Islamic and Scandinavian coins, Russian neck-rings and Irish Sea arm-rings, all in the magnificent cup #VikingsLive

Exhibition Curator Gareth Williams says Vikings travelled because inheritance laws were broke up the land and shrank wealth. The best illustration of this interconnected world comes in the variety of objects from Viking sites. Silk was found in Dublin, probably from the Islamic Caliphate – not what you'd expect a Viking to wear #VikingsLive

Cinema audiences are seeing their first glimpse on the screen of the warship in the #VikingExhibition. Roskilde 6 is the longest Viking warship ever found – it would have carried 100 men, with 80 oarsmen #VikingsLive

British Museum Director Neil MacGregor's favourite object in #VikingExhibition is a silver figure, thought to be Odin, sitting on a throne. Odin is associated with war and conquest, wisdom and magic, poetry and prophecy. For Vikings, these characteristics would have been a mix of both masculine and feminine. We think it's Odin as he is flanked by two ravens Huginn and Muninn – Thought and Memory #VikingsLive
…and we're live! Michael Wood welcomes everyone to #VikingsLive – a private view of the show of the season, #VikingExhibition

This panel showing a roaring lion has been loaned to the Museum from the Pergamon Museum in Berlin. The lion is made from glazed bricks, and was originally part of the decoration of the throne room  in Nebuchadnezzar II's palace at Babylon. If you want to visit him over the Christmas holidays he can be found in Room 55.

The British Museum holds the national collection of Western prints and drawings, with over 50,000 prints and 2 million drawings! You can ask to see any of the Museum's works on paper in our beautiful Study Room – it's free http://ow.ly/rr2MI

We're grateful to receive an early Christmas gift – an extraordinary collection of modern German drawings given to the Museum by Count Christian Duerckheim! It includes key works by George Baselitz and Gerhard Richter, which will be displayed in a free exhibition in February 2014. Around half the works in the exhibition will be by Baselitz, including this remarkable 1965 drawing 'A new type'

Today is the Mexican #DayOfTheDead. The celebration of the festivals of All Saints and All Souls at the beginning of November evolved in Mexico into a joyful and ironic commemoration of the dead who experience a brief return to the pleasures of their former existence.  Here is a figure representing War from The Atomic Apocalypse, by the Linares family. See it in Room 24 http://ow.ly/qhcOm

In ancient Colombia, bats were associated with the underworld and admired for their night vision, agility in flight and hunting. Maybe you've seen our #BeyondElDorado 'bat-man' travelling around the London Underground…?

Happy Halloween! To celebrate here is the 'bat-man' from our #BeyondElDorado exhibition. Long before Bruce Wayne, this figure shows a man (probably a priest or a ruler) transforming into a bat. He's flown a long way to be here. Catch him while you can… http://ow.ly/qkFHj
Representations of bats were often worn by ancient Colombian elites. See beautiful stylised and abstract bats made of gold in the #BeyondElDorado exhibition http://ow.ly/qlNoI
Getting ready for #Halloween tomorrow? Here are a few suitably spooky things from the Museum's collection, exhibitions and archive http://ow.ly/qjRPS

This week is your last chance to see this beautiful Japanese painted screen in our free Room 3 display. The rare surviving screen depicts elaborately dressed courtesans, who would be known today as female sex workers. 

If you can't make it to the display, explore the screen online and watch a video narrated by Sir David Attenborough about its restoration http://ow.ly/qh9aT

Born #onthisday in 1797, Anthony Panizzi became the Principal Librarian at the British Museum in 1856. The 'SPQR' inscription on this gold coin stands for Senatus Populusque Romanus ('The Senate and People of Rome'). No matter where they were minted, the same gold coins were used as currency across the Roman Empire, including the province of Britannia.

The kitchen (culina) was usually small and dark, even in larger Roman houses – usually only slaves used it. Diet varied from multi-course banquets for the rich to pies, pastries and bread for the poorer Romans. We asked Giorgio Locatelli to recreate the recipe for the 2,000-year-old bread on display as part of his culinary investigations for Pompeii Live http://ow.ly/nzbdS

Have you been to #PompeiiExhibition yet? In it you go through the rooms of a Roman house to see how the Romans lived.

The living areas of a wealthy Roman's house were sumptuously decorated with frescoes, mosaics and painted ceilings. The dining room was called the triclinium, but we don't know what they called living spaces – Greek words exedra and oecus were both used. Find out more about how Romans lived in the #PompeiiExhibition http://ow.ly/nsxxW or download the official app http://ow.ly/nsxCV

 'The Mummy' will be showing on Saturday 31 August! Beware of the Museum's 'unlucky mummy' while you're here though. The 'unlucky mummy' is actually not a mummy at all but a painted wooden 'mummy-board' or inner coffin lid. In ancient Colombia gold was not used as currency, but was valued for its symbolic properties and relationship to the life-giving sun.

One of the most spectacular archaeological discoveries ever made. 

Explore our new online exhibit in the Google Cultural Institute to discover the story of the Anglo-Saxon ship burial found at Sutton Hoo in the east of England. From a remarkable helmet, to an exquisite gold belt buckle, the extraordinarily rich treasures were unearthed in 1939, buried inside a huge ship. 

Discover the objects, and the story of their burial and discovery http://ow.ly/mmrYS

status_message: #PompeiiLive has finished! Thanks to everyone who helped make the first ever live broadcast from the British Museum such a great success. Join us on Friday 21 June at 14.00 BST over on Twitter @britishmuseum for a live Q&A with Exhibition Curator Paul Roberts and presenter Peter Snow.
The people of Herculaneum died first at around midnight, with the people of Pompeii and their animals to follow around 07.00 or 08.00 the next morning #PompeiiLive
Bettany Hughes and Rachel de Thame are in the garden room of the exhibition, discussing the profusion of flowers and wildlife in the frescos #PompeiiLive

Chef Giorgio Locatelli has just talked about baking bread in #PompeiiLive. http://ow.ly/m9KpT Find out how to make your own bread to a 2,000-year-old recipe here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYTuNXq1eBk

Presenter Peter Snow explains how the people of Pompeii thought that Mount Vesuvius was inactive, despite an eruption 16 or 17 years before AD 79, as shown in this marble relief of the Temple of Jupiter in Pompeii's Forum
…and we're live! #PompeiiLive from the British Museum is now live in HD to cinemas around the UK and Ireland http://ow.ly/m9BVd
Here are some pictures of the presenters arriving...
With a matter of hours until the live broadcast of #PompeiiLive, here are some images of the preparations taking place! Are you coming tonight? Where are you watching the show? http://ow.ly/m8Lnh

Are you coming to the schools broadcast of #PompeiiLive? http://ow.ly/m8wCq 
We're taking questions from children in advance of the Schools broadcast tomorrow. What have you always wanted to know about Pompeii and Herculaneum? Send us your questions using #PompeiiLive!
Catch up on the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas tonight at 19.00 http://ow.ly/m6LVy

We're publishing the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas tonight at 19.00.
As dawn breaks, the cloud collapses for the last time and darkness spreads across the Bay of Naples. Between 06.00 and 08.00 huge pyroclastic surges pour onto Pompeii killing everyone still there and smashing remaining buildings http://ow.ly/m6IHV

Today, we're publishing the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas on Tuesday at 19.00.
The cloud reaches its maximum height of over 30km then collapses spectacularly. A massive pyroclastic surge cascades down Vesuvius's north-west slopes, instantly killing everyone it touches http://ow.ly/m6DHF

Today, we're publishing the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas tomorrow at 19.00.
Ash and pumice stones rain down on Pompeii. People are trapped by blocked doors and roofs collapse http://ow.ly/m63Zx

Today, we're publishing the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas tomorrow at 19.00.
After several small explosions, Vesuvius erupts, sending a tall mushroom cloud of superheated rock and gas over 20km into the sky http://ow.ly/m5OOL

Today, we're publishing the story of the day Mount Vesuvius erupted in AD 79, in anticipation of #PompeiiLive – in cinemas tomorrow at 19.00.
For the peoples of Pompeii and Herculaneum, the day of the eruption would have started like any other…

Over 600 students, teachers and parents from community schools in London visited the Pompeii and Herculaneum exhibition last weekend and created their own fantastic Roman mosaics.

This bronze statue of the Roman emperor Augustus' wife Livia was found in the theatre at Herculaneum. As a public figure in a position of power, Livia would have been the female role model of her day. Read more about the unknown city of Herculaneum from project curator Vanessa Baldwin on the Museum's blog http://ow.ly/kTFXq
Have you seen any lambs yet this #spring? This drawing from 1863 is by Jemima Blackburn http://ow.ly/jjHPx

Wearing decorative objects is an almost universal human custom with very early examples existing in #IceAgeArt. Amongst other things, jewellery can communicate information about personal identity, belief and social status.
See these mammoth ivory beads that are at least 26,000 years old in the #IceAgeArt exhibition, now open until 2 June 2013 http://ow.ly/kTJrt

Image © Anthropos Institute, Moravian Museum, Brno, CZ

Are you relaxing in the garden now spring is here? By AD 79 the garden had been transformed into a place for relaxation and luxury in the Roman home. See garden sculpture and furnishings – from a carbonised wooden bench and marble sundial to a phallic bronze wind-chime – inside the Pompeii exhibition http://ow.ly/kTtpy

The Romans even brought the garden into the centre of the home as you can see in these stunning garden frescoes from the House of The Golden Bracelet.
Experience fine dining in Roman Britain in our free Room 3 display from 23 May. Recline on a curved couch (stibadium) and take your place around the glorious Mildenhall Great Dish! http://ow.ly/kR3ny

In this painting of a party in a Pompeian house, one slave takes off his master's shoes, while another stops his drunken master from falling over.

Aulus Umbricius Scaurus made his fortune making something held in bottles like the one in this mosaic. What was it?
Shakespeare died on this day in 1616. Here is the title page of his First Folio, which was displayed at the exhibition Shakespeare: staging the world last year. http://ow.ly/kduXE

Happy 132nd birthday Natural History Museum, London. Here's the British Museum before the natural history collection moved to South Kensington!

The brand new Pompeii and Herculaneum exhibition app is now available to download! Immerse yourself in these two ill-fated Roman cities with over 250 images and an interactive timeline of the eruption: http://www.britishmuseum.org/pompeiiapp

Carbonised wooden furniture like this cradle comes from Herculaneum, where the temperature reached 400°C during the eruption. If you can't make the Pompeii exhibition, don't miss the world première of Pompeii Live for an exclusive private view of the exhibition – coming soon to a cinema near you http://ow.ly/jTdku

Happy Birthday to Sir Hans Sloane! Born in 1660, his collection of over 71,000 objects (including natural history specimens, books, coins and medals) became the cornerstone of the British Museum. Are you a collector? Tell us what makes your collection special!
Want to get closer to Pompeii and Herculaneum? Enter this prize draw to win a holiday to Italy and see both cities for yourself! http://ow.ly/k45nB

To encourage some sunshine in London this spring, we'll share some spring-themed images from the collection. Take inspiration from this beautiful Chinese hanging scroll which shows a peony and cherry blossom in a vase http://ow.ly/jjHwp
To say Happy Birthday to Leonardo da Vinci, here is his striking drawing of a warrior in profile http://ow.ly/k4Vfg

There are just two weeks left to see a beautiful selection of travel drawings and watercolours by scholar Edward Dodwell and artist Simone Pomardi in the free exhibition 'In search of Classical Greece' http://ow.ly/jZLfP Don't miss this 'ancient Greek gap year' – Brian Sewell reviews: http://ow.ly/jZKSr

Happy Vaisakhi! To celebrate, come and see the Museum's Sikh fortress turban http://ow.ly/jXws9 The turban is a rare object – only five exist in Britain. It's currently on tour around the UK and you can see it at Birmingham Museum until 28 April http://ow.ly/jXyfH

Final stop – Monty is back at the British Museum where his #mammothadventure ends. He's taking part in the family activities this week for #IceAgeArt http://ow.ly/jZUlN 

Thanks for following Monty's #mammothadventure and thanks to Creswell Crags, The Manchester Museum, National Museums Scotland, Royal Pavilion & Brighton Museums and Natural History Museum, London for being great hosts!
Monty has come face to face with a fierce sabre-tooth cat that became extinct around 9,000 years ago on his #mammothadventure. Where is he?

This bronze statue of Lucius Mammius Maximus, a wealthy ex-slave, used to stand in the theatre at Herculaneum. For the next six months it will be in the Great Court. See more from Pompeii and Herculaneum inside the exhibition http://ow.ly/jTcqz
Monty is 'chilling out' at a new icy-themed exhibition beside the seaside. Where is he today on his #mammothadventure?

Just two weeks left to visit our fabulous free exhibition on African textiles in Room 91 http://ow.ly/jQsTc. The translation of this warning kanga from Tanzania means 'you know nothing'. Explore more of the textiles on our Pinterest board: http://ow.ly/jQt2o
The female face has twist to her smile and an injured eye, the chin is dimpled. This is the first known human portrait, see it at #IceAgeArt until 26 May http://ow.ly/joRGN
During the last Ice Age, the location of this museum would have been covered with glaciers. Where is Monty today on his #mammothadventure?
Monty has found one family member on his #mammothadventure – Maharajah, an Asian Elephant! Where do you think he is?
There are many fakes and forgeries in the collection – here's a famous one for April Fools' Day http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/r/rock_crystal_skull.aspx
In the UK clocks go forward 1 hour today – there are hundreds to change in the Clocks and Watches Gallery http://ow.ly/jjMI6

What is your favourite room or space in the Museum and why?

Counting your pennies this January? All of the one pound coins in this case at the Citi Money Gallery are fake. The Royal Mint estimates that around one in 35 one pound coins in circulation today are counterfeits. Discover more fascinating facts about the history of money for free at the Citi Money Gallery http://www.britishmuseum.org/money

A wonderful new Roman gold hoard found in St Albans, which featured in the Treasure Annual Report launch yesterday, went on display today in the Citi Money Gallery. 

The hoard is one of the largest ever finds of late 4th-century Roman gold coins in this country, and is of national significance. Read more about it here: http://ow.ly/fOI1f

status_message:
Money fact Monday: Ring the changes
With infrastructure virtually destroyed in the devastating earthquake in 2010, the people of Haiti rapidly embraced mobile phone payments. When it comes to turning the phone into a wallet, the UK and much of Europe fall well behind countries like Haiti where wireless and mobile technologies are changing people's lives. Watch this video to find out more: http://ow.ly/djp7W

This object is a vessel used in a drinking game from China during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911). Each player would aim arrows at the openings and the person who did not hit the target would have to drink alcohol. The more one drank, the greater the disadvantage! http://ow.ly/efiMd

Find more Asian drinking objects at the free exhibition Ritual and revelry: the art of drinking in Asia http://ow.ly/eq9pM

Money fact Monday: Shell out for currency
Currencies made from stone, feather or shells, like this Kina shell from Papua New Guinea, have performed an important social and cultural function alongside their economic one in many parts of the world. Today, this heritage is a source of pride for some countries, and traditional currencies often feature in the design of their national coins and banknotes.

Discover more stories about the history of money at the new Citi Money Gallery http://ow.ly/djpFJ

Left to right: Professor Kobayashi (Emeritus Professor of Archaeology at Kokugakuin University, Tokyo), Mr Tamio Mori (Mayor of Nagaoka city), Mr Wataru Sawamura (London Bureau Chief and European Editor, The Asahi Shimbun, sponsor of the display).

Those of you that said figs are correct!

Carbonised figs and pieces of bread. Probably from Herculaneum, AD 79. 
These are almost certainly from Herculaneum, where the ash was hotter than that which covered Pompeii, and so carbonised wood, leather and foodstuffs. Copyright Trustees of the British Museum
link_name: Life and death in Pompeii and Herculaneum

status_message:
Money Fact Monday: ways and means
As well as being used as money, coins can symbolise spiritual well-being, fertility or other sorts of wealth. In Buddhist cultures, offerings of money were thought to bring spiritual benefit to the donor. This vase and 66 bronze coins were part of a group of offerings dedicated to the Buddha by a man called Vagramarega, for the benefit of himself and his family. Find more interesting facts at the British Museum's new Citi Money Gallery.

http://ow.ly/e7emm
link_name: British Museum - Bronze reliquary and Kushan coins from a Buddhist relic deposit

status_message:
Money fact Monday: Money talks
As well as having purchasing power, coins also have the power to send messages through the images or writing on them. Roman emperors, such as Nero, often used money as a way of presenting a particular image of themselves on coins that circulated throughout the empire's many provinces.

Watch this video from the new Citi Money Gallery of the emperor Nero as he ages from 14 to 25 on his coins http://ow.ly/djrbj

The free special late event Unfolding Shakespeare's London is on tonight at the Museum from 18.00. It includes talks with Michael Dobson, costume demonstrations with the Royal Shakespeare Company, singing in the galleries and the chance to sample syllabub shots.
Come along for some Shakespeare-themed merriment and tag your photos on Instagram and Twitter.

RSVP: http://ow.ly/dSN7P
More info: http://ow.ly/dSOrn

Just announced – the Museum's major exhibition for 2013 is Life and death in Pompeii and Herculaneum from 28 March to 29 September. The exhibition will explore the Roman home and everyday people who lived in these ill-fated cities. Many of the objects have never before been seen outside Italy. Curator Paul Roberts said this morning 'there has never been an exhibition quite like this'. 

Tickets on sale now http://ow.ly/dQYRu
link_name: Life and death in Pompeii and Herculaneum

Money fact Monday: Something of note
It was the Chinese who first printed a value on a piece of paper and persuaded everyone that it was worth what it said it was. The whole modern banking system of paper and credit is built on this one simple act of faith.

Discover more stories about the history of money at the new Citi Money Gallery: http://ow.ly/djgsQ

status_message:
Money fact Monday: Change is good
In the early 1900s this British penny was defaced to promote the suffragette cause. This bold criminal act was one of many that catapulted the movement for women's right to vote into the political limelight. The penny stands for all those who fought for this monumental change http://ow.ly/djger
Over the next few Mondays, discover how money has changed our world with fascinating facts from the Museum's new Citi Money Gallery. http://ow.ly/djgsQ

status_message: It's Nelson Mandela Day today. Sonny Venkatrathnam, who was imprisoned with Nelson Mandela on Robben Island during Apartheid, and Greg Doran from the RSC came to the Shakespeare exhibition yesterday to speak about the 'Robben Island bible' – a copy of the Complete Works of William Shakespeare that was brought into the Robben Island jail by Sonny and used by fellow prisoners including Mandela. It is on display in the exhibition opening tomorrow. Listen to the interview with Sonny and Greg here: http://ow.ly/cjORd

Today in 1687, renowned scientist and all-round genius Sir Isaac Newton published his seminal work 'Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica' which included his laws of motion. This carved bust of him (on display in Room 46) shows him in informal dress and without his famous wig! What would he have made of the recent Higgs boson discovery in CERN? http://ow.ly/c1VzM

Here's a sneak peek of the Shakespeare exhibition opening 19 July! This ship model was just installed in the section of the exhibition called 'Kingship, rebellion and witchcraft' – three important themes for Shakespeare and his audiences. It was possibly made to give thanks for survival at sea. King James VI of Scotland and his new bride Anne of Denmark had been at the mercy of powerful storms in the North Sea at the time of their marriage, which were thought to be the work of witches. A string of trials and executions followed both in Denmark and Scotland.

The new Citi Money Gallery is now open! Featuring over 1,000 objects, the gallery looks at the history of the world through the lens of money, from 4,500 years ago to the latest developments in digital technology. At a time when the global economic situation is rarely out of the news, discover the fascinating stories of how money has shaped the world we live in.

Dr Dee's magic mirror and the Great Seal are two objects in our Shakespeare exhibition thought to have been owned by Dr John Dee. Dee might have been the model for Prospero in Shakespeare's The Tempest. Find out more about the exhibition: http://ow.ly/bJgun

What passage or play in the Complete Works of Shakespeare would you mark?
This morning, the 'Robben Island Bible', one of the objects in our upcoming exhibition Shakespeare: staging the world, was installed in the exhibition space.
link_name: Shakespeare exhibition: The Robben Island Bible

status_message: The Robben Island Bible is a copy of the Complete Works of William Shakespeare that was kept in secret in the Robben Island jail near Cape Town during Apartheid in the 1970s. Prisoners marked their favorite passage or play including Nelson Mandela, who was imprisoned on the island for 18 years.
link_name: Shakespeare exhibition: The Robben Island Bible

status_message: The book was kept by political prisoner Sonny Venkatrathnam, and its cover was disguised with Diwali cards to prevent its seizure by prison authorities. It  is a testament to the continuing importance and relevance of Shakespeare and his plays through time and across the globe and how, 400 years after they were first written, these plays and poems still have the power to speak to the world.
link_name: Shakespeare exhibition: The Robben Island Bible

status_message: Mandela chose a passage from Julius Caesar; his signature dated 16 December 1977. In Africa, the play Julius Caesar had long been a symbol for rebellion against imperial rule. The prisoners used the book as a tool for learning, debate and inspiration.
link_name: Shakespeare exhibition: The Robben Island Bible

status_message: It's Albrecht Dürer birthday today. This famous woodcut records the arrival of an Indian rhinoceros in Lisbon in 1515. Rhinoceros had not been seen in Europe for over 1,000 years, so Dürer worked solely from sketches and reports that had reached Nuremberg of the event. He covered the creature's legs with scales and the body with hard, patterned plates. Explore more: http://ow.ly/b2W3d
13 to 18 year olds: This Saturday, join Present Joys and learn how to design, illustrate and print your own mini-magazine. All free but make sure you book in advance: http://ow.ly/b2sDc
Our conservation team has begun to excavate one of the largest hoards of Roman coins ever found in the UK. How many coins do you think are in the hoard?
link_name: The Beau Street Hoard: excavating Roman treasure, one coin at a time

status_message: Here's a peek behind the scenes of the free exhibition on the horse, opening next Thursday. Curator Nigel puts the finishing touches to a reconstruction of an Assyrian chariot horse's harness. The original is around 3,000 years old and includes cheekpieces and blinkers which helped horses to keep calm in the noise and confusion of battle.

North American Landscape is now open! The team from Kew have been working hard to build the landscape in rainy weather over the last few weeks and it has paid off. Come and visit if you're in London - it's free. You can also explore some of the landscape's star plants online.

A free exhibition of Picasso's most important set of prints opens tomorrow. Picasso's Vollard Suite was made between 1930 and 1937 when he was involved in a passionate affair with his young muse and model, Marie-Thérèse Walter. Read more about it on our website: http://ow.ly/aEyc6 or in an article in the Guardian: http://ow.ly/aEBXD

Every age has its own fantasy of the great city and in Shakespeare's time it was Venice. 16th-century Venice was the shopping capital of Europe, the centre of trade, and a melting pot of nationalities, religions, classes and cultures all existing within one magnificent city built on water. So the question is: What's your vote for today's 'great city'?
link_name: BBC - Shakespeare's Restless World - 2012 - Sex and the City - A Goblet...

status_message:
This Chinese porcelain Zamzam water flask is one of the objects on display in the Hajj exhibition. 
'Zamzamiyas' are bottles containing water from the sacred well of Zamzam, in Mecca. Pilgrims would often bring their own flasks to Mecca and fill them with Zamzam water which they would use to drink from during their Hajj. Flasks containing Zamzam would also be bought back home to give as gifts. Find out more about Hajj, the sacred Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, in the exhibition. More info: http://ow.ly/9nGl8

Don't forget to test your knowledge on Hajj in our Facebook quiz. You could win tickets to the exhibition. Hint: visiting the tomb of the Prophet Muhammad in Medina is NOT one of the rituals one must do on Hajj... http://ow.ly/9pVeZ

The British Museum team is installing the Mahmal, for the forthcoming exhibition which explores the pilgrimage to Mecca - known as Hajj. The exhibition - Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam - opens to the public on Thursday 26 January 2012.
The Mahmal was the ceremonial palanquin carried on a camel which was the centrepiece of the pilgrim caravan. It was the symbol of the authority of the sultan over the holy places.

The Silverdale Viking Hoard was discovered in mid-September 2011 by Darren Webster, a local metal-detectorist, in the Silverdale area of North Lancashire. The find was reported to the local Finds Liaison Officer that evening, which is part of the Portable Antiquities Scheme that the museum manages (more info on www.finds.org.uk.). The find is hugely significant containing a total of 201 silver objects such as coins, arm-rings, ingots and brooches. Of particular interest is the fact that the hoard contains a previously unrecorded coin type, probably carrying the name of an otherwise unknown Viking ruler in northern England. Read more about it on the blog: http://ow.ly/80dyn
Just revealed: a Viking hoard has been uncovered containing a new coin type with the name of an unknown Viking ruler...
link_name: Two hoards and one unknown Viking ruler

status_message: Today we announced the major acquisition of a complete set of Picasso's Vollard Suite, which will go on display next year from 3 May to 2 September 2012. The suite comprises 100 etchings produced by Picasso between 1930 and 1937 and is the only complete Suite held by a public museum in the UK.  Some of the themes explored in the etchings are classical sculpture and the myth of the Minotaur (the half-man, half-animal of classical myth which became central to Picasso's personal mythology). His model was his young lover Marie-Thérèse Walter who also features in many of the etchings. The acquisition was made possible through the  generosity of the Hamish Parker Charitable Trust in memory of the donor's father, Major Horace Parker.

Hajj is a life-changing journey for the 3 million Muslims every year who make their pilgrimage to Mecca. To get a sense of what it's like, take a look at the stories we've collected for our forthcoming exhibition on Hajj (opening in January 2012) from those who've been – like Heni Setiyowati from Bandung Jawa Barat in Indonesia:
'I am from Indonesia. One year ago I go to Mecca with my husband. Seeing so many people from all around the world, from different countries, different skin colour but praying together is the thing I remember the most. So many people and such a peaceful and safe place.'

In the spirit of clarity, the British Museum wants to be unambiguous and accurate on this issue – the Buddha was born in Lumbini which is in Nepal. The Museum is always seeking to find the clearest way to put past history into understandable statements in the Museum, on our website and in our online records. Thank you for your feedback. Please be assured this is an important issue to the Museum and has been passed on to our curatorial team to establish where further clarity in the Museum and online may be required.

In light of recent comments about the Buddha's birthplace, we would like to reassure you that the Museum does not state that the Buddha was born in India. We state that the Buddha was born into a small kingdom that flourished in north-eastern India in about 500 BC. The kingdom covered a reasonably wide area in the northern plains, along with several others of the time. When the Buddha's mother was expecting, the family decided that she should proceed north to the hills to give birth. This she did, but gave birth along the way, in Lumbini at foot of the Himalayas. The site of Lumbini is in Nepal about 20 miles from the modern border with the Republic of India. If you are aware of an instance where the incorrect information is written or posted please let us know where so we can look into it. You are welcome to leave comments about this subject on the main wall but please note that comments about this subject on unrelated posts will be deleted as they are off topic. Please see further information about commenting in the info tab.

What is Grayson Perry's exhibition, The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman, about? In this short BBC video, Grayson – curator of the exhibition that opened today – introduces some of his new works and British Museum objects on display.

Grayson Perry's exhibition The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman opens tomorrow. Grayson has been working with the Museum over the last 2 years selecting objects from various departments to curate these alongside his own objects and create an imaginary civilisation. At the press view this morning, Director Neil MacGregor introduced the exhibition saying it was quite different to anything we've done before. Usually exhibitions will be based on academic research of a particular subject, but the British Museum is also a storehouse of the world's imagination. It's a source of inspiration and has been for many artists. The exhibition shows how we can think about the world and the extraordinary imaginative power of the collection.
link_name: British Museum -  Grayson Perry: The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman

status_message: St John… St Thomas Becket… David Beckham? Part of the Treasures of Heaven exhibition looks at modern veneration. Christian relic veneration began around AD 330 and the practice has continued to this day. However, by the 18th century, relics had also moved into the popular and secular sphere and today there are many forms of secular pilgrimage or veneration – think of Elvis's grave in Graceland or Juliet's balcony in Verona. Have you ever been somewhere to venerate a non-religious icon?
link_name: A look at modern veneration, part of Treasures of Heaven at the British Museum

status_message: Today some parts of the world are celebrating the Assumption of Mary, the mother of Christ (when she was carried to Heaven after her death). This panel-shaped reliquary of the True Cross, which is on display in the Treasures of Heaven exhibition, once contained what was believed to be a fragment of Virgin Mary's belt. In Eastern Orthodoxy, the belt or cincture is believed to have been given to Thomas the Apostle by the Virgin three days after her funeral. Though the festival of the cincture is only celebrated in the Orthodox church, the feast of the Assumption of the Virgin is celebrated by both East and West. Is it being celebrated where you live?
How do you get 4,000 years of the history of money into just one room? This is exactly what Catherine Eagleton, Curator of the new Money Gallery, is figuring out.

Christian relics are objects associated with Christ and the saints such as body parts or possessions. Relics were usually set into ornate containers made from precious materials known as reliquaries and had spiritual and symbolic value. There are thousands of relics in the world. Are there any reliquaries in the town or region where you live?

This free display shows Oman's recent cultural heritage through items of adornment such as clothing and jewellery. In the video, Fahmida, the exhibition's curator, introduces the display and tells some of the stories behind the objects. Open until 18 September 2011.
link_name: Adornment and identity: jewellery and costume from Oman

Film screening: Set in Sydney, Kevin and Bob roam the city's suburbs in their yellow FJ Holden. This once controversial, now rarely seen film, is an account of coming of age in 70s urban Australia.

Grayson Perry has just sent the Museum this video appeal. He's looking for stunt double teddy bears for his exhibition The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman (6 October 2011 - 19 February 2012). Can you help? Enter here http://bit.ly/ohXNDY

status_message: The Museum's current major exhibition Treasures of Heaven has received some great feedback. Have you seen it? If so, what did you think? Was it a spiritual experience for you or were you stunned by the objects' amazing craftsmanship and their place in history?
link_name: Introduction to the Treasures of Heaven exhibition at the British Museum

status_message: The Museum is open late every Friday until 20.30. Most galleries are open as well as the Treasures of Heaven exhibition, snacks and drinks are served outside in the forecourt, there are free spotlight tours every half hour and film screenings on some evenings! Have a look at the summer programme.

Director Neil MacGregor announced at this morning's press launch the major exhibition that will kick off 2012. It is on Hajj, the sacred journey to Mecca. Tickets are on sale now at www.britishmuseum.org/hajj. 
If you have been on Hajj, the Museum wants to hear from you! Please share your memories here http://bit.ly/nM35B4
link_name: British Museum -  Hajj: journey to the heart of Islam

status_message: Thanks to everyone who has made a guess.... some are certainly closer than others! This major exhibition kick starts the Museum's 2012 exhibition programme. There's a press launch tomorrow morning and all will be unveiled then....
This astonishing object will be in the Museum's new major exhibition. Can you guess the theme?

WANTED: Charismatic bears with great brains and delusions of grandeur. 
Grayson Perry is looking for three teddy bears to star in his exhibition opening in October at the British Museum. This is your teddy's chance to take the spotlight in front of millions of visitors. Follow the link and enter now.

Pharaoh: King of Egypt is opening at the Great North Museum Hancock this Saturday. After travelling for 7 hours, the objects  - including some of Egypt's greatest pharaohs Thutmosis III and Ramesses the Great - are now ready to be seen. What does it take to bring the objects together? Read to find out.
link_name: The pharaohs are coming « British Museum blog

status_message: If you've seen Treasures of Heaven and you feel the need to explore the world of medieval devotion a bit more, take a look at the National Gallery's great new exhibition Devotion by Design. It looks at some of the Gallery's most beautiful paintings in new ways by showing how altarpieces were designed and built.
link_name: Devotion by Design: Italian Altarpieces before 1500 | Exhibitions and displays | What's on | Nationa

status_message: 'A nation stays alive when its culture stays alive'. Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World closes this Sunday, 17 July. This is your last chance to see the surviving treasures from the National Museum of Afghanistan before they leave London that were nearly lost during civil war and Taliban rule. Book your tickets now http://bit.ly/gyLgBa
link_name: British Museum -  Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World

status_message:
EVENT HIGHLIGHT OF THE WEEK
This Friday, come and see a screening of the award-winning film Samson and Delilah. A story of two Aboriginal teens who escape from the violence and poverty around them to live together in the Central Australian desert. http://bit.ly/hNhHKH

You've seen the image of St Ursula's companion as the current profile picture or perhaps on one of the posters around London. It is one of the many fascinating objects in the Treasures of Heaven exhibition that reveals more about the medieval mind. This video tells the story of St Ursula and her 11,000 virgin companions and the elaborate craftsmanship of this female bust.

A new Cycladic figurine from around 2300-2200 BC has just been acquired and is on display in Room 11. He is the first male figurine of this kind to be added to the collection, and so is vastly outnumbered by the female figurines surrounding him. Who did he belong to? Why is he so rare? Find out in the blog.
link_name: Newly-acquired Cycladic figurine goes on display « British Museum blog

status_message: BIG NEWS: artist Grayson Perry will curate a special exhibition at the Museum. Opening in October, The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman shows his new works alongside objects by unknown craftsmen throughout history from the Museum's collection. Watch Grayson's introduction to the exhibition: http://bit.ly/iYInUp
link_name: British Museum -  Grayson Perry: The Tomb of the Unknown Craftsman

status_message: The Money Gallery is being refurbished. For the next 12 months, follow the project team as they blog about which objects to display, how to design the new space, what information to write on the panels and how to keep track of the thousands of small objects while the gallery works are in progress...
link_name: Making a new Money gallery at the British Museum « British Museum blog

status_message: The Afghanistan exhibition contains 19 glass vessels found in the ancient storerooms at Begram. Some functioned as tableware but others remain something of a mystery, including ones shaped as fish. Read Curator St John's blog to find out more: http://bit.ly/kD7weT. Also, watch the video to see the first ever attempt at replicating them...

The Afghanistan exhibition is in its final weeks and now's your chance to chat to the Afghan curators that have accompanied the exhibition objects as they travelled the world. Join Curator Farhad Sediqy and Conservator Abdullah Hakimzada from the National Museum of Afghanistan for a live Q&A on Twitter this Thursday, 30 June at 13.00(BST). Ask your questions now or tweet them to @britishmuseum using #afghanistanBM

status_message: A History of the World won the Art Fund Prize! The British Museum is delighted to win the Prize on behalf of the unique partnership with BBC and in collaboration with 550 other heritage partners. It was this collaboration that made the project so successful. Therefore, the Prize money will be used to fund loan programmes with museums across the UK.
link_name: The Art Fund Prize for museums and galleries

status_message: Read St John's, Curator of the Afghanistan exhibition, blog post about the story of a Buddha sculpture from the National Museum of Afghanistan that had been lost for nearly 20 years. The sculpture dates back to the second or third century AD when a naturalistic style of art flourished in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The Buddha is on display at the Museum in Room 1 until 17 July.
link_name: A Buddha returns to Afghanistan « British Museum blog

status_message: Watch the remarkable story of conservation and repatriation of the Begram Ivories. Excavated in the 1930s, they were part of the National Museum of Afghanistan's collection but went missing during the unrest. They re-emerged in 2010 and have been conserved at the BM. See them before their return to Kabul in the exhibition: Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World – until 17 July 2011. Tickets at britishmuseum.org

status_message: In 2007, 80 gold dollars were found in Hackney, London when residents were digging a pond for their garden. The find was reported and with help from the Museum's Department of Portable Antiquities & Treasure they were identified as $20 'double-eagle' coins. They belonged to Martin Sulzbacher, a German Jew that had fled Nazi Germany. The coins tell a fascinating story with a surprising twist... Read to find out more.
link_name: Unearthing the story of the Hackney Hoard «

Alexander the Great conquered Afghanistan between 329 and 327 BC. Ai Khanum, a city in northern Afghanistan and a year's march away from Athens, became the furthest outpost of the Greek empire. Watch this video to find out more about the Greek legacy left in Afghanistan by Alexander and his successors. The Afghanistan exhibition is open during the Easter bank holidays, so book your tickets now: http://bit.ly/eGSv6j

Psst...each day this week the Museum is giving away Book of the Dead prizes on Twitter. Go to www.twitter.com/britishmuseum for details on how to enter.

Love may be older than Aphrodite and Eros, but it hasn't become less complicated. So if you're in need of a Valentine's Day present (it's coming sooner than you think) have a look at gifts for him and her in the online shop.

status_message:
EVENT HIGHLIGHT THIS WEEK
This Thursday at 13.15 join a special lecture on objects which tell the story of same-sex desire from ancient Egypt and Babylon to modern times. Followed by a poetry workshop with the option to enter your work for the Write Queer London competition 2011.
Free, just drop in
Calling all young (or young at heart) explorers! Watch these videos to discover one or two unusual facts you might not have known about everyday things...

Don't miss Exhibition Curator Frances Carey's introduction to 'Picasso to Julie Mehretu: modern drawings from the British Museum collection' next Tuesday. The exhibition features  great artists of the 20th century such as Matisse, Louise Bourgeois and Gerhard Richter. The talk is BSL interpreted and free.
link_name: British Museum - An introduction to Picasso to Julie Mehretu

status_message:
Did you know there are FREE gallery talks by experts every Tuesday to Saturday at 13.15? This week's topics are:
Tuesday - Collectors of Chinese ceramics
Wednesday - Looking at Buddhist art
Thursday - Ancient Anatolia
Friday - Views of the afterlife in ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia 
Saturday - Alexander the Great and the conquest of Egypt

What are you looking forward to this year at the Museum? Some exhibition highlights include:
Book of the Dead (open until 6 March), Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World opening in March, an Australian season from April, Treasures of Heaven opening in June, and the highly anticipated show of Ice Age art opening in October.
New Zealand, Australia, Antarctica, Japan and many more are already in the year 2011. Only a few more hours to go until it's the new year in London. How do you celebrate in your part of the world?
Don't forget, the ancient Egyptian Book of the Dead exhibition will be open on 1 January from 11.00-17.30. The rest of the Museum is closed. Book your tickets now so you don't miss out!
link_name: Book of the Dead › The British Museum

status_message: How did the ancient Egyptians imagine the Book of the Dead would be used - Did they think the dead would unroll this document and read it? Or was it more just the fact of having it there in the tomb that magically conveyed the spells to you? Find out in Curator John Taylor's new blog post and read what else he reveals about the exhibition's background.
The Museum is closed on 24, 25 and 26 December. Wishing you happy holidays and safe journeys.
Here is the video of head priest Murakami Taiin chanting in the Agents of Buddha display. Have you ever been to a Buddhist temple? If so, upload your photos and share!

This Wednesday from 11.00-16.00 is a special Book of the Dead family day. Families get priority entry to the exhibition and can take part in a range of free family activities. Come along and bring the kids!

Next Monday is the Members' Christmas Party in the Enlightenment Gallery, with live music, a Christmas menu, cash bars and experts on hand to talk about the collection. Become a Member now to join the party.

As part of the Agents of the Buddha display in Room 3, Murakami Taiin, deputy head priest of the famous Yakushiji temple in Japan (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), gave an atmospheric live performance of Buddhist chanting.

The display focuses on two lively sculptures of bodhisattvas – enlightened beings who act on behalf of the Buddha.

On display until 9 January, admission free. Find out more http://bit.ly/bLhp1o
The Museum's curator St John Simpson has posted a new blog on Visit London about the upcoming exhibition on Afghanistan. Read it to find out why this exhibition is so important.
link_name: World in London: Afghanistan at the British Museum –  Visit London Blog

status_message: Have you taken the Time Out London lunch hour tour of the Museum yet? Which objects would you see if you only had 60 minutes?
link_name: London in your lunch hour - British Museum - Around Town - Time Out London

status_message: Due to popular demand, the Book of the Dead exhibition will be open this Saturday and Sunday until 20.30 (last entry 19.00). Advance booking is recommended.

The British Museum Friends now has a page on Facebook. Like the page to join the online community for updates on the latest event information, special offers, photos and reviews. It's a great opportunity for you to comment on your experiences as a Member and to share suggestions with the Membership team.
Visitors to the Museum's major exhibition Journey through the afterlife: ancient Egyptian Book of the Dead share their impressions. Have you seen been to the exhibition yet? What did you think?

Today Saint Nicholas' Day is celebrated in many countries to commemorate the Greek Bishop of Myra and patron saint of children, sailors and falsely accused – amongst other things. In Germany, for example, children leave out their stockings in hope of finding them filled with treats. 
What holidays does your part of the world celebrate, and can you find an object in the Museum's collection that represents this?

The mummy movie marathon is taking place this Saturday 12.00-18.00. A day of horror films featuring mummies and ancient Egypt (yes, you can come dressed in bandages). What is your favourite mummy movie?

Surviving treasures from Afghanistan nearly lost during years of civil war and Taliban rule will be on display at the Museum from 3 March 2011. Watch the video for more information and tweet your thoughts using #afghanistanBM.
link_name: Afghanistan: Crossroads of the Ancient World

status_message: 'My favourite place in West Africa is Ife and the reason is that Ife is in Nigeria, my country of birth. Ife people are of the Yoruba ethnic groups of which I am, and are one of the largest ethnic groups in the whole of Africa'. Godfrey Abeshin, British Museum.
New photo album for Kingdom of Ife: sculptures from West Africa now up - find out more abut Ife in Nigeria and see behind the scenes photos of the exhibition install.
New photo album now up - find out more abut Ife in Nigeria and see behind the scenes photos of the exhibition install.

'Ife is the origin of the Yorubas. This is because it is believed that Ife is the origin of the whole world and that dawn came into existence from Ife.' Elumade Florence Foluke, Principle Technical Officer, National Museum of Lagos, Nigeria.
'Ife means love and caring for one another. Because any place that there is love and caring, things are always easy to do with understanding.' Edet Okon, National Museum of Lagos, Nigeria.

What does Ife mean to you?  'Ife means love. Ile-Ife means 'house of love'. I see Ife as the origin and root of the Yoruba people's hospitality. They are second to none in Nigeria when it comes to matters of caring for people.'  Chris Unuakpor Ovie from the National Museum of Lagos, Nigeria, West Africa

Keep checking the Facebook Wall for updates about the latest exhibition Kingdom of Ife: sculptures from West Africa – You'll get to see some behind the scenes photos and comments from people involved in the project. First up on the fanpage is Chris Unuakpor Ovie from the National Museum of Lagos, Nigeria, West Africa…
Hear from Godfrey Abeshin, in conversation with curator Hassan Arero, remembering the Ife of his childhood

status_message: This Ice Age sculpture of swimming reindeer (carved from a mammoth tusk!) is the oldest in the British Museum. There is lots of interest in this new display opening today, come and see a star of the Radio 4 series A History of the World in 100 objects for yourself.
Upcoming exhibitions for 2010: What are you looking forward to?

Take a peek behind the scenes at what the conservators are currently working on at the Museum. Objects featured include a marble 'jigsaw puzzle' of Hermes, a dirty and unstable wall painting from the tomb of Nasonii and an ancient Egyptian artefact. There's also an example of how the conservators have used lasers to clean stone objects. 

If you would like to find out more about the work of this department you can find out more on the Conservation and Research pages of the British Museum website:

http://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/departments/conservation_and_scientific.aspx
link_name: Behind the scenes with the conservators

status_message:
Join the fiesta!

In Mexico, Day of the Dead is an annual festival where families gather to remember the dead. This year, celebrate Day of the Dead at the British Museum on 1 November 2009 with free events and activities. You can find out more about the day at www.britishmuseum.org.

Share your Day of the Dead experience online by posting up photographs of your Day of the Dead festivities. This may include photographs of Day of the Dead altars, decorations such as flowers, candles, your paper decorations or even sugar skulls and skeleton figures. Or maybe you have photographs of Day of the Dead celebrations in Mexico. There will also be some photos from the British Museum to inspire you. 

If you are coming to Day of the Dead at the British Museum, join the fiesta online and upload your photographs of the experience here. Photos of what's happening around the Museum on the day will also be uploaded in case you can't make it.
link_name: Day of the Dead at the British Museum

India Landscape is inspired by the collections of the British Museum and the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. 

It features a selection of plants from the Indian subcontinent, displaying a range of colours and scents from South Asia.

You can find out more about the India Landscape, as well as view the plants and plan of the landscape here: http://tr.im/oUsn
